column2: The United States has now associated itself with the Military Committee of the Baghdad Pact, linking Pakistan, Iran, Iraq, Turkey and Great Britain.
WASHINGTON, June 3--A powerful Senate group is moving cautiously toward the creation of a climate tolerable to a relaxation of restrictions on trade with Comunist China.
BONN, Germany, June 3--The Roman Catholic Bishop of Muenster announced yesterday that no practicing Catholic could vote for the Social Democratic party in the Sept. 15 general election.
WASHINGTON, June 3--The Supreme Court, 7 to 1, ruled today that Federal courts had the power to enforce arbitration clauses in labor-management contracts.
Of all the commencement exercises in town these days, there is perhaps but one in which the graduate is required to keep his thumbs out of the soup.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3--The United States delegate to the Human Rights Commission has made a personal appeal to White House and Congressional leaders to speed action to admit more Hungarian refugees.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)-- Manufacturers' shipments totaled $29,000,000,000 in April, about $1,500,000,000 higher than in April, 1956, the Government reported today.

PRINCETON, Me., June 3-- Mrs. Ann Crosby, who believes that people who have not learned to eat baked beans and ham every Saturday night can scarcely be called civilized, says that anybody who sets his mind to it can catch fish in Grand Lake and its satellites any time.

Governor Harriman accused the Republican leadership of the Legislature last night of using the "technique of the big lie" to misrepresent his position on social legislation that will come before the special session at Albany next week.

WASHINGTON, June 3--When the Supreme Court, in 1937, began the abrupt reversal of past concepts and in the next ten years adopted all the major constitutional interpretations of the New Deal, the change was widely accepted as a direct reflection of the influence of the appointees of two Democratic Presidents and of the overwhelming popular endorsement of the New Deal at the 1936 elections.
At the season when most trees in the metropolitan area are at their greenest, the leaves of many birch trees are turning a dingy brown.

The three "Value Line" investment funds managed by Arnold Bernhard Co., Inc. yesterday filed suit in Federal Court against Hyman Marcus, chairman of United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation, asking a return of the $3,247,000 purchase price of 191,000 shares of Hoffman common stock they bought from him last June.
ARLINGTON, Va., June 3-- Vernon Lee Whitney, a retired director of the Standard Vacuum Oil Company, died yesterday at his home here after two years of ill health. He was 7l years old.
KEMPTEN, Germany, June 3 (UP)--Fifteen West German paratroop recruits lost their footing and drowned in a march across the Iller River near here today.
ALBANY, June 3 (AP)--A state Supreme Court justice today ordered the state harness racing commissioner to show cause why he should not be held in contempt or court.
A nation-wide advertising program to promote savings in banks is paying dividends.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 3 (UP)--Airman 2/C William Roberts Jr. a 110-pound 22-year-old drill instructor, slapped a recruit who pleaded sick and banged his head against a foot locker, six airmen testified today at a court-martial. The recruit later died.

A drop of 20 to 25 per cent in fir plywood prices during the year was chiefly responsible for the lower sales and earnings of the United States Plywood Corporation, according to S.W. Antoville, president.
Maritime unions are backing two labor bills now before Congress.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 3 (AP)--Dr. Harold Stonier, retired executive vice president of the American Bankers Association and husband of Mrs. Lucille Stonier, well-known artist, died in a hospital here today after a long illness. He was 67 years old.
A few hours after their doll manufacturing business burned yesterday morning, two Manhattan owners admitted they had set the fire to collect the $30,000 insurance.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3-- Johnny Podres, who pitched Brooklyn into its first world championship a year ago last October, tonight once again became the Dodgers' man of the hour.
PITTSBURGH, June 3--The Giants, who completed their first three-game winning streak here, tonight, had a three-game losing streak.

BETHESDA, Md., June 3 (AP) --Robert Crosser, who served thirty-eight years between 1913 and 1954 as Democratic member of Congress from the Twentyfirst Ohio District, died in a hospital here early today. He would have been 83 years old Friday.
Three "tentative" but fairly consistent forces that dominate marketing situations were set down here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Department of Justice officials were studying today the Supreme Court's ruling yesterday in the Jencks case. They sought to discern how big a hole it had poked in the wall that guards Federal Bureau of Investigation reports from disclosure.
Secretary Mitchell's proposals for Federal legislation dealing with labor welfare and pension funds throws the whole weight of the Eisenhower Administration behind drastic "full disclosure."
Improvements to the George Washington Bridge and adjacent Manhattan streets slated to cost $110,000,000 were formally approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
CLEVELAND, June 4--The six Yankees who were fined and reprimanded by the front office yesterday were a grim and tightlipped lot as the Bombers arrived here today.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 4-- The telephone conference system used by harried business executives is to be adopted by harried volunteers of the New Hope fire company here.
IN Atlantic City, where he practiced his profession of surgery for thirty-five years, Dr. David Bacharach Allman is almost a public institution. "Work," he has said, "is my hobby."

"Separate Tables," the successful London importation that has been at the Music Box since Oct. 25 will interrupt its run Juiy 13. The reason for the suspension is a lucrative bid from Central City, Colo., to play there Aug. 1-31.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that policemen employed by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority had the power to issue summonses for traffic violations.
WASHINGTON, June 4--One of the most solemn and intricate civil rights debates of modern times is under way in the capital.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 --It appears that Gomalco Productions, owned by George Gobel and David P. O'Malley, have hit the jackpot on the first try.
Soviet officials have been praising the recent national convention of the American Communist party.
WASHINGTON, June 4--Foods and Drug Administration officials gave details today of longrange plans to safeguard the country's future food supply against radioactivity.
PRINCETON, Me., June 4-- There are whole areas in Maine where the small-mouth black bass is considered virtually a trash fish. Anglers dismiss it contemptuously as a nuisance.
WARSAW, June 3--The political order of the day in Poland is "consolidation" and to achieve it Wladyslaw Gomulka has once again forgiven his political enemies.

MORE than 70,000 New York City boys and girls will be doing their summer camping on the city's front doorsteps this, year. According to records of the day camp unit of the Department of Health, that many...
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 4 (AP) --Frederick W. Schumacher, Columbus philanthropist, art patron and civic leader, died here early today. His age was 93.
Two resolutions seeking specific state legislation were adopted yesterday by the City Council over Republican minority charges that the measures were "politically motivated."
LONDON, June 4 (Reuters)-- The sterling area's gold and dollar reserves rose by $25,000,000 during May, the British Treasury announced today.

PLANNING to make the grand tour this summer on a dwarf size budget? When packing, don't think you are about to leave the Olympus of mechanical civilization behind for the charms of the artistic and old world. Nor should you think that all of Europe is a bargain center.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)-- James F.Murray, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Senate Interior Committee, today called the Government's newly announced long-range minerals program "an insult to Congress *** a betrayal of the mining industry."

CORNING, N.Y., June 4-- The splendor and infinite variety of glass during nearly 3,000 years of man's devising are qualities most apparent in a show that will open here tomorrow at the Corning Glass Museum.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)-- Shipping--interests and state agencies today contended the railroads were risking further serious loss of business in seeking additional freight rate increases.
PARIS, Wednesday, June 5-- Pierre Pflimlin, leader of the Roman Catholic Popular Republican Movement, appeared close to failure today in his effort to end the fifteen-day governmental crisis.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 5-- Premier Nobusuke Kishi said today he would urge the United States to underwrite an Asian development program to combat communism.
Baseball is big business in New York, but not big enough as far as the Dodgers and the Giants are concerned.
WASHINGTON, June 4--Four prominent geneticists told Congress today that radiation from atomic weapon tests would harm tens of thousands and perhaps millions of chil-... dren in future generations.
MIAMI, Fla., June 4--Lieut. Col. Harry Austin Knox, an early designer and builder of automobiles, died here Sunday. His age was 82.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- George C.McConnaughey, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, is leaving his post at the expiration of his term on June 30.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 4--The Community Hospital of Glen Cove, L. I., was the big winner of today's annual charity pro-amateur golf tournament at the Piping Rock Club.
Dr.Gray son Kirk yesterday envisioned Columbia University growing into an international center of education, leading the way to world peace.
Officials with speeches and a penguin without words will officially dedicate the new Aquarium at Coney Island today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)-- Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that he was marking time on some additional Red-front registration cases for the Subversive Activities Control Board.

BUFFALO, June 4--A member of Governor Harriman's staff charged today that the Republican effort to raise payroll taxes for unemployment insurance threatened to increase the cost of the state highway program by more than $10,000,000.
LONDON, June 2--Prime Minister Macmillan hinted to the House of Commons today that the current series of British hydrogen bomb tests might be curtailed as a contribution to nuclear disarmament.
Legislation that would give the vote to every shareholder in every publicly held company and that would force proxy solicitation by managements was recommended yesterday by
The five-story apartment house for eihgt families at 28 West Tenth Street was sold by the 425 East Seventy-eighth Street Corporation.

CHICAGO, June 4-S.C. Hollister, dean of Cornell University's College, of Engineering,, called today for a sound, non-. political national policy on water use and machinery adequate to make that policy effective.
Barnard College awarded diplomas to 330 seniors yesterday at ceremonies in Barnard Hall. Forty-six were graduated with honors.
DENVER, June 4 (AP)--Floods fanned out over Colorado's western slope today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP)-- Following is the text of a joint statement by the State and Defense Departmerats on the Girard case:

WASHINGTON, June 4-Republican campaign strategists advised President Eisenhower today that his big budget proposals had slowed campaign contributions, particularly from those who formerly were big givers.
FEW fictional themes are more shiny with use than the trials and tribulations of a sensitive boy with a lively imagination and a literary turn of mind.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday reversed a State Supreme Court order prohibiting the State Commission. Against Discrimination from holding its first public hearing on a housing discrimination case.
Commodity futures trading was nervous yesterday in many of the New York markets. Prices fluctuated in fairly wide ranges.

Like a housewife engaged in spring cleaning, the refining branch of the oil industry is busily putting its house in order. But the reason is more serious: a seasonal decline in demand, coupled with heavy stocks. This comes despite the normal increase of 4 to 5 per cent a year in the total demand for petroleum products.
PARES, June 4--The use of terror has become orthodox strategy in guerrilla warfare. This brutal fact is what lies behind the hideous Melouza massacre in Algeria.

Efforts of the state to get property owners to join in planning a Brooklyn neighborhood improvement got off to a confused start yesterday because the three groups involved misunderstood each other's plans.

WASHINGTON, June 4--If the current trend continues, defense spending in the fiscal year starting next month will reach $42,000,000,000, and not $38,000,000,000 as estimated by President Eisenhower in January, the Defense Department controller said today.

Most of the Supreme Court justices of the First and Second Judicial Districts are signing their pay checks under protest. Their purpose is to lay the basis for possible future claims against the city for back pay.
LA PAZ Bolivia, June 4-- President Hernan Siles Zuazo attempted to give the nation a simple lesson in basic economics last night.

Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick and the major league presidents, Warren Giles . and Will Harridge, have been subpoenaed to appear before the House Judiciary Committee in its investigation of sports, which begins June. 17.
Wall Street remains just as much in the dark about the fate of the stock interest of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in General Motors Corporation as does the general public.
WASHINGTON, June 4--A $95,000,000 Polish aid agreement got hung up on a point of order in the House of Representatives today.

CLEVELAND, June 4--The Yankees began a thirteen-game tour of the West tonight with a 7-4 victory over the Indians at Municipal Stadium. In the process,the Bombers showed anew that they were stronger on the road than at home.

DELMAR, N.Y., June 4--Mr. and Mrs.George E.Stevens have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arlette Elaine Stevens, to Pvt. Mark Hamilton Dyott of the Army. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Dyott of Merrick, L.I., and Quito, Ecuador.
Dr. E.Cuyler Hammond and Dr. Daniel Horn puffed on pipes yesterday as they submitted evidence on the relationship between lung cancer and smoking.

In its ruling that the 23 per cent interest of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in the General Motors Corporation constitutes a violation of the antitrust laws the Supreme Court has brought to a presumptive conclusion one of the biggest and most important suits of this kind in recent history.
DURBAN, South Africa, June 4 (Reuters) Vice Admiral Sir Benjamin Martin, whose cruiser sank the German battleship Bismarck during World War II, died yesterday. He was 66 years old.
ROME, Wednesday, June 5-- Premier Adone Zoli's Government was given a vote of confidence in the Senate early this morning by a margin of 132 to 93 with 4 abstentions.

GENEVA, June 4--The first skirmishes in next year's big battle on the United States labormanagement front are likely to be fought in the conference of the International Labor Organization opening here tomorrow.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 4-- A controversy over fee versus free television was aired today as the General Federation of Women's Clubs began its sixtysixth annual convention.
INVERNESS, Calif., June 4 (UP)--Mrs.Mary Hay Hastings, former Ziegfeld Follies girl ands Broadway musical comedy star, died unexpectedly today in her home at the age of 56.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 4 (Reuters)--The West Indies team, which earlier in the match seemed virtually certain to win the first cricket test, today had to fight desperately to foil a great victory bid by England and settle for a draw.
The bond market sagged yesterday to the lowest levels in more than twenty years as big new corporate issues continued to compete for investment funds. Major developments were:
Soviet propaganda agencies have suppressed a remark made by Nikita S.Khrushchev that revealed the existence of an ideological split between Moscow and Peiping.

Following are the texts of a report to the American Medical Association yesterday by Dr.E. Cuyler Hammond, director, and Dr.Daniel Horn, assistant director, of statistical research for the American Cancer Society, and of comment by Timothy V. Hartnett, chairman of the Tobacco Industry Research Committee:

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4-- The Army is ready to suppress any "brush fire" war before it can spread into a "great nuclear conflagration," Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Chief of Staff of the Army, declared today.

Following are the texts of citations read by Dr. John A. Krout, vice president and provost of Columbia University, in presetting candidates for honorary degrees conferred by Dr.Grayson Kirk, president, at the university's commencement exercises yesterday:
The Transit Authority expects a $6,000,000 operating surplus at the end of the current fiscal year on June 30, it announced yesterday.
LARCHMONT N. Y., June 41 -Samuel K. C. Kopper, assistant to the chairman of the board of the Arabian American Oil Company, died-here today in his home at 85 Willow Avenue. His age was 42.

Two weeks ago a tornado ripped through suburban Kansas City, Mo., killing thirty-five persons, hospitalizing 200 and causing damage to homes, churches, schools and business properties estimated at $10,100,000.
The decision of the Supreme Court in the Jencks case once again emphasizes the great concern of the nation's highest tribunal for the protection and preservation of individ ual rights.
The presidents of the Dodgers and the Giants met with Mayor Wagner yesterday and told him they were willing to remain in New York if suitable new homes were found for them.

In contrast to the rather apathetic attitude of Brooklyn fandom, which mustered only 9,300 welcomers, the Dodgers reacted enthusiastically last night to their return to Ebbets Field after an eight-day absence.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- President Eisenhower was pictured by Rupublican Congressional leaders today as being concerned over delays of consideration of his proposals to liberalize immigration laws.
TOKYO, June 4--It will cost a Japanese more to drink, smoke, play the piano or ride in a foreign automobile under new import restrictions announced today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4-- The general executive board of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union today proposed a milliondollar promotional campaign for the men's hat industry to be sponsored jointly by the union and management.
Rear Admiral Roy A. Gano, deput commander of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, succeeded Rear Admiral Redfield Mason yesterday as commander of the service's Atlantic area.

The United Nations Charter is not destined to be revised in the near future. This is the not very surprising deduction to be drawn from the first session of the General Assembly Committee of the Whole, which was set up to discuss the subject of a Charter revision conference "at an appropriate time."
WASHINGTON, June 4--The United States agreed today that a Japanese court should try and American soldier charged with having killed a Japanese woman.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP)-- Lawrence H.Smith, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that the Communist party was trying to create "national hysteria so the people will demand that our H-bomb testing be stopped."

New issues of corporate securities amounting to more than $99,000,000 are being offered to investors today. The issues include railroad equipment certificates, public utility bonds and corporate stock. The offerings are:
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 4--Collaboration by some employers in labor racketeering practices to gain advantages over competitors was charged here today by Senator John F. Kennedy.
Ground was broken yesterday for the first unit of the future home of The New York Times. The site is on the west side of West End Avenue, between Sixty-second and Sixty-fifth Streets.

IT was a rather hign cover charge that was slapped on the six Yankee ballplayers for their visit to a night club last month. It cost five of them $1,000 apiece while the sixth culprit, Johnny Kucks, was clipped only $500 the half-price-for-children rate.
ST.LOUIS, June 4--Overcoming air pollution "can trigger a complete rennaissance of cities," Mayor Raymond R.Tucker of St.Louis declared tonight.

CAIRO, June 4--The Soviet Ambassador flew to Moscow today. Diplomatic circles believed he would take part in urgent talks on the mounting differences between Egypt and the Soviet Union on economic affairs.
CRESSON, Pa., June 4 (AP)--An insurgent group of stockholders today succeeded in placing two members on the eight-man board of the Penn-Texas Corporation.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Wednesday, June 5-French troops and nationalist rebels clashed early today in a fierce battle in mountains about sixty miles east of Algiers.
The New York Telephone Company leased large space in the office building rising at 575 Lexington Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-first Street, for a new district office..
The Giants snapped their losing streak at three games last night at the Polo Grounds but it took them thirteen innings and almost four hours to do it.
RYE, N.Y., June 4--Two players shared the lead in the fifty-third United States Senior Golf Association's championship today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 4 --Differences of viewpoint were reported to have emerged today as the Baghdad Pact Ministers' Council met to discuss the Middle Eastern political situation and the question of subversion.
A report to the American Medical Association yesterday showed a high degree of association between cigarette smoking and total death rates.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed yesterday $17,687,000 on short-term notes to finance two state-subsidized, low-rent projects-Sumner Houses in Brooklyn and Edgemere Houses, Far Rockaway, Queens.
The Waterfront Commission acted yesterday to eliminate the last resistance among pier watchmen to physical examinations.

War Piper of the Brae Burn Farm won the main race at Belmont Park yesterday, defeating Howell Jackson's Tick Tock by three-quarters of a length, Those horses came from behind to achieve their placings in the seven-furlong sprint.

THE earned college degree as a mark of scholarly at tainment goes back 700 years or so. The idea was borrowed from the ancient guilds, which issued documents certifying apprentices as proficient in a trade.

BUFFALO, June 4--The politically explosive issue of legislative reapportionment was brought into the open today at the first public hearing of the state commission planning for a constitutional convention.

BONN, Germany, June 4--The United States was reported today to have agreed to accept a 50 per cent reduction in funds contributed by West Germany for the support of United States forces in the Federal Republic.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4-- Twenty-five former West Point cadets began their careers today as officers and gentlemen-and as husbands.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -Associated Artists Productions, Inc. (the corporate designation is being changed to A. A. P., Inc.) , has made a four-picture releasing agreement with Columbia Pictures.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's filmed interview program featuring Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, has been sold for repeat showings by stations in this country and abroad.
PATERSON, N.J., June 4-- Buses of the Inter-City Transportation Company, which normally carry 15,000 New YorkNew Jersey commuters, were made idle today when 270 drivers struck against the company.
Terms of a proposed merger of the Colonial Life Insurance Company of America and the Federal Insurance Company were announced yesterday.

STRAWBERRIES fresh from Long Island fields are one of the prettiest sights at fruit counters this week. The season on the Island, which began last Monday, will reach its peak next week and continue till the end of the month.
The flag of free Poland has temporarily disappeared from the high seas.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 4--President Tito's price for reconciliation with the Soviet Union is reckoned here at 700,000,000 rubles.
WASHINGTON, June 4--President Eisenhower will not try to match on Soviet television screens Nikita S.Khrushchev's interview on a United States network.
The Paramount Pictures Corporation intends to become an important supplier of motion pictures for television, Barney Balaban, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 4--A panel of six private economists agreed today that Federal spending in the fiscal year beginning July 1 would be higher than the $71,800,000,000 estimated by President Eisenhower, despite Congressional cuts in appropriations.

Sam Hanks, the winner of the Indianapolis 500 last Thursday, wasn't just talking through his hat when he said, a moment after achieving that long-sought triumph, that he was finished with "big--car" racing.

Stocks did little yesterday, moving sluggishly through most of the day with slight signs of strength only in the first and fifth hours. Volume was 2,200,000 shares on the New York Stock Exchange, against 2,050,000 on Monday.
WASHINGTON, June 4-Dave Beck Jr. echoed his father's Fifth Amendment plea before Senate racket hunters more than a hundred times today.
A world-widg system of alliances is indispensable to the security of the United States, Gen. Alfred M.Gruenther asserted here yesterday.
Juvenile artists in Greenwich Village made it plain yesterday that they don't want to have any truck with proposals to put a roadway through Washington Square Park.
Physicians today find that they must give sympathy and compassion along with all the best that modern science can offer.
TZANEEN, South Africa, June 4-A Negro tribe is resisting Government expulsion from a valley in which it has resided for generations.
The Empire State Music Festival will open its third summer season at Ellenvilie, N.Y., with a concert on the evening of July 4.
BONN, Germany, June 4--The Social Democratic party reacted cautiously today to the ruling of the Roman Catholic bishop of Muenster that practicing Catholics could not vote for Socialists.

CHICAGO, June 5 (U.P.)--Luis Aparicio scored on Billy Klaus' fifth-inning throwing error and Tom Brewer walked in the winning run today as the Chicago White Sox posted a 6-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 5 --A cheering Parliament heard a demand today for a purge of Hungary's intellectual life that would be more sweeping than anything attempted by the old Rakosi dictatorship.
WASHINGTON, June 5--A Senate Appropriations subcommittee voted today to keep the soil bank in business for another year as urged by the Eisenhower Administration.
These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook.
The world's woman figureskating champion and a Broadway actor received their diplomas yesterday at graduation exercises of the Professional Children's School
The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation has motorized the grinding process at its Brackenridge, Pa., plant. Seven new hydraulic-electric billet grinders have been installed to remove surface...
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)-- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

The State of Louisiana has decided not to go ahead at this time pith the sale of an issue of $16,000,000 of war veterans' bonus bonds. The obligations were scheduled to be sold today. The postponement was ascribed to "unfavorable market conditions."

ALGIERS, Algeria, June 5-- French military forces reported today that they killed 125 nationalist rebels in an operation that ended yesterday in the region of Fort National in the Department of Algiers. French losses were not disclosed.

An increase of 912,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies on Friday were 195,285,000 barrels, compared with 194,373,000 a week earlier and 184,870,000 a year ago.
For an agonizing five minutes yesterday a sign painter dangled upside down from a broken scaffold seventy feet above the sidewalk at Broadway and Forty-fifth Street.

BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N.J., June 5--In the Diamond Hill Community Church Miss Jean Geary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose J. Geary: of Summit, was married here this afternoon to Dr. O. Ross McIntyre, son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Ross McIntvre of Omaha.

WASHINGTON, June 5--President Eisehower told balking Republican campaign contributors today that the big Federal budget about which they complained probably would be higher if the Democrats still were in power.

ONCE upon a time there was an English miler with the slightly implausible name of Joe Binks. One June morning the Briton trudged through the streets of London with his bride-to-be, shopping for furnishings for their new home. It was an exhausting expedition and the male, naturally, was far more wearied than the female.
SUMMIT, N.J., June 5--Miss Saranne Ruth Kinch and Russell Kennedy Jones Jr. will be married in the winter.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Leopold Staff, a leading Polish poet and dean of his country's writers, died Friday in Skarzysko-Kamienna, Poland, according to word received today by the Polish Embassy. His age was 78. He published more than thirty volumes of verse.

WASHINGTON, June 5--President Eisenhower said today the United States never could accept a "total and complete" ban on nuclear weapons testing until there was total and safeguarded nuclear disarmament.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) --Jerry Lynch's eleventh inning pinch triple and Roy McMillan's single enabled the Cincinnati Redlegs to beat Philadelphia, 4--2, tonight.

When he takes over the reins as Secretary of the Treasury as successor to George M. Humphrey, Robert B. Anderson will take over at the same time a number of pieces of unfinished business that rate the designation of "problems."
A New York television operator offered yesterday to pay $5,000,000 a year for the rights to televise Dodger and Giant games if the two baseball clubs remained in New York.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 5--Saudi Arabia charged in a letter today that Israeli destroyers had bombarded coastal positions near Taba in a series of "provocative and aggressive acts."

A $1,400,000 damage suit was filed yesterday against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Local 584 of the Milk Drivers and Dairy Employes Union. It charged violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.
Eve Arden, who has been off television this season except for filmed reruns of "Our 'Miss Brooks," probably will return next fall in a situation comedy series titled "It Gives Me Great Pleasure."
A test version of the Army's Jupiter, an intermediate range ballistic missile (I.R.B.M.), has performed the first successful flight of such a weapon in this country.
The American Medical Association voted yesterday to find out how widely stimulants were being used by amateur and professional athletes.

LONDON, June 5 (Reuters)-- Art critics of the world's press had a previews here last night of the most important collection of Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings ever to be auctioned in London.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The President made clear today the position of the United States Government on the issue, anxiously and sincerely posed by some scientists and members of the political community, but promptly exploited for
The International Harvester Company experienced a 20 per cent drop in earnings in the six months ended April 30 from a year earlier, while sales dipped 9 per cent.
A union official, who had been denaturalized in Federal Court, Brooklyn, after a six-week trial, moved yesterday for a new trial.

MANCHESTER, England, June 15 (AP)--Reg Bennett, 19, a British airman, came from behind today to upset Gil Shea, a 28year-old Californian, 4--6, 9--7, 6--4, in the third round of the Northern lawn tennis championships.

"The New Class: An Analysis of the Communist System," by bilovan Djilas, former Vice President of Yugoslavia, is planned by Praeger for July publication. It is an indictment of communism as a political, social and economic system, ...

Mr. and Mrs. Dennis J. Sullivan of Rockaway Beach, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Angela Sullivan, to Lieut. William H. Party, U.S.A. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Parry of Brooklyn.
HONG KONG, June 5--Because of an austerity program, it was reported today, women in the main cities of Communist China have been told to put the traditional slit skirts and high collars into storage.

JERSEY CITY, June 5 (UP)-- The world welterweight champion, Carmen Basilio, today set June 13 as the deadline for the middleweight champion, Sugar Ray Robinson, to make up his mind about their proposed fight.
Science and sight-seeing became partners under the same roof in Brooklyn yesterday when the new Aquarium at Coney Island was dedicated.
ALBANY, June 5--An assertion that the state's Republican leaders are opposed to holding a constitutional convention in 1959 was challenged today before the commission planning for such a session.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (U.P.)-- The Federal Maritime Administrator urged the coal industry to get into the shipping business as oil operators had.
American scientists plan to examine a cache of canned food that was taken to Antarctica in 1910 by the British explorer Capt. Robert F. Scott.

RYE, N.Y., June 5--Franklin G. (Fritz) Clement of Lake Forest, Ill., moved into a commanding position in his bid to retain the title as the first half of play ended today in the fifty-third United States Senior Golf Association's championship.

Dean Alfange said yesterday that he would accept the Republican nomination for Mayor under two conditions: that he have a united party behind "my kind of campaign" and that adequate financing be provided.

Former President Harry S. Truman and Mrs. Truman will arrive here this morning to see their first grandchild for the first time. The baby, a 6 pound boy, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Daniel at 12:11 A.M. yesterday in Doctors Hospital.

WEEK of hopping about central, eastern and north ern Maine in a small float plane appears to show that the state is the last frontier in the East of isolated fishing, and that it will not be able to maintain that status.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 5-- An atomic bomb suspended from a captive balloon was detonated today for the first time on record.
Nikita S. Khrushchev inadvertently has made a contribution to the spreading debate over United States policy on China.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- President Eisenhower expressed confidence today that Specialist 3/c William S. Girard would get a fair trial in Japanese courts.
Superintendent of Schools William Jansen has nominated Dr. Joseph O. Loretan to be associate superintendent in charge of the city's junior high schools. The position pays $18,750 a year.
HAVANA, May 5--An atmosphere of uneasiness and uncertainty pervaded Cuba today as the opposition against the regime of President Fulgencio Batista seemed to gather force.
GENEVA, June 5--A special message from Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, was read today at the opening session of the fortieth annual conference of the International Labor Organization.
The National Maritime Union has asked the National Labor Relations Board to settle its controversy with the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman ruled invalid yesterday the patent rights for "zoom" lenses used on motion picture and television cameras to obtain closeups of moving objects at a distance.
WASHINGTON, June 5--President Eisenhower opened the door wide today to the possibility of a resumption of trade with Communist China.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- Young Mr. Daniel, grandson of former President Harry S. Truman, was less than twenty-four hours old today when he figured in a White House news conference question.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5-- Two graduating midshipmen carried off a total of thirteen prizes and awards for scholastic attainments and military proficiency today.

After a, full review of the case of Army Specialist Girard, charged with killing a Japanese woman on an American rifle range in Japan, President Eisenhower and Secretaries Dulles and Wilson have agreed to yield to Japanese demands and to turn the accused man over to the Japanese courts for trial.

A five-story building containing forty-six apartments at 1275 Grant Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Renisa Corporation. It is 100 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $125,000. Ehrlich, Corso, Feldman Co. were the brokers.
A 22-year-old girl, an employe and student at New York University, was stabbed in the back yesterday morning in a Greenwich Village subway station.
Progress against a group of viruses that constitute a major problem of military medicines was reported yesterday to a section of the American Medical Association.
NEW DELHI, India, June 5-- Influenza is epidemic in many parts of the country and is spreading.
OTTAWA, June 5--Monday's general election in Canada may provide some-surprises for both major parties.
WASHINGTON, June 5--A group of five economists got an unexpected opportunity today to debate before a Congressional committee what was coming to be called "the new inflation."
BUFFALO, June 5--Wilber M. Brucker, Army Secretary, warned today that Congressional reductions in the military budget would cut off the Army's "trigger finger."
MILWAUKEE, June 5--A fiveweek color television set promotion in this area was reported today to have "demonstrated conclusively that the public is ready to buy" color television "in large volume."
The head of one of the leading United States liquor producing concerns yesterday embarked on a mission to get European countries to lift import restrictions against American alcoholic beverages.
The Corn Products Refining Company will unite its twenty consumer and 450 industrial products under a new trademark.
NEWARK, June 5--Senator Forbes denounced, Governor Meyner in two appearances today.

JERSEY CITY, June 5--The Dodgers, a baseball club that specializes in trying to be everywhere to all people, paid another happy visit to their present alternate home base of operations tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) --The United States Government has denied security clearance to a 26-year-old engineer of the Radio Corporation of America on the ground he "currently maintained a close, continuing, association" with his mother, an alleged pro-Communist.
PARIS, June 5--Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, 42-year-old Radical and present Minister of National Defense, agreed tonight to try to form a new French Cabinet.

The Bawl Street Journal, the financial district's once-a-year, $1-a-copy satirical newspaper, is out today on time. The occasion is the eve of the annual field day of the Bond Club of New York tomorrow at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough, N.Y.

Wool prices continued to advance sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Tops climbed 2 to 2.9 cents a pound and grease wool 2.2 to 2.7 cents. The near-by July positions have gained about 5 cents a pound this week.
The recently formed American Banner Line has been admitted to membership in the Trans-Atlantic Passenger Conference, according to word received from Arnold Bernstein, president of the line.
R.H. Macy Co., Inc. yesterday reported sales for the thirteen weeks ended May 4 of $97,971,000, compared with $87,105,000 for the corresponding quarter a year ago.
Back in 1955 The Economist, British weekly, invented Parkinson's Law, which holds that government officials tend to multiply subordinates, and these subordinates make work for one another.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- President Eisenhower joined in tributes today to his old chief, General of the Army George C. Marshall.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs told Congress today that the Soviet Union and Communist China were "solidly aligned" in a program of "predatory and expansionist force."

Officials of the Forstmann Woolen Company and J.P. Steverts Co., Inc., announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached for the acquisition of all the outstanding capital stock of Forstmann and of Julius Forstmann Co., Inc., by J.P. Stevens.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 5-- President Hernan Siles Zuazo faced a serious Cabinet crisis today as ranking army and police officials joined in an attempt to oust the chief of the secret political police.
DETROIT, June 5--Walter P. Reuther spelled out today the policy of the United Automobile Workers regarding union members who invoked the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, June 5--A Senate power investigation turned today toward the possibility that a leak of Government information had given "those on the inside a chance to make a killing" in stock of the Idaho Power Company.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 5 --The Thai police arrested seven labor leaders at Don-Muang Airport here late tonight on their return from a visit to Communist China. The delegation had gone to Peiping to attend a May Day celebration.
A large committee has been chosen to work for the success of the benefit performance of "Jamaica," starring Lena Horne, on Nov.4.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP)--A late rally brought wheat futures pri ces back to around the previous close on the Board of Trade today after an early slump.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 --Sir Carol Reed, who visited here recently, signed a threepicture deal with Hecht-HillLancaster before returning to his home in England.
WASHINGTON, June 5--President Eisenhower's civil rights program won its first test in the House of Representatives today.
WASHINGTON, June 5--The United States and Britain ended today a long stalemate on the exchange of information on atomic power development.

Li'l Fella of the Jaclyn Stable won the $36,025 Juvenile Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The race, one of the oldest in the country, attracted a field of fourteen for its eighty-first running. The competition was at five furlongs on the Widener course.

CLEVELAND, June 5--After Yogi Berra, the victim of a freak accident, had suffered a possible fracture of the nose in the third inning, the Yankees exploded for four runs in the fourth and seven in the fifth and gained a 13-3 victory over the Indians tonight.

CHANTILLY, France, June 5 (AP)--A former public links champion, Gene Andrews of Beverly Hills, Calif., today led fifteen Americans into the second round of the French international amateur golf tournament.
Four new band compositions by well known American composers will be presented by the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts this summer on the Mall in Central Park and in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.
People who have been wondering when the subway entrance in Times Square at Forty-third Street would reopen can stop wondering. It is not going to unless public opinion makes itself felt.
PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP)-- Lindy McDaniel gave only five hits and struck out eight men tonight as he pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

About 400 persons prominent in the arts and in public life signed an appeal yesterday urging Congress to enact bills to aid art. They seek the establishment of a Federal Advisory Council on the Arts in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
BOSTON, June 5 (U.P.)--Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today there was good reason to believe the rise of communism "has reached and passed its peak."

HARTFORD, June 5--The General Assembly adjourned sine die tonight shortly before 11 o'clock after a five month's session.

Howard Levy is a man who refuses to compromise. He could have won a suspended sentence on a parking charge yesterday in Traffic Court, but he declined. He pleaded innocent and elected to go to trial next Wednesday.
WARSAW, June 5--An appeal for immediate "social" aid to Poland from the West has been made by a newspaper known to be close to Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate.
Manuel E. Kulukundis, owner of the property at the southeast corner of. Madison Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street, has purchased an abutting parcel running through the block from Fiftyfifth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 5--President Eisenhower said today that the Administration would gladly accept any Soviet invitation for a United States official to appear before the Russian people through mass communications media.
RABAT, Morocco, June 5-- Two ships arrived here today with milk, cheese and corn meal from the United States for the needy and undernourished in Morocco.
Twenty-seven boys were deClared ineligible to compete yesterday in the fifty-third annual Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
Jews will end at sundown today their observance of Shabuoth, the Feast of Weeks.
The rise in shipbuilding in this country during the last year has caused the industry to triple its percentage of the world's ship work.
WASHINGTON, June 5-- Prospective bidders for the Government's holdings of Hugo Stinnes Corporation filed qualifying statements today with the Alien Property Office of the Department of Justice.

CHICAGO, June 5--Taxes, territory and tyranny are the three "T's" spelling real danger for the investor-owned electric power industry, Harlee Branch, Jr., president of the Southern Company, asserted today.
WASHINGTON, June 5--Dr. Willard F. Libby, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, told Congress today that continued atomic testing presented "a very small" risk to the health of mankind.

THE suggestion by President Eisenhower that the Columbia Broadcasting System had been motivated by commercial considerations in televising an interview with Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist party in the Soviet Union, can only be regretted.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 5-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon expressed cautious optimism tonight about disarmament talks and the possibility of a pact with the Soviet Union.

Walter Pidgeon has come to the aid of "The Happiest Millionaire," the Kyle Crichton comedy in which he plays the starring role of Anthony J. Drexel Biddle.

This is the time at which thousands upon thousands of young. American men and women, on campuses throughout the country, celebrate the completion of their formal academic training. They are entering upon a somewhat different world from that which they have known thus far.

Times Square has lost, probably permanently, one of its busiest subway entrances.
IN our baroque Age of the Picassozoic, Ogden Nash is a stoic. He deplores gaudy graces, and, I imagine, paintings of three-eyed girls with split-level faces.

An expected official revaluation of the Colombian peso will still leave a variety of effective exchange rates on imports for that country, according to views aired yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau, held at the Advertising Club.

An almost-forgotten sterling silver trophy donated sixteen years ago for the first American to break the four-minute mile passed last night into the possession of Don Bowden, a University of California junior.
SALZBURG, Austria, June 5 --Ten years in a refugee camp can make a man attached to the surroundings he hates.
The International Longshoremen's Association decided yesterday to link its 1957 biennial convention to a new organizational drive.

Directors of the General Time Corporation cut the quarterly dividend in half with the declaration yesterday of 25 cents ashare on the common stock, payable July 1. In previous quarter shareholders received 50 cents a common share.
THE twain have met. The sheath dress is as oriented in Tokyo as on the streets of New York, says George Oka, a Japanese dress designer.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- A Government inquiry into the prices of "wonder drugs" has been revived and broadened. It is scheduled for completion in August.
THE novice who hesitates to prepare anything as elaborate as lobster thermidor or green pepper dolma for guests loses her timidity and becomes a Cordon Blue cook on acquiring a home freezer.
"Home Freezers, Their Selection and Use," U.S. Department of Agriculture, Home and Garden Bulletin 48, is available from the Super intendent of Documents U.S. Government Printing Office.
JERICHO, L.I., June 5--Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley won low gross honors at 38, 39--77 in a Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, June 1--In the months since Israel forced open the Gulf of Aqaba her economic planners have been working quietly to capture new markets in Asia and Africa.
The stock market was almost a stand-off yesterday. On minor volume, The New York Times combined average rose a little, but more stocks fell than gained.
WASHINGTON, June 5--Donald A. Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense, indicated today that the Administration was engaged in a desperate struggle with runaway defense costs.
EPSOM, England, June 5-- Crepello, a strong favorite, burst out of the ruck in the last quarter mile and won the 178th Derby Stakes today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 5 --"Who's on first" has a new meaning in Hollywood these days--whether theatrical films or television creations get to the public first.

"Big E"--the aircraft carrier Enterprise, which participated in virtually every major battle of the Pacific war, has won a reprieve.

Charles Hann Jr., a lawyer and a leader in veterans organizations, died yesterday in Victoria Hospital, Miami, Fla., after a long illness. His age was 69. He had residences here, in Coral Gables, Fla., and in West Yarmouth, Mass.
Short-term money rates were advanced yesterday. Dealers increased the rate on one maturity of commercial paper and on all bankers' acceptances one-eighth of 1 percentage

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 5 --Holy Cross scored its fourteenth baseball victory in seventeen starts today as the Crusaders whipped Yale, 12-4. Hal Deitz, who fanned twelve Eli batters, was the winning pitcher, gaining his seventh triumph in eight decisions.
At the Polo Grounds yesterday, Ruben Gomez was hit by a misplaced fungo ball just as the Puerto Rican right-hander was crossing the field to warm up.

GUATEMALA, June 1--Along the sleepy Montagua River, as seen from the air, the sun glints from the water of an artificial lagoon. Some miles up the river, huge pumps drain a marsh already enclosed by a protecting levee.
BONN, Germany, June 5-- The Free Democratic party, third largest in West Germany, opened its election campaign today in Hamburg.
WARSAW, June 5--Wladyslaw Gomulka told the workers of Poznan today that Poland's alliance with the Soviet Union was "necessary for Poland to exist."
MIAMI BEACH, June 5 (AP)-- Gil Turner of Philadelphia won a split decision over Yama Bahama of Bimini tonight but suffered a head injury that put him in a hospital for examination.

New York University will graduate 6,297 students today and will confer honorary degrees upon eight public figures. The ceremonies will begin at 10:30 A.M. at the institution's University Heights campus in the Bronx.

The cotton futures market advanced 3 to 17 points (15 to 85 cents a bale) yesterday. Volume on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate.

ONE of the inexplicable, but cogent, forces in the secluded world of aquariists is the "wet thumb," a combination of science and near-witchcraft even more remarkable than the "green thumb" of horticulture. An outstanding example of the power of the wet thumb is Christopher William Coates.
Among the certificate recipients at New York University's commencement today will be a Nigerian physician who once was apprenticed to a witch doctor.

Two of Gene Sarazen's favorite topics of conversation are farming and golf. As the owner of a 300-acre farm in Germantown, N.Y., he worries seasonally about his Black Angus cattle or his fruit crops. But he seldom frets about his putting.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5--Americans are "faltering badly" in foreign policy and in providing adequate educational facilities for their children, Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of Rutgers University, said tonight.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 6-- Mrs. Ellie Lee Kahl, a 69-yearold teacher in a high school in Phoenix, Ariz., was cited as "Teacher of the Year" today at the sixty-sixth annual convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

HAVANA, June 6--President Fulgencio Batista, in an interview last night, reiterated his desire to advance the date of Cuban elections to June 1, 1958.

The American Waterways Operators, Inc., announced yesterday the eleation of Braxton B. Carr as president. Mr. Carr succeeds Chester B. Thompson, who had served for thirteen years.

The silent filibuster that has been going on all winter and spring against the Administration's mild civil rights bill has now ended in the House, and formal debate on the measure has begun at last. Gen. George C. Marshall, retired drove forty miles in the rain on Wednesday to receive a medal from the Organization for European Economic Cooperation on the tenth anniversary of the speech at Cambridge, Mass., in which his famous Plan was announced.

A FIRST one-man appearance is made by painter William Crovello at the Passedoit Gallery, 121 East Fifty-seventh Street. Landscape is his chief interest and he sees it as a glamorous spectacle, portraying it in an unconstrained, fervid way, substantially aided by his fauve color.

CLEVELAND, June 6--Yogi Berra, whose nose was broken early in last night's game here, had one regret today. The Yankee catcher was unable to take advantage of the Indians' "soft touch" pitching this afternoon at Municipal Stadium. His teammates did, though.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 6--Plans for a state-wide drive for a constitutional amendment to earmark highway user revenues for road building were initiated today by the New York State Automobile Association.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 6--Scientists at the Southwest Research Institute here are experimenting with a me chanical device that sniffs coffee all day long. It may some day be used to tell coffee processors just how long to roast coffee to maintain a given flavor and aroma.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 6 --The Baghdad Pact Ministers' Council ended its four-day meeting here today after having agreed to set up a joint military planning staff at Baghdad with United States participation.

Occasionally, Milton Baron is prompted to step away from the duties of a producer's aide de camp to do an attraction himself. This time he has accepted the challenge in behalf of "The Brass Section." A fall presentation is planned for the Max Wilk comedy.
PARIS, June 4--The idea seems to be growing here that the United States may soon make some move to facilitate a settlement of the Algerian war.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy ordered ten newly promoted high-ranking officers yesterday to reduce the city's undesirable big and little shots to "blank shots."

WASHINGTON, June 6--The South lost its first floor attack on President Eisenhower's civil rights program in the House of Representatives today. It lost through a parliamentary ruling by a Southerner, Speaker Sam Rayburn of Texas.

An evaluation of Franklin D. Roosevelt and his times is presented in a new book bay Dexter Perkins, president of the American Historical Association and John L. Senior, Professor of American Civilization at Cornell University.

The biggest purse of the afternoon at Belmont Park yesterday was won by a horse owned by the president of Delaware Park. Countermand, representing Donald P. Ross' Brandywine Stable, collected first money of $6,500 in the $10,000 handicap that had top billing.
Winners of the fifth annual national collegiate playwriting contest were announced yesterday by Samuel French, Inc., sponsor.
A setback for relatively nationalistic forces in the Communist party of the United States was indicated yesterday. Former City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis has been elected state chairman.

THE end of the school year brings report cards describing pupils' progress in the academic' sphere. It wouldn't be amiss for parents to do a little end-of-theyear evaluating of their own, one high school guidance counselor has suggested.

The Transit Authority bowed to its customers yesterday and announced that it would reopen a busy Times Square subway entrance.

John A. Moroso of New Rochelle, N.Y., author, criminologist and newspaper man, died yesterday in an upstate hospital after having suffered a broken hip in a fall the previous day. His age was 82.

The property at 229-49 East Eighty-fifth Street has been selected as the site for a new building to house the Yorkville branch post office.

LONDON, June 6--"The Trojans," Berlioz' long-winded Virgilian epic, is always reputed to be a hopeless proposition in the theatre. Tonight, London's Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, began to demolish that legend.
Foote, Cone Belding has obtained the complete advertising account of the Hawaiian Pineapple Company, Ltd., with estimated billings in excess of $3,000,000 a year.

Those concerned with athletics in any form and sports lovers as well should welcome a thorough exploration of the charge leveled before the Americain Medical Association that deleterious drugs are in wide use to improve athletic performance.

The National Department Stores Corporation had a net profit of $140,892 in the first quarter ended April 30 in contrast to a net loss of $610,836 for the similar three months last year. Frank L. Kellogg, chairman and president, made the disclosure at the annual meeting here yesterday.

The Federal Reserve System added $94,600,000 to its holdings of Government securities in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. All were acquired under repurchase agreements with dealers.
Once outboard motors had simpler and more primitive uses. Originally they were designed to replace oars, elbow grease and muscle strain.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) --A baseball fan pounced upon what he thought was a foul ball in the Philadelphia--Cincinnati game last night. But it was fair.

Sosthenes Behn, co--founder and former president and chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died yesterday morning in St. Luke's Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 75 years old.
The Cuban-American Sugar Company was enjoined permanently yesterday from voting the stock it owns in the American Crystal Sugar Company.

WASHINGTON, June 6--A Federal court ordered today that William S. Girard, a United States soldier, should not be placed in Japanese custody pending determination of an application for a writ of habeas corpus.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey appealed last night for acceptance of the Eisenhower foreign aid program as he defended the broad range of Administration budgetary policy.

Increased selling and merchandising costs resulted in a decline in the six months' earnings of the Dayton Rubber Company as compared with the profit a year earlier. But sales for the six months to last April 30 were $37,356,158, against $34,321,742 for the six months ended April 30, 1956.

No one writing literary criticism today excels Lord David Cecil in taste, insight and discrimination. And no one can rival him at all in the limpid clarity of his prose. Some learned critics have wrestled longer and more violently with a particular work or author and have amassed a larger collection of unimportant facts and personal theories.
A ship's captain, a police launch, a Coast Guard patrol boat and a hospital ambulance combined yesterday to track down some suspect hot dogs.
A dense sea fog--equal to anything the Pacific could have produced--swirled off the Atlantic last night and wove a cottony shroud around Ebbets Field, where the Dodgers were facing the Cubs.

Miss Ella Flesch, dramatic soprano and former member of the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday morning at her home, 2 West Eighty-sixth Street, after a long illness.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 --The name Louis B. Mayer is due to appear next year on motion picture film for the first time since the 1924 merger of three independent companies that gave birth to Metro-GoldwynMayer.

DETROIT, June 6--Automobile manufacturers decided today to flag down the industry's advertising emphasis on speed and horsepower. In line with the decision, they agreed that they would no longer participate in racing competition.

An additional investment of $60,000,000,000 will be neeed by the oil industry in the next five years to meet the increasing world demand for petroleum products, Augustus C. Long, chairman of the Texas Company, predicted yesterday.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which seemingly aroused the displeasure of President Eisenhower with its interview of Nikita S. Khrushchev, will present a panel discussion Sunday titled "Comment on Khrushchev."
PARIS, June 6--Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, Radical Minister of National Defense, obtained the approval of a party caucus today for his efforts to form a new government.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6-- Miss Katharine Tucker of Flourtown, a leader in public health nursing and nursing education, died today in University Hospital after a long illness. Her age was 72.

Today's new film is "Bailout at 43,000," a United Artists drama with John Payne, Karen Steele and Paul Kelly, at the Palace. The William C. ThomasHoward Pine Production was written by Paul Monash and directed by Francis D. Lyon.
Trading in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday left prices unchanged to 10 points (50 cents a bale) down.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 6--Humphreys O. Siegmund of 18 Harvard Terrace, military development engineer of the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Whippany, died last night while driving his car in Livingston, N.J. His age was 61. Mrs. Siegmund, who was with him, managed to brim the car to a halt.
WASHINGTON, June 6--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the core of the Eisenhower Administration's new design for the foreign aid program.
LONDON, June 6--Britain is speeding production of a vaccine for a new type of influenza now epidemic in the Far East.

BEEF, lamb and pork prices have surged to the year's highest levels this week. Some cuts have advanced as much as 4 to 6 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)-- The House Banking Committee approved today a bill to make the Small Business Administration a permanent agency of the Government.

CINCINNATT, June 6 (AP)-- The United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit, ruled today that the Federal Trade Commission had no jurisdiction to regulate the insurance business in states which had regulatory laws.
The nation's chief medical policy-making body refused yesterday to regulate closely the actions of doctors who receive salaries from hospitals and other organizations.
JERSEY CITY, June 6--Striking truck drivers, in defiance of their own union president, refused today to let Army and Navy men deliver perishable food to ships bound for overseas bases.
WASHINGTON, June 6--United States policy on Algeria is, now more than ever, to keep hands off, high ranking administration officials said today.
RYE. N.Y., June 6--W. Hamilton Gardner, a 64-year-old Buffalo contender, led the second section of 170 contestants in the United States Senior Golf Association championship at Apawamis today.
Heavy fog over parts of the metropolitan area last night disrupted airline schedules, highway traffic and even a baseball game at Ebbets Field.
The new Toronto Stock Exchange will be a sort of "theatre-in-the-round." That is disclosed in a progress report just made by its board of governors on a contemplated new building.

TOKYO, June 6--Premier Nobusuke Kishi's purpose in going to Washington this month is to try to make it impossible for the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communists to "drive a wedge between the United States and Japan" by using local instruments, he said today.
A national clearinghouse for information on the prevention and treatment of accidental poisoning has been established by the Public Health Service.
CHICAGO, June 6 (AP)--A late selling wave sent grain futures down on the Board of Trade today.
A subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee has taken issue with the House in the latter's attempt to kill off the acreage reserve phase of the year-old Soil Bank program.
WASHINGTON, June 6--The Eisenhower Administration has sent Congress the draft of a bill that would give the Treasury unrestricted authority to fix interest rates on loans by the Federal Government.
The continuous long-term use of blood anti-coagulants in patients who have suffered heart attacks diminishes considerably the danger of later attacks, a scientist reported yesterday.
Former President Harry S. Truman and Mrs. Traman saw their new grandson yesterday, forty-five minutes after they had arrived in New York.
An abundant economy may bring an abundance of problems, but faith in man will provide the solutions, New York University's graduating class of 6,297 was told yesterday.
CHANTILLY, France, June 6 (AP)--Three of fifteen Americans survived the second and third rounds of the French international amateur golf championship today and reached the quarter-finals.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 6--Dr. and Mrs. Hendrik Marinus Rozendaal have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katrina Scranton Rozendaal, to Robert Woodman Harris. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Melish Harris of Greenwich, Conn.
Mrs. Jane Gavin, 36-year-old widow of a war hero and mother of two children, yesterday became the ten-millionth beneficiary under the Federal Social Security system.
ROME, June 6--Premier Adone Zoli's new Government has decided to nationalize urban telephone services.

Cocoa futures advanced the limit of 1 cent a pound a day yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The rise followed a sharp decline registered on Wednesday. This was the third time in the last five trading days that all positions rose the daily limit.

LONDON, June 6--A further advaace by South African gold mining stocks highlighted today's stock exchange dealings. Government securities continued to decline. Movements in the industrial market were irregular but for the first time this week gains outnumbered losses.
MESHTA KASBA, Algeria, June 6--The stench of death is still sickening in this mountain village nine days after the worst massacre of the Algerian war.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 6 (AP) --Governor Harriman said tonight that "it is unbelievable that, after more than four years, the Secretary of Agriculture [Ezra Taft Benson] is still talking about reducing the prices for dairy products."
Ruben Gomez couldn't pitch Wednesday because he was hit on the head by a ball just before he was to warm up. But yesterday Gomez, his health restored, hurled his first shutout of the campaign.

We have the pleasant duty to report this morning that the official decision to keep closed "permanently" the subway entrance in Times Square at Forty-third Street was reversed only twelve hours after it was revealed to the public.
TORONTO, June 6--Here in central Ontario, in the heartland of Canada the major battle in the national election campaign is being fought.

Robert H. Craft, president of The Chase Bank, foreign financing subsidiary of The Chase Manhattan Bank, is slated to succeed W. Randolph Burgess as Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 6--No further sales of local housing authority bonds will take place until Labor Day "unless there is a very substantial improvement in the market for taxexempt bonds," Public Housing Commissioner Charles. E. Slusser announced here today.
WASHINGTON, June 6--A "substantial volume of shortweighting and short-measuring" in this country was reported today to the state authorities responsible for accurate scales.

MANCHESTER, England, June 6 (AP)--Althea Gibson of New York and Australia's Lew Hoad, the top-seeded players and Wimbledon favorites, today had to go all out to reach the semi-finals of the Northern lawn tennis tournament.
ST. LOUIS, June 6--The first program in the nation for preventing disasters from air pollution has run into snags.
TRENTON, June 6--Widely divergent views on the best way to solve New Jersey's water shortage problem were manifested today at a legislative hearing here.

CHANTILLY, France, June 7 (UP)--Col. Ken Smith of Kansas City celebrated his thirty-seventh birthday anniversary today by gaining the final of the French international amateur golf championship. Smith defeated G.B. Wolstenholme of England on the nineteenth hole.

Two thousand BMT subway riders spent an uncomfortable half-hour yesterday morning on two trains that were immobilized at the Queens end of the Sixtieth Street tunnel under the East River. Several thousand passengers on other BMT trains were delayed or inconvenienced.

Three old but sturdy apartment buildings, survivors of an era of more spacious living, stand among the fifteen unfinished structures of the Frederick Douglass Houses, a West Side public housing project.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here questioned yesterday the validity of a Securities and Exchange Commission rule concerning deals by corporation "insiders."

Harry La Montagne's 4-yearold filly Plotter, who has been the delight of the players of favorites at the New York tracks this year, won the $10,000 Oyster Bay handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. She ran a mile in a good 1:37 1/5 and scored with three-quarters of a length to spare.

Responding to the same compulsions that drive West European nations toward increasing unification in a world of super-powers, the states of South and Central America are also beginning to move in the same direction.

HONG KONG, June 7--The Peiping radio announced today that Communist China's second Five-Year Plan would place greater emphasis on agriculture and light industry for the production of consumer goods than did the first plan.

DETROIT, June 7--Baseball's largest turnout of the season, 43,474, saw the Tigers come from behind and pin a costly 6-3 defeat on the Yankees tonight at Briggs Stadium. WASHINGTON, June 7--The United States signed an agreement today to help Communist Poland's fragile economy with $48,900,000 in surplus farm goods and mining machinery.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 7-- William B. Franke, Under Secretary of the Navy, told 848 graduating midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy today that they would be serving in an era of "dizzying material progress."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 7-- Lebanon will receive tomorrow the first concrete military aid sent to any country under they Eisenhower Doctrine for combating communism in the Middle East.

AKRON, June 7 (AP)--Tommy Bolt, a firebrand, and the youthful, mild-mannered Dow Finsterwald shot their second sub-par rounds today to share the lead at the end of the second round of the $22,000 fourth annual Rubber City open golf tournament.

ZEEBRUGGE, Belgium, June 7--Proving that a little town can have a big dream, this port with a population of 4,000 dreams of becoming as well known to trans-Atlantic travelers as France's Cherbourg or Britain's Southampton.
WASHINGTON, June 7--President Eisenhower challenged Republican leaders in Congress and the country today to unite behind his Administration and the pledges of the party's 1956 platform.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 7-- On most campuses, jazz is something the authorities tolerate because the students like it. Brandeis University, though, looks on it as an art to be recognized and fostered.
Several athletes stepped forward yesterday ot report that "pep pills" had been used by sports performers in the United States, Canada and Australia.
Sales of Armour Co. and its domestic subsidiaries in the half year ended May 4 were 0.8 per cent below those a year earlier, but earnings declined $9,209,089.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) --Jack Sanford, pitching a threehitter and striking out thirteen batters, mowed down the Chicago Cubs for the Phillies, 1-0, tonight. The rookie hurler's performance enabled Philadelphia to keep pace with the Dodgers, a half game behind the leagueleading Redlegs.
LONDON, June 7--The British Home Office has been caught wiretapping.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 7 --Trading stamp companies won today the first round in their fight against 1957 legislation that undertook to place prohibitive taxes on the use of trading stamps in Tennessee.

Governor Harriman has asked the State Legislature to deal with a situation next week that should never have arisen. Involved are amendments to the State Unemployment Insurance and Workmen's Compensation laws.

An atomic scientist sailed his hand-made ketch into New York Harbor yesterday afternoon forty-one months after he had left Japan. He had covered 36,000 miles, and by the time he gets back to Japan in a year or more he will have added 15,000 miles to his log.

WASHINGTON, June 7--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today an authorization of $3,637,000,000 to carry forward the foreign aid program for another year.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 7--Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood won the Elizabeth Goss round-robin memorial tournament over the Upper Montclair course today.
A "break-through" in under standing major mental disorders, particularly schizophrenia, within the next decade was forecast last night by Dr. Paul H. Hoch, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene.

RYE, N.Y. June 7--Franklin G. Clement of Chicago was declared the winner of the United States Senior Golf Association's championship today. Clement, who participated in the first division of the competition on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Apawamis Club, found his 36hole total of 146 unbeatable.

TORONTO, June 7--Privately Liberal candidates in Ontario expect to lose a majority of Ontario's eighty-five seats in the House of Commons but to win the national election by a slim majority on June 10.

The six-story building containing thirty-one apartments at 1647 Popham Avenue the Bronx, has been sold by Geisinger Germain, realty operator, who bought it a few days ago. Philip Fogel was the broker in the resale of the building, which was erected in 1938. The property is 50 by 100 feet and is assessed at $110,000.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 7-- Iran's new Government, confronted by a deficit estimated as high as 6,000,000,000 rials (about $80,000,000), has been cautioned by the United States to expect no further grants for budgetary support.

WASHINGTON, June 7--The chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy moved today to bring under strict control of Congress the Administration's multi-million dollar program to develop atomic power.
BIG, juicy mangoes from the sub-tropics are becoming almost as familiar a sight on local fruit counters as apples, pears, grapes or any other fruit that grows here in the North.

Without attracting much attention, the Giants keep playing thrillers. They staged another one last night, against the Cardinals. If it didn't have a happy outcome for the loyalists among a Polo Grounds crowd of 8,419, it at least provided bonus entertainment values.
Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed generally off yesterday. Volume was light in most markets, with dealers evening holdings for the week-end.

The city used a "flying spray gun" yesterday against a particularly irritating type of mosquito that municipal health officials have dubbed the "flying tiger."

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 7 --Democratic women leaders of fifteen states were told at a symposium here today that their party was steadily gaining strength in the traditionally Republican suburbs as the "country club set" was nudged aside by a "supermarket set."
TOKYO, Saturday, June 8-- Specialist 3/c William S. Girard has dropped his Japanese defense counsel, the young soldier's Army legal adviser said today.
WASHINGTON, June 7--The Eisenhower Administration won the support of the Senate Appropriations Committee today for a one-year continuation of the soil bank.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 7--The Naval War College, oldest service war college in the nation, passed another milestone today.
WASHINGTON, June 7-- George Meany called today for the immediate resignation of Dave Beck as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
EASTON, Pa., June 7--The American adventure of the wealthy young French cavalry captain, the Marquis de Lafayette was recounted here tonight at the college that bears his name.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 7--The Bolivian Governments signed today an agreement with the United States that will provide $6,750,000 to help develop Bolivia's economy.
The Red Star Express Lines of Auburn, N.Y., has purchased the truck terminal at 639-41 Greenwich Street, at Barrow Street, in the lower West Side trucking area.
Merchant marine officer unions will ask for large salary increases when they meet with employers next week, but their principal aim will be improved vacations and pensions.
WASHINGTON, June 7-- Southern leaders said today that the House of Representatives stood ready to vote a guarantee of jury trials into President Eisenhower's civil rights bill.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 7-- Eighteen members of the Naval Academy's newly graduated class of '57 were married today in the Academy Chapel. Twentyone will be married there tomorrow and another eighteen by the middle of the month.

LONDON, June 7--Interest on stock exchange was still focused today on South African gold mining shares which advanced strongly in active trading. Oil shares also extended their gains after opening higher on overnight buying from New York.
The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham made a personal appeal for funds last night to help finance his New York Crusade.
LONDON, June 7--Harold E. Stassen, head of the United States delegation to the United Nations Disarmament subcommittee meeting here intends to fly to the United States tomorrow.

CHICAGO, June 7 (UP)--Gene Fullmer, who lost the world middleweight championship thirtyseven days ago, gained a tenround unanimous decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones tonight. The bout was an almost continuous slugging match.
Professional tennis returns to the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, in July, offering six of the world's foremost players in a week of round-robin competition.

George P. Monaghan, the State Harness Racing Commissioner, last night suggested a fourteenday "cooling off" period in an attempt to forestall a strike by horsemen at Yonkers Raceway next Friday night.
