JERSEY CITY, June 7 (AP)-- A group of New Jersey business men, who had offered $105,000 to Carmen Basilio for a welterweight title defense here, today made the same offer to the middleweight champion, Ray Robinson.
SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 7 --Warm and hazy spring weather waited on executives of the financial district here today on the occasion of the thirty-third annual field day of the Bond Club of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 7--A shoe that literally is molded to the foot was patented this week.
The Air Force has enlisted the aid of several university groups to determine the effect on the human body, other than heat effect, of powerful high-frequency beams like radar.

Mrs. Elizabeth Seelman Kingsley, who invented the DoubleCrostic, which has challenged and delighted puzzle fans for twenty-three years, died yesterday in the Dresden Madison Home, 36 East Sixty-seventh Street. She was 85 years old.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 7 --The Attorney General of the Unite-States urged judges and lawyers today to dedicate themselves to furtherance of a world order based on the restraining and constructive force of law.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 7-- The General Federation of Women's Clubs adopted a resolution today calling for reforms in the laws governing political campaign spending.

JUDITH BROWN is a young lady who creates with a torch. Welding is her skill, metal sculpture her medium. At 25 she has already been "shown" in prominent if slightly unorthodox places--in Fifth Avenue shop windows and on television.

NOORDWIJK-ON-SEA, The Netherlands, June 7 (AP)--Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode of Forest Hills, Queens, and Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., gained the semi-finals today in the Netherlands tennis championships.
EPSOAM, England, June 7 (AP) --Queen Elizabeth's underrated filly Carrozza won the 179th Epsom Oaks today. She then refused to follow her royal owner into the winner's circle.

The latest Federal security-risk case to come to public attention involves a 26-year-old employe of the Radio Corporation of America denied access to classified information apparently on the ground that he has maintained "a close continuing association" with and is subject to the influence of his mother, who allegedly had been a Communist some years ago.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP)--The United States Golf Association today ruled the National Amateur champion, Harvie Ward, out of amateur competition for one year for accepting unauthorized tournament expenses over a five-year period.

PARIS, June 7--The West is assuming an increasingly disadvantageous position at the London disarmament talks. Moscow, when it suits its book, violates pledged secrecy and advertises Soviet propaganda suggestions. At the same time it blames us for lack of agreement.
PARIS, June 7--The French Socialist party suddenly stopped playing hard to get today and brightened the prospects for a new Government in France.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 7 --Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, said today that he found it "terrifying" when young women considered campus life merely a means of finding husbands. He spoke at the college's twenty-ninth annual commencement.

CHATHAM, N.J., June 7-- Forest Grant of 114 Lafayette Avenue, who retired in 1940 as director of art for the New York City Board of Education, died yesterday at the Pine Acres Nursing Home in Madison. His age was 86.

ROME, Saturday, June 8-- Premier Adone Zoli and the oneparty Government he heads were given a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies early today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7--A two-story, $800,000 marble and granite building was dedicated today as the new headquarters of the marine Firemen, Oilers, Watertenders and Wipers Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 --Formation of an Academy of Animated Arts for motion pictures and television was announced today by a group of artists and executives engaged in the production of animated movies.

WASHINGTON, June 7--A witness testified today that she had been told by the Office of Defense Mobilization that no de cision had been made on tax concessions to the Idaho Power Company five days after the benefits had been granted.

Dayton Hedges, American industrialist in Cuba, died here today in St. Luke's Hospital. He had come from Cuba ten days ago to stay at his summer home in East Hampton, L.I. His age was 72.

The steamship charter market ended a five-month slide last week. The skid was interrupted only once, over a two-week period.

PARIS, June 9--Western Europe observed with notable restraint the tenth anniversary of our Marshall Plan. But the manner of remembrance has no importance. LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 9 --The board of directors of the American Planning and Civic Association voiced limited approval today of a Senate subcommittee's proposal to provide for the Federal Interstate highway project some control of roadside advertising.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 9--James and Allegra Mertz' 210, Allegra; John H. Kunz' Atlantic, Sprite, and Emil (Bus) MOSbacher's International, Susan, were leading victors today in the Orienta Yacht Club's fiftieth anniversary regatta on Long Island Sound.
GAYLORDSVILLE, Conn., June 9--This historic little village paid warm-hearted tribute today to one of its sturdiest possessions--its only teacher for nearly half a century, Mrs. Bessie Cornwell.

The Roman Catholic Church was described yesterday by the Rev. William B. O'Brien as the "living body of Christ in the world." He spoke at the 10 A.M. solemn pontifical mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) --The Chicago Cubs rallied to take the opener of a doubleheader from the Philadelphia Phillies today, 7--3. The second game was a 4-4 tie that was ended by the curfew in the tenth, with the Cubs at bat. The game will be replayed from the beginning.
GENEVA, June 9--Some under-developed countries fear that automation will kill their infant industries.
OTTAWA, June 9--Eight weeks of campaigning in Canada's general election came to an end today. The issue now is up to the 9,000,000 Canadians qualified to vote tomorrow.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 9-- W. Mahlon Dickerson's twelvemeter Gleam in Class A and J. Henry Scholtz Jr.'s forty-twofoot cutter Condesa in Class B were trophy winners this sparkling day when the 103d annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club was completed.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP)--The Baltimore Orioles, playing the role of giant killers, defeated first-place Chicago twice today, 7--5 and 5--0. The setbacks cut the White Sox' American League lead to four and one-half games.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 9-- China is asserting herself within the Communist bloc.

LONDON, June 9--Queen Elizabeth II is to visit the United States and Canada in October. The arrangements for the trip are virtually complete.
On a recent Sunday, when sand traps glistened in a benign sun, golfers waiting to tee off at the Dyker Beach golf course in Brooklyn whiled away the hours swapping stories.
HANOVER, N.H., June 9 --Combined commencement and baccalaureate exercises were held today for 620 Dartmouth College seniors.

DETROIT, June 10 (AP)--Automobile production apparently will hold firm through this month, thanks to a slightly improved sales outlook.

Bolivia yesterday agreed to resume limited interest payments July 1 on $56,278,000 of dollar bonds that have been in default since 1931. The High School Teachers Association has asked Mayor Wagner to set up a school system composed solely of junior and senior high schools.

PINAR DEL RIO, Cuba, June 13--Pinar del Rio on the whole seems to share the demonstrated feelings of the other parts of Cuba against the regime of President Fulgencio Batista.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif, June 13 --Although Republic Pictures is not now engaged in picture production, the company has started a $1,500,000 building program to expand its studio facilities.
DENVER, June 13--The American Federation of Musicians in effect acted today to continue its policy of racially segregated locals.

The Penn-Texas Corporation announced yesterday that its board of directors had authorized the purchase in the open market of up to 100,000 shares of the company's $1.60 cumulative convertible preferred stock.
Persons interested in the diversity of situations in which communities of the so-called underdeveloped sort may find themselves should be interested in the sessions of the U.N.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 13 (UP)--The Massachusetts women's champion, Joanne Goodwin, shot a three-under-par 72 today to win the Eastern women's amateur golf championship at the Agawam Hunt Club.

MASSENA, N.Y., June 13-- The State Power Authority took just twenty-five minutes today to approve unanimously the General Motors Corporation request for 12,000 kilowatts of St. Lawrence River power production.
Negligence suits totaling $2,111,670 were filed yesterday in Federal Court against the Federal Government and two air lines growing out of the Rikers Island plane crash last Feb. 1.
MANILA, June 13 (UP)--At least 1,185 persons have been killed by the epidemic of influenza that invaded the Philippines early last month, the Health Department reported today.

Juan Ramon Jimenez, who received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1956, is noted mainly for his poetry. His only prose work was written in 1917 and was called "Platero and I." Since its publication it has sold more...
A new 27,500-ton tramp freighter that will sail the St. Lawrence Seaway carrying grain and petroleum has been proposed to the Maritime Administration.
TRENTON, June 13--Gov. Robert B. Meyner criticized the Republican majority in the State Senate today for voting to reduce by more than $10,000,000 his record budget of $342,463,962.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- Critics of the $3,637,000,000 authorizing bill to carry forward foreign aid attacked it heavily today as Senate debate on the issue neared a close.
Wide use of wiretaps and close cooperation between Federal and state agencies to get evidence against Frank Costello were detailed yesterday in Federal Court.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were unchanged from the corresponding week of last year.
Carpenter Steel Company, Redding, Pa., has offered to exchange from 40,000 to 65,000 common shares for a new issue of Northeastern Steel Corporation's common stock.

Hull Associates, Inc., has sold the six-story apartment house at 3472 Knox Place, southeast corner of Gun Hill Road, the Bronx. The Maxine Operating Corporation, the buyer, paid cash over mortgages of $220,000.
The 180th anniversary of they adoption of the United States flag will be observed today, Flag Day, with patriotic ceremonies in several parts of the city.
An empty beer can thrown into the path of a BMT subway train last evening caused 75,000 homeward-bound passengers on fifty-five trains to be delayed up to an hour and twenty-eight minutes.
OTTAWA, June 13--Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent and his Cabinet considered today whether to hang on to office a little longer or resign immediately.
The program of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue will be furthered by the proceeds of the Golden Ball on Oct. 1.
The prospect that a dark horse not yet mentioned was likely to win the Republican nomination for Mayor arose yesterday after a secret meeting of city Republican leaders.
Any appraisal of the results of the Khrushchev-Bulganin visit to Finland must depend upon one's assumptions of the Soviet leaders' initial objectives in making the trip.

Dr. C. Martin Wilbur has been named director of the East Asian Institute of Columbia University. He succeeds Dr. Hugh Borton, who tomorrow becomes the fifteenth president of Haverford College, near Philadelphia.
QUANTICO, Va., June 13-- Charles E. Wilson forecast today a stretch-out in procurement of weapons and gradual reduction of armed forces because of money difficulties.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) --Representative Francis E. Walter introduced a bill today to carry out several of President Eisenhower's suggestions for relaxing immigration restrictions.
SANTAREM, Portugal, June 12--Brightly painted American farm machinery is attracting wide interest at the annual country fair here.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 13 --Raymond Bill, president and board chairman of the Bill Brothers Publishing Corporation of New York, died this morning at his home, 200 Old Church Road. His age was 60.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) --The Federal Communications Commission ended a three-year battle today by granting a renewal of a television license to Edward O. Lamb.
One of the fastest mile-and-asixteenth races ever run at Belmont Park was won yesterday by Lofty Peak, a 5-year-old gelding owned by C. Mahlon Kline of Philadelphia.
The Fund for the Republic has organized a search for long-range answers to these questions: What is a truly free society? How can such a society be maintained?
The performance of "Tosca" at the Metropolitan Opera on Dec. 5 will be a benefit for the Bagby Music Lovers' Foundation, Inc., which aids needy musical artists in their later years.
The special session of the New York Legislature called by Governor Harriman lasted four days and was extraordinary for its lack of accomplishment, This was not unexpected.
WARSAW, June 13--A Polish correspondent in Peiping indicated today that some Chinese Communists were alarmed over the effect of Mao Tse-tung's fundamental revision of Marxist doctrine.
MOSCOW, June 13--Soviet leaders challenged the United States today to propose a monthly half-hour exchange of views on radio and television.
The Hempstead, L.I., Central High School District 3 (Metham) borrowed $8,185,000 in the bond market yesterday on an issue of serial obligations due from 1958 to 1986.
Hugh E. Jackson, general sales manager of the American Oil Company, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Riverside Hospital, Newport News, Va.
BUFFALO, June 13--Organized labor proposed today that a Government official be put in charge of radiation safety in each of the 1,500 atomic industry plants.
THE Organization of the General Slocum Survivors, reduced now to twenty-nine members, will meet for prayer at the Lutheran Cemetery in Middle Village, Queens, come Sunday.

MANY of the features in the supermarkets this Father's Day week-end include hearty suggestions of steaks and roasts. Ribs of beef, round roast, pot roast and sirloin steaks are just a few of the specials at attractive prices.
THERE are many decisions of daily life that children can and should make for themselves but decisions about music practice are not among them.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) --An expert on union welfare funds testified today that public disclosure was the surest safeguard against abuses or mishandling of the funds.
WASHINGTON, June 13--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today United States membership in an international atoms-for-peace agency proposed by President Eisenhower.
THE death of Howard Swiggett two months ago robbed the American literary scene of one of its most determined individualists. Unlike so many writers who are determined to be literary at all costs,...

A new direct air route between Houston, Tex. and Amsterdam, Holland, will be offered to the American traveler shortly after Labor Day. Passengers now flying to Europe from the Texas city must change planes and airlines in New York.

YONKERS, June 13 (UP)-- Adios Harry, the world recordholding pacer owned by J. Howard Lyons of Greenwood, Del., survived a head-and-head duel with Duane Hanover to score a narrow victory in tonight's $10,000 Billy Direct Pace before 21,917 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

The Motion Picture Association of America will expand its Production Code Appeals Board to include film indsutry, representatives from the ranks of exhibitors and producers not belonging to the M.P.A.A.
Justin C. O'Brien, former head of a leading building and general contracting company, died yesterday in his home at 45-52 Fortieth Street, Long Island City, Queens. His age was 66.
ALBANY, June 13--The special session of the Legislature ended today, as it began Monday, in an exchange of political recriminations.
Mao Tse-tung is now quoted as having stated officially that his Communist regime in China "liquidated" some 800,000 persons in the first five yeas of its power on the mainland.
The city is ready to extend retroactive Social Security coverage to 110,000 eligible employes, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday. The coverage would date back to Jan. 1, 1956.

LONDON June 13 (Reuters) --African Negro infants studied in Uganda have a development "equal to that of European children twice or three times their age," the British medical journal, The Lancet, reported today.
Nearly 100 pilots will be added to the air defense of New York City tomorrow when the National Guard converts its bomber wing here to jet fighterinterceptors.

YONKERS, June 13--In an on-again, off-again turn of events in which there was plenty of double-talk, no one appeared able to say with certainty tonight whether there would be racing at Yonkers. Raceway tomorrow night.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP)--John Tsitouris, a rookie pitcher, atrived at Briggs Stadium after today's game between the Detroit Tiger's and Baltimore Orioles had started but he still picked up a victory in his first major league appearance as the Tigers downed the Orioles, 2--1.
CHICAGO, June 13--A knockdown pitch, a knockdown punch and suddenly, in full view of 23,401 fans at Comiskey Park today, there it was--the most violent free-for-all of the baseball season.

Forty-four percent of those who made "decisions for Christ" in the first four weeks of the Billy Graham Crusade here did not have a church affiliation, the Protestant Council of the City of New York reported yesterday.
LONDON, June 13 (AP)-- America's leading tennis stars advanced with only one break today in both men's and women's singles competition in three English tournaments.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 13-- Victor King, former Mayor who helped in changing Camden's form of government from councilmanic to commission in the Nineteen-twenties, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)-- Cash dividend payments by corporations issuing public reports totaled nearly $4,000,000,000 during the first five months of this year. This was 3 per cent more than the figure for the same period of 1956.
Pik-Record, Inc., has bought for investment the six-story apartment house at 225 West Twelfth Street, northeast corner of Greenwich Street.
Four vessels may be prevented from sailing from the Port of New York today as a result of a sudden dispute yesterday between the American Radio Association and ship owners.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 13 --The Soviet Union proposed today the establishment of inspection posts within its borders arid in the United States, Britain and elsewhere to speed an international ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
Henry W. Leland, an advertising executive of the General Electric Company in Schenectady, N.Y., died yesterday in the Beverly Hotel, 125 East Fiftieth Street. His age was 54. He lived in Schenectady.
New York City residents have an annual social welfare bill of more than $1,400,000,000, and nearly 80 per cent of it comes from some government source.
In the comparative privacy of the Polo Grounds--there were only 1,875 cash customers present--the Giants yesterday won their third straight game. They beat the last-place Cubs, 7--4.
Western nations, despite frictions in their relations, will continue to draw closer in cooperative institutions, including, eventually, a form of common market, James A. Farley asserted yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 13 (UP)-- Federal agents fought a gunbattle today with alleged leaders of a narcotics ring in a roadhouse. Two agents and a gunman were critically wounded.
LONDON, June 13--The "thin red line" of Britain's imperial wars was arrayed under a bright sun today for the annual Trooping the Color ceremony before Queen Elizabeth, who took the salute.

A $13,000,000 plan for reconstructing vehicular approaches to the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge and for providing direct connections between the bridge and the South street Viaduct was announced yesterday.
CARLISLE, Pa., June 13 (AP) --Dr. Raymond J. Saulnier, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, suffered an attack of "mild fatigue" and was hospitalized today.

The quarter-century of David Dubinsky's presidency of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union was celebrated yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., June 13--Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt, Westchester C.C., and Gail Wild, Greenwich C.C., won the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's four-ball tournament at Apawamis today with a 75 for 153.
Negotiators for The Associated Press and the Commercial Telegraphers Union agreed early this morning on a wage rise for the union's 650 members and a new one-year contract.

TOKYO, June 13--It is in the best interests of the United States to help see that a conservative Government remains in power in Japan, Premier Nobusuke Kishi said tonight.

CLEVELAND, June 13 (UP)-- Ted Williams today became the first player in American League history to hit three homers in one game twice in one season. His booming bat powered the Boston Red Sox to a 9-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., June 13--Fourteen soldiers were killed and nine injured here today when a two-and-a-half-ton truck failed to make a curve and overturned. This army base is home of the 101st Airborne Division.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 13--Two hundred contestants competed for thirty-two places in the qualifying round of the fifty-sixth annual New Jersey Golf Association's state amateur championship over the Rock Spring course today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 13 --President Iskander, Mirza charged in an interview today that Indian Communists were intensively carrying out subversive activity in East Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, June 13--A Senate subcommittee lawyer recommended today that the Justice Department investigate, and that Congress consider new legislation to restrict, the overseas operations of American oil companies.
TOLEDO, June 13--"I hit the ball off the ninth tee," said Bobby Cruickshank, the Wee Scot. "It shot up in the air and never came down."

WASHINGTON, June 13--The Director of the Budget labeled "premature" today a series of recent forecasts that Federal spending in the next fiscal year would exceed President Eisenhower's January estimate of $71,800,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 733,477 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP) --A Federal District judge fined the Philadelphia Radio and Television Broadcasters Association $5,000 today for violation of the Antitrust Law.

Commodity futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, copper, lead, zinc, hides and potatoes rose; cocoa, coffee, rubber and wool declined, and price movements for sugar were mixed.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 13 --J. Allen Breed Jr. of Mount Hermon, Michael F. Dorsey of The Hill, James Frick Jr. of Brunswick and Jeff Graham of Poly Prep reached the semifinal round of the forty-first...

WASHINGTON, June 13--The president of the Idaho Power Company charged today that there was "persecution of the worst sort" against him and his company in the continuing fight over public versus private power.
GENEVA, June 13--The United States suffered a first-round defeat today in a dispute with the Soviet Union over the form of a world ban on racial discrimination in employment.
IT can be said of "Kaleidoscope," the revue that opened last night at the Provincetown Playhouse, that never have so many toiled in behalf of a venture and accomplished so little.
In his recently published book "My Dear Dorothea" Bernard Shaw gives advice to a young girl.
Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley did an about-face yesterday, and as a result so will motorists on five one-way East Side streets near the Queensboro Bridge.
Steps were taken yesterday to inject new life into two of New York's lagging slum clearance projects.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13-- Lebanon's diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union are severely strained.

Pleasure boating is getting easier by the hour. It is becoming more automatic, more pushbtttton-ish, even more delightful.

After another round of musical chairs France has acquired a new Government which, except for a new Premier, Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, looks very much like the preceding one and is dedicated to very much the same policies and programs.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics increased to 89.7 on Wednesday from 89.6 on Tuesday. The figure for June 13, 1956, was 89.
The operators of the 448 motion-picture houses here got official encouragement yesterday in their struggle to escape the burden of the city's 5 per cent amusement tax.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., June 13-- The Mayflower II reached Plymouth harbor today under conditions undreamed of by the men who sailed her predecessor 337 years ago.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 --Miss Barbara Ward, British economist and editor, urged the western world today to revive the Spirit of the Marshall Plan.
The city gave the Port of New York Authority the green light yesterday for sweeping improvements to the George Washington Bridge and adjacent Manhattan streets.
TOKYO, June 13--The Bank of Japan has ordered nine leading commercial banks to cut their proposed lending during June from 50 billion yen to 22 billion ($138,800,000 to $61,100,000).
Reginald Hood Giles, former president of the Bankers Safe Deposit Company here, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. His age was 85.

Net earnings of the South American Gold Platinum Company in the first quarter this year reached a record $658,290, or 34 cents a share, more than doubling the $292,276, or 15 cents a share, earned in the initial three months last year.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP)--Wheat futures dipped 1 to 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today, in selling that partly was profit taking, following the advances of the previous session.
Susan Strasberg is aligned with "Time Remembered" again. An authoritative source says the romantic comedy will arrive Sept. 12 at the Morosco.
MADISON, N.J., June 13-- David Morton, poet and Professor of English at the Azores branch of American International College, died here today at Pine Acres Nursing Home after a long illness.
WASHINGTON, June 13--Defenders of President Eisenhower's civil rights bill defeated six attempts to amend it in the House of Representatives today.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 13-- The Kings of Jordan and Saudi Arabia issued today a communique on their talks this week that reaffirmed all standard Arab positions and ignored the glaring divisions in the Arab world.
Two events this week call attention to the achievements of American unionism at its best--to be weighed heavily in the balance against the shortcomings which the McClellan committee has disclosed.
WITH the world debating the potential dangers of radiation there has been an upsurge recently in reports that television picture tubes emit rays that might be harmful to home viewers.

The Federal Reserve System reduced its holdings of Government securities $218,600,000 through open market operations in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

In a game marked by a wild second-inning melee in which Don Drysdale and Johnny Logan were the principal combatants the Milwaukee Braves outslugged the Brooklyn Dodgers, 8--5, at Ebbets Field yesterday.
An English visitor, out for a stroll late Wednesday evening along the East River, became so fascinated with the lights and passing boats that he absentmindedly stepped off the end of a pier.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation has abandoned a plan to sponsor a series of feature films next season on the American Broadcasting Company television network.
WASHINGTON, June 13--The House Appropriations Commit tee approved today a moderately pruned bill providing $814,813.023 to carry on various public works programs in the fiscal year 1958.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 13-- The Carib Creole Carnival came to this college community tonight and was well received.

TOLEDO, June 13--A storm and then darkness curtailed play, but the withdrawal of Ben Hogan beeause of illness overshadowed all else today in the first round of the United States Open Golf championship.
The new Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn was installed yesterday by Cardinal Spellman.
Prospects for the nation's lead and zinc industry this summer are beginning to look depressingly like the hard times of four years ago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 --Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Television is planning to draw upon its large unproduced story files for a new anthology series called "You're Only Young Once."

JERSEY CITY, June 13-- "Old No. 1000," the first commercially successful Dieselelectric locomotive in the United States, headed for an honored place in railroad history today after thirty-two years of continuous service.

WASHINGTON, June 13-- President Eisenhower again pledged his personal assistance today to an effort to build the Republican party in the South and increase its Congressional representation from that area.
The new 6 per cent preferred stock of the Alleghany Corporation will have to remain in limbo until September. Alleghany is the holding company which controls the New York Central Railroad.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 14--Robert Jacobson of the Hollywood Club started defense of his New Jersey state amateur golf championship by taking two matches today, over the 6,466-yard, par 71 Rock Spring course.
More Government assistance for young Americans traveling overseas on exchange programs was among a dozen recommendations made yesterday to promote world peace.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 14 --Robert W. Neall of 77 Bronxville Road, sales consultant for Bigelow Rugs and Carpets, 140 Madison Avenue, New York, died here Wednesday at Lawrence Hospital. His age was 61.

QUANTICO, Va., June 14-- Military leaders participating today at the annual defense conference here were reported to be dissatisfied with the conditions of a projected disarmament agreement with the Soviet Union.
Mrs. Natalia Sedova Trotsky never intended to testify before a Congressional committee, she said in a statement issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- President Eisenhower termed "almost ridiculous" today the delay in the entrance of the United States into the Organization for Trade Cooperation.
BOSTON, June 14--Boston opened its Sixth Arts Festival today--a seventeen-day program of painting, music, poetry, drama, opera, ballet and jazz.
LONDON, June l4 (AP)--Herb Flam, Althea Gibson and Darlene Hard scored victories today to join Louise Brough and Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode in the finals of English lawn tennis tournaments.

A bi-lingual production of Aeschylus' "Prometheus Bound" will be presented in Athens this summer under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy in cooperation with the Greek Ministry of Education.
ALBANY, June 14--The first special session of Governor Harriman's Administration left him today with ten proposed pieces of legislation but no apparent difficult decisions involving them.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., June 14-- The thing to do on any fishing trip in this vicinity is to take along a marine biologist for class and sound scientific atmosphere. These fellows identify on sight anything that comes aboard, and are handy for settling bets.
WARSAW, June 14--A Polish airliner with thirteen persons, including five Americans, crashed just before it was due to land at Moscow tonight, the Polish State airline L.O.T. announced.

WILTON, Conn., June 14-- Miss Sandra Marshall Peabody, daughter of Charles M. Peabody of Wilton and Mrs. Robert K. Farrand of Philadelphia, was married here this afternoon to Smith Walker Bagley. He is the son of Mrs. Nancy Reynolds Bagley of Greenwich and Henry Walker Bagley of New York.
A seriously split Queens Democratic organization called off a showdown yesterday over the choice of a candidate for borough president.

In the struggle for the soul of the Arab peoples now under way between the pro-Soviet and imperialist elements led by President Nasser and the anti-Communist forces backing the principles of the Eisenhower Doctrine, King Saud of oil-rich Saudi Arabia is obviously emerging as the key figure.
RUMSON, N.J., June 14--Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Faris King Jr. gave a dance in their home this evening in honor of their daughter, Miss Nancy Kent King.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee took a long time to approve the treaty setting up the International Atomic Energy Agency, but it has finally done so.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)-- Senator Estes Kefauver told the Senate today that preliminary investigation "certainly shows me" that profits were made on advance word of fast tax writeoff permits.
OCEAN CITY, Md., June 14 (UP) -- Federal Communications Commissioner T.A.M. Craven said today that those who oppose toll television were trying to "stop progress."
NEW LONDON, Conn., June l4--Harvard and Yale will race here tomorrow for the ninetysecond time in the oldest of intercollegiate sports competitions, dating from 1852.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)-- The newspaper of the Washington Roman Catholic Diocese replied today to remarks made by the Rev. G. Bromley Oxnam, Methodist Bishop, about the Foreign Service School of Georgetown University.

VALERIAN A. ZORIN has been zealously engaged in making friends at the disarmament talks in London. Typical of the Soviet diplomats recent role as peacemaker was his suggestion yesterday than a moratorium of two or three years be de clared on nuclear tests.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would discuss the Title I program with the Committee on Slum Clearance and its chairman, Robert Moses, in an effort to plug up loopholes. The loopholes have caused long delays in starting construction on several housing projects.
BRISBANE, Australia, June 12--Tests have estabaished the existence of huge bauxite deposits in Australia. It is believed the deposits may prove to be the largest in the non-Communist world.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) --Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee today led an attack by Senate Democrats against Administration increases in interest rates on Government bonds.
NORFOLK June 14--United States tactics and techniques of amphibious warfare were demonstrated today to officers and seamen of the foreign men-ofwar visiting Norfolk.

The public market for new capital is still going full steam. Underwriting capital is under heavy commitment, as major issues of debt securities and common and preferred shares follow in quick succession.
One obstacle an industry must hurdle when it experiences a phenomenal growth is a lack of competent management just below the top level. The food business is no exception.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) --The Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee reported today that profits of five major oil companies were 18.6 per cent higher in the first quarter of 1957 than in the same period in 1956.
The real estate boards of the five boroughs have joined in an all-out campaign against a proposed law that would bar racial discrimination in more than 70 per cent of all housing in the city.

Add this perplexing question to the list of jet-age problems that an earthbound layman might not suspect exists: how does a jet pilot who is wearing a pressurized helmet find relief from an itching nose?
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 14--The Protestant Episcopal Church or St. James the Less was the setting this evening for the marriage of Miss Lynne Ruth Butcher to Merrell Mays Clark.

WASHINGTON, June 14--The United States has indicated willingness to let Qantas Airways fly across this country and on to London if Australia will grant American rights for several Southern Hemispheric routes, including one across the South Pole.

A welcome mat for new business is being prepared in the Virgin Islands in the form of a tax exemption bill. Four island Senators arrived here yesterday to explain the promise the measure holds both for the islands and the investor.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)-- Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today a Congressional Economic subcommittee would try to learn why farm prices and incomes were relatively low in a period of national prosperity.
DARIEN, Conn., June 14-- Members of the United States Equestrian team scored a sweep in the open jumper events in the first session of the three-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today.
Federal Judge Richard H. Levet yesterday enjoined a milk drivers' local of the teamsters' union from promoting strikes by employes of various milk dealers.
Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, will observe at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow its "titular festival."
BUFFALO, June 14--New York's pioneer State Industrial Code on radiation protection in the atomic industry is likely to undergo amending in the next three months.
CHICAGO, June 14--Grain futures prices moved irregularly on the Board of Trade today.
DETROIT, June 14 (AP)--Yvon Durelle fought heavily-favored Tony Anthony to a draw tonight in a ten-round nationally televised bout.

A bill now in committee in the City Council would require organizations of city employes to keep regular accounts, properly audited, and to render an annual account of their financial operations to their members.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., June 14--Fifty-eight women convicts who recently completed high school courses in Westfield State Farm here received graduation certificates today from the State Board of Regents. Each also received a corsage.
MOSCOW, June 14 (AP)-- Pravda told its readers today the case of two new Soviet repatriates showed that Russians who tried life in the United States could end up eating dog food or going to jail.

That ready help in tracing events gone by, The New York Times Index for 1956, has come from the press. This master key to the news has been published continuously since January, 1913, and it is unique as the only service summarizing and classifying news alphabetically by subjects, persons and organizations.

Mayor Wagner appealed yesterday for changes in the state Constitution to help cure government's newest headache--the rising problems of metropolitan areas. He warned that the present Constitution might hobble the big cities unless they got more power to act.

MASSENA, N.Y., June 14-- Governor Harriman, speaking at the ground-breaking today for an $88,000,000 Reynolds Metals Company plant, predicted for Northern New York economic expansion "never before contemplated."
WASHINGTON, June 14--A National Commission on Literacy will be organized here next Monday.
The State Rent Commission plans to end controls on apartments and hotel accommodations in the city that rent for at least $375 a month unfurnished or $455 furnished.
The Flag Day unfurling of "the biggest flag in New York" had an unexpected climax on Fifth Avenue yesterday.
The Police Department began a concerted drive yesterday to rid the city of "narcotics peddlers, gamblers, prostitutes, procurers, tinhorns and drifters."

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -President Eisenhower was quoted as telling forty-two Republicans in the House of Representatives today that the Administration's foreign aid program amounted to one of the "best possible ways to wage peace."

LONDON, June 14--Government securities staged another rally on the Stock exchange today. Gains ranged up to ten shillings ($1.40) on 100 ($280) shares; largest rises were in long dated and undated issues.
The Legislature's watchdog committee prepared yesterday to test its powers to grant balky witnesses immunity from criminal prosecution.
LONDON, June 14--The Soviet Union accepted today a Western proposal that an international control system be established to assure observance of an agreement to suspend nuclear tests.
Last night at the Polo Grounds the Cincinnati Redlegs snapped a four-game losing streak by beating the Giants, 5--4. The victory moved the Redlegs into second place in the National League race.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- George M. Humphrey, the Secretary of the Treasury, said today he believed tax cuts might become possible for part of the fiscal year that will begin July 1, 1958. Mr. Humphrey emphasized however, that he could make no "definite statement" on the point now.
YALTA, U.S.S.R., June 11-- Soviet winemakers have declared war on vodka.
OTTAWA, June 14--The question of who will form the next Government of Canada remained unanswered today. It will not be answered until early next week.
Commodity, futures closed mostly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges in generally dull trading.
WARSAW, June l4--The Folish Writers Union has condemned a purge of Hungarian writers as action "against the essential fights of men."

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) --Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate Democratic leader, told the Eisenhower Administration today that its "tight money" policy could lead "only to a depression which will actually curl everyone's hair."
LONDON, June 17--Esme Percy, actor and producer of many of George Bernard Shaw's plays, died yesterday in his sleep at a hotel in Brighton. He was 69 years old.
OTTAWA, June 17--For the first time in twenty-two years a Conservative party leader was invited tonight to become Prime Minister of Canada.
The Citizens Union urged yesterday the most sweeping overhaul of the executive branch of this state's government since the late Alfred E. Smith was Governor.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 17 (UP)--Walter (Mousie) Blum, a jockey from the sidewalks of New York, booted home three winners in a row and barely missed a fourth at Monmouth Park today.

The first copper refinery to be built east of the Mississippi in more than half a century will begin operations this summer near Reading, Pa., it was announced yesterday by the Reading Metals Refining Corporation.
TRENTON, June 17 (AP)--The appellate Division of Superior Court today upheld a $42,000 jury verdict for a boy who lost his right eye when a soft drink bottle exploded.

Notre Dame and New York University will meet in a regularly scheduled game at Madison Square Garden this coining season. The Irish and Violets started the college basketball at the Eighth Avenue arena when they met in 1934.
LONDON, June 17 (AP)--Gil Shea of Los Angeles and three of America's younger players won first-round matches today in the London lawn tennis championships, the final tune-up for Wimbledon.
In a flabby market devoted almost entirely to stocks supported or depressed by corporate news and rumors, The New York Times combined and industrial averages yesterday edged up to new 1957 highs.
ALBANY, June 17--Governor Harriman today urged New York's Congressional delegation to oppose present plans for construction of the Allegany reservoir.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)-- Personal income in the United States reached an adjusted annual rate of $340,500,000,000 during May.
State Senator James J. Crisona was designated last night for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Queens over the opposition of James M. Phillips, the county leader.
WASHINGTON June 17--A Congressional investigation into the workings of slum clearance in New York City became a possibility today.
A college course carrying undergraduate credit will be offered over regular television by New York University beginning in September.

CAIRO, June 17--President Gamal Abdel Nasser announced today a list of hand-picked candidates who are to be "elected" to the revolutionary regime's first Parliament. No one even vaguely suspected of opposing the regime was allowed on the ballot for the elections scheduled July 3.
WASHINGTON, June 17--A New York business spokesman told Senators today that proposed legislation took a "blunderbuss approach" to the problem of employe welfare and pension funds.

Edward J. Fitzgerald, former Government economist, who appeared before one grand jury in connection with a wartime Washington espionage ring, was questioned yesterday by another Federal panel investigating a Russian spy apparatus.
THIS month, while some girls are marching down the aisle into matrimony, others are marching into fitting rooms.

John Stewart Service was born of American parents in Chengtu, China, on Aug. 3, 1909. He was a educated in Shanghai, at Berkeley (Calif.) High School, and at Oberlin College, where he received his Bachelor of Arts degree in 1931.
SOCHI, U.S.S.R., June 14-- A tremendous amount of volunteer work goes into the running of a Soviet city.
MADRID, June 17--An important progressive bloc of the Spanish Monarchist movement significantly has identified itself publicly with some--though not all--of the Franco regime's achievements.
WASHINGTON, June 17-- The political pendulum in the Middle East appears to some diplomats to be beginning to swing against President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 17--An uneasy peace dominated the Haitian capital today, but arrests were filling the penitentiary and jails throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) --The Kansas City (Mo.) Star was denied today a Supreme Court review of its conviction on charges of monopolizing the dissemination of news and advertising in the Kansas City area.

The basic city real estate tax rate for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be $3.99 for each $100 of assessed valuation. The rate, 3 cents below the record 1956-57 rate of $4.02, will be set by the City Council today. It will represent the first reduction in twelve years.

WASHINGTON, June 17--The Voice of America beamed to the Soviet Union today the text of a reply by The New York Times to a Leningrad mother who had written The Times. The reply was contained in an editorial in today's editions of The Times.

A United States Supreme Court justice will be asked today to block public revelation of tape-recorded conversations between Joseph (Socks) Lanza and Sylvester Cosentino, a lawyer. NEW DELHI, India, June 17 --A program to extend life insurance to peasants and workers on a mass scale was started today.

WASHINGTON, June 17--An Appropriations subcommittee in the House of Representatives moved today to ward off a threatened cutback in mail service July 1. It approved a supplemental fund of $133,000,000 for the Post Office Department.

LONDON, June 17--Industrial stocks generally remained firm of the stock exchange today despite a little selling. The turnover was said to be large and the demand selective. Price movements mostly were in pennies.
Large numbers of icebergs floating in the North Atlantic under a sizzling sun are keeping the Coast Guard in a sweat.

"Junior Miss," the stage comedy that opened on Broadway in 1941 and later was adapted for a motion picture, will be developed as a ninety-minute television musical in color. Seven young victims of cerebral palsy who have completed home instruction courses were honored yesterday in a special graduation ceremony.

Five major cigarette manufacturers increased yesterday the wholesale prices of some of their non-filter brands. The rise was 35 cents a thousand, amounting to about 1 cent a pack at the retails level. Higher costs of materials, labor, equipment and tobacco were held responsible for the increase.

The demand for domestic crude oil in the third quarter of this year is expected to be about 400,000 barrels a day below present production levels, according to the Independent Petroleum Association of America.

The American News Company, which is stepping out of the business of distributing magazines, is offering for sale its plants and equipment throughout the country. All physical assets are included, taking in office and warehouse equipment, truths and buildings.

CHICAGO, June 17--The home furnishings industry is finding more and more of its market in the field of business, Charles Whitney, publisher of Interiors magazine, declared today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 18 (UP)--Freedom of trading in foreign exchange was restored today in Colombia for the first time in more than twenty-five years.

LONDON, June 18--A contemporary portrait of William Penn, believed to be the only authentic likeness in existence, was sold at auction here today to a buyer from the state he founded nearly three centuries ago.
PEIPING, June 18--Mao Tsetung, Communist China's head of state, today made public a recommendation for a "blossoming" of democratic freedoms among the people so long as it keeps within bounds.
The Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse has been, purchased by Charles B. Moss, executive director of the Criterion Theatre, on Broadway, and a chain of theatres in Long Island, New Jersey and Florida.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18-- The chairman of the House Committee on un-American activities today advised the Supreme Court to take a minute out to bone up on communism. A colleague condemned the Board of Governors of the California State Bar.
It was a fairly lively day is the stock market yesterday. Volume expanded to 2,440,000 shares from 2,200,000 Monday. Prices went down a bit.
WASHINGTON, June 18--The Senate, by a vote of 67 to 19, approved tonight United States membership in an international atoms-for-peace agency proposed by President Eisenhower.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., June 18 --"Very strong evidence" that a form of life might exist on Mars was reported today to a major astronomicai meeting. It was said that the life was far more likely moss than man.

WASHINGTON, June 18-- Stanislaw Leopold Szpinalski, one of Poland's foremost pianists and teachers of music, died in Paris last Wednesday, according to word received here today by the Polish Embassy. He was 55 years old.
The Transit Authority adopted a $263,897,990 budget yesterday for the 1957-58 fiscal year on the assumption that it would lose no riders in the twelvemonth period beginning July 1.
The Wagner administration's push for prompt enactment of legislation barring discrimination in private apartment housing here crumbled yesterday under a barrage of opposition.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) --The Government today revoked its policy of limiting the export of heavy melting grades of iron and steel scrap to then United Kingdom, Japan and the European Coal and Steel Community.

Japan's Prime Minister, Nobusuke Kishi, arrives in Washingtoh today for his important official visit. It is important to him because he needs and wishes to strengthen his political position at home. It is important to us because any improvement in our relations with Japan that can come out of a frank discussion of the problems will be welcome.
The American Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday new highs in earnings for May and for five and twelve months ended May 31.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP)-- Most grain futures weakened today on the Board of Trade in the wake of the upturn of the previous session.

Dean M. Lewis president of the Silk and Rayon Printers and Dyers Association of America, Inc., said yesterday he was moving to call an industry-wide meeting of textile officials to plan new ways to seek Federal aid.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)-- Following is the roll-call vote today by which the House passed and sent to the Senate the Civil Rights Bill:

THE seductive aroma, of fresh baked cakes and pies greets you at the door of Dodd's, a modest bakery at 1073 First Avenue, near Fifty-ninth Street. Stop there, on the way home from work one of these torrid evenings, for such homey but good pastries as blueberry pie, devil's food cake heaped with rich fudge frosting and fresh strawberry tarts.

Morris Pudalow, a sixth grade school teacher who peddles pencils and ball point pens from door to door in his spare time, called a clerk at Public School 51 in the Bronx yesterday and reported sick. He said he would not be able to teach his class.
The Sinclair Refining Company, refining and marketing affiliate of the Sinclair Oil Company, announced yesterday that it will increase gasoline and fuel oil prices on Friday.

WASHINGTON, June 18--The Supreme Court has placed fundamental restrictions on a Congressional investigatory power that in recent years has been asserted as all but limitless.

AS if to prove a point, nature is providing ninety-degree temperatures to herald the fact that summer arrives this week. To combat her show of strength, short of buying a cool island off the coast of Maine, one must resort to indoor weather control provided by an air conditioner.
The opinion of Chief Justice Warren in the Watkins case is a major pronouncement of the Supreme Court on the rights of the individual citizen before investigating committees of the Congress.
In order to cover 5.2 miles through eleven hairpin turns to the top of a mountain in 4:44.6 minutes, a man driving a sports car has to step on the gas on every little open stretch.

LONDON, June 18--The stock market was quiet today with prices showing no decided trend. However, the undertone of the industrial market was still described as firm and oil shares again were active and mostly higher.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) --The State Department questioned anew today the Dominican Republic's account of the strange disappearance of the Oregon pilot, Gerald Murphy, in that country last December.

FIFTY years ago the Colony Club for women opened at 122 Madison Avenue at Thirtieth street. Harry K. Thaw was on trial at the time for the murder of Stanford White, the architect, but generally it was a golden-tinted age, more or less peaceful.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 18 --The trustees of Princeton conferred a surprise honorary degree on Dr. Harold Willis Dodds today at the last commencement in which he participated as president of the university.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 18 --More than 700 persons many of them jurists and officials in various branches of government, today attended a simple Protestant Episcopal funeral service for Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of the New Jersey Supreme Court, Justice Vanderbilt, who was 68 years old, died early Sunday of a heart ailment.
WASHINGTON, June 18-- Senate racket investigators accused a union president today of virtually imposing a substandard wage contract on union members whose employer had "lent" him more than $100,000.
Temporary relief from the week-long heat wave will probably come to the New York area tonight when a mass of cold air moves in from the west.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 18 (AP)--Sam Giammalva of Texas and Barry Mackay of Michigan led seeded players through the second round of the national collegiate tennis tournament with easy victories today.

The chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Diane Potter to Peter Saunders of London and Aberdeen, Scotland.
The city set a record for use of electricity yesterday, as desperate residents sought every form of artificial cooling in a sweltering 92-degree heat.
A proposal for using dog patrols tog rid the city's parks of vandals and other undesirables is being studied by the Park Association of New York City.
WASHINGTON, June 18-- Some of the most nimble minds in the diplomatic corps were at work today on a Chinese puzzle concealed in the speech of Mao Tse-tung.

WASHINGTON, June 18-- President Eisenhower's civil rights bill was passed by the House of Representatives today. The vote was 286--126. It followed a bitter fight by Southerners, who received some support from the North.

BALTIMORE, June 18 (AP)-- Billy Pierce paved the way for his own pitching downfall tonight by throwing wild and walking in a run to enable the Baltimore Orioles to defeat the league-leading Chicago White Sox, 2--1.

Andy Carey and Bobby Richardson supplied Bobby Shantz with the batting wherewithal to cash in on another nifty pitching effort last night gas the Yankees opened a fourteen-game home stand by edging the Tigers, 2--1.
LONDON, June 18--Lord Inverclyde, one of the wealthiest men in Britain, died yesterday at his home, Castle Wemyss, Wemyss Bay, Scotland. He was 59 years old.
Prices of cotton futures were unchanged to 14 points off yesterday in moderate business.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 18 (AP)--An atomic test weapon suspended from a, balloon was exploded in the Nevada desert today. Several hundred scientists and observers evacuated control and observation points as a precaution against radioactive fall-out.
The proposed home-and-home track meets between the United States and Russia were cancelled yesterday when the United States Amateur Athletic Union dropped all plans for the competitions.

Odd as it may seem, William Saroyan, a prolific author, has avoided Broadway since his "Get Away Old Man" (1943). Signs indicate that the next play by the recipient of the Critics Circle award as well as the Pulitzer Prize for "The Time of Your Life" (1940) will be "The Cave Dwellers."

The Lower East Side Neighborhoods Association has announced its third season of summer concerts in the East River Park Amphitheatre. An orchestra under the direction of Julius Grossman will play beginning Tuesday, July 2.

Kanchenjunga in the Himalayas is the third highest mountain in the world, surpassed only by Mount Everest and K2.

PARIS, June 18--The Arabs have always respected policy with teeth in it--even when the teeth were false. This was so in the imperial days of Turkey and Britain. It was true during the apogee of Soviet prestige last November. And it is again true now as American influence shows signs of recovering.

Euclid Hall, a seven-story apartment building at 2341 to 2349 Broadway, the blockfront from Eighty-fifth to Eightysixth Streets, has been purchased by the Wauregan Realty Corporation, David Robey, president. It contains 359 rooms and was sold by Euclid Hall, Inc., Philip Edwards, president. Irving Steinlauf was the broker in the sale. The property is assessed at $1,265,000.

Edmond FitzGerald, chief probation officer of the Kings County Court, was appointed yesterday to the State Parole Board.

Patrice Munsel, Metropolitan Opera soprano, will be the star of a musical variety program to be televised by the American broadcasting Company on Fridays from 8:30 to 9 P.M., beginning Oct. 18.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 --The Columbia Broadcasting System has begun construction of new television facilities at its Hollywood Television City. The plant additions will include two new studios, seven rehearsal halls, production service structures and a new administration building.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 18-- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-fourth annual match-play championship found all the top favorites advancing as the first round was completed today. Competition was over the 6,552-yard, par-74 Glen Head course.

VERMONT recently added three weeks to its general trout fishing season and three weeks on top of that for fly fishing only. New Hampshire a year ago added almost two months of fly fishing only, and has found it working out fine.

ONLY forty miles from Edinburgh on the north bank of the River Tweed, which divides Scotland from England, there is a crossroad village with one kirk, one pub and one combined post office and general store. The pub, called facetiously The House of sin, was opened sixteen years before the Mayflower set sail.

LONDON, June 18 (AP)--Mike Green of Miami, and Myron Franks of Los Angeles, junior members of the United States 1956 Davis Cup team, turned back Belgium's two top players today in gaining the third round of the Queen's Club tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, June 18-- Three ranking United States military officials warned today of the great military power of the Soviet Union and its continued threat to the United States.

Wool prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The decline was termed a reaction to the recent strength in the market. Lower prices in London and a slightly easier tone in Australia also influenced trading.

Stockholders of Philip Morris, Inc., at a special meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va., approved a plan to acquire Milprint, Inc., flexible packaging concern.
The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company raised $70,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of debentures due in 1986 at an interest cost of 4.91 per cent.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 19 --Ted Bishop, the national amateur champion in 1946, carded a thirty-six hole total of 149 to win the twentieth annual William Rice Hochster memorial invitation tournament today.
The payment of war-risk bonuses to American merchant seamen who sail in waters previously considered politically unsettled was ended yesterday.

The Railway Express Agency is testing a new type of truck featuring an elevator-like body, or van. The new vehicle, called the Lo-Loader, can cut the street loading time of conventional commercial vehicles by as much as 75 per cent and save up to 40,000 foot pounds of manual effort...

J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., voted yesterday to pay its 1,800 shareholders a 16 2/3 per cent stock dividend. This will be the third stock dividend voted by directors since 1940, when the bank was incorporated as a successor to the partnership of the old private banking house of J.P. Morgan Co.

A young miss on Park Avenue has developed a new system for airmailing. She just tosses her letters out the window. And answers have returned from a distance and with dispatch. The innovator, Janet Capron, who is 9 years old, perfected her system last April 24.

Dr. Isidor Fankuchen, Professor of Applied Physics in the Graduate School of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, believes that "a bright and determined kid can learn anything." A few days ago he set out to prove it.

NAZARETH, Israel, June 12 --In the spring of 1949, when a tenuous peace had settled over Israel, 145,000 Arabs suddenly became citizens of a new, state made up largely of Jews.

MOSCOW, June 18 -- Soviet scientists said today that they would launch from somewhere in the Soviet Union before the end of 1958 the first of a series of artificial earth satellites. It will be of some undisclosed size and will circle the earth at some undisclosed altitude.

Johnny Dio was back in jail yesterday. Dio, a labor racketeer, and two other labor Figures under indictment on conspiracy and bribery charges, were remanded to the Tombs (Manhattan City Prison) by General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen.

Sales of the Glidden Company for the nine months ended May 31 increased to $168,460,132 from the $166,358,909 a year earlier. Earnings, however, were slightly lower, largely because of a relocation program of the food division and accelerated depreciation and amortization costs.
SYRACUSE, June 19--Arthur Levitt, State Controller, declared today that proposals to abolish his office were "violently incompatible" with, the sound administration of state government.

ATHENS, June 19--Archbishop Makarios appealed today for "a full independent inquiry" into methods used by British security forces on Cyprus. He charged that the British had employed torture and brutality to suppress the move to join Greece.

Borough President John Cashmore and Supreme Court Justice Louis L. Friedman argued heatedly yesterday about who could park in an enclosed area between the Municipal and Supreme Court Buildings in Brooklyn.

Switching of major advertising accounts continued yesterday.

Mayor Wagner reiterated yesterday his support of the controversial measure barring discrimination in private apartment housing. But he conceded that his early unqualified endorsement might have been too sweeping.

The Cerro de Pasco Corporation will acquire the LewinMathes Company of St. Louis, Mo. for 303,905 common shares of Cerro de Pasco.

SALEM, Mass., June 19-- Grace Protestant Episcopal Church was tie scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Sallie E. Bourne to Carter Henry Harrison. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John M. Gessell.

The General Electric Company will continue to fix minimum store prices on its small home appliances and radios despite recent legal setbacks. A.G.E. official said yesterday that the company was committed without reservation or qualification to "fair trade."

Cocoa prices were sharply higher yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trade buying, short covering and manufacturer purchasing for price fixing firmed prices early in the session.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 20 (UP)--A new Soviet cruiser and two destroyers steamed through the Turkish Straits toward the eastern Mediterranean today in a "show the Red Flag' maneuver.

BERLIN, June 20--The twoday visit of Polish Communist leaders to East Berlin ended tonight with the signing of a joint declaration of friendship, solidarity and cooperation between Poland and East Germany.

LONDON, June 20--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan' canvassed with top Government officials today the subjects that will be covered at the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference, which opens here next week.
Dr. Alan Gregg, who retired a year ago as vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, died Wednesday night at his home in Big Sur, Calif. He was 66 years old.
The automobile insurance industry has put higher liability rates into effect in Connecticut, virtually defying the State insurance commissioner.
GENEVA, June 20--The International Labor Organization killed today a move for a permanent inspection system to police the projected world ban on forced labor.
AFTER, twenty years in the beauty business, Thelma Holland is switching from faces to "figgers."
WASHINGTON, June 20--The Federal Court of Appeals refused today to order a postponement of the trial of James R. Hoffa, vice president of the teamsters' union.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 20-- The Ceylonese Government has decided to use Trincomalee harbor, about 150 miles from Colombo, for commercial shipping. At present a naval base operated by Britain, Trincomalee will be turned over to Ceylon on Oct. 15.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 20--The chairman of the legislative committee of the New York State Bankers Association warned today that public interest may lapse before full-scale revision of the State's banking laws is completed.

There will be free chamber music concerts in Washington Square again this summer. For the fifth year they will be presented by the Washington Square Association and this summer the association is taking no chances with the weather.
The Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries, showed a drop in earnings for the nine months ended May 31, reflecting a lower volume of sales from the similar period a year ago.

Lagides of the Lacy F. Ranch liked the distance in the main race at Belmont Park yesterday. Competing in a mile and a furlong test for fillies and mares, the French-bred Lagides won by more than three lengths from the favorite, Christopher Chenery's Next Day. Morty Freedman's Gay Life was third.
The International Finances Corporation is in business at last.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20--A United Nations committee of inquiry has made a sweeping indictment of the Soviet Union for crushing the Hungarian uprising last fall and destroying the legal revolutionary Government of Premier Imre Nagy.
FARGO, N D., June 20--A tornado smashed through a residential area here tonight, killing eight persons, three of them children, and injuring at least seventy-five.

IN the spring of the year 1590 young James VI of Scotland was in Denmark waiting for the winter storms to subside so that he could return safely home with his Danish bride. A Privy Council ruled in his stead in Edinburgh and to that council came disturbing rumors about strange doings in the little town of North Berwick in East Lothian.

A strike of service workers in seventy-nine of the city's 114 private nursing homes was called last night by Local 144 of the Building Service Employes International Union. The walk out was set for 7 o'clock this morning.

MILWAUKEE, June 20--The Giants and the Braves struggled for nearby three and a half hours at County Stadium today, but Bill Rigney's, assorted athletes finally won the game in the twelfth innng, 4-3. This results displeased most of the ladies' day crowd of 28,737.

ALBANY, June 20--There is sufficient demand for air passenger travel in eastern Long Island to warrant development of MacArthur Airport in Suffolk County as an interstate center, the state Commerce Department reported today.

CINCINNATI, June 20--The Redlegs' offensive power, bottled up for almost two weeks until last night, was still erupting tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 20--The House Appropriations Committee voted today to allow the Post Office Department $133,000,000 of the $149,500,000 in extra funds urged by President Eisenhower to ward off serious cuts in service.

PARIS, June 20--Habib Bourguiba, Premier of Tunisia, urged today the creation of "a FrenchNorth African community" in which Algeria would acquire an independent status like that an Tunisia and Morocco.

The volume of commercial and sales finance paper outstanding in the nation increased 10 per cent during May, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The partnership of the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company and Indonesia has proven "surprisingly good" in the past but is threatened by continued postponement of new exploration and development rights, according to a report by the National Planning Association.

THE Park Department's spray battalions have been working dawn through dusk the last few weeks trying to decimate the millions of tussock moth caterpillars you may have seen undulating in hairy yellow tweeds on foliage in city streets and parks.

WASHINGTON, June 20--A labor leader testified today that he had repaid $40,000 borrowed from management interests to avoid any possible "misconception" that might arise from a Senate investigation of the loan.

DESPITE the warm weather, the home cook must plan in terms of varied and tempting meals for her family. This week, the attractive prices on a great variety of specials permit her a wide range of selections for week-end menus and the Sunday roast.

On the day before the holding of mass demonstrations, namely 22 October, a number of student meetings took place in Budapest. At the most important of these, the students adopted a list of sixteen demands which expressed their views on national policy.

New York will be "the world's most exciting vacation city" for the next three months, Mayor Wagner said yesterday. He offered a "friendly invitation to people everywhere," including New Yorkers, toy sample the city's vacations delights.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UP) --Taking note of the criticism in Congress, Mr. Roach said the projects were "fully qualified" for the write-off privilege.
BALTIMORE, June 20 (UP)-- The Baltimore Orioles pounded Bill Fischer, a rookie, for four runs in the first two innings today and made them stand up for a 4-1 triumph over the Chicago White Sox.
WASHINGTON, June 20-- Wheat farmers voted heavily today in favor of continuing Federal controls on production for another Year.

A former member of the Communist party cell at City College testified yesterday that Dr. Warren B. Austin had been a member of the party unit from 1939 to January, 1942. Dr. Austin, who was assistant professor of English, was suspended May 21.
Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges.

For the first time in eight years, Ed Sullivan's television show is about to undergo a change in sponsorship. Probably effective next fall, Lincoln automobiles no longer will be a sponsor, although Mercury automobile dealers will continue their association with the variety program.
WASHINGTON, June 20--The Senate by-passed tonight an old obstruction to civil rights legislation--the Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 20-- The Italian Government will deliver its second protest in three weeks Tomorrow on a sudden change in buying policy by the Bonneville Power Administration. The change virtually excludes purchases of foreign generators.
Two European-made General Motors automobiles ate to be sold in this country for the first time.

LONDON, June 20--Britain characterized the report of they United Nations Special Committee on Hungary today as a "record of a small nation's courageous and tragic attempt to regain its freedom."

Business borrowings rose sharply in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Loans to business by the major New York City banks climbed $527,000,000, the largest weekly increase on record.

S. Jay Kaufman, who had conducted a Broadway column, "Round the Town," for a quarter century, died yesterday morning in Abraham Jacobi Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. His age was 71.

Morris Karp and Bernard Sanford, realty operators, have purchased the six-story apartment house at 2241 Holland Avenue, the Bronx. The seller was the Furlang Construction Corporation, which erected the building in 1948.

TROUT fishermen have been doing much better recent ly than they did in the 1956 mid-season. There is good reason to believe that they will be as satisfied this weekend as trout fishermen ever permit themselves to be.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., June 20 --Paul Tishman General Contractor, Inc., of New York has received a contract to build a fifteen-story naval hospital here. The concern bid $14,318,808 for the project. Its bid was the lowest of six submitted to the Fifth Naval District public works office.
ALBERTSON, L.I., June 20-- Bernard M. Baruch, asserting that "people are America's most valuable asset," urged here today that disabled persons be more fully utilized in industry.

A Bronx clothing store proprietor who was knocked unconscious in a $15 robbery last Friday night supplied the bail fee yesterday for a youth he had identified as one of his assailants.

OMAHA, June 21 (AP)-The refusal of the United States to recognize Communist China was described tonight as "inconsistent" by the Rev. Dr. Carl E. Lund-Quist of Geneva, Switzerland, executive secretary of the Lutheran World Federation.

CHICAGO, June 21-Farmers yesterday voted to back up Government policies on wheat quotas next year. The referendum showed a big majority for retaining comparatively high supports.
Bernard Klonis, water-colorist and an instructor in art here, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after several months' illness. His age was 51.
PARIS, June 21--Claude Farrere, French novelist of the sea and its more exotic shores and a member of the French Academy, died today in a Paris hospital. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate voted, 45 to 38, today to authorize a Federal dam at Hells Canyon, symbol of the fight over public versus private power.
LONDON, June 21-Stock market trading was subdued to day by yesterdays reaction of Wall Street. Apart from the industrials, which advanced slightly, most sections drifted lower.
The Newsweek Building, a fifteen-story store and office structure at the southeast corner of Forty-second Street and Broadway, has been sold by Vincent Astor.

After some days of uncertainty King Faisal of Iraq has accepted the resignation of Premier Nuri as-Said, the country's pro-Western strong man, and has named Ali Jawdat, a pro-Western moderate, as his successor.

LEEDS, England, June 21 (AP) -Peter Thomson of Australia crushed an international field with record-breaking golf today and won the 72-hole Yorkshire Evening News professional tournament by fifteen strokes. His four-round total was 264.

OTTAWA, June 21-Canada's first woman cabinet minister, appointed today, has wavy white hair, the figure of a girl of 18, and a bubbling sense of fun that erupts in her sparkling brown eyes and humorous mouth.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, began an item-by-item onslaught today against the Administration's economic record. His target was George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, who had defended the program Tuesday.

No one can blame the occupants of 233 Butler Street, Brooklyn, if they are dismayed at being adopted. Almost any home, however sweet, will suffer by comparison with the new building opened at the Butler Street address yesterday morning.

LONDON, June 22--Britain refused today to relax her quarantine regulations to admit the guide dog of a blind American Fulbright scholar.

Children of seamen of the Seafarers International Union apparently do not match their fathers in the pursuit of a free college education. For the second consecutive year the active Seafarers have won four of five union-sponsored scholarships.
