Shareholders of the First National City Bank of New York yesterday approved at a special meeting the banks proposed offering of 2,000,000 shares to holders at $60 each.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 24 --The Supreme Court was publicly rebuked today by the head of the National Associatian of Attorneys General.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture recommended today that a fixed minimum price support level on upland cotton be eliminated. The proposal drew fire from two Democratic Senators, Allen J. Ellender of Louisiana and Stuart Symington of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)-- Occasional clashes between Senators Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, and Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, enlivened a Senate subcommittee hearing today on antifilibuster proposals.

Clem MCCarthy, the turf writer and announcer who has been champing on the bit to get out of Mount Sinai Hospital, got another lift toward complete recovery yesterday when his namesake, Clem, won the eightysecond running of the Withers Stakes at Belmont Park.
DETROIT, June 24 (AP)--Automobile makers are further tightening production. Instead of the scheduled 515,000 car assemblies this monthy, they will have difficulty reaching 500,000.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 24--President Eisenhower proposed tonight a Federal-state task force to reallocate the functions and revenues of the two levels of government.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- Walter H. Bowes, a founder of Pitney-Bowes, Inc., of Stamford, Conn., makers of postage meters, died at Emergency Hospital here today. His age was 75.

Neither a drizzle at 6:30 P. M. nor an overcast sky thereafter could stay Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer from letting the Lewisohn Stadium concert start last night. But there was nothing that the indomitable chairman of Stadium Concerts, Inc., could do to get the program past the opening number.

For the Guajira Indians of Colombia, going to the seashore means a chance to earn a little extra money. They do it with an annual salt harvest near Manaure on the north coast. Here the evaporation of sea water by the tropical sun jeaves new salt beds each year.

In his book "Working for the People" Robert Moses spoke of a new face in our midst, that of the pejorist, a comparative fellow who thought that the age of opportunity was over, that all frontiers had been conquered.
WASHINGTON, June 24--Israel's Minister of Finance outlined to Secretary of State Dulles today Israel's special needs for economic assistance to meet the problems of a new wave of immigration.

The spread of some businesses into outlying districts need not doom the downtown areas of the big cities, operators of commercial structures were told yesterday. They were urged to look upon the trend as an opportunity for constructive planning.

PORT-AU PRINCE, Haiti, June 24--Dr. Francois Duvalier, one of the three principal candidates for the Presidency of Haiti, asked today for the earliest possible Presidential elections. He recommended late July, but said early August should be the latest.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 24-A nuclear explosion that surprised scientists with its force was detonated this morning at the Atomic Energy Commission's desert proving ground near here.
WASHINGTON, June 24--According to James C. Hagerty, who should know, President Eisenhower thinks the Commission on Government Security has turned in a "good report."
WIMBLEDON, England, June 24--Out of the All-England ten nis championships tonight went America's No. 1 player, Hamilton Richardson.
TORONTO, June 24--Studies that establish a relationship between personality and a crippling disorder known as rheumatold arthritis were reported here today.
Patricia Jessel, winner of last year's Antoinette Perry Award for her portrayal of the enigmatic wife in "Witness for the Prosecution," has been signed for a starring role in "The French Death."

WASHINGTON, June 25-- John Cye Cheasty, the Government's star witness in the bribery-conspiracy trial of James R. Hoffa, testified today that Mr. Hoffa had told him he had two lines of information from the Senate rackets committee and wanted "triple coverage."

MOSCOW, June 25--The Soviet Union issued a series of statements today depicting the United States as an "aggressor" in Europe and the Far East and accusing it of bad faith at the London disarmament negotiations.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- A faulty electrical starting circuit on the Presidential plane, Columbine III, forced President Eisenhower to use another plane today.
MILWAUKEE, June 25-- Danny McDevitt, a 24-year-old southpaw who popped out of St. Paul less than two weeks ago to shore up the Dodger pitching staff, turned in another masterful job tonight.

KERBY FARRELL already is beginning to regret that he didn't study medical tomes or that he didn't at least pay attention to the first aid courses during his Boy Scout days. Such knowledge would be invaluable in his present capacity as manager of the Cleveland Indians.
CINCINNATI, June 25--A pinch single by Ted Kluszevdski With the bases filled and two out in the ninth inning tonight gave the Redlegs a 3-2 victory over the Giants at Crosley Field.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., June 25--This is a tale of two dogs, air freight and a case of mistaken identity. One dog's story has a happy ending--the other is to be continued.
DETROIT, June 25--A top leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People proposed today new emphasis for the association's programs.
The former commander of United States Naval Forces in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean has been named president of the Flight Safety Foundation Inc.

Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Conlon denied yesterday a motion by Ticket Clubs of New Jersey, Inc., to enjoin, enforcement of a New York City regulation forbidding theatres from selling more than ten tickets to an unlicensed broker.
THE Philippine Hut, 119 West Forty-seventh Street, is an exotic new addition to the list of city restaurants specializing in foreign cuisines.

James D. Norris Jr., though faced with the task of dissolving the International Boxing Clubs of New York and Illinois, continued to negotiate yesterday for a Sugar Ray Robinson-Carmen Basilio middleweight title fight.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 25-- Miss Julie Hattersley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hattersley of Cedar Swamp Road, was married this afternoon to John Downey Soutter in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown at Locust Valley. The Rev. Howard...

LAST September the 125-year-old red brick house at 11 Bank Street, just off Waverly Place, in Greenwich Village, came into the hands of Dr. Harvey Slatin, an engineer, and his wife, Yeffe Kimball, of Osage Indian descent, who is known for her paintings.
Gordon L. McDonough, a Representative from Los Angeles, recently read into the Congressional Record some words of high praise for "a young man...
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that the State Department had blocked her in an effort to make a newsgathering journey to Communist China.
SEOUL, Korea, June 25--President Syngman Rhee advocated today that an economic blockade be raised against the Communist world as a means of achieving justice and freedom.
Net income of the New York Central Railroad in May dropped 73 per cent to $1,084,570 from $4,008,530 in the similar month last year. The decline for the first five months was 48.6 per cent.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., June 25 --Sixty-four city boys rose early this morning for the first full day of two weeks of activities at the Princeton summer camp, opening its forty-fourth season. They are guests of Princeton University undergraduates.
WASHINGTON, June 25--The Secretary of the Treasury and a Democratic Senator concluded today a seven-hour battle of statistics with neither side conceding defeat.
Commuters on the New Haven and the New York Central Railroads, still grumbling about their late dinners on Monday, countered frustrating delays again yesterday.
THERE'S nothing dangerous about a little knowledge when you're shopping for carpeting.

IF there is any one thing that a strong, hardy outdoors man likes more than another it is to catch a fish on some unusual makeshift tackle. Let a man use a ping-pong ball for a float and catch a fish that way and he becomes insuffer= able.
CLEVELAND, June 25--A new Protestant denomination-- the United Church of Christ-- came into existence here tonight.
HONK KONG, Wednesday, June 26--New security regulations for Communist China were announced last night as delegates were gathering for the annual National People's Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 25--A plan will be drawn up immediately for best use of medical manpower should there be an epidemic in this country through spread of Far East influenza.
LONDON, June 25 (UP)--The International Whaling Commission began discussions today on the catch quota for whales during the 1857-58 summer season in the Antarctic.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 25--The accused in the court-martial at Redstone Arsenal, the Army's top-secret missile center near here, is a 41-year-old professional soldier.
New York City has borrowed $18,000,000 on tax anticipation notes maturing at various times until June 26, 1958. The notes bear interest of 3 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 --Acquisition of screen rights to "Devil at My Heels," the autobiography of Louis Zamperini, evangelist and former track star, was confirmed today by Universal-International.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- Secretary of State Dulles, happy over the results of the visit of Premier Kishi, said today that the United States and Japan had entered a new "cooperative" relationship.

Immediate reconvening of the General Assembly of the United Nations is now in order to consider the scathing report that has just been issued by its special committee of inquiry into Soviet Russia's savage suppression of the Hungarian revolt.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 25 --Col. John C. Nickerson Jr. pleaded guilty today to violating Army security regulations by failing to safeguard secret missile information and leaking it to unauthorized persons.
GENEVA, June 25--The International Labor Organization gave preliminary approval today to a draft treaty to wipe out job discrimination on a worldwide basis.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 25--Willie Turnesa, a former United States and British amateur golf champion, teamed with Fred Fiore of Knollwood to win the British Victory Tournament today. With a best-ball score of...
Two new films open at firstrun theatres today. "Saint Joan," Otto Preminger's version of the George Bernard Shaw play, arrives at the Victoria...
Oscar Schindler, a former German national who manufactured munitions for Hitler, has been feted here for the last ten days by Jewish refugees who were persecuted by the Nazis.
Great Lakes dock workers will be the target of an organization drive to begin at the convention next month of the International Brotherhood of Longshoremen.

TRENTON, June 25--Warren N. Gaffney was informed as early as August, 1954, that John R. Cooney had allegedly perpetrated a fraud against New Jersey as well as the insurance concern he headed, but Mr. Gaffney did nothing about it, a witness said Today.
NEWPORT, June 25--A flight down wind that surprised even those aboard gave Harrier, a 41-foot German-built sloop designed and sailed by C. Raymond Hunt of Marblehead, Mass., a big victory today.
The stock market continued yesterday the rally that began late Monday.
WASHINGTON, June 25--Following is the State Department's record of the news conference held today by Secretary of State Dulles:
The city has been urged to speed the handling of charges against adolescents. The recommendation was made by the Juvenile Delinquency. Evaluation Project, established by the city in January, 1956.
Mayor Wagner discovered that last year's drive for noise abatement made the city noticeably quieter and, in a three-month period, reduced auto horn-blowing by an estimated 75 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) --Representative Patrick J. Hillings, Republican of California, said tonight that he was convinced, on the basis of talks with officials of the Dodgers and the Giants, that the two...

ON Oct. 18, 1793, a brave woman with prematurely white hair was guillotined in Paris. The revolutionary mobs who cheered her death called her "the widow Capet" and "the Austrian woman." Her pitiful...
TORONTO, June 25--One of the major tasks of modern medicine is to resell certain patients on the value of aspirin. This was emphasized today at the Ninth International Congress on Rheumatic Diseases.

Mickey Mantle announced yesterday the formation of a team to fight Hodgkin's disease. His father died of the disease in 1952. It is characterized by the enlargement of the lymphatic glands and progressive anemia.
They put the "Old Woman" up for auction yesterday.
Six hundred members of the American Public Power Association arrived yesterday for their annual convention and immediately encountered a power shortage.

In an effort to punch another hole through the Iron Curtain the United States Government has proposed to the Soviets an agreement in principle for a regular exchange of uncensored radio and television programs to be broadcast across their respective countries.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 25--President Eisenhower's proposal that the states assume greater responsibility for meeting governmental problems and costs received a qualified acceptance today from most of the nation's Governors.
The Department of Investigation has inquired into fifty-nine citizens' complaints against the Department of Buildings since 1955.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 25--Althea Gibson, the girl picked to carry on the twentyyear tradition of American supremacy here, is still in the allEngland tennis championships-- just barely.

Once upon a time four wideeyed ex-convicts heard a tale about a little old lady street entertainer who was supposed to have thirty-five one-gallon pickle jars in her apartment on the Lower East Side. And every jar, so the story went, was filled with money.
VIENNA, June 25--President Tito of Yugoslavia warned the Soviet Union today that friendly words were no guarantee of good relations when accompanied by malicious and underhanded deeds.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, June 26--The Communists proposed today a new international conference on the Korean problem and demanded that the United Nations Command give up at once its plan to introduce modern weapons into South Korea.
A passenger tire with a built-in balance, said to produce a vibration-less ride even at high speed, was introduced yesterday by the Fisk tires division of the United States Rubber Company.
The City Council's majority leader, Joseph T. Sharkey, yesterday predicted speedy action on a bill by the Wagner administration to bar discrimination in private apartment housing.
GREAT NECK, L. I., June 25 --In a thrilling and exciting finish, Long Island won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association intersectional team matches today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 23--A mass recruiting campaign is under way in Bulgaria to enlist thousands of young people between the ages of 18 and 30 to work as "brigadiers" in the virgin lands of the Soviet Union.

An envious position to be in is to have retailers help pay for your advertising. The Celanese Corporation of America partially has attained this pleasant state with advertising for Arnel, triacetate fiber for apparel.
Only when cars can be made to dodge people--instead vice versa--can true urban planning be achieved, an architect and city planner said yesterday.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 25--Premier David Ben-Gurion said today that financial and spiritual support of Israel by Jews in other countries, carried no "political" connotations.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) --Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. accepted today a 19,646,427 bid submitted by the Duetsche Bank of Frankfurt, Germany, for the United States Government's 53 per cent interest in the Hugo Stinnes Corporation of New York.

The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham spoke confidently yesterday of attaining his objectives in "the greatest evangelistic effort in the history of the church." His crusade in New York is swinging into its final foul weeks at Madison Square Garden and on national television.
SOMETHING advertised as "Rosalie" opened last night in Central Park. Seldom has so much been squandered by so many to such little purpose.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) --The Detroit Tigers scored three runs in the tenth inning tonight to defeat the Washington Senators, 7--4. Harry Byrd, from the minors twenty-four hours ago, received credit for the victory.
The great coalition formed by the United States, Great Britain and Soviet Russia to combat the Axis in World War II is the subject of a book by Herbert Feis.
WASHINGTON, June 25--The Administration moved today to tighten control over farmers next year in an effort to make the soil bank more effective and prevent a build-up of new surpluses.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- Bob Feller told a House investigating panel, today that "baseball is a business" and that there could be places for antitrust controls.

It appeared yesterday that an opinion of the Appellate Division of the States Supreme Court in Brooklyn Monday had not ended the eighteen months of litigation centering on the Rev. William Howard Melish.

WASHINGTON, June 25--A seemingly guarded endorsement by President Eisenhower of the pending compromise school construction bill was made public today by the chief sponsor in the House of Representatives of the Administration's program.
LONDON, June 25--Economic problems have emerged as the principal topic to be discussed at the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference that opens here tomorrow.
LONDON, June 25--The United States today firmly tied its proposals for a reduction in the armed forces of the great powers to a reunification of Germany that would satisfy West Germany.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) --A Senate subcommittee refused today to speed consideration of the controversial Bricker amendment. This appeared to scuttle the measure's chances for Senate consideration in 1957.
MIAMI BEACH, June 25-- Changes in religious practice, including a break with tradition in regard to holy days, were proposed tonight by a leading Reform rabbi.

Cotton futures declined 3 to 15 points (15 to 75 cents a bale) here yesterday, except_old July, which rose 15 points on trade covering and lack of offerings by spot firms that are required to be the major holders of this contract.
The City Council's Committee on Ethics announced plans yesterday to hold public hearings on what should be written into the forthcoming Code of Ethics for Councilmen.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP)-- Wheat futures faltered a bit on the Board of Trade today an then continued their rally on the strength of good export demand

Because of the sustained hot weather and the prospect of recurring high temperatures in the summer weeks ahead Commissioner Ford of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity has found it necessary to appeal to New Yorkers to use...
LONDON, June 24--Teaching for a year in London has proved a gratifying experience for two United States teachers who came here under the Fulbright Exchange Program.

OXFORD, England, June 25-- England's great universities seek admirably to link abstract intellectualism and the problems of practical life. An example of this is the conference now taking place at St. Antony's College, Oxford, on "Changes in Soviet Society."
The first seeded player was eliminated from the New York state clay court tennis championship yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside Queens.
John B. Dickson, retired technical analyst for the textile division of the United States Rubber Company here, died on Monday in the Medical Arts Center after a brief illness. His age was 67.

RANGOON, Burma, June 25-- The failure of the Chinese Communist Government to complete an agreement with Burma over boundary areas in dispute between them is causing concern among Burmese officials here.
LONDON, June 25--Losses outnumbered gains on the stock market today.

If the Yankees felt that the recent spurt that carried them to the top of the American League standing ended their pennant worries, they were rudely disillusioned last night. Obviously, there's still work to be done.

Outer Space had little trouble enveloping her opposition yesterday. Opposing five other fillies her own age, the 3-year-old daughter of Saggy won the mile and a sixteenth feature race at Belmont Park by three lengths. Wana was second and Untamed was third.

PARIS, June 25--Armed with the National Assembly's approval of its financial plan, the Government will now try to check France's dangerously growing debt to the outside world. This debt results from a persistent adverse trade balance.

Puget Sound Power and Lights Company yesterday borrowed $20,000,000 on thirty-year first mortgage 6 per cent bonds-- the highest coupon rate on a long-term electric utility obligation in more than twenty years.
WOMEN are the best policy. There are statistics to prove it, one insurance company says.
Japanese Premier Nobusuke Kishi said here last night that long-term, low-interest loans from abroad were "imperative needs in keeping Japan economically afloat." He also asked...
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 25 --Thurman Arnold entered a defense of the Supreme Court today before the National Association of Attorneys General.

WASHINGTON, June 25-- Secretary of State Dulles coupled today United States consent to a suspension of nuclear Weapons tests with a simultaneous agreement on ending the production of nuclear materials for military purposes.

Cocoa futures rose sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Seven notices were issued and they were well received. Final prices were 48 to 82 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) ups on 429 lots.
Contract negotiations were under way yesterday between twenty-three employer groups and eighteen unions in New York's construction industry.

President Eisenhower in his address to the state Governors at Williamsburg dealt thoughtfully and forcefully with one of the major political trends of our time, the temptation to transfer the problems of states and cities to Washington for solution.

The New York Giants, the champions of the National Football League, will open the defense of their Eastern Conference crown Sunday, Sept. 29 against the Browns, at Cleve land. This will be one of the six games slated for the opening day of the N. F. L.'s thirty-eighth season.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 25-- Former Premier Fadhil al-Jamali is pressing to revive political party activities in Iraq.
MILWAUKEE June 25--Vice President Richard M. Nixon urged members of the Junior Chamber of Commerce today to win support for the President's foreign aid program "enthusiastically, not grudgingly."
General Motors has commissioned thb National Broadcasting Company to produce a twohour musical telecast to mark the automotive concern's fiftieth anniversary.

CHICAGO, June 25--Montgomery Ward Co. today announced it would buy for about $7,500,000 the Fair, seventyseven-year-old department store in the heart of the Loop. The transaction marks Ward's debut in downtown Chicago.

ALGIERS, Algeria, June 25-- Right-wing vigilantism is increasing among the European population of Algiers. One of its manifestations is the newly created Dispositif de Protection Urbaine (Organization for Urban Security).

WASHINGTON, June 25--The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration of securities the company sold more than a year ago to keep its magazines alive and expand into other communications activities.
FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 25 --American Jewish Orthodox communities were urged today to spend an additional $25,000,000 next year to strengthen Jewish education.
Johnny Dio received five and a half hours of freedom yesterday--in the custody of his attorney.
Nearly 70 per cent of the 1,500,000 square feet of office space for the new forty-seven story Time and Life Building has been rented.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., June 25--Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Sheila MacNeille to Peter Paul Nitze. The ceremony was...

An investment banking syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and the Dominion Securities Corporation is offering for public subscription here $39,372,000 of debentures of Metropolitan Toronto.

Wheat farmers in thirty-six states "went to the polls" last week for the fifth year in succession to vote on the question of accepting or rejecting "marketing quotas" on that grain in the coming crop year.

GASTONIA, N. C., June 25-- Robert Gregg Cherry, who served as North Carolina's Governor from 1945 to 1949 and was a leading political figure in the state for a quarter of a century, died in Gaston Memorial Hospital this morning after a twenty-day illness, He was 65 years old.
The creation by the City Housing Authority of an exempt position of assistant to the vice chairman was opposed by spokesmen of seven organizations at a hearing yesterday.
Ten thousand youngsters received diplomats yesterday when thirty-four of the city's eightyfive academic and vocational high schools held commencement exercises. Nine already had been...
WASHINGTON, June 25--Consumer prices reached a high in May for the ninth month in a row. Rising food prices, normal at this season, were a major factor.
YONKERS, June 25 (UP)-- Frisco Flyer, owned by Paul Wixom of Chicago, and driven by John Simpson, finished fast to win tonight's Brentwood Pace before 18,610 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

STADIUM CONCERTS presented its first full program of the season last night at Lewisohn Stadium. The three numbers were those that would have been played on Monday night if the heavens hadn't opened during Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker" Suite.
An employe stockholder plan was announced yesterday in the copper mining belt of Northern Rhodesia, deep in the heart of Africa.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 26--The Federal Cabinet decided today to grant the United States additional air traffic rights in return for a grant of transit rights across the United States to the Qantas empire Airway.

WASHINGTON, June 26--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended June 19:
MANY past eras are allowed to lie in obscurity's limbo, but the Civil War years and the Nineteen Twenties we have always with us. This morning it is the turn of the Twenties to take the stage again.
PURCHASE, N.Y., June 26-- Two-thirds of the nations' private colleges and universities are operating at a deficit, a meeting of college and business officials was told tonight.
Edith Hamilton, the American author who will celebrate her ninetieth birthday in August, will sail July 9 for Athens, where she Will be a guest of the Greek Government during the Delphic Festival.

THIS is no time of year for yawning in the awning business. George Hopp, head of the Bronx Window Shade and Awning Company, has been rushing around town since May 1 installing these sunshades and he doesn't expect to get a breather until July 15.
MOSCOW, June 26--A Soviet scientist predicted today that this nation would send the first radio guided reconnaisance rocket to the moon in the early Nineteen Sixties.
Futures prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was dull and featureless in most markets.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 26--"A Midsummer Night's Dream" and the dream of supporters here, became realities tonight.
Ninety music teachers from over the country began work yesterday at a three-day Conference on the Teaching of Piano at Teachers College, Columbia University.
WARSAW, June 26--The fierce intraparty strife among Poland's Communists erupted again today at a conference of the party's Warsaw committee.

TOKYO, June 26--The United States Army moved today to halt unauthorized target practice by soldiers near a school and a Shinto shrine at Otsu, a small city north of Osaka. The Japanese had protested against the firing.
PARIS, June, 26--Further steps were taken today to restore France's finances and to prepare the country for a farreaching experiment in economic integration, the Western European Common Market.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 26 (UP)--Beau Fond, a 4-year-old gelding, plowed through the mud at Monmouth Park today to register a length victory in the $16,700 Long Branch Handicap. A crowd of 15,810 saw the program.

HONG KONG, June 26 (AP)-- Mr. Chou, in his speech today, warned members of China's nonCommunist parties that they would be excluded from the present "united front" if criticism of the regime became excessive.
After considerable discussion on how to encourage young golfers to compete in the metropolitan junior championship, several practical suggestions have been put into effect this season.

WHEN George V. McLaughlin held a firm grip on the purse strings of the practically bankrupt Brooklyn Dodg ers some twenty-odd years ago, he was known to the baseball fraternity as George V or George the Fifth. Not many bankers, including Brooklyn ones, had so regal a designation.
Leading lawyers in the city are urging that "this year of Mayoralty election is the time to give help to the Mayor, not merely to select him."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 26--The first Saul Lantzis Memorial member-guest golf tournament held at the Fenway Golf Club got off to a poor start today when it was held up because of several thunder storms.

WASHINGTON, June 26-- President Eisenhower called on the nation today to respect the Supreme Court even though among its recent decisions were "some that each of us has very great trouble understanding."
Two outdoor entertainments, both operating with governmental sanction, open tonight for the summer season.

The Electric Bond and Share Company's net assets were at a record high of $178,956,844, equal to $34.09 a share, on June 14, George G. Walker, president, told 150 stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday at company headquarters here.
Hudson R. Searing, chairman of the board and former president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., died last night in University Hospital after a brief illness. He was 62 years old.

A New York Central train was derailed here yesterday and ripped up two northbound tracks. As a result, 57,000 Westchester and Connecticut commuters endured fretful delays of an hour and more on their way home last night.

WHETHER last night's revival of "The Country Wife" at the Renata Theatre in Greenwich Village is the most audible on record is obviously impossible to say. Nor is it possible to report unequivocally that it is the most energetic.
PRESIDENT EISENHOWER--Good morning, please sit down. I have no announcements.
A 31-year-old New York policeman was indicted yesterday on charges of grand larceny and illegally removing records from the Police Department.

WASHINGTON, June 26-- President Eisenhower indicated today that he had had some second thoughts about the wisdom of ending nuclear bomb tests, but he said he was going to try to negotiate a rigidly conditioned test ban anyway.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 26 --Dr. Wernher von Braun, head of the Army's team of scientists at near-by Redstone Arsenal, a highly secret rocket and missile center, today criticized the Army's security policy as too strict. He said it was so strict it actually impeded national security.
WASHINGTON, June 26--The long-expected resignation of George C. McConnaughey, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, was announced today at the White House. His term expires Sunday.
A decline of 2,092,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

The inescapable connection between disarmament and a solution of the major world problems causing international tensions which in turn cause armaments is being demonstrated anew at two widely separated points--London and Panmunjom.

WASHINGTON, June 26--Inevitably, as a result of the Supreme Court decision in the Watkins case, persons found in contempt of Congress, or threatened with it, for not answering the questions of investigating committees began today the second round of appeals to the Federal judiciary.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 26-- A Coast Guard airplane search that was a possibility tomorrow for the only yacht not accounted for in the Annapolis-to-Newport ocean race became unnecessary tonight. Richard W. Baron's 42-foot yawl Mistral from Stamford, Conn., was reported safe.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 26-- Brazil's inability to put effective brakes on inflation reportedly has led the Export-Import Bank of Washington to decide that new loans for this country's power projects would not be economically advisable now.

Today's new film is "Sweet Smell of Success," Hecht, Hill and Lancaster's version of the story by Ernest Lehman, at Loew's State. Burt Lancaster, Tony Curtis and Susan Harrison, a newcomer, are starred in the drama about the corrosive effect of power on a Broadway columnist.
Twenty-one persons were injured last night in a crash of two buses and a station wagon at a busy West Side intersection.

George D. Widener's Jester made Eddie Arcaro laugh yesterday. The 2-year-old colt won the eight-fourth running of the National Stallion Stakes, and at the same time Arcaro rode his first winner in thirty-two starts.

The sacrifice fly was a potent weapon for the Yankees yesterday. Two by Hank Bauer and another by Enos Slaughter accounted for all the home-side runs as the Bombers squared accounts with the Indians, by a 3-1 score, in a tense contest at the Stadium.

ALGIERS, Algeria. June 26-- French security forces reported today that week-end searches in the Casbah, the city's Moslem quarter, had yielded one of the largest caches of bombs and other terrorist equipment found since the start of the Algerian rebellion.

WASHINGTON, June 26--A senate Appropriations subcommittee moved today to give the Defense Department virtually all the money that President Eisenhower says is needed to preserve the country's security.

FRIDAY Escabeche stands for a method of treating fish with an acid sauce, a kind of mild pickle, that is popular throughout Latin America. A cold escabeche makes a perfect summer dish, easy to prepare and easy to eat. For it, a delicate hot souffle is the perfect introduction.
TRENTON, N.J., June 26-- Leffertz Holz, New Jersey State Superintendent of Insurance, has declined to go to New Jersey to testify before the State Law Enforcement Council.
WASHINGTON, June 26-- Following is the text of the findings of the subcommittee on Fiscal Policy of the Joint Economic Committee:
THE Wednesday night variety show starring Arthur Godfrey and his company quietly completed its engagement on Channel 2 last night.

The key prosecution witness against Johnny Dio proved so reluctant to answer questions yesterday that he was declared a hostile witness. As such he may be cross-examined by the Assistant District Attorney, who had called him as a witness.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 --A bid by Skiatron TV, Inc., for a franchise to install a closed-circuit toll television system in Los Angeles was contested yesterday by another payTV company, Telemeter Corporation, at hearings before the Board of Public Utilities and Transportation.

The tight money situation is a blessing, somewhat disguised, to the shirt and pajama manufacturers, according to Seymour J. Phillips, president of PhillipsJones Corporation, producer of Van Heusen men's furnishings.

SIX years ago this month Dr. Edward Teller provided the scientific break-through that paved the way for the first hydrogen bomb in the world. Yesterday President Eisenhower said that Dr. Teller and two other physicists had told ...
MINEOLA, L.I., June 26-- The 1,740 men of the Nassau County Police will get an average pay increase of 10 per cent, along with a forty-hour work week, starting July 1.

PARIS, June 26--A warning that disarmament efforts might end by "making war possible" was given today by Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He issued the warning in a speech to the Anglo-American Press Association.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 26--The Conference of Governors endorsed today President Eisenhower's plan for a joint Federal-state task force to reappraise the functions and revenue sources of the two levels of government.
Consumer prices, as measured by the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, reached their ninth consecutive record high in May, at 119.6 per cent of the average for the years 1947-49.
CAIRO, June 26--The Egyptian Ministry of Finance announced today that it had decided to invite a British financial mission to Cairo.
CLEVELAND, June 26--This country's newest Protestant denomination, the United Church of Christ, began life today under auspicious circumstances.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will present Edward R. Murrow's television interview with Marshal Tito on Sunday.
LONDON, June 26--The rally of industrial and oil shares was extended here today, stimulated by yesterday's recovery on Wall Street.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 26--About half of Johannesburg's Negro, Asian and Colored workers stayed at home today for a one-day protest strike against South Africa's racial segregation laws.
The nation was pictured yesterday as being on the threshold of the "Giant Power Age," but with low-cost, public-owned producing companies facing a fight for life.
SATURDAY; 11 A.M. and 3 P.M.: The final movie of the "Films for a Day in June" program will be given at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street.

MAIAMI BEACH, June 26--A warning that the wall of separation between church and state in the United States "is becoming increasingly porous" was sounded here today by a group of leading Reform Rabbis.
Sales and net income of the Fedders Quigan Corporation dipped in the fiscal quarter ended May 31 compared with the corresponding period a year earlier, but common share earn ings were unchanged.
WASHINGTON, June 26-- Frank W. Brewster, head of the eleven-state Western Conference of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was convicted today of contempt of the Senate.

A "100 per cent effective air defense system" has been predicted to a Senate committee. Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, Deputy Chief of Staff of the Army for Research and Development, was the author of this remarkable prediction.

The three-story building at 25-27-29 Eghth Avenue, corner of Jane Street, has been purchased by Max N. Hurwitz. The Greenwich Village property, on a plot 71 by 68 feet, contains stores and apartments. Mr. Hurwitz paid cash over a long-term first mortgage.
BOSTON, June 26 (AP)--Greek Spy, a game son of Greek Song, capably ridden by Eric Guerin, scored a length victory today in the $57,200 Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)-- A Senate inquiry in the field of alleged Communist influence was put off a second time today as a result of recent Supreme Court decisions. Two witnesses refused to testify.

There is a popular illusion that because Congress votes the money necessary to run the Government of the United States it must automatically have control over all expenditures. It doesn't, as the Hoover Commission and many other people long ago discovered.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 26-- Delegates to Kiwanis International convention here adopted today a resolution urging the United States and Canada to support the United Nations as "the cornerstone of our building for world peace."

CINCINNATI, June 26--Scoring more runs and making more hits in one game than they had for more than three years, the Giants tonight buried the secondplace Redlegs beneath a 17-7 score at Crosley Field.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP)--The Philadelphia Phillies bombed Lindy McDaniel and three successors for sixteen hits tonight and an 11-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Curt Simmons pitched for the Phils.

THERE is more to a cantaloupe than halving it and filling the seed cavity with vanilla ice cream. Delicious as a Lillian Russell may be (for that happens to be a name that frequently served dessert bears), it is only one of many ways of presenting the most popular member of the muskmelon family.

The plan for strengthening the office of City Administrator advanced by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York is basically sound and constructive. It proceeds from an assumption that the Mayor's office as now set up by law demands more physical and mental endurance and time than any man could possibly give it.
The owners and managers of some of this country's major Structures attempted yesterday to build a castle in the air without losing their firm footing on reality.

YONKERS, June 26 (AP)--Will Romola, owned by the Wiljoran stable of Maplewood, N.J., and driven by George Phalen, captured tonight's Hutchinson Pace before 17,658 at Yonkers Raceway. It was his first victory of the season.
Sales of $21,500,000 of school and university bonds were called off yesterday in Louisiana and Virginia because of market conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) --The Senate, within a matter of minutes, today duplicated action of the House in passing a bill approving the borrowing of an additional $35,000,000 to complete construction of the United States portion of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
The absence of retail shops in most of our public housing is in many ways a disadvantage. The Federal, state and city housing officials oppose the idea of built-in shops in general.

WASHINGTON, June 26-- Walter O'Malley,, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, told a House Antitrust investigating subcommittee today that he would keep the team somewhere in New York if the terms he twice had agreed to meet were accepted.
Mechanical and electronic devices were tested yesterday in Central Park for the city's fight on crime at parks and beaches.
WASHINGTON, June 26-- The Treasury's borrowing costs went up again today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26-- Ernest T. Weir, leader in the steel industry and stanch champion of the right of business to operate without Government interference, died today at the Institute of Pennsylvania Hospital here.

WASHINGTON, June 26-- Thomas E. Murray, who failed to win reappointment as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, was named today as a consultant to the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.
WASHINGTON, June 26--President Eisenhower designated six Cabinet members today as a special committee to investigate oil imports and to determine whether they were threatening national security.
ONE big bluefish does not make a summer but it may be a slight indicator that Long Island has a good chance for the same kind of season that blessed it last year. Will those big fish come back?

Investment banking syndicates are placing on the market today corporate securities totaling more than $84,000,000. Among them are convertible shares and debentures of aluminum and steel companies and mortgage bonds and common stock of public utilities.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26--The United States put a couple of dents in the powerful Australian tennis armor today. Two American Davis Cup youngsters, Mike Green and Myron Franks, scored notable singles victories to reach the third round of the all-England tennis championships.
The Northern Pacific Railway yesterday reported a net income for May of $2,036,821, against $2,841,631 for the similar month last year. The May gross was $15,736,399, against $15,744,626.

FALLSBURG, N.Y., June 26 --An Orthodox Jewish spiritual leader appealed to President Eisenhower today to convene a meeting of spiritual leaders of all major faiths and leading scientists on the development of nuclear energy and the testing of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, June 26-- John Cye Cheasty told today of delivering his first "stolen" information to James R. Hoffa on a Washington street corner during a February snowfall.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 26--The United Nations Command rejected today a demand by the North Korean Communists that an international political conference be called to discuss the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Korea, and the peaceful unification of the country.
The Rumrill Company, Inc., said to be the largest agency in upstate New York, is continuing to grow.
A Suffolk County police judge gave back to yachtsmen yesterday the right to anchor overnight in Lloyd Point Basin, a little harbor on Long Island Sound.
LONDON, June 26--The British Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference opened today with a review of developments at the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee meetings here.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday rose 1 to 13 points (5 to 65 cents a bale) in quiet trading.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26-- George T. Eager, assistant to the publisher of The Philadelphia Bulletin and active in civic affairs in this area, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 70 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 26--A joint Congressional subcommittee recommended unanimously today that the Government maintain tight money and resist tax cuts, as the best way to counter the inflation threat.
CHICAGO, June 26--Furniture industry spokesmen today summed up the two-week International Home Furnishings Show as disappointing in both attendance and business.
A giant gas compression plant on Lake Maracaibo, Venezuela, was dedicated yesterday by the Creole Petroleum Corporation.

The Canadian dollar has reached another high. At one point yesterday it sold at $1.05 3/64 in United States money, highest level since November, 1933, when it reached $1.05 5/8. It closed at $1.05 1/64.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 26-- Iraq's new Cabinet will continue the past policy of cooperation with the West, Premier Ali Jawdat said today.
LONDON, June 26--The United States proposed today a reduction of non-nuclear weapons through listing, sequestration and eventual disposal of substantial quantities of such arms.
Dr. Alfred Doblin, a physician who became a novelist, died yesterday at a hospital in Emmen dingen, Germany. He was 78 years old.

Matthew J. Cuffe, chairman of the Textile Export Association of the United States, warned members yesterday that despite a recent rise in exports of cotton products, foreign import restrictions were an increasing threat.
NEW ORLEANS, June 26 (AP) --Hurricane Audrey, carrying winds of 100 miles an hour, was expected to strike a 200-mile stretch along the extreme southeast Texas and southern Louisiana coasts tomorrow.

CHICAGO, June 26--Dr. E.S. Guzman Barron, who assisted in the development of the atomic bomb and later specialized in studies on the effect of radiation on the body, died of cancer here last night in Billings Hospital. He was 58 years old.
CHICAGO, June 26 (UP)--Bobby Boyd, the 8-5 favorite, was hard pressed tonight to win a tenround split decision over Rocky Castellani in a televised middleweight fight.
BUENOS AIRES, June 26-- Three of Argentina's major political parties have made formal demands on the Government to call off the elections it has scheduled for July 28.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP)--The advance in wheat prices was halted today but soybean futures provided the main interest on the Board of Trade with a climb of 3/4 to 2 cents a bushel.
FORT BELVOIR, Va., June 26 --Technicians in a cluster of ramshackle buildings on a lonely Virginia meadow threw four switches today and told the world, in effect:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26--Twenty-four nations agreed today that are General Assembly should by called "as soon as practicable" to take up the indictment of Soviet policy in Hungary made by a United Nations fact-finding committee.

CHICAGO, June 26 (UP)--The Chicago Cubs and Pittsburgh Pirates played a 5-5 tie in eleven innings in the second game of a doubleheader today after the Pirates had won the opener, 15--5, on a nineteen-hit barrage to drop the Cubs back into the National League cellar.

The foggy, foggy dew descended over the city last night, pressing its clammy imprint over everything. Up at Lewisohn Stadium, where Igor Markevitch was conducting the Stadium Symphony in the third and last of his current appearances, the dampness left a dispiriting touch.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt believes that increased control by the Russian people over the acts of their Government would increase world hopes for peace.

PEIPING, June 26--Chou Enlai, Premier of Communist China, warned the nation's non-Communist representatives today that they might be classed as "enemies of the people" if they persisted in criticism of the regime.

MILWAUKEE, June 26--The Braves and Dodgers traded home run punches tonight for the edification of 39,233 fans. But when the Milwaukeeans finally put the crusher on the Brooks in the eighth, they did it with no homers at all.
A smartly dressed husband and wife, suspects in a $37,000 jewel theft, were brought back yesterday by ship from England.
PARIS, June 26--New legal and military measures to check Algerian rebel activity here and in North Africa were ordered by the French Government today.
DETROIT, June 26-The labor secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People criticized today President Eisenhower's Committee on Government Contracts.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 26 --The National Association of Attorneys General refused today to censure the Supreme Court in two controversial resolutions.
FREIBURG, Germany, June 13--Deposits of uranium ores in commercially useful concentrations have been discovered in Baden-Wuerttemberg, the southwestern state of West Germany.
The Waterfront Commission yesterday dismissed 158 pier watchmen for failure to take physical examinations. None may work on the port's docks after midnight Sunday.
LONDON, June 26--Britain agreed today to broaden selfgovernment in Nigeria. The step would be taken in preparation for the possible independence of the West African dependency in 1960.

Stocks made two feeble attempts to push ahead yesterdays. Neither succeeded. While at no time was there any pressure of offerings, prices closed with small declines in the slowest trading since April 5.
Daniel J. Ferris, the secretarytreasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States since 1927, will retire this fall.
GENEVA, June 26--The International Labor Organization voted overwhelmingly tonight to bar the so-called worker and employer delegates of Communist Hungary.
STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, June 26 (AP)--Five miners, trapped fourteen hours by a cave-in, were rescued tonight. All had survived the ordeal in good condition.
Two of the three major obstacles to the private resale of the stalled Manhattantown redevelopment were removed yesterday.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 26--Israel will not agree to any Egyptian request for a resumption of the Israeli-Egyptian Mixed Armistice Commission, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight.
ORANGE, Tex., June 27 (AP)-- The season's first hurricane hit the Texas-Louisiana border area today, taking at least nine lives and causing widespread destruction.

WASHINGTON, June 27--A Federal Court of Appeals decided today that the Secretary of State had authority to refuse to issue passports to Rockwell Kent, artist, and Dr. Walter Briehl, Los Angeles psychiatrist.

'The Sylvania-Corning Nuclear Corporation has received the largest non-military contract for atomic fuel elements yet made, according to a joint announcement yesterday from the Brookhaven National Laboratory and Sylvania-Corning.

WASHINGTON, June 27--This article concludes an attempt (begun in the preceding article in this space) to equate one of the complaints in Congress of Chief Justice Warren's decision for the Supreme Court in the Watkins case with the record of a famous Congressional ...
Ernie Kovacs, the cigar-chewing television funnyman currently without commitments in that medium, may turn his attention to the legitimate theatre next season.
A special one-hour show starring Mary Martin and dedicated to the American woman is being considered for next season by National Broadcasting Company television.
An unorthodox traffic pattern will be tested on the New York Thruway Sunday in an effort to break the traffic jam through Rockland County.
Hearings on an application by the Consolidated Edison Company to terminate its method of conjunctional billing ended yesterday at the Public Service Commission.
THERE are two green spots in a raucous part of town little known even to New Yorkers, where birds pips and trill in season. There grasses thrive and summer blossoms.
Is money tight? Is the Government to blame? Are banks prospering at the expense of the Government, business and people? The Guaranty Trust company of New York says no to all three questions.
JONES BEACH, L.I., June 27--"Show Boat" is again gliding sentimentally up the lagoon at the Jones Beach Marine Theatre and it seems to have found a happy anchorage there until Labor Day.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed yesterday to all persons who supported the anti-bias housing bill to write Mayor Wagner urging its passage by the City Council.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 27--Haiti's military junta is giving economic matters highest priority as the situation here returns to a semblance of normality.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 27--No longer can New Jersey hold its unofficial title as the Mosquito State. The state had been known as the breeding ground for the biggest, meanest mosquitos in the nation. That's the conclusion of Dr. Bailey B. Pepper, chairman of the Entomolagy Department at Rutgers University.
GENEVA, June 27--The Soviet Union suffered two defeats at the closing session of the International Labor Organization's annual conference here today.

THE giant tuna fever is beginning to appear in iso lated and not yet quite fatal form, and fairly soon it probably will be in the pandemic stage. Pandemic is tougher than epidemic and is a very classy word that ought always to be used in connection with this expensive disease.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 27-- Col. John C. Nickerson Jr. took the witness stand today and asked an Army court-martial to let him stay in the Army despite his conviction for violating security regulations. He faces a possible maximum sentence including thirty years in prison and dismissal from the service.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, June 28 (AP)--The United States flew new-type jet planes over South Korea today to make good on its pledge to match the Communist build-up in the North.

Dairymen in seven states have voted in favor of extended market controls of wholesale milk deliveries to metropolitan New York. The proposal by the Department of Agriculture affects prices paid to the farmers.
WASHINGTON, June 27--The first earth satellite to be launched by the United States will contain instruments to record ultraviolet rays, temperature and meteor impacts.

Reports that a hurricane had hit the Gulf Coast lifted most cotton, futures prices sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The near July option rose only 1 point (5 cents a bale) but all other futures soared 12 to 31 points (60 cents to $1.55 a bale).

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27--Lew Hoad, the enigma of tennis, today took a step nearer retaining the All-England championship he now holds but his stuttering performance was overshadowed by the rest of the Australian delegation.
World sugar futures opened with mixed changes yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange but quickly began to climb. Prices rose 9 to 16 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 58,350 tons.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 27-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today labeled as "hypocritical double-talk" recent statements by Nikita S. Khrushchev that the United States was blocking a broader exchange of information and persons.

BOSTON, June 27 (AP)--The Boston Red Sox swept a doubleheader from the Chicago White Sox, 8-3, and, 9-2, today. The Red Sox carved out four-run first innings against Chicago's southpaw starters, Jack Harshman and Billy Pierce.

WASHINGTON, June 27--A pay rise that would give most postal workers an additional $546 a year was approved by the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee today despite Administration opposition.

YONKERS, June 27--Frank A. Rudolph, president of an electronics manufacturing firm, was shot through the left arm here early today in a pistol and rifle battle with the police. The battle started when he reportedly shot at a police car arriving at the Rudolph house to halt a family argument.
More than 5,000 children left the city for summer camps yesterday by rail, by bus--and by vintage automobile.
JODRELL BANK, England, June 27--A huge radio-telescope that may find a key to the origin of the universe is nearing completion here.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) --Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today the entry of a civil antitrust consent judgment against the Greyhound Corporation of Chicago. It is designed to end alleged monopolistic practices in the intercity bus field.

When the United Nations committee of inquiry on Hungary sent in its report a week ago yesterday our own State Department declared that the report merited "the most immediate and close study by all governments."

WASHINGTON, June 27-- President Eisenhower wants Congress to act to limit the impact of a Supreme Court decision requiring disclosure of Federal Bureau of Investigation files to the defendants in some criminal cases.
Baseballs take funny bounces, too. A couple of them sent the Yankees down to a 2-0 defeat at the hands of the Indians yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27-- The new moon tonight signaled the beginning of Dhu al Hijjah, the great pilgrimage month.
LONDON, June 27--The British Government announced today it would warn the nation of the dangers of smoking.

MILL NECK, L.I. June 27-- The marriage of Miss. Joan Babcock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Babcock of Horseshoe Road, to James Cox Brady Jr. took place this afternoon in St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church, Oyster Bay.
SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., June 27--The delicate process of launching the Air Force Texas tower that will stand guard off New York City was accomplished here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27--The United States formally asked today that the General Assembly be recalled to consider the situation in Hungary and the repressive measures taken against the Hungarian people.

An advertising medium for concert fans is in its fortieth season. The Stadium Concerts Review, distributed free at all performances of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts, has been around as long as the musical series. Much of the advertising appearing in the program is prepared specially for this medium.
LONDON, June 27--Despite small volume, the undertone of the stock market was firm today. Government funds advanced on a wide front and gains outnumbered losses among the industrials.
WARSAW, Friday, June 28-- A council of 120 persons was elected early today for the Warsaw committee of the Communist party.

MOSCOW, June 27--Sol Harok signed the Bolshoi Theatre Ballet for a ten-week United States engagement today, but left himself two years to figure out a way of lifting the world's most famous ballerinas over formidable diplomatic barriers.
WASHINGTON, June 27--Republican Governors showered President Eisenhower today with gifts and invitations to spend his summer vacation in their states.
TURKEYS are in the limelight this week at all of the ma jor chain stores. The featured poultry ranges in price from 33 cents a pound to 39 cents a pound, according to size.
Robert K. Christenberry, a self-styled neophyte in politics, was chosen yesterday as the Republican candidate to oppose Mayor Wagner's bid for re-election next November.
Business loans extended by the major New York City banks increased $29,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Cardinal Spellman, gowned in black and wielding a trowel, laid the cornerstones yesterday afternoon of new buildings for three institutions representing a total investment of about $23,400,000.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 27-- Shortage of water for operating the Panama Canal has necessitated notification to shipping agencies that draft limitations for certain vessel types--such as ore carriers and super tankers-- must be lowered about six inches.
Webb Knapp, Inc., offered yesterday to meet the last major condition set by the city now the real estate concern to buy control of the stalled Manhattantown redevelopment.

HONG KONG, Friday, June 28--Communist China has re ported the seizure of six "counter-revolutionary assassins" in a gun battle in which a Government political worker was killed and two soldiers were wounded.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- Senator Alexander Wiley walked out of a Senate subcommittee hearing today in protest against what he called Congressional "meddling."
The New York, Ontario and Western Railway was dismembered in Federal Court here yesterday.

The General Instrument Corporation will show a net profit for the first fiscal quarter (ended May 31), in contrast to a loss of $84,355 in the similar three months last year, Martin H. Benedek, chairman, told ...

"CLIMAX!" undertook last evening to dramatize the trial of Capt. Henry Wirz, who was in command of a notorious, Confederate prison camp at Andersonville, Ga. The play on Channel 2 was mostly an excursion in undisciplined melodrama, never a work of suspense or substance.
The Newport (R.I.) Casino put in an application yesterday for the holding of an open tennis tournament should the powers of the amateur game sanction such an event.
A crowd of young adults raced up and down a Bronx street yesterday carrying marbles in spoons, jumping in potato sacks and generally behaving as children.
ALGIERS, Algeria, June 27-- A French military spokesman said today that at least 10,000 Moslems had been uprooted from homes in rebel areas in eastern Algeria and forced to move elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, June 27--In his long and bitter fight with Lewis L. Strauss, Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, Thomas E. Murray has never issued a more sweeping indictment than he did today.
Stock prices turned firm late yesterday after drifting irregularly lower in the slowest session since April 1.

MONTREAL, June 27--The port of Montreal, already in the midst of a $57,000,000 expansion program, will be the site of a new multimillion-dollar passenger terminal, it was disclosed today by C.D. Anderson, assistant port manager.

MOSCOW, June 27--The Soviet Union warned West Germany today that if it equipped its army with nuclear weapons it would bury forever the prospects of German reunification. The Kremlin claimed for itself a "special responsibility" to guard European nations against aggression by West Germany.
Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman signed a consent decree yesterday ending the Government's action against the SwanFinch Oil Corporation and nineteen co-defendants.
In pleasaure boating, some things just have to sink--an anchor, for instance. But when the wrong thing sinks and especially at the wrong time--awkwardness and damage can result.
ROME, June 27--Objects that are unique or extremely rare have been found in excavations of a pagan Roman cemetery inside the 110-acre state of Vatican City.
The possibility of a Boston syndicate building a twelve meter yacht as an America's Cup defense candidate emerged yesterday.
WEST CALDWELL, N.J., June 27--Jack Dowling of Lake Mahopac, a 65-year-old Bronx detective, won the Metropolitan Golf Association's thirtieth annual senior championship today.

A capital budget of $106,350,000 for 1958 was approved yesterday by the Board of Education. The sum is an increase of $1,400,000 over the tentative proposal made last month and it may run higher because of spiralling building costs.
Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by Robert K. Christenberry, the Republican candidate for Mayor:

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP)--The serious condition of the winter wheat crop in many portions of the Southwest caused buying that raised wheat futures as much as 5 cents a bushel at times today on the Board of Trade.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP)--Dededon's Joy, a surprise $69.80 winner, and Calumet Farm, celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary, shared the spotlight at Arlington Park today.

Cooper, vice president of Mobil Overseas Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Socony Mobil Oil Company. With that he bade bon voyage yesterday to ten college students who leave today for summer jobs with Socony in six foreign nations.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 27-- The engagement of Miss. Ann Mason Kirkland to Thomas Reavis Bullen has been announced by her mother, Mrs. R. Mason Kirkland. Mr. Bullen is the son of Mrs. Addison F. Vars of Easton, Md., and the late John N. Bullen of Miami Beach.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- The Eisenhower Administration initiated today a step-by-step bipartisan liaison with the Senate on the London disarmament negotiations.
TORONTO, June 27--Lady Kemp, known throughout Canada, for her tireless efforts for the blind, died yesterday in a hospital here.
Harold Waldrige, a retired actor, who on stage and screen usually portrayed indolent office boys, died Wednesday of a heart attack in his apartment in Essex House.
LONDON, June 27--The Soviet Union pressed the United States today to speed up the presentation of its arms reduction proposals to the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee.
THE Department of Parks made no mistake when it decided to permit Joseph Papp to bring his Shakespeare troupe into the city's sylvan glens.

WASHINGTON, June 27-- Thomas E. Murray, who is retiring as an Atomic Energy Commissioner, declared today that it would be "indefensibly reckless" to enter into any disarmament agreement to ban the testing or production of small nuclear weapons.
Premier Nobusuke Kishi has now gone back to Japan after a brief, and we hope profitable, visit to the United States. One specific change in the American-Japanese position was announced.
MOSCOW, June 26--Ever conscious of anniversaries, the Soviet Union assessed the United Nations today as a necessary but in some respects an unsatisfactory organization.
Rapid tax write-offs for private power companies came under attack yesterday at the close of a convention here of the American Public Power Association.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- President Eisenhower will dedicate the new Islamic Center here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 27--Judge Charles F. McLaughlin promised today an early ruling on a motion that he reverse himself and acquit Arthur Miller, the playwright, of contempt of Congress.
MILWAUKEE, June 27--One devastating shot by Hank Aaron was all the Braves needed today to down the Dodgers in their series finale before 31,051 howling fans.

DACCA, Pakistan, June 27-- A measure of political stability has been achieved here, at least temporarily, by the recent intraparty victory of Prime Minister Hussein Shaheed Suhrawardy over Maulana Abdul Hamid Khan Bhashani.

PARIS, June 27--Robert Lacoste, French Minister Residing in Algeria, urged tonight that France speed the elaboration of a system of local autonomy for Algeria to help check the Moslem rebellion there.
TELEVISION, recognizing Lord Mayor Robert Bris coe of Dublin as a natural subject for a biographical drama, had the good sense to waste no time in doing something about him.
POZNAN, Poland, June 27-- This city was quiet and peaceful today on the eve of the first anniversary of the riots that shook the Communist world and loosed a political avalanche in Poland.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 --Harold Hecht, president of Hecht-Hill-Lancaster, today clarified the status of the independent producing company in regard to its distribution association with United Artists and a prospective production-distribution alignment with Metro-GoldwynMayer.
