WASHINGTON, June 27--The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted, 18 to 8, today for a resolution to stop trials of United States service men by foreign courts.
TRENTON, June 27--Leffert Holz, New York State Superintendent of Insurance, accepted today an invitation he had rejected only yesterday to testify before the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council.
BY designing the clothes that make him, three women are doing their bit to remodel the American male.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 27--Two sisters shared the lead with sub-par rounds of 72 as the United States Golf Association's women's open championship started today.
WASHINGTON, June 27--The Federal Tax Court has ruled that William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York, received a $10,000 contribution from John P. Crane of the Uniformed Firemen's Association in 1949.

FALLSBURG, N.Y., June 27 --A warning that a "very large segment" of American Jews had identified themselves with the synagogue for social and secular reasons rather than "genuine religious promptings" was sounded here today.

YONKERS, June 27--Max Hochberg's Torpid set a world half-mile-track record for 3year-old pacers at Yonkers Raceway tonight by taking the $66,952 William H. Cane pace. He scored in 2:09 1-5 for the mile and a sixteenth.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) --A Pittsburgh educational television station, WQED, told the Federal Communications Commission today its operations had been so successful that it wanted to put a second educational station on the air in the same area ...

The Port of New York Authority yesterday designated July 10 for the sale of $28,800,000 of revenue bonds to finance improvements at the La Guardia and New York International Airports. The bonds will come due serially from 1958 to 1975.
Railroad commuter difficulties diminished yesterday. Meanwhile, the New Haven Railroad set up a special investigation of its own recent troubles.

A DAY or two ago I picked up a travel folder about the joys of journeying in Central Africa and read with itching feet about how pleasant and rewarding it is to admire the flora, fauna and scenery of Kenya, Uganda and the Belgian Congo.
A marine contender for world weight-lifting honors will make her maiden call here tomorrow. She is the 10,000-ton Banggai of the Nederland Line of Amsterdam.

WASHINGTON, June 27--A Senate Appropriations subcommittee shaped the military budget more to President Eisenhower's liking today. It approved outlays of $34,534,229,000 for the 1958 fiscal year, which begins Monday.

BUENOS AIRES, June 27-- The Westinghouse Electric International Company and the General Electric Company today each bid more than $100,000,000 for the construction of a 600,000-kilowatt power station for the Argentine capital.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday delayed the removal of the Rev. William Howard Melish as the supply priest at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity so that its decision may be reviewed by the New York State Court of Appeals.
CINCINNATI, June 27--In a game interrupted twice by rain for a total of an hour and eight minutes, the Giants finally gained a 7-2 decision over the Redlegs tonight at Crosley Field.
CAIRO, June 27--For the first time, the Soviet Union has begun to buy comparatively large quantities of cotton from the Sudan.

CLEVELAND, June 27--The new United Church of Christ ended its first general synod here today with a plea to Christians everywhere to chart their paths diligently along the road toward unity of all Christendom.

HAVANA, June 27--The Confederation of Cuban Workers is "neither for nor against the Government of President Fulgencio Batista," according to Eusebio Mujal, Secretary General of the labor organization.

The King Ranch's Beam Rider beat the Brandywine Stable's Countermand by a nose in the mile-and-an-eighth feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. This was the big thrill of the day for 15,376 mutuelwindow shoppers.
TORONTO, June 27--A test that can be performed quickly and simply for identification of rheumatoid arthritis was described here today. The test can be made in a physician's office.

There is no reason to fear that New York is building too many apartment houses. This view was expressed yesterday to a meeting of building owners and managers by a realty executive whose concern handles residential leasing.

THE largest crowd of the young season of summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium turned out last night to hear the famed Italian soprano, Renata Tebaldi. The figure of 14,000 listeners was supplied by Stadium, authorities.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday increases in steel prices averaging $6 a ton, effective Monday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 --"The Jet Propelled Couch," a comedy of the dangers that beset a brash young psychiatrist when he becomes immersed in a patient's fantasies, will be produced by "Playhouse 90" on the Columbia Broadcasting System early next fall.

Paul W. Fleischmann, onetime executive of the Fleischmann Company, yeast manufacturers and distillers, and later an official of Standard Brands, Inc., died on Wednesday at his home, 22 East Thirty-sixth Street. His age was 80.
DETROIT, June 27--The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is planning new offensives aimed at achieving an open housing market for Negroes.

Despite the railroads' figures showing a good average over the long haul, the rather extraordinary coincidence of train breakdowns in the past week certainly justifies commuter curiosity as to what, if anything, is the matter.
WASHINGTON, June 27-- Charles E. Wilson said today that weapons production would be stretched out and surplus military personnel brought home from overseas to hold down defense spending.
Social Security coverage was extended to 120,000 city employes yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The benefits will be retroactive to July 1, 1956.
ST. ANDREWS is to golf what Cooperstown is to baseball--only more so. It's the legendary birthplace of the game and is some four centuries older.
IN full swing now is the brief season for fresh gooseberries and blackberries. They are in the stores to tempt palates and the enthusiasm of those cooks who like to make their own jams and jellies.
The strength of the New York Police Department reached a new high of 23,800 members yesterday as 708 probationary patrolmen and one policewoman were graduated, and 538 rookies were sworn in.

The superliner United States has been inspected by 13,000 sight-seers on four visiting days since May 1. Another 25,000 persons are expected to tour the ship on the six remaining visiting days this year.

LA PANNE, Belgium, June 28 --If you are 6 or 8 years old and have the money you can hire a tiny tank and pedal it up and down the broadwalk pointing its toy gun at the empty channel and shouting "boom" "boom." The tanks bear Belgian or French or British flags.
Two highly significant developments this week point to the improvement in the relations between amateur and professional tennis in the United States.

ST. LOUIS, June 28--Nothing stops this strange momentum of the Giants for long. They continued their recent habit of beating the National League's top teams by outscoring the Cardinals, 4--1, tonight at Busch Stadium.
Two Broadway productions will interrupt their runs after tonight's performances, one to fill a five-day engagement in Paris and the other to afford its star a five-week vacation.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 28 --Prosecution and defense both rested this afternoon in the court-martial of Col. John C. Nickerson Jr. at near-by Redstone Arsenal.
WASHINGTON, June 28-- Maj. Gen, Walter A. Wood Jr., U.S.A., retired, died yesterday at Walter Reed Hospital of a lung disorder. His age was 63.
TORONTO, June 28--The first set of uniform standards for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis has been developed by a special committee of the American Rheumatism Association.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation plans to enter the cold-rolled strip steel market through the acquisition of the Cold Metal Products Company of Youngstown, Ohio.
MADRID, June 28--Legislation for restoring some degree of press freedom, for more debate and for civil prosecution of Cabinet ministers and officials on charges of malfeasance is being prepared here.

WASHINGTON, June 28-- Representative Wilbur D. Mills today challenged "any one" to dispute the conclusion that the Government at present "must rely on general fiscal and monetary restraints to curb inflation."
The United States Steel Corporation has just announced that it is raising prices of its products an average of $6 a ton. This advance,
NEWARK, June 28--Property taxes levied by local governments in New Jersey this year reached a record high of $645,-- 724,000, the State Chamber of Commerce reported today.
A Government motion to extend for another five years court jurisdiction over the Aluminum Company of America was denied yesterday by Federal Judge John M. Cashin.
Flowers, flags and floodlights will soon brighten and beautify Manhattan in a $309,500 cityfinanced Salute to the Seasons.

Soviet Russia has again threatened to prevent German reunification unless West Germany renounces nuclear arms forever and prevents third powers from stockpiling such weapons on German soil. The Soviets
LAKE CHARLES, La., June 28 --Smashing tidal waves swamped the Louisiana coast today in the wake of Hurricane Audrey, leaving an estimated 120 dead and hundreds injured.
Following is the text of an address by Secretary of State Dulles yesterday before the convention of Lions International in San Franscisco, as recorded by The New York Times:
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 28--Alice Bauer of Palos Park, Ill., took sole possession of the lead at the halfway mark in the United States Golf Association's women's open championship today.

The twelve-story loft building at 143-5 West Twentieth Street has been purchased by Fischer-Landis, real estate investors. The land and building, on a plot 45 bY 92, are assessed for $200,000. The annual rental
A seventy-two-day vacation started yesterday for 1,000,000 youngsters in the city's public schools.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 28--The chief judge of the Court of Appeals proposed today that court reorganization be limited for the present to New York City.
Queens and Richmond Counties were major concerns of Republican leaders yesterday as they sought running mates for Robert K. Christenberry, their candidate for Mayor.
TOULOUSE, France, June 28 --A strong, attempt to rally the French Socialist party behind negotsated peace in Algeria was made at the party's annual congress here today.

Today's new film is "Fernandel the Dressmaker," a French comedy with English titles, at the Paris Theatre. In addition to Fernandel, the French comic, the cast includes Suzy Delair and Francoise Fabian.
Stock prices eased in late dealings yesterday.

HAVANA, June 28--Reports circulated in Havana today that enemies of the regime of President Fulgencio Batista would stir up disorders here to coincide with a mass meeting of members of the Government political parties in Santiago Sunday.
The Mayflower II has a new problem. It is how to proceed through Long Island Sound tomorrow on her way to New York City without creating a seagoing type of traffic jam of welcoming yachts.
Lawyers were introduced yesterday to new problems awaiting then in the atomic age.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) --Robert B. Anderson won unanimous approval of the Senate Finance Committee today to be Secretary of the Treasury. He testified that the public interest would be his sole guide in determinine fiscal policy.

GREAT corporations that sometimes have no more at stake than "public relations" sometimes move forward in providing public hunting and fishing when state governments lag. This trend even seems to be growing in recent years.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28--Big, burly Ashley Cooper, the 20-year-old Australian who was picked to fight Lew Road for the Wimbledon tennis crown, moved serenely into the quarterfinals today with a straight-set victory over Mike Green of Miami Beach.
Thinking Cap, the Christian Stables' 5-year-old horse, had an easy gallop in winning the mile and a half top-billed $7,500 allowance race at Belmont Park yesterday.
LONDON, June 28--The Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference surveyed today the current international situation in Southeast Asia and the Far East.
More new securities were offered publicly here in June than in recent months or in June of last year.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) --The Senate today approved a bill to set up a Presidential "airways modernization board" to develop a new system of controls for the nation's airways.
Mme. Maria Ghislaine Metten Savage, who was known as the grand lady of the chorus at the Metropolitan Opera House, died yesterday at her home, 22 West Sixty-eighth Street. Her age was 92.
WASHINGTON, June 28-- President Eisenhower directed the mobilization of Federal resources today for relief in the hurricane-stricken area of southern Louisiana.

"New Directions 16," another volume of avant-garde writing by new and established authors, will be published next Friday by New Directions. The book will contain sixty poems by William Carlos Williams, many of them not previously published. They
THINK in mink? Budget weary but luxury minded? If the problem is money, but you can afford to wait, why not adopt four mink and let them multiply into a mink coat?

AFTER many a page of woolly rhetoric in Waldo Frank's "Bridgehead: The Drama of Israel," we come upon Mr. Frank's talk with Gen. Yigdael Yadin, the Israeli Chief of Staff. The general is by profession an archaeologist. He is asked by Mr. Frank how a scholar could have learned so swiftly and so well the arts of war.
CINCINNATI, June 28 (UP)-- Hal Jeffcoat hurled a four-hitter against the Phillies tonight and contributed a two-run homer in a 7-1 victory for the Cincinnati Redlegs.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 28 (Reuters)--A capacity audience at the Schauspielhaus last night gave an enthusiastic reception to the first performance in German of Thornton Wilder's play "The Alcestiad."
BONN, Germany, June 28-- Felix von Eckardt, the principal government spokesman, described the latest Soviet note on atomic armament today as "bordering on the limits of normal procedure."

To bond men, the last days of June were a matter of "all's well that ends well." New issues, floated on a wing and a prayer earlier in the month finally found the favor of investors and several major issues were bid up in the market to healthy premiums over issue price.

Spurred to action by a late avalanche of votes from Cincinnati that threatened to make a farce of the All-Star Came balloting, Ford C. Frick, the Baseball Commissioner, untangled the situation yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, June 28 (UP)-- Warren Spahn pitched a fivehitter and cracked a homer and Del Crandall batted in three runs with a double to give the Milwaukee Braves a 4-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.
Operating earnings of the major New York City commercial banks will reach record high levels in 1957, according to M.A. Schapiro Co., Inc., bank analysts here.
NEW DELHI, India, June 28 --The Indian Planning Commission has reported substantial gains during the first year of the Government's second five-year plan, but has warned of difficulties ahead:
Dr. Mordecai Soltes of 596 Riverside Drive, executive director and Professor of Community Service of Yeshiva University from 1944 to 1956, died yesterday after a long illness. His age was 63.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 28 --Premier Pibul Songgram said today there would be no coup to over throw his Government.

WASHINGTON, June 28--An Administration move to limit the use of files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation by defendants in criminal cases won quick approval today from a senate Judiciary subcommittee.

STANTON, Del., June 28 (AP) --Nineteen of the nation's swiftest fillies and mares were entered today for the twentieth running of the Delaware Handicap tomorrow. The gross purse of $157,625 or better is the larg est ever sought by distaff racers.
The Appellate Division yesterday upheld Sylvester Cosentino's refusal to answer official questions based on his talks with Joseph (Socks) Lanza. The ruling was unanimous.
RANGOON, Burma, June 28-- Sharp differences have developed between the Government of Burma and the petty princes, or sawbwas, of the big autonomous Shan state in the northeastern part of the country.
A new type of switch--a thin silicon wafer, no bigger than the head of a match--has been devised to make telephone switching operations entirely electronic.

DACCA, Pakistan, June 28-- Special efforts are being made by the Central Government in Karachi to dispel regional feelings of neglect and discrimination here in the eastern part of geographically divided Pakistan
CAIRO, June 28--Egypt has expressed preliminary agreement to a proposal to build an oil pipeline between Suez and Port Said along the Suez Canal, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 28-- Arnold R. Jones of Kansas, Deputy Director of the Bureau of the Budget, was selected by President Eisenhower today to be a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
The celebration of evening masses will be permitted in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, beginning Aug. 15.

HONG KONG, Saturday, June 29--A high-ranking public official in Peiping made the first major public apology for his recent outburst of criticism against the Red leadership of China in the copy of the People's Daily that reached here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28--Dr. Elizabeth L. Hazen of the New York State Department of Health spent her vacation with friends on a Virginia farm several years ago, and took back to Albany a sample of the soil. As a result, a patent was issued this week for an antibotic.

Sugar Ray Robinson of Harlem agreed yesterday to defend his world middleweight championship against Carmen Basilio of Canastota, N. Y. The fight will be promoted by Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, in this city in September.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 28-- Secretary of State Dulles emphatically reiterated today the United States determination to give no comfort to Communist China diplomatically; commercially or culturally.
The Tidewater Oil Company announced yesterday that it had purchased the assets of James A. Clappison, Inc., of Bath, Me., a
The first encouraging word that a general building construction strike tomorrow at midnight might be averted was voiced yesterday.
The Board of Estimate yesterday approved William Zeckendorf's plan to put up the money and know-how to get the stalled Manhattantown redevelopment under construction.
The Stadium Symphony will present its fifteenth annual Viennese Night at 8:30 tonight. Marta Eggerth and Jan Kiepura will be the featured singers. Julius Rudel will conduct.

A young business man got into a JAM yesterday and he couldn't be happier about it. JAM stands for John A. Morin Co., and the 12-year-old founder of the company hopes it will soon stand for DOUGH as well.
The second week of summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium, beginning Monday evening, will feature three composers, each with a special program.

TOKYO, June 28--The Central Committee of the opposition Socialist party concluded a twoday session today with adoption of a foreign policy report that would, in effect, put Japan in a position of opposition to the western world.
Miss Jean Drummond and Porter Ijams were married here yesterday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany by the Rev. Hugh McCandless, the rector.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 28 (Reuters)--Harsh treatment for "intriguers" within the Hungarian Socialist Workers (Communist) party was promised by a party leader in a speech published here today.
Six top officials in the Department of Buildings were reassigned yesterday "to improve and coordinate the administration of the department."

The chief medical examiner of New York City is seeking the ouster of a Brooklyn assistant on eight counts of "incompetence and misconduct in office."

POZNAN, Poland, June 28-- Under somber rain-laden clouds that matched the people's mood, Poznan today marked the riots of last June 28 with the calm and dignity requested by the nation's Communist leaders.
WASHINGTON, June 28-- President and Mrs. Eisenhower removed their shoes today to join Moslems from sixteen countries in opening formally a new Islamic Center on Massachusetts Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 28--The State Department rejected today request--by eleven Arab nations that the United States suspend military aid to France.

ROME, June 28--Pope Pius XII told representatives of the American Jewish Committee today that he was with them in their fight for the rights of man. The Pontiff deplored racial discrimination and the persecution of Jews in various parts of the world.
Last Tuesday the first hurricane of the season, Audrey, began to build up in the southwestern part of the Gulf of Mexico and headed northeast. On Thursday about 8

LYNBROOK, L.I., June 28-- James W. Connally, formerly vice president and director of the Brooklyn Federal Savings and Loan Association for more than thirty-three years, died here Wednesday at his home, 16 Wilson Street, after a long illness. His age was 89.

BALTIMORE, June 28 (UP)-- Baltimore's bargain basement pitching staff tied an American League record tonight by accounting for its fourth straight shutout as Ray Moore blanked the Cleveland Indians with three hits for a 6-0 Oriole victory.
An early-morning raid yesterday on a small-scale opium den in Chinatown uncovered a $250,000 cache of narcotics under a floor.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 --The life story of the late Edna St. Vincent Millay, noted poet and literary figure, will be brought to the screen by Coumbia pictures.
--Mayor Terry D. Schrunk of Portland was found innocent tonight of lying when he denied that he had taken a gambler's bribe.
The Chilean airline Cinta has been authorized by the White House to extend its route in this country to New York. The company operates two flights a week from Santiago to Miami.
The city announced plans yesterday for canvassing 120,000 eligible employes to see if they wish Social Security coverage in addition to their own retirement systems.

YONKERS, June 28--Adios Harry, with Luther Lyons guiding him, won the $10,000 New Rochelle Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 6--year--old brown horse sped the mile in 2:03 and picked up half of the purse as his winning share for his owner, J. Howard Lyons of Greenwood, Del.
Cotton futures here closed 3 points down to 10 up yesterday, with the far-off October and December showing the most strength.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 28-- The Lebanese Government, stung by recent Opposition attacks, is pressing Parliament for the right ao jail newspaper men.
Thanks to Enos Slaughter, the Yankees defeated the Athletics, 5-4, before 19,084 sweltering spectators at the Stadium last night.
DETROIT, June 28--Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., 28-year-old Montgomery, Ala., minister, was awarded the Spingarn Medal today for the highest achievement of an American Negro during the last year.
WASHINGTON, June 28--Announcements of higher steel prices produced a politico-economic mixture of disappointment, protest and plans for investigation today.
WASHINGTON, June 28-- Probably the most sensational disclosure of a Federal Bureau of Investigation report in history was made nearly fours years ago by Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General.
Customers of Duquesne Light Company expect to be lighting their homes late this year with atomic-fueled electricity.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 28-- Premier David Ben-Gurion said today-it was not logical to ask Israel how-many of the 1,000,000 Arab refugees from Palestine she was now willing to take back.
WASHINGTON, June 28--The House Foreign Affairs Committee recommended tonight the elimination of a long-term authority for the foreign aid program that the Senate had granted.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP) --The House of Representatives gave swift approval today to a bill permitting smaller down payments for Government-insured housing and authorizing $l,740,000,000 to spur home building and slum clearance.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 28--Miss Cary Randolph Fox was married to Peter Rowe Fisher this afternoon in St. John's of Lattingtown Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Howard M. Lowell, the rector, performed the ceremony.

CARSON CITY, Nev., June 28 (AP)--Nevada's Gaming Control Board today blamed a Tropicana Hotel casino manager and a former cashier for giving Frank Costello exact details on Tropicana Gambling profits.
WASHINGTON, June 28-- President Eisenhower trimmed nearly half a billion dollars today from projected net outlays for military construction.

YUCCA FLATS, Nev., June 28--With 2,000 marines crouched in sandy trenches and poised to engage in simulated nuclear warfare, a potentially devastating test atom bomb 4,000 yards away failed today to explode.

OXFORD, England, June 28-- There is something peculiarly fascinating about an analysis of Marxism by a group of ex-Marxists, antiMarxists or non-Marxists, all of whom are now devoted to studying what makes that social philosophy tick.

James J. Wadsworth, deputy United States representative at the United Nations, warned yesterday against possible dangers in a "premature" meeting of the General Assembly on the Soviet repression in Hungary.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 28--A Baltimore man was killed and his wife was critically injured-today as a bus and truck collided on the New Jersey Turnpike.
LONDON, June 28--Western delegates to disarmament talks here flew to Paris tonight to consult with their Atlantic pact allies.
BUENOS AIRES, June 28-- The people of Argentina formally regained their complete civil liberties today.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm-product prices increased .4 of 1 per cent during the month ended June 15.
MOSCOW, June 28--Peace is more than a propaganda word for the Soviet people.

WASHINGTON, June 28--A Federal judge reaffirmed today his earlier conviction of Arthur Miller, playwright, for contempt of Congress.

ROBERT SAUDEK and the Metropolitan Opera are planning to harmonize on "Omnibus" next season. Mr. Saudek, producer of the telecast, has taken out an option on the opera's television activities for the season.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 29-- Gov. George Dewey Clyde, a former engineer who dwells in a modest but modern brick bungalow, attended the Governors Conference at Williamsburg, Va., this week.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 29--The National Guard has taken over Georgica Station from the Coast Guard, but it's neither a case of inter-service nor Federal-state rivalry.

BOSTON, June 29 (U.P.)-- Frank Malzone, a rookie, belted his first major league grandslam homer and drove in six runs today to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 12-4 victory over the slumping Detroit Tigers.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 29-- Does Westport's town government need modernizing?
To Aubrey Lewis, who recently became the first Negro to captain a Notre Dame sports team, June is a month he will always remember--both with sadness and elation.
LAKE CHARLES, La., June 29--The bodies of victims of the ruthless surge of water that overwhelmed the Cameron area to the south kept reaching here early this morning.
A "stock exchange" for realty brokers has been formed to provide real estate investments with more liquidity and to broaden market activity.
THAT picnic pastime--swatting mosquitoes -- may soon be ended. The good news is a highly effective repellent that was developed by entomologists in the United States Department of Agriculture.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 29 --Poly Hi sprinted to an easy victory in the $26,100 Colleen Stakes at Monmouth Park today. With Eric Guerin guiding her with skill, the daughter of Polynesian led most of the way in the five-and-a-half-furlong test for 2-year-old fillies.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 29 --In a candlelight service in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church here this evening, Miss Georgia Stillman Rockefeller was married to J. Harden Rose.

GUTHRIE, Ky., June 29--A freight train rammed a Chicago-Miami passenger train at the Guthrie railroad station today, killing six and injuring twenty-one, the railroad reported.
SARAGOSSA, Spain, June 24 --A young Spanish cadet, in smart uniform and well-shined cavalry boots, can frequently be seen at week-ends in the lobby of a hotel here.

Thomas E. Murray has been called the last man in the Atomic Energy Commission who dared say "boo" to Chairman Lewis L. Strauss. Last week Mr. Murray marked his impending retirement from the commission with a loud "boo."

The Railway Express Agency announced over the week-end that it was filing new express tariffs in the East, effective July 15. The new tariffs were authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission June 17.

Business was light in the steamship charter market last week but rates held, at least at the low levels of a week ago.

The New York City Opera will open its fall season at the City Center on Oct. 9 with "Turandot." The Puccini opera, which was introduced into the company's repertory by Laszlo Halasz in the spring of 1950, has not been given at the Center since the fall season of that year.

CHICAGO, June 30--Wheat futures led a strong price recovery in the grain market last week, unfavorable weather developments encouraging investment buying. Shorts were on the defensive most of the week.

OLD German soldiers are nearly dying of bitter laughter over the debacles of their last bivouacs this year. We have already had Erich Maria Remarque's "The Black Obelisk," a saturnine satire about life in Germany after World War I. Now we have Hans Hellmut Kirst's "The Return of Gunner Asch,"* a novel rich with rascality and strange revenges that marked the end of World War II.

NEUCHATEL, Switzerland, July 2 (AP)--Mrs. Joanne Connelley Ortiz-Patino, a New York debutante of 1948, died today of a heart attack in Montmollin, five miles from here. She was 27 years old.
An American's shopping tour in Paris generally produces a variety of clothes, furnishings, and art items. A scientist, however, picked up the only model of a coelacanth to be seen here.
STRATFORD, Ont., July 2-- Having a spirited, modern theatre at their disposal, the Ontario Stratfordians have done the logical thing.
The merger of Robert W. Orr Associates, Inc., with Fuller Smith Ross, which was reported yesterday, has been confirmed.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2--Ahmed Shukairy, long a spokesman for Syria at the United Nations, was reported today to have been appointed as head of the Saudi Arabian delegation to the next General Assembly session.
Last week-end the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America put on an interesting two-day show at Thompson Raceway over in the northeast corner of Connecticut.
BERLIN, July 2 (AP)--Two American films won grand prizes today at the close of the fortytwo-nation Flim Festival in West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP)-- Robert B. Anderson of Greenwich, Conn., formerly of Texas, was confirmed by the Senate today to succeed George M.
ST. LOUIS, July 2--Percy J. Orthwein, president of the D'Arcy Advertising Company, died today in suburban Huntleigh Village after a long illness. He was 68 years old.
Sal Maglie returned to the pitching wars last night after spending more than a month on the sidelines with assorted ailments. He put on quite a show for 28,667 Polo Grounds spectators.

Gregory Peck will join a posse in tracking down the murderers of his wife in Twentieth CenturyFox' "The Bravados," to be produced by Herbert Bayard Swope Jr. No starting date was announced for the Western, based on an original story ay Frank O'Rourke.

Adolph Flashner, owner of the King of the Sea Restaurant on Third Avenue, in association with Morris Goldman, has bought the twelve-story store and showroom building at 107-09 West Thirty-eighth Street for investment.
Warner Brothers yesterday threatened a summer theatre group with legal action if it went ahead with plans to star Carroll Baker in a production of Shaw's "Arms and the Man."

BONN, Germany, July 2 (AP)-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's followers deliberately sabotaged a Government atomic-powered bill today because they feared it would stop the West German armed forces from having nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, July 2--The Secretary of Defense told Congress today that the Allied defense against communism would be destroyed by any violation of status-of-forces agreements with the United States military partners.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 2--Earthquakes killed at least 200 persons and spread ruin through 120 towns and villages of Northern Iran today. The tremors reached to and doubtless beyond the Soviet border.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 2 --In 90-degree heat, a silent queue of fully 200 women stands before the barred entrance to a dress shop in the Vaci Utca.
CHICAGO July 2--Representatives of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the country's railroads have agreed on a three-year wage package, the National Mediation Board announced today.

The First National City Bank of New York reported yesterday that net operating earnings of the bank and its affiliate, City Bank Farmers Trust Company, for the six months ended June 30 were $28,760,000 or $2.88 a share. This compared with $25,568,000, or $2.56 a share earned in the same period of 1956.

MERCED, Calif., July 2-- "Common sense, faith in the Lord and good physical condition were credited today by an Air Force pilot as having saved his life during a fifty-four-day ordeal in a High Sierra range where his jet trainer had exploded in flight.
Atlanta will offer $15,465,000 of 3 per cent various-purpose bonds, maturing from 1958 to 1986, on July 16, the city announced yesterday.
The city warned commercial enterprises yesterday that beginning July 16 they most engage private cartmen to carry off trade waste or handle the disposal themselves under rigid licensing.
ON EASTER SUNDAY, 1772, a Dutch admiral sailing in the South Pacific some 2,000 miles west of Chile discovered "an insignificant little island."
CAMP WHITTINGTON, Japan, July 2 (AP)--Specialist Girard and his Japanese fiancee were married today, and promptly were subjected to a demand for money by a shopkeeper who had posed as their friend.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.)-- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the International Paper Company to sell its recently acquired stock in the Longview Fiber Company, a leading West Coast paper company.
A historic debate that promises to change the economic and ultimately the political map of Europe is now under way in the French National Assembly.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 2-- The security police tonight arrested Osman Bolukbasi, leader of the Republican Nation party, on charges of insulting fellow members of the National Assembly.

Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan immediately granted a stay of execution of the injunctions he handed down yesterday against the Madison Square Garden Corporation, the Chicago Stadium Corporation, James D. Norris and Arthur M. Wirtz.
CAIRO, July 2--A dispirited campaign with no issues at stake came to a close tonight, the eve of the election for Egypt's first post--revolution Parliament.
Robert K. Christenberry, Republican candidate for Mayor, met for the first time yesterday with both of his running mates and said he "could not be happier."
The New York and Washington television stations of the Du Mont Broadcasting Corporation have affiliated with Sylvester L. (Pat) Weaver's new "program service" network.

LONDON, July 2-The United States formally proposed today a ten-month suspension of tests of nuclear weapons.

A television circuit designed to broaden the horizon for sidewalk superintendents was put into operation yesterday at the site of a thirty-four-story office building under construction on Lexington Avenue at Fifty-first Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 2--Joseph P. Kelly, New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said here today that the state's new compulsory automobile liability insurance law was serving its purpose well.
The anniversary cocktail dance benefiting the Children's Health service will be held Nov. 13 in the ballroom of the Pierre.

LONDON, July 2 (AP)--Britain's gold and dollar reserves rose by $36 million during June to reach the highest point in eleven months, the Treasury announced today. On June 30, the reserves stood at $2,381 million.

LONDON, July 2 (Reuters)-- Three mighty explosions today burst on the surface of the sun, giving scientists at observatories around the world a chance for study of the effects on the second day of the International Geophysical Year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2--A spokesman for the Israeli delegation today called reports from Cairo that Israel was massing troops around and inside the demilitarized zone at Lake Hula "a complete fabrication."
Australia's vegetarian swimming star, Murray Rose, a guzzler of carrot juice and a connoisseur of sunflower seeds, said yesterday that he would not attend Yale this fall, as had been rumored.

The State Commission Against Discrimination ruled yesterday in the first decision of its kind, that a New Rochelle landlord had violated the state anti-bias law by refusing to rent an apartment to a Negro.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 2 (AP) --Displacing To Cash after the eighth pole, Mrs. C.M. Greer's Heavens Above scored a fivelength triumph in today's feature at Monmouth Park.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 2-- Richard Edgar Benson Jr., a textile commission merchant, died at his home here today. He was 68 years old.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 2-- A Democratic member of the House of Representatives declared today that the nation's foreign policy had reached a point where neither friend nor foe would believe statements by Secretary of State Dulles.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 --Susina Associates, new production company formed by William Castle, producer-director, and Robb White, a writer, today announced plans to make five motion pictures and a television flim series.

WASHINGTON, July 2--State Department officials strenuously opposed today a Congressional move to limit the President's authority to make nuclear fuels available to the proposed international atomic energy agency.
WASHINGTON, July 2--The Senate approved tonight a defense appropriations bill tailored closely to President Eisenhower's specifications.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)--Feed grains took the spotlight today on the Board of Trade in a rally from the retreat of Monday.
WASHINGTON, July 2--The Air Force ordered into mass production today the country's first military missile of intercontinental range.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) --Cutbacks in construction projects today appeared possible by the end of the week, as a cement strike spread to plants in major producing centers.
Moscow-affiliated churchmen retained control of the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Nicholas at 15 East Ninety-seventh Street by virtue of a court order handed down yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 2--The House Judiciary Committee created today a special subcommittee to make an immediate review of recent controversial decisions by the Supreme Court.
A salty-looking crew of adventurers received a cheering ticker-tape reception on lower Broadway at noon yesterday.
LAKE CHARLES, La., July 2 --The post-hurricane clean-up in southwestern Louisiana was in full swing today. But more than l00 miles of coast remained practically, if not officially, uninhabitable.
A new venture in coated textiles was announced yesterday by two American companies and an Italian concern.
Dr. Milton Helpern, Chief Medical Examiner, was accused yesterday of being anti-labor.

TWO days ago the Mayflower reproduction stood in from the sea. Men looked down on her in awe from Manhattan's highest towers. They marveled that anything so seemingly frail had crossed the wide Atlantic and come to landfall here.

Earnings and output of the aircraft industry will remain high for the rest of this year with a large backlog of orders on hand, Robert E. Gross, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, said yesterday.
BOSTON, July 2 (AP)--Boston made the most of a meager ration of three hits to nip Washngton, 2--1, today. Sammy White's sacrifice fly produced the winning run.

Kidder, Peabody Co., White, Weld Co. and Shields Company jointly head a group that today is offering $15,000,000 of Rochester Gas and Electric Company 4 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1987, at 101.185 to yield 4.8 per cent.
John P. Marquand's recently published Novel, "Life at Happy Knoll," is headed for the musical stage.
John Charles Riedel, retired chief engineer of the Board of Estimate, died Monday night at his home, 505 Macon Street, Brooklyn. His age was 84.

The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham announced last night that his Crusade has broken Madison Square Garden's record for cumulative attendance.
EAST HILLS, L.I. July 2-- A 32-year-old mother killed her two young sons today and attempted to take her own life, according to the Nassau County police.
Directors of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company yesterday elected Summer Blossom president and R. Carl Chandler chairman.

Some of the freedom of the auction market that the New York Stock Exchange affords was denied temporarily yesterday to one issue. The Exchange banned "stop" orders on common stock in Haveg Industries, Inc.

Albert Fracht conducted a program of orchestral music last night at Lewisohn Stadium. There were no soloists. There were, however, some extraneous tonal effects.
ALGIERS, Algeria, July 2-- Heat, transportation difficulties and unsettled political conditions in Algeria have slowed but not halted International Geophysical Year activities in the Sahara.

LONDON, July 2--The most important cold war battlefield is Asia. There democracy and communism are in open rivalry for friendship of the uncommitted nations. The issue is not really ideological. It is essentially emotional and it is expressed by the word "imperialism."

The Maritime Administration has approved in principle two more industry proposals under the Government's so-called trade-out and build program. The program permits owners of older ship tonnage to transfer the ships to foreign registry in return for a pledge to build new tonnage in this country.
WASHINGTON, July 2--A poll of Republican members of the House of Representatives has indicated that the bill for Federal aid to school construction is dead for this session.

ALBANY, July 2 (AP)--The Rev. William Howard Melish basked the state's highest court today to permit him to continue in the pulpit of a Brooklyn church pending appeal from a lower court's ouster order.
Mrs. Gerard Smith's Outer Space cooperated with those scientific-minded horse players who have an eye on the International Geophysical Year.
POINT LOOKOUT, L.I., July 2--Doc Robins, a fishing enthusiast for eleven years, prided himself on being a follow without one of those "bigfish-that-got-away" stories. However, his tune has changed.
NEWARK, July 2--Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. said today he had been unaware that the state was investigating the Loyalty Group until last February three years after the inquiry began.
WASHINGTON, July 2--Senator John F. Kennedy called on the Administration today to stop supporting France's Algerian war and start working for Algerian independence.
A five-story building containing twenty-four apartments at 2605 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the 2605 Marion Avenue Realty Company.

Wall Street staged an early Fourth of July celebration of its own yesterday. Stocks climbed out of the recent doldrums with a bang as prices scored the biggest gains in a week. Trading expanded in a generally strong market.

Two new features will open at first-run theatres this morning. "The Delicate Delinquent," a Paramount comedy starring Jerry Lewis, is at the Mayfair. Mr. Lewis also produced the Vista Vision offering, which was written and directed by Don McGuire.
Safety leaders urged extra precautions as heavy travel for the Fourth of July week-end was scheduled to get under way today.

The New York City Republican leaders have shown chivalry in selecting a woman, for the first time, to run for a city-wide office. But more important is the woman selected for President of the City Council.
WASHINGTON, July 2--Secretary of State Dulles said today he believed in and was working for the eventual peaceful liberation of the Soviet and Chinese peoples.
Beginning tomorrow and continuing through Saturday and Sunday, many thousands of stock car fans will go out to witness what to them are the "crucial" races of the season in all the various classes.

Futures prices on the New York exchanges closed generally higher yesterday in dull and featureless trading. The domestic sugar contract, cottonseed oil, hides, rubber wool, copper, zinc and soybean oil advanced. Cocoa, the world sugar positions, coffee and potatoes were mixed. No commodity closed lower in all traded months.
RANGOON, Burma, June 30-- There is uncertainty here at this stage about the effect of Premier Nu's call for less socialism and more private enterprise in Burma.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 2-- Chile, second largest producer of copper, is studying a plan to cut output 10 per cent. But no decision is expected for several days.

State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray announced plans yesterday for a public housing project to be tenanted entirely by elderly couples and individuals.

Beset by a growing boycott by horsemen who are removing their animals from the grounds, Yonkers Raceway last night faced a serious threat of a suspension of racing by Saturday.
MOSCOW, July 2--A heated debate is under way in Soviet legal circles concerning the limits on polices power.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP)--Billy Pierce pitched a five-hitter for his eleventh victory today and Larry Doby cracked a three-run homer in a 4-2 Chicago White Sox triumph over the Detroit Tigers.

MARIA BERGSON, who grew up behind the footlights in Vienna, has been performing in quite a different role with fluorescent and incandescent lights for the last ten years.

IT was an item of such relative unimportance that many newspapers didn't print the story. The Baltimore Orioles sent Art Houtteman to the minors, an inconsequential development by normal editorial standards. How many games had he won last season? Only two. Hence the shrug of the editorial shoulder in a so-what gesture was quite understandable.
WASHINGTON, July 2--With flashing lights and split-second calculations, a large electronic brain demonstrated today how it would fix the position of a tiny earth satellite in space.
WASHINGTON, July 2--Secretary of State Dulles said today that he would like to see a revival of the Johnston plan "for putting the waters of the Jordan to use both in Israel and Jordan."

ALBANY, N.Y., July 2 (AP)-- Supreme Court Justice Donald S. Taylor denied today a motion to transfer trial of a $200,000 slander suit against Louis A. Wehle, former Conservation Commissioner, to Jefferson County.
WASHINGTON, July 2--A Senate-House conference committee gave President Eisenhower a victory today by approving his request for authority to barter surplus farm crops to Iron Curtain countries.
LONDON, July 2--The British Commonwealth Prime Ministers agreed at their conference here today that United Nations procedures could and should be improved.
LONDON, July 2--Buying continued to be selective on the stock market today and price movements were generally in pennies.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2--An American threesome--Althea Gibson, Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode and Darlene Hard-- marched into the Wimbledon tennis semi-finals today, but it was the performance of a British teen-ager that brought the great stadium alive.

OTTAWA, July 2 (AP)--The new Progressive Conservative Government has made "strong representations" to the United States over its decision to continue restrictions on rye imported into that country, Gordon Churchill, Minister of Trade, said today.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)--The Cincinnati Redlegs, after blowing an early five-run lead, fashioned on Wally Post's grandslam homer, rallied today for an 8-6 victory in ten innings over the chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, July 2--A House Interior subcommittee apparently paved the way today for burial of the Democrats' bill for a high Federal dam at Hells Canyon in the Pacific Northwest.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 2-- The Carastee, a trim ocean-going yacht built here by a dentist in his spare time over the last five years, was shifted today from her back-yard berth to the edge of Manhasset Bay at Port Washington.

MUZAFFARABAD, Kashmir, June 22--Assistant Police Superintendent Mohammed Akbar Kiani, 44 year old, tough, lean and homesick, looked longingly at the mountains to the east. He remarked that Srinagar, capital of India-held Kashmir, was only 110 miles away from this Pakistani-controlled area.

YONKERS, July 2 (U.P.)--Ensign Lad, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Peterson of Limon, Colo., and driven by Clint Hodgins, captured tonight's Elmont Pace before 18,739 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

Joseph H. Compton, who retired last Aug. 31 as a vice president of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank, died on Sunday in his home at 45-24 171st Street, Flushing, Queens. His age was 65.

The new Lowell Thomas series will be presented over the Columbia Broadcasting System Television network starting in November.
LONDON, July 3--Industrial equities were in good demand on the stock market today. Although gains continued to be mostly in pennies, the buoyant trend was more widespread than yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3--Technicians of United Nations specialized agencies have for several years aided governments of protein-poor countries in the development of neglected fisheries resources with marked success.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 --James Mason and Inger Stevens will be husband and wife in "Cry Terror," a suspense melodrama to be directed and produced by Andrew Stone for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

JERRY COLEMAN was in a corner of the Yankee dressing room just before yesterday's game with the Red Sox. He was trying on a new gray uniform. It was the latest model of the summer-weight road suits that had just arrived from the tailors. He was struggling into the gray pants when Mickey Mantle stopped to stare at him.

CAIRO, July 3--More than 5,000,000 Egyptians voted today in elections for the country's first post-revolution Parliament. The list of candidates was handpicked by the regime of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 3-- Rescue teams roving the still trembling earth of northern Iran expressed fear today that yesterday's quake killed more than 1,000 persons.
It should be a happy Fourth of July for Wall Street traders. Stock drove ahead again yesterday and volume expanded. Trading was unusually heavy for the eve of a long holiday week-end.

YANGAMBI, Belgian Congo-- The so-called "dark continent" is much brighter scientifically than many people believe.
Roy Campanella, who has hit 241 home runs in his distinguished career as a Dodger, picked on his favorite victim last night to win an important game for the Brooks.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- The United States Court of Appeals blocked today the first attempt of a Congressional committee to compel testimony in return for immunity from prosecution. The attempt was labeled "premature."

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, urged today that Congress give quick approval to a bill to allow 5,000 orphans to enter this country without regard to present immigration quotas.
A $7,000,000 plant to process bauxite from South America is taking form in the pasture lands and sugarcane fields on the Mississippi thirty miles south of Baton Rouge, La.
Communist parties in many parts of the world are hastening to fall into line with the victors in the latest Moscow convulsion.
ISLIP, L.I., July 5--Judge Alfred J. Hofmann of the Queens County Court died today apparently of a heart attack, in his summer home here. He was 57 years old.
The stock market did not take a holiday yesterday despite the long Independence Day weekend.
A device that permits testing of 1,200 airctraft electrical circuits in less than a minute, thereby uncovering short circuits quickly, has been announced by the Republic Aviation Corporation.

MILWAUKEE, July 5--Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the United States open junior champion, and Larry Evans of New York, former champion of the United States, won again in the second round of the Western chess championship at the Hotel Astor today.
LONDON, July 5--The first reaction on the Stock Exchange to the Governments new exchange restriction was to raise prices of dollar stocks and to lower those for most oil shares.

WASHINGTON, July 5--Talk of compromise was in the air today as both sides marshaled for the opening Monday of the Senate's fight over the Administration's civil rights bill. William F. Knowland of California, the Republican Senate leader, who will lead the bipartisan civil rights coalition, left open the possibility of some accommodation with the embattled Southern opposition.

Richard Savitt will make one of his few appearances on turf in recent years next week. The former Wimbledon and Australian champion heads the en try for the Nassau Bowl invitation tournament which is being revived at the Nassau Country Club, Glen Cove, L.I., starting Tuesday.
The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham held the first "night of dedication" of his New York Crusade last night, and nearly 1,000 young persons responded.
MOSCOW, July 5--Two former Soviet economic planners, Milkhail G. Pervukhin and Maxim Z. Saburov, were removed today as First Deputy Premiers.

PITTSBURGH, July 5--Conrad F. Nagel Jr., an eminent light-metals scientist and retired vice president of the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa), died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

PINE BLUFF, Ark.--For toxophilites, this town should be a target of interest. What is said to be the world's largest archery equipment factory covers some fifteen acres in Pine Bluff. A toxophilite is an archery enthusiast. Again it was the Greeks who had the word for it, deriving it from toxon which means bow.

Belmont Park had as its feature yesterday one of those guess-what's-happening races in the Widener chute--the straightaway course with the start somewhere up near Floral Park and the last three furlongs cutting across the infield.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP)--Live hog prices today hit $21.50, the highest price since June 22, 1955.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 5-- Keyboard instruments dominated the second day of the fourth annual American Jazz Festival.

SANTANDER, Spain, July 5 (AP)--The yawl Criollo, owned, skippered and navigated by Dr. Luis H. Vidana of Havana, was the first yacht to cross the finish line tonight in the 3,000-mile race from Newport, R.I.

PARIS, July 5--One of the most spectacular weddings of Republican France was celebrated today in Dreux, fifty miles west of here, where Prince Henri, son of the Bourbon Pretender to the French throne, married the Duchess Maria-Theresa of the German House of Wuerttemburg.
YONKERS, July 5--Rebellious horsemen at Yonkers Raceway forced the track today to plan to repeat the last four races of an eight-race card tomorrow as exact duplicates of the first four events.
WASHINGTON, July 5--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- The construction phase of the Distant Early Warning line--a 3,000-mile electronic network to warn of the approach of enemy bombers--has been completed.

WASHINGTON, July 5--Load ings of revenue freight in the week ended last Saturday totaled 732,349 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,415 cars, or 1.9 per cent, fewer than in the preceding week, 22,930 cars, or 3.0 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 36,508 cars, or 5.2 per cent, more than in the corresponding week two years ago.

The shake-up in Moscow appears to have interested politicians more than investors. Little buyer interest in Russian bonds was displayed on Wall Street yesterday, and there was almost no trading in East bloc securities.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 5--Mrs. George W. Hale, one of the original members of Westport's Representative Town Meeting, knows how to use the direct approach when she feels it is necessary. Angered by the posting of two large signs at Compo Beach, a community recreation area, urging a "yes" vote on revision of the town's charter, Mrs. Hale tore the signs down yesterday.

In recent years bonus players haven't been paying off so well in the major leagues. However, it looks as if the Cardinals were about to cash in on the second half of a $100,000 investment that could enable them to score a double bullseye--all in one family.
The Fourth of July week-end grew hotter and grimmer yesterday. Temperatures soared above 90 in many places and the nation's accident death toll rose to 403 in the first half of the four-day holiday.

EDENTON, N.C., July 5 (AP) --A section of a forty-five-yearold wooden trestle collapsed early today under the weight of a Norfolk Southern freight train, plunging five crewmen, two Diesel locomotives and a freight car into the dark, choppy waters of Albemarle Sound.
In August, 1944, two American aviators who had been captured when their plane was shot down in the bombing raid on the Ploesti oil fields in Rumania escaped.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- Davey Moore, scoring one knockdown, fought his way to an upset victory over Isidro Martinez in a lively ten-round featherweight scrap at Capital Arena tonight.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., July 5-- The most powerful of the fiftytwo atomic explosions set off on this continent since 1945 was detonated early today at the Atomic Energy Commission's desert proving ground here.

PEOPLE whose business it is to see that Soviet citizens get clothing, shoes and the like normally have not risen very high in the Kremlin hierarchy. Alexei Nikolayevich Kosygin, however, has been one of the few exceptions.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) --A Senate-House conference committee ordered the Administration today to abandon plans to cut soil conservation payments to farmers in 1958.

WASHINGTON, July 5-- With one pitch Art Ditmar choked off the Senators' ninthinning threat and the Yankees, remarkably successful in overtime games this season, proceeded to win in the tenth, 5--3, tonight at Griffith Stadium.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 5--Lew Hoad is still the best amateur in tennis. The 22-yearold Australian powerhouse today annihilated Ashley Cooper, rated the only man in the world with a chance to beat him.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 5--Queen Mother Elizabeth was installed today as the first president of a little college full of hope for the future of race relations in Central Africa.
ROCKVILLE CENTRAL, L.I. July 5--It will be thirty days possibly longer, before the wealthy Birchwood section can be annexed to the Village of Rockville Centre, officials said today.
The Legislature's watchdog committee will consider recalling former Parole Commissioner James R. Stone for questioning in the Joseph (Socks) Lanza parole case.
LONDON, July 5--The United States asked the Soviet Union today to join in dismantling a proportion of their nuclear weapons and transferring the fissionable material thus obtained to industrial use.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 5-- The Government asserted tonight that "certain elements," presumably Communists, were planning to create an upheaval. It said it was adopting measures to check any surprise move by student masses.

Americans dipped into the till for almost half a billion dollars to tide them over the long Independence Day week-end. Money in circulation increased $448,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

LONDON, July 5 (Reuters)-- With Tom Graveney hitting 258 and Peter May becoming the third century-maker with 104, England set the West Indies a huge task today when it declared its first innings at 619 for six on the second day of the third cricket test at Nottingham.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, formally asked President Eisenhower today for full details on how the Idaho Power Company had obtained fast tax write-offs for dams in the Pacific Northwest.
LENOX, Mass., July 5--The Berkshire Festival's twentieth season at Tanglewood has been opening by degrees. On Sunday the Berkshire Music Center began its sessions.
THE marasea cherries of Dalmatia, small, bitter and wild, have been the basis through the centuries of a colorless liqueur, sweet and tangy, known as Maraschino, Zara, in Dalmatia, ...

ATLANTIC CITY, July 5-- Officials conducting the first Greater Atlantic City tuna tournament had an extracurricular worry today. It was a problem similar to the one faced by a fight promoter who had to call a championship bout off because of rain.
The Ford Foundation is now distributing over $130,000,000 to some 630 private colleges and universities.
The reserve position of Federal Reserve member banks eased in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP)--An eleventh-inning double by Joe Cunningham sent home Ken Boyer with the winning run tonight and gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-3 triumph over Cincinnati and first place in the National League pennant race.
BONN, Germany, July 5-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer believes that the ouster of four high Soviet officials has brought Nikita S. Khrushchev a long step closer to the dictatorial throne of Stalin.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- A legal study prepared for Congress recommended today that professional baseball's player deals be made subject to the antitrust laws.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture announced today a further increase of 200,000 tons in sugar quotas for the domestic market.
ROME, July 5--Mayor John B. Hynes of Boston, who left for home today after a goodwill mission to Rome, was assailed by local newspapers on charges that he had fraternized with neo-Fascists.
MOSCOW, July 5--The Soviet Union virtually rejected today a United States proposal for regular exchanges of television broadcasts.
WHY settle for half a loaf when there are so many products and services available that can make a full-time loafer of you?
GREENWICH, Conn., July 5 --Paul Starrett, builder of the Empire State Building and other famous skyscrapers, died today at his home on Hillside Road. He was 90 years old.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 5--Small but revealing clues in Eastern Europe indicate the recent Soviet upheaval resulted from a sudden climax of the struggle within the Soviet Communist party.
The new booth of the Travelers Aid Society in Pennsylvania Station was opened yesterday in time to help a Hungarian refugee.

RYE, N.Y., July 5--James Sears McCulloh, retired president and board chairman of the New York Telephone Company, died in his home at 890 Forest Avenue this morning after a long illness. His career with the Bell System spanned forty-five of his eighty-eight years.
RICHMOND, Va., July 5--A recently healed rift in Virginia's Democratic organization was reopened today as a dispute developed over the party's candidate for State Attorney General.

LONDON, July 5 (Reuters)-- In a surprise move that caused some consternation on the London Stock Exchange, British authorities today banned the purchase of dollar and other foreign securities from other parts of the sterling area.

The Canadian Car Company, Ltd., of Montreal announced yesterday the acquisition of the railway equipment business for merly conducted by the Standard Railway Equipment Manufacturing Company at Lachine, Quebec. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed. Canadian Car will continue to operate the Lachine plant until it completes modernized facilities of its own in about a year.

A special committee of the City Council, set up eighteen months ago to find ways of easing the dislocation resulting from slum clearance and other public improvements, has not yet reported its findings.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5-- The strongly left-wing Peoples Progressive party of British Guiana strengthened its chances to win the Aug. 12 elections when rival parties failed in recent attempts to unite against it.
HAMILTON, N.Y., July 5 (AP) --Whitelaw Reid, chairman of the board of The New York Herald Tribune, defended today continuance of United States aid to the Tito regime in Yugoslavia.
How many beauties in a bevy? It was academic yesterday to Randolph Haynes of Cornell University. He was sole guide and counselor to fifty-seven young women visiting New York.

LONDON, July 5--The 1957 conference of British Commonwealth Prime Ministers ended today. Their final communique called for strengthening of the United Nations, which they described as having "certain deficiencies and weaknesses" in its functioning.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 5 (AP)--Independence shed its normal calm today as public figures converged for the dedication of the Harry S. Truman Library and Museum tomorrow afternoon.
HAVANA, July 5--Despite repeated denials by Government sources, reports and rumors continue concerning clashes in Oriente Province.
In a report on his two-month tour of the Middle East Senator Humphrey, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on that region, makes a wise and timely proposal.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 2 points up on the July and 5 to 21 points down on other months.

ATHENS, July 1--The American School of Classical Studies has begun its sixth season of excavation in Lerna, in the Peloponnesus, with high hopes of shedding further light on a community that flourished uninterruptedly from about 4000 B.C. to classic times.

HONG KONG, July 5--Plans for opening up a million hectares (about 3,860 square miles) of virgin land in northwest China for the cultivation of cotton were announced in Peiping at this afternoon's session of the National People's Congress.
More than 7,000,000 American children are attending vacation church schools and camps, according to the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A.

The International Shoe Company reported yesterday that sales and earnings in the six months ended May 31 were lower than in tthe corresponding period a year earlier. The company is the nation's largest manufacturer of shoes.
LONDON, July 5--A.J. Cummings, political commentator, died here today at his home in Finchley. His age was 75.

BERLIN, July 5--The Central Committee of the East German Socialist Unity (Communist) party met secretly today to discuss the Kremlin changes with all signs indicating that unity of the leadership remained unbroken.
BUENOS AIRES, July 5--A break in Argentine-Venezuelan relations appeared imminent tonight. The Venezuelan Government ordered the immediate return of its Ambassador, Dr. Atilano Carnevali, to Caracas.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 5 (U.P)--Bobby Locke of South Africa whipped around the historic Royal and Ancient Club's Old Course in six-under-par 68, 70 today for a record-tying total of 279 to win the British Open golf championship for the fourth time.

WASHINGTON, July 5--So far as brakes go, the General Motors Corporation is ready for the jet car of the future. The company received a patent this week for apparatus that opens a pair of flaps to exert a drag through the air.
The chiefs of heavy industry in the Soviet Union appear to have been completely routed as a significant political force in that country's ruling group.

The fine success thus far of compulsory automobile liability insurance in New York State has been described by Joseph P. Kelly, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, in a speech to fellow-Commissioners of Eastern states.

MILWAUKEE, July 5 (AP)-- A rookie right-hander, Don Elston, beat Milwaukee for the second straight time and Jerry Kindall hit his first major league home run tonight as the Chicago Cubs gained a 7-4 triumph over the Braves.
ALGIERS, Algeria, July 5-- Robert Lacoste, French Minister for Algeria, outlined today plans for sealing the Tunisian frontier against the flow of arms to Algerian Moslem rebels.
A shopping center containing eleven stores in Farmingdale, L.I., has been sold by Louis Jacobs, realty operator, in conjunction with Joseph L. Steinfeld Associates.

WASHINGTON, July 5--The United States invited the Soviet Government today to prove the peaceful purpose of its latest Government shake-up with "practical" steps toward disarmament, German reunification and easing Middle East tensions.
FLUSHING, the Netherlands, July 4--With a simulated fragment of the seventeenth century as a background, the Netherlands is wistfully trying to recapture a moment from her glorious past.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 --Michael Curtiz has been engaged to direct the Samuel Goldwyn Jr. production, "The Proud Rebel." Joseph Petracca is writing a final version of the screen play, set for filming the first week in September.

Yonkers Raceway, already threatened with the suspension of its racing season because of a boycott by horsemen, received another blow yesterday. It may have to return more than $400,000 to the state because of an opinion given by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
Although no holiday records were set, movie attendance in the midtown area on July 4th generally was good and continued that way yesterday, according to managements of the larger theatres.
After a week of activity greatly reduced by the Independence Day holiday, the nation's investment bankers will have a full calendar of new securities issues to cope with next week.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP)--New walkouts spread through the cement industry today, and contractors in the East, South and Midwest felt a growing supply pinch.
CHICAGO, July 5 (U.P)--The Chicago White Sox blasted fourteen hits off Cleveland's secondstring pitching tonight for a 14-4 victory.
BONN, Germany, July 5--The West German Parliament approved tonight ratification of the European common market and atomic energy pool treaties.

CINCINNATI, July 5 (AP)-- United States District Judge John H. Druffel today named a receiver for Stevens Furniture, Inc., after a creditor said the company was losing "several thousands of dollars per day."

FORT CHURCHILL, Man., July 5--A twin of the research rocket that climbed about 160 miles above this base yesterday failed at low altitude early this morning.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 5 --Miss Beverly Simpson and Lieut. (j.g.) John Knickerbocker Porter Stone 3d, U.S.C. G.R., were married here this evening in the South Church (Congregational).

PARIS, July 5--When Senator Kennedy demanded that the United States support Algeria's "political independence" he raised interesting questions on both sides of the Atlantic. Some Frenchmen see in his words a "handwriting on the wall."

WASHINGTON, July 5--Counsel for Specialist 3/c William S. Girard suggested to the Supreme Court today that lack of "backbone" in the executive branch explained Washington's decision to let a Japanese court try the soldier.
Scoring seven runs in the sixth inning, the Giants snapped their five-game losing streak last night, beating the Pirates, 11--6, before only 4,998 cash customers at the Polo Grounds.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5-- The school integration issue split the National Education Association wide open today.

The chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting last evening for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Connor of New York and Marshfield, Wis., to Douglas Campbell Jr. He is the son of Mr. Campbell of Cos Cob, Conn., and Mrs. James A. Leftwich of La Jolla, Calif.

Samuel Hoffman of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, senior partner of the law firm of Hoffman, Buchwald, Nadel, Cohen Hoffman, and a former Assemblyman, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Mount Sinai Hospital. His age was 76.
TUNIS, Tunisia, July 5--Finland's labor movement joined the anti-Communist International Confederation of Free Trade Unions today.
DUBLIN, July 5--Scott McLeod, the new United States Ambassador to the Republic of Ireland, was warmly welcomed on his arrival today.

RICHMOND, Va., July 5 (AP)-- A Virginia legislative committee today appealed to other states to join in resolutions of interposition against the United States Supreme Court's decision barring racial segregation in public schools.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics declined to 90.0 on Wednesday from 90.1 or Tuesday. The figure for July 5 1956 was 88.1.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 5-- An exuberant boy, born here seven years ago, returned to his playmates today after six unhappy months in the Arabian state of Kuwait.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5 (AP)--The Cornell University crew, kingpin of American rowing this year, shattered the Henley course record today in its first appearance on the Thames.
DAMASCUS, Syria, July 5-- The diplomatic rift between Syria and Saudi Arabia was still under discussion today despite Syrian statements yesterday that the matter had been settled.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- James Stewart, motion picture actor, and ten other Air Force reserve officers nominated in February for promotion faced a new check-up today before the Senate decides on confirmation.

A new high-speed medium bomber with sharply swept-back wings has been seen in flight over Moscow in recent weeks, according to information reaching the United States.
A considerable amount of free food and other products will be distributed to the 50,000 Boy Scouts gathering at Valley Forge, Pa.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 8 (AP)--The British cruise ship Reina del Pacifico remained hard aground on a coral reef late tonight, after an erroneous report that she had been pulled free at high tide.
Senator Estes Kefauver, who heads a Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee, has announced "a complete and thorough diagnosis to determine the cause of the inflation facing the country."
WASHINGTON, July 8--A move is under way in the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy to increase the nation's production of fissionable material for use in atomic weapons.
A public hearing was postponed yesterday after Trans World Airlines had agreed to reconsider a Negro woman's application for a job as a flight hostess.
OMAHA, July 8--Water in the Missouri River's main stem dams reached an all-time high today.
James Lee, author of "Career," one of the season's most succesful off-Broadway productions, has completed a new play with a role he feels is tailored for Shirley Booth.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 8--Mrs. Grace Goodhue Coolidge, widow of Calvin Coolidge, former President of the United States, died today at her home Her age was 78.
BURLINGAME, Calif., July 8 --Arthur Brown Jr., architect who has served as one of three chief advisers on design for the remodeling of the national Capitol, died at Peninsula Hospital here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8--A Federal Communications Commission examiner today granted a special service authorization to WNYC in New York to continue its present schedule of broadcasting.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 8 --The South's first jury trial involving a Federal court's use of criminal contempt charges against racial segregationists opened here today.
WASHINGTON, July 8--The solemnity of the Supreme Court yielded today to frequent moments of dignified acerbity as the justices heard arguments in the Girard case.
Yonkers Raceway and the Standardbred Owners Association each gained a Federal Court victory yesterday in the legal action developing from the withdrawal of harness horses from the track.

TRONDHEIM, Norway, July 8 (AP)--Audun Boysen of Norway, who was third in the Olympic 800 meters, finished with a terrific kick tonight to beat Tom Courtney of Livingston, N.J., the Olympic champion, in a sluggish 800 at Trondheim Stadium.
The Ward Industries Corporation has sold its investment in the Permutit Company, amounting to about 25 per cent of Permutit's 220,000 outstanding shares, to the Pfaudler Company of Rochester, N.Y.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 8-- United States defense aid to Jordan is only a stopgap. She needs an assured income to keep afloat.
August is now tentatively agreed on by City Council leaders for passage of a revised bill to bar discrimination in private rental housing.
Record production, sales and earnings were achieved by the Champion Paper and Fibre Company in the fiscal year ended March 31.
Bond traders, who have been breathing easier for almost two weeks, may find the easiness is only temporary. In its weekly money market comment, the Bankers Trust Company says, ...

THE living masters of expression by free association--William Faulkner and Casey Stengel-have something to learn from Pati Hill. In time she may surpass the Nobel laureate and the manager of the Yankees and rank right along with James Joyce.

MIAMI, Fla., July 8--Circuit Court Judge John W. Prunty recognized today the fitness of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Ellis to adopt Hildy McCoy, but withheld a final ruling until he could study the case further.
GREENLAWN, L.I., July 8-- The Huntington Township police have a case of minknapping on their hands. The culprit made off with 900 live minks valued at about $40,000.

As Althea Gibson was flying home last night from England with a new tennis trophy, her mother was having her hair done, her father was working as usual as night man in a garage, her sister hoped the boss wouldn't mind her taking today off and her brother answered the constantly ringing telephone.

Wall Street apparently was in a confident and hopeful mood yesterday--confident about the business outlook and hopeful that the political upheaval in Moscow might lead to an easing of international relations.
