AT 8:22 last night Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer stepped to the front of the stage of the Lewisohn Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 8--The $600,000,000 Niagara power development program was put before the Senate today after months of controversy and compromise, but only briefly. It was forced to give way to the civil rights fight.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the upland cotton in cultivation on July 1 totaled 14,224,000 acres, a decrease of 15 per cent from a year earlier.
WARSAW, July 8--Marshal Zhukov pledged the support of the Soviet Army to Mr. Khrushchev and against Mr. Molotov in the recent Soviet crisis, according to Polish sources.

EACH day's news from Moscow makes it clearer that Georgi Maximilianovich Malenkov is being pictured as the worst villain among the Soviet leaders deposed a week ago: plotter, warmonger, suborner of forgery, arranger of false accusations, among others.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 --Andrew J. Fenady and Irvin Kershner, young producer-director team, apparently have made quite an impression on Jack L. Warner, president of Warner Brothers.

Safeway Stores, Inc., which operates a food chain of 2,012 retail stores, had the highest earnings in its history in the first half of this year. The record was derived from less than 1 cents out of each dollar of customer purchases, Robert A. Magowan, president, reported.
The perils of Greenwich Village and the New York subway system were set forth yesterday for the benefit of a score of jurists here for a seminar.
Egotistical was easily the best in the main race at Belmont Park yesterday. This son of Better Self ran in front all the way in the six-furlong sprint and finished five lengths ahead of Golden Sun.
HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 9--A trip by Mao Tse-tung to Shanghai was interpreted here today as an effort to improve the Peiping regime's relations with Chinese intellectuals and entrepreneurs.
If the United States had developed the port of Chicago and Canada threatened to block the passage of American ships through the St. Lawrence River, the situation might ...
Publication of mid-year bank income reports confirms a trend toward rising earnings, Kugel, Stone Co., dealers in bank stocks, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8--One of the outstanding friends of the West in South Asia will visit Washington this week in search of proof that friendship with the West pays off.

Mrs. Minga Pope Duryea Patchin, artist, sculptor and author, died Friday in Central Valley, N.Y. Her age was 89. She was the widow of Robert H. Patchin, former vice president of W. R. Grace Co., an international industrial concern.
LONDON, July 8--High-class industrials, particularly stocks of American companies, were in good demand here today.

A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted a former Army intelligence officer and his wife, once a respected employe of the Office of Strategic Services, on five counts of spying for the Soviet Union. The couple live in France.
Fourteen men, encamped on a wind-torn fringe of the Antarctic coast, are waiting in some trepidation for a return engagement with an army of 150,000 penguins.

THE first Greater Atlantic City tuna tournament last week-end indicated that the big gamefish like the camping grounds off the New Jersey resort city. They have been playing tag with fishermen behind the Atlantic City ridge for almost a month.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 20 points (20 to $1 a bale) yesterday.

Troubles continued to pile up yesterday for the city's $400,000,000-a-year building industry. With 7,600 members of three construction unions already on strike, contractors faced the possibility of still heavier blows.
STUTTGART, Ark.--Rice farming, a food-producing process as old as civilization itself, in the Deep South today is hardly a kissin' cousin to the practices widely associated with the popular image.
New York headed into a period of near-90 degree temperatures yesterday, after a warm but pleasant Fourth of July week-end.
The three major television networks and proponents of subscription television resumed their arguments yesterday before the Federal Communications Commission in Washington.

TUNIS, Tunisia, July 8--The world's free trade unions ran into trouble today in attempts to halt a move by Arab unions and Communist-oriented labor groups in the Far East to weld an alliance of Asian and African workers.

ALTHOUGH George Farquhar's "The Beaux' Strate gem," by virtue of its age and position as the last of the Restoration comedies, is entitled to classroom veneration, it should be treated in the theatre with bounce and zest and style.
Regular drinkers at the St. Regis Hotel will be in for something of a surprise when "Old King Cole" comes back from the cleaners in about a month.

A national lawyer's panel heard arguments yesterday for applying to noninsured employe pension plans the same rules under which insurance companies operate. Noninsured plans represent perhaps two-thirds of the present coverage.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP)-- The Air Force is protesting the news blackout on guided missile tests to Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.

ALBANY, July 8--The Court of Appeals has upheld the validity of a Rockland County town zoning ordinance that placed forty-seven acres of quarry acquired by the New York Trap Rock Corporation in a residential area.

The Kaiser Steel Corporation has placed $40,000,000 of 5 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1977 and $5,000,000 of 5 7/8 per cent convertible promissory notes, due 1982, with a broup of institutional investors, it was announced yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 8 (UP)--Brazilian coffee exports in June fell below 1,000,000 sacks for the fourth consecutive month, according to figures released today by the Brazilian Coffee Institute.
Spotty buying and attendance below that of last year marked the opening yesterday of the local summer furniture market.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell has taken the initiative in an effort to smooth the labor difficulties that have beset the American merchant marine for years.
WASHINGTON, July 8--Representatives of sixteen nations began work today on the organizational and financial structure of an Asian nuclear center to be established at Manila.
ST. LOUIS, July 8--At breakfast this morning that avid reader of box scores, Charles Dillon Stengel, looked up from his newspaper with an exaggerated expression of horror and dismay.

The Redstone ballistic missile, which now makes a towering sixty-eight-foot display in Grand Central Terminal, could fly fast enough to go from here to Washington in about five minutes, an Army officer estimated yesterday.

TRENTON, July 8--State Senator James F. Murray Jr. pledged to Gov. Robert B. Meyner today the "full and active" support of the powerful Hudson County Democratic organization in the Governor's bid for re-election.
Commodity futures prices were generally higher yesterday in dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges.

WASHINGTON, July 8--On a number of previous occasions this department has been privileged to make public the reports to the Kremlin from its roving agent in the United States who signs himself "Astigmatoff."

In the steadily sharpening indictment of the ousted Soviet chieftains there are key passages of special significance to the outside world which transcend in importance the fate of the fallen scoundrels themselves.

MOSCOW, July 8--Nikita S. Khrushchev, confident he had successfully quelled a revolt by former colleagues against his leadership of the Soviet Communist party, left Moscow today for a visit to Czechoslovakia. He was accompanied by Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin.

WASHINGTON, July 8--Secretary of State Dulles declared today that the shake-up in the Soviet Government had proved his contention that Communist despotisms "are not as unchangeable as they sometimes appear."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8--President Tito of Yugoslavia has sent his two chief lieutenants to the Soviet Union, ostensibly on vacation.

The name and unlisted telephone number of a former lieutenant in charge of the guards at the Federal Detention Headquarters here was found in Frank Costello's jacket pocket the night he was shot, it was reported yesterday.

Title to the apartment house at 41 Fifth Avenue, at the southeast corner of Eleventh Street, has been acquired by Anne and George Popkin. They head a syndicate that controls 30 Fifth Avenue as well as several East Side properties.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 8 (AP)--Taking command from the inside approaching the quarterpole, Jimminetty pulled away from six opponents in the stretch at Monmouth Park today and scored by four lengths.
WASHINGTON, July 8--The course of the civil rights debate, it now appears, will be determined in large measure by President Eisenhower.
New York became a veritable paradise yesterday for old ladies wanting go cross streets. There were 8,000 Boy Scouts' in town.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 9--Nikita S. Khrushchev laconically summed up the dismissal of his Kremlin opposition today in three short sentences.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- Agriculture Department officials said today they had dismissed two Upton County, Tex., farmer committeemen for abuses of drought relief funds.
NEW GUINEA, the second largest island in the world, received a bad press some fourteen years ago when numerous American soldiers landed there and found no trace of Dorothy Lamour and her famous
THE man Governor Harriman has chosen to head the committee to investigate the state's parole system is a New York lawyer of Spanish descent with extensive experience in investigation.
The strike of drivers for J.P. Carey Co. went into its second day yesterday, inconveniencing users of the company's bus service between major local airports the three mayor local airports.

CHICAGO, July 9--Maxwell Abbell, owner of a chain of hotels and office buildings throughout the United States and a prominent national and international Jewish leader, died today in Michael Reese Hospital here. He was 55 years old.
Project vanguard, the United States Government's Earth Satellite program, is the subject of a book by Arthur C. Clarke. In telling the story of the project, Mr. Clarke discusses how
The Flintkote Company is planning to expand its building materials line through a union with the Kosmos Portland Cement Company of Louisville, Ky. The transaction would involve about $15,000,000.

The departmental trial of Dr. Warren B. Austin, suspended assistant professor at City College, was adjourned yesterday until Sept. 9. Dr. Austin is accused by the Board of Higher Education of falsely denying past membership in the Communist party.

TRENTON, July 9--State Senator Malcolm S. Forbes challenged Gov. Robert B. Meyner today to appear voluntarily before the State Law Enforcement Council and explain what he termed the Governor's "role in the $2,000,000 insurance scandal cover-up."

Mounting evidence indicates that Nikita S. Khrushchev was deserted at a critical moment in the Moscow power struggle by Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, the nominal chief of state.
Argentina has taken a drastic move in partially breaking diplomatic relations with Venezuela, but it is understandable.
WASHINGTON, July 9--The door to compromise on the Administration's civil rights bill was opened wider today.

Labor disputes that have caused a critical shortage of cement and three strikes here may virtually halt all construction in the city this week. The $400,000,000-a-year building industry faced one of the worst crises in its history yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP)--The bargaining stalemate that has curtailed half the nation's ce
Chota Peg, perhaps the most traveled dog in the American merchant marine, has logged his last mile.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 9-- Syrian and Israeli forces battled for nearly ten hours today with mortars, machine guns and rifles on Israel's northeast frontier.

The so-called religious revival in the United States was termed partly illusory yesterday by a Roman Catholic priest. He said that in many cases it had become a "form of respectability" and was really a social phenomenon rather than a true return to religious precepts.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., July 9 (AP)--Boy Scouts by the thousands pitched tents in Valley Forge State Park today in preparation for the fourth National Jamboree, which begins officially on Friday. A brief thunder shower greeted the first arrivals, a contingent of 815 from Texas, as they disembarked at near-by Norristown.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- President and Mrs. Eisenhower have selected the Newport, R.I., naval base in Narragansett Bay as their summer vacation site.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 9-- With two boat lengths separating each of the first three finishers, Chris Drake of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club won the opening race of the round-robin series for the Syce Cup today. The series is being sailed in Lightnings.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- The Senate Banking Committee today approved a bill to impose about $2,250,000 of additional fees a year on stock trading.
Employe pension and welfare funds are continuing to show "striking growth," the State Banking Department reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 9--The House of Representatives reversed itself today and gave life to the farm soil bank for another year.
HAVANA, July 9--Fidel Castro, rebel leader, must surrender soon, according to Col. Pedro A. Barrera, chief of the Cuban Army's field operations.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 9--Politically confused Honduras has resolved again to try for constitutional government, something it has been without since 1954.
LONDON, July 9--With volume small, price movements in industrial shares were mixed and narrow today.

The nation's bankers expect business to remain strong and active in the second half of this year, a survey by the American Bankers Association disclosed yesterday. Employment, income and demand for credit are expected to remain high and steady.
LONDON, July 9--Prospects of agreement on a disarmament treaty between the East and the West receded rapidly today as thornier aspects of the Soviet Union's position became known.
A long-delayed merger of the New York State organizations of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations moved another step forward yesterday.

Soft-voiced, small and frail appearing, Mr. Kresel was a courtroom attorney of formidable reputation at the height of his career. He and the late Max D. Steuer, a lawyer of similar skill, often opposed each other in court. The struggles of these giants of the bar created a legend of rivalry not exceeded among New York attorneys in recent decades. Mr. Steuer died in 1940.

ST. LOUIS, July 9--The American League, which left this city four years ago, returned today to relive the days of its earlier midsummer triumphs. It tripped the National League, 6 to 5, in the twenty-fourth annual All-Star game before a gathering of 30,693.
WASHINGTON, July 9--A leading economist found cause for alarm today in the big-business practice of cutting production and raising or maintaining prices in the face of sluggish demand.
The State Court of Appeals, in a decision in the case of a Mexican divorce lawyer, has reserved all rendering of legal service to the public here to members of the New York bar.

An investment banking group headed by the Harris Trust Company, Chicago, and the Bankers Trust Company entered best bid yesterday for a $15,000,000 offering of water works bonds by the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California. The bonds mature from Aug. 1, 1958 to 1969.
FROM now until the end of August, New York will look like a ghost town over the weekends.

The central bank of West Germany, the Bank Deutscher Laender of Frankfurt-am-Main, has agreed to lend $100,000,000 for one to three years at 4 per cent interest to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Develonment (World Bank).

MICHAEL ROSENKER, concertmaster of the Stadium Symphony Orchestra, had his evening in the limelight at Lewisohn Stadium last night as soloist with Alexander Smallens and the orchestra in the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9-- The embattled horsemen of Yonkers Raceway shifted their attack today to Roosevelt Raceway and fired three demands at the management that is opening a new $19,500,000 plant on Aug. 1.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 9 --Isidor J. Kresel, for many years one of New York's most widely known and colorful attorneys, died here today. His age was 78.
BUENOS AIRES, July 9--A woman was killed and more than fifty persons were injured today when a wooden stand collapsed during celebrations of Argentina's 141st Independence Day.
Anyone asked to name the most bowling-conscious American community probably would settle on St. Louis or Milwaukee. Wrong both times. The correct answer is the oil colony of Saudi Arabia!
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP)--Flour buying was the main influence as wheat futures continued their advance on the Board of Trade today, but prices turned downward near the close on profittaking.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9-- Philip Acosta Carroll, senior partner in the New York law firm of Shearman Sterling Wright, died here last night at his home, Eagle's Nest. He was 78 years old. His New York residence was at 33 East Seventieth Street.
PARIS, July 9--The greatest single step yet taken toward European economic union was assured by France today.

A grand Jury that investigated the collapse of a tenement on the lower East Side reported yesterday that it had found negligence on the part of the Department of Buildings. It recommended an inquiry into the department's practices.
WASHINGTON, July 9--The conviction for contempt of Congress of Marcus Singer, Cornell University Zoology Professor, has been reversed by the United States Court of Appeals.
The city's Medal of Honor, together with a citation, went to Lieut. Gen. Thomas W. Herren in a City Hall ceremony yesterday. Mayor Wagner made the presentation.
PUGWASH, Nova Scotia, July 9--Twenty-two scientists from ten countries are gathered here to assess the values and dangers of the atomic age that some of them helped to bring about.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 9--Carol Beinbrink of Stony Brook, L.I., led the field in the first qualifying round of the Women's New York State Golf Association's twenty-eighth championship today. Over the rolling Briar Hall course, Miss Beinbrink scored a two-over-par 76.
TRENTON, July 9--New Jersey will permit no further curtailment of commuter railroad service until the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission has completed its final report.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 9-- Selection of a trial jury was completed today in the Federal Government's criminal contempt case against racial segregationists.
ANYTHING replacing the inept production of "Rosalie" at Central Park's Theatre Under the Stars had to be an improvement.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- President Eisenhower re-emphasized today his opposition to abandonment of status-of-forces agreements with military allies.
ST. LOUIS, July 9--Losing and All-Star game for the first time in three managing stints today didn't seem to depress Walt Alston.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to require compulsory Government inspection of poultry and poultry products.

United States Supreme Court Justice John Marshall Harlan refused yesterday to issue an injunction asked by the General Electric Company to prohibit the Masters Mail Order Company from advertising G.E. products in New York at below "fair trade" prices.

The first game of a ten-game match between Samuel Reshevsky, international grandmaster, and Arthur B. Bisguier, the United States champion, was played last night at the Manhattan Chess Club and was adjourned after forty-one moves in a position regarded as lost for Bisguier.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 --Twentieth Century-Fox apparently subscribes to the theory that just because a story was filmed once it should not be forgotten.
Afer about a year of debate and experiment the Peiping regime has given up its widely proclaimed "reform" of putting the writing of Chinese into an alphabetized form.

History was written in large letters in Paris last night when the French National Assembly approved two treaties designed to merge the economies of six European nations into an economic and atomic power bloc comprising 175,000,O0O people.
GENEVA, July 9--The widespread use of Salk anti-poliomyelitis vaccine throughout the world has confirmed studies in the United States of its safety and effectiveness, it was reported today.
The stock market called a halt yesterday to the drive that had sent prices up for seven straight sessions.
Before leaving for a month in Europe, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy promoted 168 members of the department yesterday.
The New York business man will be the hero of a new series projected for television.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 9--The first plant producing a new high-energy aviation fuel on a "semi-commercial" basis was opened here today to public inspection--on a restricted basis. The fuel, which is being produced so far in limited test quantities, is expected to extend the range of existing bombers by at least one-third and perhaps one-half or more.
Domestic smelters' shipments of zinc dropped last month to the lowest level since the steel strike last July, the American Zinc Institute reported yesterday.
Heavy commission house selling, tired long liquidation, profittaking and stop-loss selling lowered cocoa prices almost the 1 cent a pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

METHUEN, Mass., July 9-- Miss Mary Elizabeth Conway and Arnold Fredrick Gwin will be married on Aug. 10. Mr. and Mrs. George J. Conway have announced their daughter's engagement. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien C. Gwin of Natchez, Miss.
PARIS, July 9--Purge in the Soviet Union serves as a built-in retirement and promotion method within a somewhat stultified society.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 9 (AP)--Representatives of a consulting company testified today that it would be three years before the Northeastern Steel Corporation of Bridgeport, Conn., could overcome its losses. And they said Northeastern could not achieve this as an independent concern without added capital of $6 million to $7 million.

HONG KONG, July 9 (AP)-- Premier Chou En-lai told the National People's Congress [Parliament] of Communist China today that Burma had agreed in principle to his plan for settling the long border dispute.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 9 (AP)--The daily double today at Monmouth Park paid $2,833.60 for $2 when the Mar-An Farm's Cosette won the second race at odds of 137--1.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)-- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. indicated today that he would not go along with Democratic backing of Hells Canyon dam legislation until "the smell is cleared away" in an "infamous" civil rights vote's "trade."
WASHINGTON, July 9--John L. Lewis attacked welfare and pension fund bills and their advocates today.
WASHINGTON, July 9-- Herve Joseph L'Heureux, United States Consul General at Montreal, died today at the Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 58 years old.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., July 9-- Tommy Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club, a fourtime champion exempt from qualifying for the New York State amateur golf championship at Fairview, elected to play for the medal today and took it for the eighth time.
PARIS, July 9--President Rene Coty stated in unequivocal terms today France's continued refusal to grant independence to Algeria.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 9--Jordanian authorities are completing indictments for an immediate trial of some of the country's leading personalities on charges of treason.
It is a fascinating story of intrigue and double dealing that has reached the world from Moscow as the "inside story" behind the latest Soviet purge. A cabal is formed.

Samuel H. Schwartz, a theatrical business manager since l927, is representing interests in St. Paul for the purchase of one of Broadway's best musical houses, the St. James Theatre. The asking price is reported to be between $1,500,000 and $2,000,000.

ST. LOUIS, July 9--Once upon an All-Star game there were a pitcher (Jim Bunning) and a catcher (Yogi Berra). Together this pair worked three smooth, spotless innings. In fact, so smooth and so spotless were the efforts of this American League battery that not a National Leaguer who, faced Bunning reached base.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP)-- The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved today a bill to authorize $3,242,333,000 in foreign aid.
WASHINGTON, July. 9--A bill to ease Federal control of natural gas prices won its first Congressional test today, but its future remained much in doubt.

June usually busts out all over with municipal bond sales. But not this year. The Investment Bankers Association of America reported yesterday that $382,000,000 of tax-exempt issues were sold last month, smallest volume this year and well below the $546,000,000 sold in May.
The Consumers Power Company announced yesterday plans to raise more than $70,000,000 for the utility's construction program, budgeted at $93,000,000 this year and $95,000,000 in 1958.

MOSCOW, July 9--A rash of new denunciations of three recently deposed Soviet leaders in the press today stressed the penalty of expulsion from the Communist party for those who violate its discipline.
A chain reaction that is expected to advance materially the city's $187,000,000 waterfront rehabilitation program will be set off within two weeks.

ACCORDING to news reports carried by this paper recently, the limited edition most in demand out Mineola way then was a free, thirty-three-page booklet prepared by a school teacher. Titled "Sixty-three Ideas for Summer Fun," the

Henry Goelet, realty investor and builder, announced yesterday a series of realty transactions involving an office building and two apartment houses in Manhattan. The properties are valued at more than $6,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July, 9 (UP)-- The House of Representatives approved without debate today the Administration's request for authority to barter United States.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 9-- Playing his first singles match on grass in more than two years, William Talbert, the Captain of the Davis Cup team, defeated Paul Cranis of Fort Dix, N.J., 6--2, 8--6, today at the Nassau Country Club.

ATLANTA, July 9 (UP)--Col. John C. Nickerson Jr. was formally reprimanded today and his sentence for having given out guided-missile secrets was approved by Lieut. Gen. Thomas F. Hickey, Third Army commander.
PARIS, July 9--George Zlatovski and his wife, accused by the United States of spying for the Soviet Union, tonight called the charges against them "false and in addition quite ridiculous."

IN A month or so wreckers will pound into dust the four weathered old brick buildings on the north side of East Fortieth Street just east of Lexington Avenue. They will tear away the plane trees that have long kept the house fronts in dignified shadow. From the dust, a twenty-fourstory office tower will rise.
LEMONT, Ill., July 9--The synthesis of the heaviest manmade element was announced here today by the Argonne National Laboratory.
Five hundred sixty-eight persons answered the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham's call for a rebirth of man's soul last evening at Madison Square Garden.

The City Council brought out for public study and discussion yesterday several tentative amendments designed to modify the Sharkey-Brown-Isaacs bill. The measure would bar discrimination in private rental housing.

RICHMOND, Va., July 9 (AP) --J. Lindsay Almond Jr., Attorney General, won by a wide margin in the Democratic primary for Governor today. He predicted a "decisive victory" over the Republicans in November.

Mr. Al L, made a thrilling late rally to win the Summer Festival Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Under the guidance of Ray Broussaro, Joe W. Brown's 5-year-old horse overtook preferred rivals in the stretch to win the mile event by more than two lengths.
ST. LOUIS, July 9--It was only last night that Charles Dillon Stengel was discussing his singular lack of success in the All-Star series, one victory in six tries.
ALBANY, July 9 (AP)--A group of residents today urged James E. Allen Jr., Education Commissioner, to set aside a school district annexation in Ulster Coun
LONDON, July 9 (Reuters)-- Communist Rumania said today that Ana Pauker, once Europe's most powerful woman Communist, had tried to frame trials to "exterminate" some party leaders.
CINCINNATT, July 9--George M. Harrison and Jacob Potofsky forwarded recommendations today for solving two jurisdictional problems affecting the maritime industry.

H.V. Kaltenborn will celebrate his eightieth birthday today in his usual habitat. The news analyst will appear on the National Broadcasting Company "Today" telecast at 8:15 A.M. and 9:45 A. M. He will look, as he has been doing on the air for many years, at the past, present and future.

WORLAND, Wyo., July 9-- The ten states of the Missouri River Basin are suffering "a continued, rapid decline in number of farms and farm population and a very severe drop in total and per capita farm income."
More than $104,000,000 in new corporate securities are being offered to investors today.
Althea Gibson received two welcomes to New York yesterday--one at the airport and the other on the Harlem play street where she learned to play tennis.
The six-story business building at 33 West Fifty-seventh Street has been purchased by Fischer-Landis, realty operators.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 9--Special Prosecutor Edward E. Rigney declared today that a deputy welfare commissioner had been dismissed in reprisal for having testified against his chief. The deputy, Sergei Bessaraboff, was dropped from his $6,250-a-year job on June 26 by County Welfare Commissioner J. Milford Kirkup Jr.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, told a special Senate subcommittee today that relaxation of the Government's ban on trade with Communist China would constitute gambling with national security. He also minimized the commercial value of such trade.
Governor Harriman appointed a committee of experts yesterday to investigate and advise upon reforms in the state's parole system.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 9--Israeli officials have recently held a series of secret talks in Rome with private representatives of the Palestine Arab refugees. The discussions apparently concerned possible resettlement of some refugees in one of the Arab states.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 3 points up on old July and 1 to 16 points down on other months.
LONDON, July 9--Britain has begun a new effort to find a solution to the Cyprus problem.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 --The National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians and the National Broadcasting Company in Hollywood have reached an agreement on staff requirements for the video tape-recording operation, a union official said today.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 9 --Leaders in many walks of life were among more than 200 persons who attended a funeral service here today for David Alva Gimbel. It was held at Chieftains, the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel.

Earnings of Hiram Walker Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its consolidated subsidiaries increased $1,1613,422 in the nine months ended May 31 over the period a year earlier. The net for the May quarter declined, however, according to the report issued yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 9-- Nathan Leopold, now 52 years old, who at 19 helped to murder 14-year-old Bobby Franks, was pictured today as a quiet convict who had atoned for his savage crime "in a pit as black as life can make it."

Jack Kramer yesterday turned over his disagreement with his star player, Pancho Gonzales, to his attorney but the tennis promoter left the door open for Pancho to play in the Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills, Queens, starting Saturday.
The return to normal conditions in the world-wide oil supply pattern after being disrupted by the Suez crisis will enable the Navy to lay up nineteen tankers pressed into emergency service.
LONDON, July 9--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Sir Winston Churchill joined to urge that Britain establish economic unity with the rest of Europe.

HAVE you been coming home with an empty creel much too often to suit you? Have fish been shaking off your hook as if they could visualize the sizzling frying pan that awaits them? Do you have to sit in the corner if a boat, away from friends, because you're considered a jinx?
The Liberal party designated Mayor Wagner, Council President Abe Stark and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa for re-election last night.
BALDWIN, L.I., July 10--In a scene somewhat reminiscent of the old Wild West, a burglary suspect escaped here today after fighting a fifty-shot gun battle wih ten Nassau County policemen.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 10 --The Federal Government's criminal contempt trial of sixteen defendants in the Clinton segregation case became entangled today with the controversial Supreme Court decision concerning confidential files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP)--Physicians tonight said they are unable to determine whether Willie Hartack, the nation's No. 1 jockey, had suffered a broken back in a spill from his mount at Arlington Park today.
Robert W. Sedam of 1112 Park Avenue, assistant vice president, public relations, of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Tuesday of leukemia in Lenox Hill Hospital. His age was 52.
TODAY, 11 A.M.: Stories will be told by Miss Janet Pinney at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, for very young children.

The perennial problem of Cyprus, one of the most intractable of the post-war era, seems again to be set for an effort at a solution. Field Marshal Sir John Harding, Governor of Cyprus, is now in London discussing the matter with British Government officials.
One of the puzzles of nature is how penguins can succeed in hatching their eggs on a bar sheet of Antarctic ice.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP)--The House Ways and Means Committee today approved an Administration bill to block liquor distillers from receiving more than a billion dollars in tax "windfalls."
LONDON July 10--The Moscow radio said tonight that Georgi M. Malenkov had been made manager of a hydroelectric plant in East Kazakhstan, a remote area of Central Asia.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10--Hungary faces the same economic crisis that confronted the Communist regime at the time of the revolt last fall, but now she is less able to cope with it, the Economic Commission for Europe reports.

The Esso Standard Oil Company, marketing affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), yesterday reduced prices of heating oil, kerosene and diesel fuel by two-tenths to four-tenths of a cent a gallon in eighteen Eastern and Southern states.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 10-- Two highly contrasting pictures of Samuel Goldwyn were drawn in Federal Court here today.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Senate Antitrust subcommittee released a statistical report today specifying how much manufacturing was in the hands of how many businesses.

LONDON, July 10--British political leaders strongly discount a recent warning to the United States Embassy that anti-Americanism remains strong in Britain and will be an important, perhaps a dominating, feature in the next general election.

Building construction in the metropolitan area was reported to be "rapidly closing down" yesterday as a result of a cement shortage and strikes by three construction unions. Howard McSpedon, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council, asserted that unless the strikes were settled and something was done to restore the flow of cement into the area, "Friday will see the beginning of impressive lay-offs" in the building unions.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 10 (AP) --The Philadelphia-owned yacht Gilliard today was declared winner of the seventh biennial Marblehead, Mass.-to-Halifax sailing race.

True-tracking radar, an adaptation of conventional radar, was unveiled yesterday by the marine division of the Sperry Gyroscope Company. It offers virtually an electronic motion picture of the area surrounding a vessel, the company said.
LONDON, July 10--The United States challenged the Soviet Union today to produce a disarmament formula that the Russians thought would be acceptable to the West.

Books by and about Bernard M. Baruch will be published one day apart next month. Holt has scheduled for Aug. 19, Mr. Baruch's eighty-seventh birthday, the first of his two volumes of memoirs, entitled "Baruch: My Own Story." It tells of his boyhood ...

Cocoa futures fluctuated sharply yesterday in the fifth largest volume of the year on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices fell sharply early in the session but then recovered to close at about Tuesday's final levels.

When attendance drops at a race track to the point where about the only customers around are the diehards, the track management would do well to take another look at the situation. And when the diehards begin to grumble and hold back on their bets, the persons interested in the pari-mutuel revenue should take a couple of looks.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 10--Israel repeated today her warning to the Syrians against further violence along their border.
A group of Italian-Americans fought yesterday to save a historic church from the onrush of public improvements.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 10--Nikita S. Khrushchev was praised today as the man who had "uncovered and destroyed the anti-party group" in the Soviet Communist leadership.
LONDON, July 10--Paintings, drawings and a few bronzes collected by the late Wilhelm Weinberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., brought 326,520 ($914,256) at an auction at Sotheby's today.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Senate majority leader surveyed the work of the current session today and found it good.
TOKYO, July 10--A Cabinet entirely of his own choosing was named tonight by Premier Nobusuke Kishi. He immediately took its members to the Imperial Palace to be formally invested by Emperor Hirohito.

Lieut. Gen. Thomas W. Herren, who is retiring from the Army at the end of this month, in many years of service has gained a reputation as a stern disciplinarian. But yesterday he ordered all the First Army installations under his command to take steps to make life in the Army happier.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)--Willie Vaughn flailed Chebo Hernandez with lefts and rights in the seventh round tonight to beat the rugged Mexican middleweight from Juarez on a technical knockout at 2:19.

Wall Street's "breathing spell" of Tuesday was short-lived. Stocks advanced briskly again yesterday in an afternoon rally, more than wiping out the previous day's mild losses. The New York Times combined average hit a new 1957 high during the day.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 10--The Dutch are enthusiastic about the principle of an integrated Europe, but have some misgivings about the way it will work out.
The Soviet Union and three satellite nations have invited an independent packager of television news shows to make filmed documentaries on life within their borders.
Two judges of the state's highest court struck different notes yesterday in discussing the progress of court reform in the state.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Liberal Southerners are prepared to propose a compromise civil rights bill. It would give full protection to voting rights but would withhold Federal power to force school integration.
FORT WORTH, Tex., July 10 --The United States now has a workable jet bomber that will go about twice as fast as the speed of sound.
KITCHENER, Ont., July 10 (AP)--Ed (Porky) Oliver of Canton, Mass., and Henry Ransom shared the first-round lead in the $25,000 Canadian open golf tournament today with threeunder-par 68's.

ST. LOUIS, July 10--Commissioner Ford C. Frick met today with minor league baseball's top officials to set in motion machinery that would be needed to meet the problems certain to arise "if and when major franchise shifts are made."

HAVANA, July 10--Dramatic action by enemies of the regime of President Fulgencio Batista to divert Government forces from their campaign against the rebel leader Fidel Castro is believed possible here.
CHICAGO July 10 (AP)-- Wheat and rye futures showed strength on the Board of Trade, today but feed grains and soybeans were weak.

TUNIS, Tunisia, July 10-- Union leaders from twenty-four Asian and African countries demanded today that the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions adopt a much sharper stand on the explosive issue of Algerian independence.

The Department of Justice said yesterday that a direct, personal appeal would be made to the French Government for the extradition of George and Jane Foster Zlatovski, accused by the United States of spying for the Soviet Union.
Edward J. Donovan, who recently retired from the State Parole Board, yesterday was named executive director of the legislative committee that is investigating the parole of Joseph (Socks) Lanza.
WASHINGTON, July 10--Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. has emerged in the Senate civil rights debate as the chief whipping boy of the Southern opposition.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 10-- If there are any bluefish in the Atlantic Ocean off western Long Island, they must be on a diet. Not one of them appeared interested today in such tasty piscatorial tidbits as butterfish and freshly-ground-up moss bunker.
A central unit on school zoning will be set up by the Board of Education as part of its program to promote integration.

CONSIDERING the fact than he played only an inning and a half, the impact of Minnie Minoso on the recent All-Star game was out of proportion to the length of his service. It was in the ninth inning that the fans suddenly became aware of the presence of Saturnino Orestes Arrieta Armas Minoso. The Cuban Comet exploded in all directions at once.
LONDON, July 10--Buying was selective on the stock market today and small losses predominated.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 (AP)-- Young Bob Purkey allowed only six hits as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated Milwaukee, 5-2, tonight and dropped the Braves three full games back of the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals.
MIAMI, Fla., July 10--Hildy McCoy was declared the legal child and heir of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin B. Ellis in as adoption case ruling today by Circuit Court Judge John W. Prunty.

The seventy-one New York State mutual savings banks that own the Institutional Investors Mutual Fund, Inc. will vote at a special meeting Sept. 12 on a proposal to split shares of the fund l0-for-1. Approval of two-thirds of the shareholders is necessary.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP)--Representative Patrick J. Hillings, Republican of California, said today that Congressional investigators were checking whether baseball owners and officials were "intimidating" Bob Feller...
WASHINGTON, July 10--The American Council on Education appointed today a sixteen-member commission to survey dentistry.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Senate debate on the Administration's "civil rights" bill furnishes a negative demonstration of the value of the usual procedure of referring measures to committees.
The Concourse Plaza Hotel, a 425-room Bronx landmark at the Grand Concourse and 161st Street, has been sold by Hotel Concourse Plaza, Inc., of which Frank W. Kridel is president.
WASHINGTON, July 10-- George M. Humphrey conceded today that "tight" money was harder on some persons than on others and added, "I don't know just what to do about it."

The sixth of the National Planning Association's case studies of "United States Business Performances Abroad"--on the StandardVacuum Oil Company's operations in Indonesia--is in many ways the most important and useful of this notable series.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 --Universal-International has presumably joined Twentieth Century-Fox in the belief that old pictures never die. The Printers' Ink Publishing Company, publisher of Printers' Ink, has been purchased by Vision, Inc., it was learned yesterday.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 10 --The Supreme Court of Thailand split with the Government today on interpretation of a key clause in the Constitution.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 10 (AP)--A two-engined plane crashed on take-off from King Salmon Airport on Bristol Bay today, killing at least six persons. Among the victims were members of a prominent Washington State fishing family and a New York business man.

Preliminary steps were taken here yesterday to set up the same state chemical tests for drunken driving and the same procedures for handling traffic offenders throughout the country. A law group recommended such a statute for adoption.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 10 (AP)--The River Divide Farm's Decathlon carried 133 pounds to his sixth consecutive stakes victory today as he scored by two and a half lengths over Nahodah. Decathlon was the 2-5 favorite in the $16,250 Rumson Handicap at Monmouth Park.
The State Power Authority urged the Federal Power Commission yesterday to act on the state's request for a license to develop Niagara power.

MARYSVILLE, Ohio, July 10--Miss Anne Carol Stephens and the Rev. Charles William Strohbeck 3d, assistant pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church of Manhattan in New York, were married here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 10-- Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, has agreed to a Democratic proposal for the commission to construct small atomic power plants for rural cooperatives, informed sources said today.

SIR WILLIAM DRUMMOND STEWART, baronet, went about his wild pleasures methodically. If he lived today, instead of in the middle of the last century, he would probably be organizing huge safaris to the Amazon and the Congo, accompanied by other big-game shots and scientists and artists and bearers overloaded with bullets, billets and champagne.

A drop last week of 237,900 barrels a day in the nation's average gross oil output was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Production for the week averaged 6,952,000 barrels a day, compared with 7,085,850 in the similar week of 1956.

News from Detroit indicates that automobile production in July, usually a slow month, will be a little more than 500,000 passenger cars, about the same as in June. In July last year, the industry rolled out 448,870 cars.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 2 to 8 points (10 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday after some irregularity early in the session.
Mass vaccination with Salk vaccine has sharply reduced the number of paralytic polio cases in the city and state this year, health officials reported yesterday.
LONDON, July 10--Sholem Asch, noted author, died here today while on a visit to his daughter. He was 76 years old and had made his home in Israel since last year.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 10 --Director Jack Landau has not tried any special stunts with "The Merchant of Venice," which entered the repertoire of the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre this afternoon.

The city moved yesterday to tighten inspection of all shoredup buildings. The action, ordered by Edward T. Crinnion, Acting Buildings Commissioner, followed a presentment handed up Tuesday by a grand jury.
Georgi M. Malenkov's new jobs will take him to eastern Kazakhstan, a remote and mountainous area of the Soviet Union.

With United Nations troops maintaining an uneasy truce along the Egyptian-Israeli border, violence is beginning to erupt along another frontier around Lake Hula. Since the middle of last month border incidents have been taking place in that area, culminating in a tenhour gun duel between Syrian and Israeli forces on Tuesday.
ROME, July 10 (AP)--Carlo Augusto Linch, Argentine-born president of the Italia (Italian Lines) Shipping Company, died today in a Rome hospital at the age of 75. The cause of death was not announced.
The Grace Line abandoned yesterday its hope to pioneer American-flag steamship service between the Great Lakes and the Caribbean this summer.

BONN, July 10--The West German Government, striving to trim an embarrassing export surplus with its European trading partners, today ordered a 25 per cent slash in import duties on manufactured goods.
A written agreement designed to eliminate racial discrimination in employment has been signed by the United Automobile Workers of America and the National Urban League.

Jewel's Reward of the Maine Chance Farm took the sixtyfifth running of the Tremont at Belmont Park yesterday. The race, at five furlongs and a half on the Widener course, was for 2-year-old colts and geldings, and it had a gross value of $23,300.

The Port of New York Authority paid a net interest cost of 3.66038 per cent yesterday in awarding $28,800,000 of La Guardia and New York International Airport revenue bonds, maturing from 1958 to 1975. The funds will be used in the airport building program.

MOSCOW, July 10--The Soviet Union announced today that it was testing four new large planes for transport and passenger service.

Robert E. Hill of Stamford, Conn., a founding partner of Hill, Rivkins, Middleton, Louis Warburton, admiralty lawyers, of 96 Fulton Street, died yesterday in Beekman-Downtown Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 63.
WASHINGTON, July 10--Miss Melissa Ann Hildebrand and Ensign Lloyd Dallas Follmer Jr., U.S.N., will be married in September.

THE "Kraft Television Theatre" quietly ignored on Channel 4 last night one of the supposed taboos in the Television Code of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters. The so-called violation did not help the play, but it was good to see TV have the forthrightness to show how life sometimes can be, even if it doesn't happen to fit moral standards conceded to be desirable.
STOCKHOLM, July 10 (AP)-- Six American athletes touring Scandinavia won seven events in an international track and field meet tonight at Stockholm's Olympic Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)--The bribery trial of James R. Hoffa, Midwestern leader of the Teamsters Union was snagged today when a defense attorney was taken to a hospital with a heart ailment and a juror excused for illness.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Administration tried but failed today to stop the House from passing a bill to set up a "code of conduct" for Government advisory committees.

Dick Mayer and his wife, Doris, had little time to stroll through Central Park and enjoy many leisure moments during their latest visit to New York. Ever since Dick won the United States open at Toledo on June 16, the Mayers have had a very busy off-the-golf-course schedule.
GLEN COVE, L.I., July 10--A former major in the air force scored by far the most notable tennis victory of his career today at the age of 37.

PUGWASH, N. S., July 10--Leading scientists from the Communist and non-Communist countries debated today how much they should tell the world about their conclusions on the outlook for civilization and survival of humanity in this nuclear age.
American Telephone and Telegraph Company noted "no let-up in activity in the telephone business" through the first half, according to the quarterly report released yesterday.

J. B. Priestley's "Ever Since Paradise," which was written in 1939 and largely rewritten after the war, will have its New York premiere at the Carnegie Recital Hall at 7:45 o'clock tonight. The playhouse is at 154 West Fiftyseventh Street.
THE annual Photographers' Night took place at Lewisohn Stadium last night, and flashbulbs were popping even before the concert began.
A twelve-acre tract in Babylon, L.I., had been purchased by the Universal Stamping Company, which plans two buildings for its own occupancy.
More than 5,000 gallons of hot asphalt spilled yesterday from an overturned tank truck and turned a Queens intersection into a quagmire.
LONDON, July 10--Peter Thorneycroft, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, described inflation today as the most intractable and difficult problem faced by Britain.
Workers in the financial district turned out by the thousands yesterday to hear the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham denounce sin.
WASHINGTON, July 10--An Arizona cotton producer will receive $209,701 from the Federal soil bank this year for not growing cotton.
Newly converted trailer ships, equipped with self-contained loading equiument, will start operating next month in coastal service for the Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The House Rules Committee bottled up today a bill to bar trials in foreign courts for United States servicemen accused of crimes committed abroad.
The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday an increase in net assets on June 30 over both the preceding quarter and the like 1956 date.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture said today crop output this year seemed likely to be the smallest since 1951.
CHICAGO, July 10--Cautious optimism that the spreading strike of the nation's cement workers would be halted and that vital construction could be resumed was voiced here today.

WASHINGTON, July 10--Pakistan's jovial Prime Minister, Hussein Shaheed Suhrawardy, got a warm welcome today from President Eisenhower, Vice President Nixon, Secretary of State Dulles, the diplomatic corps-- and a large group of photographers.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The absolute margin of the United States economy over that of the Soviet Union is still widening, a report to Congress said today.

The late Chief Justice Arthur T. Vanderbilt of New Jersey was cited to court reformers in New York yesterday as an example of courage and persistence in the face of early reverses in efforts to modernize the state's court system.

The $132,000,000 George Washington Bridge improvement was authorized yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, July 11-- Prime Minister Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy of Pakistan told Congress today that "peace is safe" in American hands.

WASHINGTON, July 11--A Federal judge ordered a mistrial today in the bribery-conspiracy case against Hyman I. Fischbach, Miami lawyer, because of the sudden illness of his counsel, Daniel P. Maher. He will be tried later.
WASHINGTON, July 11--For the first time in history, a President of the United States will fly in a helicopter tomorrow.

LONDON, July 11--The United States asked the Soviet Union today to choose between the American proposal for suspension of nuclear weapons tests for a short period, preferably ten months, and continuation of these tests.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 11--Syrian troops opened fire on an Israeli settlement early this morning as the uneasy quiet along this border was again broken.
WASHINGTON, July 11--A United States District Court Judge today acquitted Seymour Peck, an employe of The New York Times, of contempt of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The dwindling Hudson River ferry service moved closer to extinction today. The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Erie Railroad to dis- continue its line between Jersey City and Chambers Street in Manhattan, effective Aug. 15.
Pension and profit-sharing funds that have lent money back to their donor companies are being given more favorable tax consideration.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)-- The Army ordered today the release from prison of a British woman serving a life sentence for the murder of three of her children. The incidents took place while she was overseas with her husband, a United States soldier.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 11--Don Hoenig and Bob Grant, Connecticut golfers, teamed to lead the qualifiers in the John G. Anderson Memorial tourney today. Playing on the West course of the Winged Foot Club, they combined for a best-ball score of 65, six under par.
Mark Twain's "The Prince and the Pauper" will be the second "Du Pont Show of the Month" next season on Columbia Broadcasting System television.

When you hear the three-minute warbling sound of the air-raid sirens today it means take shelter. This is part of the fourth annual national exercise in meeting problems of a nuclear attack. It is Operation Alert--1957.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 11 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hunter Tuthill of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joyce Tuthill, to Howard Davidson Noble Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Noble of Garden City, L.I.
WASHINGTON, July 11--The Air Force is abandoning the Navaho intercontinental guided missile after having spent about $500,000,000 on its development.
CHICAGO, July 11--Wheat futures declined on the Board of Trade today, largely as a reaction to the Government crop estimate issued after the close yesterday.
PARIS, July 11--The French Government faced mounting opposition today to its request for special police powers to deal with agents of the Algerian rebellion in France.

Stocks rode a roller coaster yesterday. Prices opened up in fairly active trading, then fell and rallied in the afternoon, only to ease again. The market closed irregularly off for the day with volume quite heavy. Earlier, The New York Times combined average hit a new 1957 high.
TRENTON, July 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner denied today that any official of his admiaistration was guilty of wrongdoing in the state's investigation of the Loyalty Insurance Group.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- John B. Hollister resigned today as director of the International Cooperation Administration. High officials said no successor had been picked.

TURKU, Finland, July 11 (UP) --Three Finnish runners, speed ing over the same track on which Australia's John Landy set the world mile record of 3 minutes 58 seconds, all smashed the world mark for 1,500 meters today. Olavi Salsola was the photo-finish winner in 3:40.2.

KITCHENER, Ont., July 11 (AP)--The scramble for the top spot in the $25,000. Canadian open golf tournament became wide open today as three players--Henry Ransom, Doug Ford and Fred Hawkins--shared the halfway lead with six-under-par 136's.

Samuel Reshevsky, international grandmaster, at chess, last night defeated Arthur B. Bisguier, United States champion, in twenty-nine moves in the second game of their ten-game match at the Manhattan Chess Club.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 11-- J. Francis Gallagher of 840 Flora Avenue, principal of Alexander Hamilton Junior High School here since 1936, died last night of a heart ailment at the Alexian Brothers Hospital. His age was 56.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 Henry Cabot Lodges, United States Ambassador to the United Nations, hailed the Boy Scout movement tonight as an eloquent example to the world of what can be accomplished by free men in a free society.
