A leader in President Eisenhower's people-to-peple program asserted yesterday that "recently the voice of Communistic propaganda has become somewhat shaken and confused."

SOMETIMES a teen-age girl can see a truth that the experts miss or--in their concentration on an immediate problem--have temporarily lost sight of. It happened that way some years ago with one 16year-old and a life-time interest in child welfare work resulted.

Rejecting the appeal of Army Specialist Girard, the center of an international storm raised by a tragedy resulting from an accident or a bit of juvenile horseplay that endangered our whole alliance system and free world security, the Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that

More than 400 married students were unable to enroll for courses at Columbia University in this last school year for want of housing accommodations, the university disclosed yesterday in a petition filed in Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, July 11--Meat packers' earnings in 1956 improved over 1955 but were still well below those reported by other food processing and manufacturing industries, the American Meat Institute said today. In 1956, the meat packing industry produced more meat than ever before, it added.

WHEN Frank Malzone was graduated from Samuel Gompers High in the Bronx, his vocational training had been along electrical lines. So he and a friend applied to Consolidated Edison for jobs as electricians. But before Malzone could replace a fuse, he received a train ticket from the Boston Red Sox to their minor league base in Florida. The Bosox rather than Con Ed have controlled his destinies ever since.
One of the city's largest housing projects is scheduled to rise on fifty-nine acres in Coney Island. Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa approved the project yesterday.
LONDON July 11--The Government rejected today a demand from a Labor member of the House of Commons for the appointment of a Royal Commission to inquire into inflation and the cost of living.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined $103,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $154,000,000 in the like week last year.

Althea Gibson, who took her first tennis lessons on the streets of Harlem and went on to show the world at Wimbledon how good her teaching had been, rode up Broadway yesterday to City Hall in one of our city's traditional welcomes. It has been a generation and more since, as Grover Whalen wrote in his auto
EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 11--Arthur A. Blaicher, New York investment broker, died last night of a heart ailment in East Orange General Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 233 Prospect Street.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP)-- The Federal Trade Commission today charged the Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical company, with violating the antimerger law by acquiring the Visking Corporation, one of its major customers.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 11-- Members of the Standardbred Owners Association pressed a three-point demand today on Roosevelt Raceway. The track is scheduled to open its new $9,500,000 harness plant here on Aug. 1.

World sugar futures declined yesterday for the third consecutive day on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume was the largest since May 16. Prices fell 2 to 18 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 75,700 tons.
TAIPEI, Taiwan July 11--A 20,000-word report issued here today for students in Taiwan (Formosa) and the mainland said the time had come for open revolt against the Chinese Communist Government.
An explosion and fire yesterday in a twenty-seven-story building off Wall Street killed one person, injured three and trapped fourteen in stalled elevators.
WASHINGTON, July 11-- The defense department said today that it had in no way changed its attitude toward the necessity of a strong merchant marine.
Councilman Jeremiah B. Bloom, Democrat of Brooklyn, is under city inquiry for possible violation of conflict-of-interest provisions of the City Charter.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 11--President Tito's hopeful assumptions about the dawning of a new day in Moscow got a rude jolt today.
The magazine field provided the lion's share of news for advertising people yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 11--The Government's anti-inflation strategy of credit restraint was attacked at two Senate hearings today as a harmful failure.
Robert K. Christenberry, Republican candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that "Liberal party bosses" had endorsed top Democratic candidates in a "deal" with Tammany Hall.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11-- Herbert Hoover warned today that Congress "has lost control of the purse." He said this control had been "the first protection of fundamental liberty" since the signing of the Magna Charts in 1215.

WASHINGTON, JuLy 11 (AP)-- Following are the texts of the Supreme court's opinion today in the case of Specialist 3/c William S. Girard and of an affidavit on the case submitted by Robert Dechert, Defense Department general counsel.

In the seventh inning of last night's game between the Cincinnati Redlegs and the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field, Raul Sanchez, a right-handed pitcher, knocked Jim Gilliam, the Brooklyn second baseman, down with a head high pitch.
TOKYO, July 11--Plans for the trial of Specialist Girard are to be made in the Maebashi district court. There are no juries in Japan.

That time capsule has been found. For almost a week, workmen tearing down the United States Trust Company's old building at 45 Wall Street had been searching for a box of memorabilia placed somewhere in the building's thick walls on June 27, 1888. Yesterday the trust company ...
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 11--Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that he considered President Eisenhower a man of "talent and great principles," but one who "talks stupidities."

The Aga Khan was such a colorful character all his long life that his virtues were generally overlooked. Americans will doubtless be thinking especially today of his four marriages, his love of good living, his wonderful stable of horses, his great wealth, his status as father of Aly Khan and other much publicized
New York paid official tribute to Althea Gibson yesterday for her victory at Wimbledon, England, in the women's tennis championship.

Over a full racing campaign, Favorites win 30 per cent of the races. Yesterday was not a favorites' day at Belmont Park. It wasn't till the last of the eight events that one of the people's choices made the grade.

In every sense, Johnny Antonelli and Valmy Thomas formed a winning battery for the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds, where Johnny pitched and Valmy slugged the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals into a 1--0 setback. While the southpaw ace

The composer last night at Lewisohn Stadium was Brahms; the conductor was Alexander Smallens; the soloist was Isaae Stern; the orahestra was the Stadium Symphony. It was a pleasant evening, a fine program, and about 9,000 people turned out to hear the music.
Civil defense organizations and Government departments completed yesterday preparatory phases of the nation-wide civil defense training exercise that will be held today.
PARIS, July 11--French security forces arrested tonight a Tunisian political leader carrying messages from Premier Habib Bourguiba to his Ambassador here, Mohammed Masmoudi.

CHOICE at meat counters now is confined in most cases to beef and veal. Pork, as usual in summer, has risen sharply in cost as supplies decline Roast loin of pork is up 4 cents this week to 69 a pound and center cut pork chops have increased

HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., July 11--Yesterday was D-Day for Mickey Altenkirch. Mickey, the proprietor of the famous dock here, went in quest of swordfish. With him, as usual, was his sister Miriam. Both have been angling since their grammar school days.
LONDON, July 11--With investors showing hesitancy, only selected high-class industrial ordinary shares were in demand on the stock market today.
Nikita S. Khrushchev appears from latest Moscow reports to have devised a Communist-style purgatory in which the fate of his opponents will depend upon their good conduct.
TUNIS, Tunisia, July 11--The world's non-Communist trade unions began a campaign today to bar Hungary from the United Nations and all its specialized agencies.

CLEVELAND, July 11 (UP) The Baltimore Orioles entered the first division tonight by sweeping a double-header from the Cleveland Indians. Both contests were decided by 5-4, the first game going eleven innings.
MOSCOW, July 11--People of Moscow showed great interest tonight in the fate of their deposed leaders.

An application has been filed by Farrell Lines, Inc., for a twenty-year contract, involving an operating differential subsidy, Ben H. Guill, vice chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, said yesterday. This would replace a twelve-year agreement expiring Dec. 31, 1959.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (AP)--The American Newspaper Guild demanded today that John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, rescind the State Department ban against United States newsmen traveling in Red China.
Leaders of the Liberal party of New York County yesterday endorsed all Democratic judicial candidates in next fall's election.
"Simply Heavenly," whose successful off-Broadway run was abruptly halted by the Fire Department last week, will reopen on Aug. 20 at a Broadway theatre--the Playhouse on West Forty-eighth Street.
An increasing tendency of some judges to punish parents for the crimes of their children was criticized yesterday by the District Attorney of Los Angeles County.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 11-- A Federal prosecuting attorney used a scissors in court today to snip off parts of a confidential report of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
WASHINGTON, July 11-The Government reported today a June employment record of 66,500,000.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP)-- The Air Force announced today it Planned to launch a rocket from a balloon sky-platform in an attempt to send a missile thousands of miles higher than any rocket yet fired.

The Alice in Wonderland tone about recent news from Moscow is heightened rather than diminished by the latest news about Georgi M. Malenkov. Radio Moscow's foreign broadcasts say that he has been named head of one of the major post-war Soviet hydroelectric sta

LONDON, July 11 (AP)--Vivien Leigh, stage and screen actress, was led out of the House of Lords tonight for having shouted from the gallery. She said she had been provoked by a slighting remark on British artistry.
DID you ever hear an essay talking?
Mrs. Ruth Hirsch Brall, sculptor, died yesterday of cancer in her home, 45 Park Terrace West. Her age was 55. She was the wife of Joshua Brall.

PUGWASH, N.S., July 11-- Twenty Russian, Chinese, Japanese and Western scientists joined today in a warning to the governments of the world that misuse of nuclear energy could lead to the annihilation of mankind.

PUGWASH, N.S., July 11 -- Three of the Soviet Union's top scientists left here this morning pleased with their experience at the conference here. They were especially gratified that other world scientists thought as they did about the dangers of nuclear warfare.
WASHINGTON, July 11--The Supreme Court upheld unanimously today the decision of the United States Government 10 surrender Specialist 3/c William S. Girard for trial by a Japanese court.

New York City's fifth borough--Richmond--could have used a champion yesterday at a special meeting of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Stockholders from the floor demanded to ... know what gain the bank could expect from acquiring five branches in Staten Island.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 1l --Richard Strauss' "Elektra" is more than an opera. It is a cataclysm of passion. Onlythe great opera houses have the resources to perform it with the savage intensity it requires. But the Empire State Music Festival had the au
The supply of cement for the city's $400,000,000-a-year building industry reached the vanishing point yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) --A House Ways and Means subcommittee overrode Administration opposition today and approved a bill to cut the 20 per cent Federal sales tax on night
TOKYO, July 11--The Japanese began examining today the new Cabinet that Premier Nobusuke Kishi presented to them last night. No one seemed too pleased.
KANSAS CITY, July 11--The Athletics struggled for eleven innings tonight in a valiant effort to gain their first victory of the year over Casey Stengel's Yankees. But it still was no go.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)-- True D. Morse, Under Secretary of Agriculture, announced today that Government and private credit agencies had reached a voluntary agreement to tighten credit on expansion of the nation's poultry industry.
HONG KONG, July 12--A top Communist spokesman has made a sweeping denunciation of "bourgeois Rightists" in Communist China.
LONDON, July 12--Archaeologists at the British Museum believe that the grave of an ancient British warrior has been unearthed at Hertford Heath, Hertfordshire.
THE cruelest part of a bullfight is the crowd. Many persons sitting safely above the ring have come to see animals die. Some have come to see men tossed, gored, perhaps killed.

In May of 1846 the New York State Legislature incorporated the Prison Association of New York as a private agency dedicated to "the amelioration of the condition of prisoners" and "the improvement of prison discipline and government."

GENEVA, July 12--A 20-yearold Harvard student, grandson of the late Aga Khan and son of Prince Aly Khan, was announced tonight as the new religious leader and temporal guide of Moslems of the Ismaili sect.
TOKYO, July 12--The decision of the United States Supreme Court in the Girard case was received in Japan today with two emotions. The Japanese were satisfied; most Amer icans were relieved.

S. BROWN, director of the Australian News and Infor mation Bureau here, takes exception to a remark of Otto Bismarck, chef for the United States Line, quoted here recently. Mr. Bismarck said that he ...

SAN FRANCISCO July 12-- A Canadian-United States project to import natural gas into California from Alberta through a 1,300-mile, $330,000,000 pipeline system was announced here today by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 12 (AP)--The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court today upheld a ruling that a stockholders' suit to halt the acquisition of the Spokane International Railroad by the Union Pacific Railroad was a proper one to be tried.

Attorneys representing James D. Norris Jr., Arthur M. Wirtz, the Madison Square Garden Corporation, the International Boxing Club of New York and the International Boxing Club of Illinois yesterday filed a motion for a new trial for their clients in the United States District Court.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 12-- Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the Shah of Iran, arrived by air tonight from France to supervise relief operations in the Caspian area, where at least 1,000 of his subjects perished in earthquakes July 1.
Ice conditions in the North Atlantic are the worst in decades end constitute a definite threat to traps-Atlantic shipping.
Only twenty-five New York teachers have volunteered to serve in the city's so-called difficult schools. Between 1,000 and 1,200 are needed.

The epidemic of knockdown pitches spread to the Polo Grounds last night. However, because of prompt and effective action by Umpire Tom Gorman, there were no fights and the St. Louis Cardinals, with Sam Jones hurling a two-hitter, went on to down the Giants, 5-1.
LONDON, July. 12--Heavy selling before the Chancellor of the Exchequer's speech lowered stock market prices further today. Dollar stocks were the only firm group.

WHITE PLAINS, July 12-- Truman S. Mersereau, former first vice president and general manager of the Butterick Publishing Company of New York, fashions publishers and makers of patterns, died of a heart ailment in St. Agnes Hospital here.

LONDON, July 12 (Reuters) --Twenty-six American passengers from the liner Reina del Pacifico, the 17,827-ton British luxury liner that was grounded off the Bermuda coast, arrived here by plane today from Bermuda.
For eight minutes in New York and other northeastern states time stopped at 1:47 o' clock yesterday afternoon.
TUNIS, Tunisia, July 12--The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions successfully avoided today a split over the controversial issue of Algerian independence.

MOSCOW, July 12--Soviet scientists contend that one of their radio balloons, sent to explore the upper strata of the atmosphere, has reached a "record" height of 35,000 meters (21.75 miles) above sea level.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- President Eisenhower has asked Federal agencies to hold their spending and contract signing this year, where possible, to the levels of the fiscal year just ended.
Securities underwriters and investors all over the country continue to be faced with a sizable volume of new financing in the capital market.

World sugar futures recovered on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday after three consecutive days of declines. Final quotations were unchanged to 36 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) up on 35,450 tons.
A five-story apartment house, containing forty-three suites, at 525 East Eighty-first Street has been sold by the Peezee Realty Corporation, represented by Morton Leavy.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 12-- Phil Klausner of Elizabeth, N.J., got a thrill today that comes only once in a lifetime. He caught his first fish. It was an experience that had him walking on air.
Councilman Jeremiah B. Bloom was cleared yesterday of any possible violation of conflict-ofinterest provisions of the City Charter.
WASHINGTON, July 12--Senate racket hunters have arranged a new series of hearings next week, including a look at the affairs of United Textile Workers.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 12-- Herbert Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., second-ranking player of the country, and Don Fontana of the Canadian Davis Cup team reached the semi-finals of the invitation tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa. July 12 --The raising of the Stars and Stripes opened the fourth National Jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America at 9 A.M. today. The signal for the ceremony was the bursting of a bomb in the air.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP) --Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles late today capitulated in his cross-country row with Promoter Jack Kramer.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., July 12 (AP)--Donald Campbell hit 200 miles an hour early today in his jet speed boat, Bluebird II, and was on the dock waiting when the refueling boat came in from the far end of the course.
Police Commissioner Kennedy has determined that the policeman in the ranks today shall have educational and training opportunities that did not exist when Mr. Kennedy himself was a patrolman.
WASHINGTON, July 12--The Government issued today a new and sobering handbook of the atomic age--a lengthy, detailed publication describing the devastating effects of nuclear bombs.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 --Tempers are rising here along with the temperature.
Five musical artists will be making their Lewisohn Stadium debuts during the five concerts starting Monday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) --Home runs by Chicago's Jerry Kindall and Ernie Banks snapped the Phillies' winning streak at five games as the Cubs scored a 5-2 victory at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.

WARSAW, July 12 (Reuters) --A Roman Catholic delegate to the Polish Parliament charged today that the Communist Government had discriminated against Catholic activities and censored the statements of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski.
Shell bursts over the island of Quemoy have emphasized recently that a new phase of activity has opened along the "invasion coast" of the Chinese mainland opposite Taiwan (Formosa).
WASHINGTON, July 12-- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, completed his testimony before the Senate Finance Committee today after being on the stand fourteen days over a four-week period.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 12--Winfred B. Holton Jr. of 98 Rockledge Drive, who retired recently as board chairman of the Walworth Company, valve and pipe fitting manufacturers, died today in New Rochelle Hospital after a long illness. His age was 68.

A pre-rush-hour fire interrupted through northbound service on the White Plains Road and Dyre Avenue lines of the IRT subway yesterday afternoon for an hour and half. About sixty thousand riders were affected.
VIENNA, July 12 (AP)--Stanislav Jungwirth of Czechoslovakia today smashed the world record for the 1,500-meter run. Jungwirth's time was 3 minutes 38.1 seconds.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12--In a remote stretch of Egyptian desert, resourceful Finnish soldiers have built two "saunas," or steam baths, Finnish style.
ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP)--The American Newspaper Guild today raised its minimum wage goal for experienced newsmen to $200 a week.
Nuclear scientists describe the sodium graphite reactor as "a good reactor."
The Board of Education has been forced to turn away between 2,000 and 3,000 students seeking admission to summer high schools.
KANSAS CITY, July 12--The Athletics, with five former Yankees in their battlefront tonight, still found the task of beating the Bombers too confusing for them.
WASHINGTON, July 12--The Southern opposition staged a tactical retreat today as the Senate unanimously agreed to vote next Tuesday on a motion to call up the Administration's civil rights bill.
Nikita S. Khrushchev has obviously been having a good time in Czechoslovakia. Cheering crowds have greeted him. He has had an opportunity to pontificate on a wide series of topics.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- President Eisenhower signed the omnibus housing bill today. But he issued a statement criticizing four phases of the bill.
GENEVA, July 12--A Soviet scientist say she has isolated a new and fourth type of poliomyelitis virus.
The Kings County Republican executive committee and the Liberal party of the Bronx yesterday announced the completion of their designations for the fall election.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 12 (UP)--The International Olympic Committee president, Avery Brundage, warned today that a United States ban on his travel to Iron Curtain countries and refusal to permit their athletes to come here could prevent America from staging the Olympic winter competition.

It is just about a month since the three-man military junta headed by Brigs Gen. Antonio Kebreau took over in Haiti and proclaimed a state of emergency. There has been internal peace after the months of strife and chaos that followed the overthrow of President Paul Magloire on Dec. 12.

CHICAGO, July 12--Dr. Louis E. Schmidt, Chicago virologist and an early leader in the drive against venereal disease, died today in a hospital in Wausau, Wis., where he had lived since 1949. He was 88 years old.
PARIS, July 12--During most of our history, when not devoted solely to Pan-American affairs, United States foreign policy has been concerned primarily with Europe. The reasons are apparent.

BONN Germany, July 12-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer as serted today that the central issue of the September national elections was continued freedom or a slow surrender to communism by the German people.
JERSEY CITY, July 12--Big Don Newcombe tonight pitched the Dodgers into fourth place in the National League race. He got a lot of help from Gino Cimoli and Gil Hodges.
New York's sagging population, as revealed by this year's special census, has touched off a storm of controversy.

The Freeport Sulphur Company has just received Government permission to mine sulphur in the Grand Isle area, six miles off the coast of Louisiana. It will be the first completely offshore sulphur mining operation in the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12-- Editors of American daily newspapers today declared it to be the right of citizens to "gather information at home or abroad, except where military necessity plainly prevents."
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP)--Soybeans futures spurted almost the daily 10-cent limit in active buying on the Board of Trade today, carrying grains upward slightly at times.
LONDON, July 12--The British Foreign Office denied today that Jawaharlal Nehru of India acted officially in his efforts to mend relations between Britain and Egypt.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 12-- William B. Pollard, president of the National Bank of Commerce since 1948, died yesterday, in Baptist Hospital. His age was 61. He suffered heart attacks Monday and Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 12--Secretary of State Dulles will meet informally with Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada in Ottawa July 28.
Agents of the Federal Trade Commission are watching television at all hours to detect false advertising of foods, drugs and cosmetics. This was reported yesterday by Charles A. Sweeny, ...
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 12 --The Federal Government presented evidence today in support of the crucial conspiracy phase of its criminal contempt case against sixteen segregationists.
The iron workers, one of two striking unions in the building industry, reached agreement on a contract yesterday.
CHICAGO, July--12 (AP)--Hog prices ended the week on a slightly higher note today by reaching a top of $21.65, the highest here since June 21, 1955.
The labor relations section of the American Bar Association asked Congress yesterday to enact legislation to end grit and corruption in health, welfare and pension funds.
ABOARD U.S.S. FORRESTAL, West of Mallorca, July 12--The man who may one day be Sultan of Morocco saw and heard the might of the United States Navy in action in the Mediterranean today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday tumbled 26 to 67 points ($1.30 to $3.35 a bale). The largest decline was in the old July option, in which trading will expire at noon Monday.
HONG KONG, July 12 (UP) A young American business mana said today that his trip to Communist China to satisfy his curiosity" had not been worth the trouble.
SEATTLE, July 12--Dave Beck and his son, Dave Jr., were indicted today on grand larceny charges. They were accused of selling Cadillacs owned by the Teamsters Union and pocketing the money.
For thirty-five years Mercer Beasley has been coaching tennis players and he has been called the Alonzo Stagg of the court game.
PARIS, July 12--France charged a Tunisian lawyer and political leader today with endangering the security of the state in attempting to pass a message to an imprisoned Algerian rebel leader.
LONDON, July 12--Mr. Thorneycroft urged his fellow Britons today to work harder and more effectively to combat inflation.
The stock market suspended trading for half an hour yesterday during the nation-wide air raid drill. Apparently it was a pause that refreshed.

A team of four New York collegians made an unpropitious start against a quartet representing Czechoslovakia in the first round of the fourth international students chess tournament in Reykjavik yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 12--Tim Holland, the Long Island amateur champion, and his partner, John Humm of Rockville, eliminated the defenders, Bob Wilke and Larry Bell of Allentown, Pa., in the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament today, 3 and 2.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The Public Health Service took the official position today that there was "increasing and consistent evidence" that "excessive cigarette smoking is one of the causative factors of lung cancer."

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP)-- Following are the texts of a statement by Leroy E. Burney, the Surgeon General, on the effects of excessive cigarette smoking on health, and of a statement in reply by Dr. Clarence Cook Little, chairman of the Scientific Advisory Board to the Tobacco Industry Research Committee:
IT has been said that a Harvard man may aspire to anything. Yesterday, one of them succeeded to the titles and perquisites of the late Aga Khan.
Summer vacations are in full swing. And so are sales of suntan lotion.
The civil defense test yesterday was 60 to 90 per cent effective in the suburban areas, authorities reported.

A moderately priced weather forecasting device has made at possible for business men to learn more of what the weather is fixing to do before it does it. Knowing the outlook earlier and with greater accuracy is of important dollar advantage to business and industry.

Members of the American Bar Association, which is holding its annual convention here, will be welcomed tomorrow at special services at St. Patrick's Cathedral and New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
Preliminary results of the city's special census indicated yesterday that the population had dropped by 120,448 persons since 1950.
Tokyo's claim to being the world's most populous city, eclipsing New York by several hundred thousand, becomes more solid every day.
Bernard Berk, senior partner in the brokerage firm at 72 Wall Street bearing his name, and three accountants pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to charges of stock manipulation.

Canada's expanding economy has taken an unexpected spurt. The Canadian Press reports that the Canadian Government has raised its first-of-the-year forecast of expenditures for new construction, machinery and, equipment.
A bank and a longshore union local that joined three months ago to campaign against waterfront loan sharks said yesterday that the venture had passed the "experimental" stage.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 12 (AP)--Mrs. Jan Burke's Dedicate, with Eddie Arcaro replacing Bill Boland in the saddle, takes on eight rivals, including two who have beaten him this season, in the $113,500 Monmouth Handicap tomorrow. The winner will ...

WASHINGTON, July 12-- Two Philadelphia engineers have invented a telephone that a skindiver can strap on his back. It is, they believe, the first practical instrument to carry the voice for a considerable distance through water.
BUENOS AIRES, July 11-- Argentine politicians are vitally interested in a startlingly new type of campaign being waged by the youngest party on the nation's political scene.

As summer vacation driving increases in tempo the Automobile Club of New York reminds auto owners that a car is no safer than its brakes, and one crucial key to safety is the use of proper brake fluid.
An unusual concept in industrial advertising--a newspaper on chemical advances--made its appearance in paid business publication space just twenty-five years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, told Congress today, in effect, that it should not expect him to ignore Federal water law.

MOSCOW, July 12--The Government newspaper Izvestia suggested today that the ouster of Vyacheslav M. Molotov from Soviet ruling circles might open the way to improvement of relations between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia.
The clock of animal history has been turned back more than 1,000 years by the American Museum of Natural History in an exhibit that it put on display yesterday.
A robber who was not too grasping got away with $1,583 from a Broadway savings and loan office yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 12--The wholesale price index of primary market prices advanced 0.3 to 117.8 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics repbrted today. All commodity groupings registered higher average prices.
BERLIN, July 12--Three Protestant church workers are reported under arrest in East Germany for having helped needy children to go to West Germany for vacations with relatives there.

When the long rise and fall of the siren broke through yesterday's usual din the coursing bloodstream of this city came slowly to a halt. It seemed as if the life of the megalopolis was ebbing away in full daylight.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) agreed yesterday to make four loans to India totaling $90,000,000 for modernizing and developing, her railways.

Solomon Brandstein has purchased for investment the apartment house for thirty-two families at 1268-70 Grant Avenue, the Bronx. The building, on a plot 75 by 100 feet, was sold by the Lilike Realty Corporation. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
Chain store sales in June were 3.1 per cent higher than in the similar month of 1956, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 12--Judy Frank of Old Oaks and Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley won the penultimate matches in the twenty-eighth New York State women's golf championship at Briar Hall today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 12--Nikita S. Khrushchev's three days of speech-making around Czechoslovakia have made clear that no changes in Soviet foreign policy are to be expected as an immediate aftermath of the Kremlin shake-up.

Seven radio engineers who have been holed up on Madison Avenue for the last two weeks started home yesterday. But their self-imposed durance was extended when the civil defense alert sounded as they headed for the street.

In the Saranac Handicap at Belmont Park last Saturday it didn't count when Joe W. Brown's Tenacious finished first. He had dumped his rider in a stumble at the start. Yesterday in Belmont's top race he did no stumbling and he did no jockeydumping. So, when he finished ...

CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP)-- President Warren C. Giles of the National League today fined two Cincinnati Redleg and two Brooklyn Dodger players $100 each for last night's brawl at Ebbets Field. He said he would not tolerate fighting on the baseball diamond.
CLEVELAND, July 12 (UP)-- Harold Gomes of Providence punched his way to a sixthround technical knockout over Lulu Perez of Brooklyn tonight in their televised fight scheduled for ten rounds.
A great city lay virtually still for about eight minutes yesterday as New York took part in the nation-wide civil defense test.

HAVANA, July 12--A rally of the Union Radical party is scheduled for Sunday at Chivirico, in the Sierra Maestra, not far from where Fidel Castro, rebel leader, and his men are reported to be holed up.
YONKERS, July 12--Public school teachers here will get salary increases ranging from $200 to $300 a year, beginning next Jan. 1.

The Rev. Michael A. Clark, spiritual director of the Community at St. Ignatius Loyola Residence, Park Avenue and Eighty-third Street, died Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. His age was 75.
LONDON, July 12--The Soviet Union offered today to negotiate its differences with the United States on the duration of a temporary suspension of nuclear tests.
TOKYO, July 12--Premier Nobusuke Kishi and his new Cabinet met today in their first business session since the Cabinet took office Wednesday night.

EMERGENCY WHITE HOUSE, July 12--President Eisenhower flew by helicopter today from the lawn of the White House to a secret mountain-top relocation center. His flight preceded a mock nuclear bombing attack on Washington.

After nearly four months of renewed attempts to break the elevenyear-old disarmament deadlock the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee is approaching a showdown on whether it is possible to take even a first step toward an initial and experimental armament reduction and control system at this time.

ASCOT, England, July 20 (AP) --French-bred Montaval, owned by Ralph Strassburger, a Pennsylvania publisher, made a thrilling stretch run today to win the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 20 (UP)--Louise Suggs of Sea Island, Ga., and Mickey Wright of San Diego today shot a sparkling 69 to take the 54-hole lead in the 72-hole, $7,500 Hot Springs four-ball women's golf tournament with a score of 210.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 20 --In the First Church, Congregational, here this afternoon, Miss Diana M. Biggar was married to Alexander Halliday Neiley. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond Calkins. He was assisted by the Rev. George S. Cooke.

A victory against Finland, 3 to 0, with one game adjourned, rewarded the efforts of the United States college, chess players in the eighth round of the world students' championship tournament in Reykjavik, according to a report received yesterday through Icelandic news sources.

Builders, like producers of most consumer goods, find it difficult to appeal to the tastes of all potential buyers. One developer on Long Island, however, has just completed construction of a model house that reflects preferences expressed by 1,617 families who had seen his earlier models.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 20--The assignment of Col. William H. Allen Jr. as commandant of Cornell University's Army Reserve Officer Training Corps has been announced.

Only the villagers and townspeople along the busiest stretch of the St. Lawrence Seaway construction job feel the full impact of the colossal digging and building that has now passed its halfway mark.

ST. LOUIS, July 20--Construction of a 3,000-acre industrial district on the bottom lands at the junction of the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers eight miles north of downtown St. Louis, was proposed this week.
Miss Margot Blain Mann of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gurney Mann of Richmond, Ind., will be married Sept. 7 to John Edward Helms 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Helms Jr. of Morristown, Tenn.

After having been twelfth in the field of thirteen in the early yardage, Mrs. Hirsch Jacobs' 5-year-old mare Searching went around some of the opposition and then cut through a deep-inthe-stretch opening to win the $23,950 Distaff Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

GREAT changes are taking place in garden lilies. The annual show of the North American Lily Society, held earlier this month at Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y., brought together an amazing number of new types.

HAVANA, July 20--The resignation of President Fulgencio Batista and the establishment of a Provisional Government is demanded by Dr. Fidel Castro, rebel leader, from his stronghold in the Sierra Maestra range, according to a statement published here by the newspaper El Pais.

The engagement of Miss Barbara Ann Beirne Witzell to Yalcin Atatimur has been announced by her father, Paul J. Witzell. Mr. Atatimur is the son of Mme. Nefise Onen of Ankara, Turkey, and Hadi Atatimur, also of Ankara.

Pat Stewart of Indianapolis yesterday won the Rose Taubele memorial tournament at the New York Tennis Club. She defeated Carmen Lampe of Forest Hills, Queens, 7--5, 6--4. ATHENS, July 20 (AP)--The total tonnage of Greek-owned ships, including vessels now under construction, has reached 17,500,000 gross tons. They have an approximate carrying capacity of 26,500,000 tons, according to unofficial statistics.

OFFICERS of the newly formed New York Chapter of the Society of Photographic Scientists and Engineers were elected at the first meeting of the board of directors held last week.
WEST HAVEN, Conn., July 20--Frank Hovey Smith, a New Haven newspaper man for sixtyone years, died today at his home here. He was 76 years old.

CAIRO, July 20--A glistening new Shepheard's Hotel was officially opened today. Its owners expressed almost wistfully the hope that the romance and tradition of its once-proud predecessor soon would be revived.
Dr. Peng Chun Chang, former Chinese Nationalist delegate to the United Nations, died Friday of a heart ailment at his home in Nutley, N.J. His age was 65.
The Union Carbide and Carbon Company Fellowship at Columbia University for the 19571958 academic year has been awarded to Frank J. LoSacco of 2440 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx.
SAN JOSE, C.R., July 4--The Latin American Aerotechnical Service is preparing to move its base of operations here from the old La Sabana airfield to the new Coco International airport.
HONG KONG, July 20--Pham Van Dong, Premier of Communist North Vietnam, formally proposed today that North and South Vietnam hold talks to discuss elections for reunifying the country.

A GOOD many New Yorkers we know now start their dinner parties by offering the first course in the living room --a practice pleasing to all present. Beginning the meal away from the table, rather than at it, eliminates the exchange of plates between first and main dishes that can be a nuisance to a woman acting, as most do these days, the roles of hostess, cook and maid.
YONKERS, July 20 (UP)-- Meadow Mim, owned by the K K Stable of New York and driven by John Berry, scored an easy triumph in tonight's Mount Vernon Pace before 18,433 fans at Yonkers Raceway.
SHANNON AIRPORT, Ireland, July 20 (AP)--William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York City, arrived here today for the first look at the land of his birth in twenty-one years.

The third anniversary of the Geneva conference on Vietnam has been marked by a fresh proposal from Communist North Vietnam for a conference on unification.
The subject of exchange of persons between the United States and the Soviet Union is very much in the news these days.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) --The Detroit Boat Club won the national club crew championship for the second straight year on the Schuylkill today by taking three races to overcome the first-day lead held by the Vesper B.C. of Philadelphia.

Pancho Gonzales, the monarch of the tennis courts, added Lewis Hoad to his list of conquests yesterday to complete a sweep of his five matches in the professional round-robin tournament at Forest Hills.

One-way avenues discriminate against bus riders, John E. McCarthy, president of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., declared yesterday.

Tennesse Williams said yesterday that his next Broadway entry would be "Sweet Bird of Youth." Unless the recipient of two Pulitzer Prizes and three awards from the Critics Circle should change his mind, the poetic tragedy is to arrive here during the 1958-59 season.

KANSAS CITY, July 21 (UP) --Bob Cerv's two-run pinch homer in the seventh today enabled the Kansas City Athletics to post a 3-2 victory after the Baltimore Orioles won the opener, 7--2, behind Hector Brown.

TODAY we do not, like the ancient Greeks, compel crim inals to eat garlic to purify themselves of their crimes or, like the Romans, press the juice from artichoke hearts to use as a lotion for restoring the hair.

MONTREAL, July 21 (AP)-- Brazil ousted Canada from the North America zone play for the Davis Cup today. Carlos Fernandez whipped Don Fontana of Toronto, 6--3, 6--3, 10--8, to give his country its third victory in the best-of-five first round series.

ROME, July 21--Benito Mussolini's widow has published a new volume of memoirs in which she depicts the Italian dictator as a family man, a man with hypnotic eyes and a would-be editor in the United States.

TURIN, Italy, July 21--A United States Navy Neptune bomber, searching for a missing sister plane, hit a mountain today and burst into flames. Nine airmen were killed and a tenth was dragged from the wreckage suffering from severe burns.
WASHINGTON, July 21--Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, predicted today that the Senate would pass the Administration's civil rights bill without substantial change.

PARIS, July 21--The Paris address, 5 Rue Solferino, has a certain particular significance in France. Solferino Street is named for a battle won by Emperor Napoleon III. And No. 5 is headquarters for General Charles de Gaulle.
WASHINGTON, July 21--The Food and Drug Administration has begun a campaign against an increasing number of doorto-door salesmen who make false claims for products to combat malnutrition.
An addition to the growing unification of Western Europe is a passenger train service recently started under the name of Trans-Europe-Express (TEE).

Arthur B. Bisguier, the United States chess champion, recorded a gain yesterday in his tengame match with Samuel Reshevsky at the Manhattan Chess Club. His rival resigned without further play in the fourth game of the series, which had remained undecided after a five-hour session last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 21-- High officials here are giving serious consideration to two major developments in Western defense.
PATERSON, N.J., July 21-- These days there is more than the usual activity in the basement and backyard of 971 East Twenty-second Street here, where Philip J. Del Vecchio Sr. lives with his family.

ROME, July 21--Simonetta has put the waist back on the woman but her "Rondo" line still effectively obscures the other vital statistics. Her cocktail dresses have short, melon-shaped skirts with the fullness caught in under the hem. Suit skirts, allowed a fraction more length, are topped by jackets barely fitted in front with full bloused backs dipping over the hips.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- President Eisenhower starts the second six months of his second Administration this week confident that he is making progress on his three major problems: disarmament, equal voting rights and inflation.
For a long time Arthur Langton's most intimate experiences with ships were careful daydreams between tallying figures for the T.J. Stevenson Shipping Company of 80 Broad Street.

Buenos Aires, July 21--Argentina's state oil monopoly is facing a rebellion by the Governments of the oil-rich provinces. Two provincial governments have refused to sign contracts with the State Oilfields Department (YPF) for prospecting and exploitation rights.

In a move that could imperil the whole atoms-for-peace project, the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee has voted 14 to 2 to approve legislation forbidding the President to allocate atomic fuel to the International Atomic Energy Agency without specific approval by Congress.
THE Rev. Dr. Herman Suker Sidener has a church today, but no pulpit.

CLEVELAND, July 21--The Yankees were all set to wind up their Western tour with a grand flourish today. But at the last moment Casey Stengel's wires got crossed and the Bombers had to settle for a draw in a long and blistering hot double-header.
WARSAW, July 21 (Reuters) --The Communist party chief, Wladyslaw Gomulka pledged tonight that Poland would not return to the capitalist regime of the past.

The annual "Italian Night" program drew a near-capacity audience to Lewisohn Stadium Saturday night to hear Italian opera. The performers were Eileen Farrell and Beverly Sills, sopranos; Jan Peerce, tenor, and Richard Torigi, baritone.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20-- Bolivia, desperate for dollars, was reported today to be pressing Brazil to give up her rights in half of the huge oil-bearing tract where the two countries planned joint exploitation.

MELBOURNE, July 21 (Reuters)--Night watchmen, lighthouse keepers and airline pilots will work with professors and science teachers during the next eighteen months on an Australian team of observers for the International Geophysical Year.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 21--A rise in the Dutch bank rate last week to 4 per cent from 3 came not entirely as a surprise, because financial and monetary tensions had been increasing steadily.
BINGHAM, Neb., July 21 (AP) --A 17-year-old girl was pulled from the wreckage of a small plane today after she had spent forty hours pinned inside with the bodies of her parents and the pilot.
PARIS, July 21--France's foreign trade deficit in the first six months of this year amounted to 322,000,000,000 francs ($920,000,000). This was almost the 1956 figure.
WASHINGTON, July 21--Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended July 20:
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 21--Luther Beck's Happy Daze nipped Andrew Haire Jr.'s Intrepid by a quarter-length today in the Resolute Class race in the interclub regatta on Manhasset Bay.
A Presbyterian minister yesterday hailed the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham's New York Crusade as indicative of a great spiritual "rebirth" over the world.
MOSCOW, July 21--Pravda criticized a number of other Soviet journals today for not giving enough space to the ouster of three leaders from the party and Government hierarchy.
WASHINGTON, July 21--Senator George A. Smathers has called upon President Eisenhower to oppose a State Department plan to return enemy assets seized in this country during World-War II.

A bill described as "one of the most vital and far-reaching economy measures" ever proposed by the Hoover Commission will shortly come before the House, having just been cleared by the Rules Committee.
ZURICH, July 21--Volume on both the bond and stock markets was heavy all last week, but price fluctuations were at a minimum.

LITTLE VALLEY, Utah, July 21 (AP)--The biggest nonatomic explosion ever set off in the United States rocked this northern Utah peninsula in Great Salt Lake exactly as scheduled at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

Both West Germany and Austria have embarked on programs to develop a "people's capitalism" that would distribute ownership of the means of production among the broad masses as the better alternative to the state ownership advocated by communism and socialism.
