Grants totaling almost half a million dollars were announced yesterday by the Carnegie Corporation of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 --The sales department of Television Programs of America, Inc., will have greater influence on programming decisions as the result of a new pilot-film policy announced today by Milton A. Gordon, president.
The Rev. Raymond J. Baughan yesterday preached the first sermon of his new pastorate at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 (UP)-- Don Blasingame, who had only one hit in twenty times at bat going into today's play, drove in four runs to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-3 ten-inning victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in the first game of a double-header.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 21-- Bob Grossman of West Nyack, N.Y., drove a Jaguar XK140 to victory today in the twenty-lap feature race of the Long Island Sports Car Association meeting today. He averaged 69.3 m.p.h.

Milwaukee's Braves, protecting first place in the National League, came from behind and defeated the Giants, 7--4, in the second game of a double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The New Yorkers had taken the first game, 5--4, on Hank Sauer's pinch-hit single with two out and two aboard in the ninth inning.
VENICE, Italy, July 21--The opening here tonight of the second International Congress on the History of the Theatre was attended by 250 theatrical experts from sixteen countries.
RABAT, Morocco, July 21-- Adi Mohammed el-Amin, Bey of Tunis, appears destined to join the ranks of former monarchs this week.

OTHER countries' politics always seems a trifle peculiar, puzzling and irrational. Just pause to consider the politics of Indonesia, Haiti and France. But few countries today can boast of politics quite as baffling as Egypt's.

Sales and earnings of the H.J. Heinz Company in the fiscal year ended May 1 were the highest in its eighty-eight-year history, H.J. Heinz 2d, president, reported in the annual statement released today.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 --Two youths of the sponsoring club made successful defenses of championships during the Larchmont Race Week sailing today.
ATHENS, July 21 (Reuters) --To cater to the increasing numbers of tourists, the Greek Government is building new hotels and roads and improving archaeological sites.

The nation-wide shortage of social workers has reached large proportions. It is now predicted that by 1965 between 125,000 and 150,000 social workers will be needed to fill positions in public and voluntary agencies across the country.

A new project to discover and develop talented pupils will be started in Hartford, Conn., next fall. Sponsors will be the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students and local school officials.
A group of 140 young men from twenty countries arrived yesterday for a three-day visit as guests of the Civil Air Patrol. The youths are members of organizations equivalent...

A twelve-story apartment house for sixty-four families at 140 West Seventy-ninth Street has been sold by Samuel Fain and Joseph Klein. It was bought by J. Bimko for cash over mortgages amounting to $425,000.
OUENZA, Algeria, July 20-- This iron mining town near the Tunisian frontier has the look of a besieged camp.
The symbolism and significance of water to Roman Catholics was discussed yesterday by the Rev. Bernard McMahon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
BAHREIN, July 21 (Reuters) --Britain has agreed to help the Sultan of Oman and Muscat in his three-day-old battle with rebel tribesmen, an official British spokesman said here today.
WASHINGTON, July 21-- A Federal school aid bill that may touch off a fight over racial integration is scheduled for House debate this week.

LENOX, Mass., July 21--The extremes of the remark able career of Igor Stravinsky were highlighted at Tangle wood last night and this afternoon. Last night's program recalled with "Le Sacre du Printemps" the primeval violence the composer could summon forth from an orchestra forty-ifve years ago.
LENINGRAD, July 20--Each year at this time the Russians go through some capitalistic motions in a Romanesque palace built by the Communists amid Czarist shrines here.

Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, has sold the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Forty-first Street. The buyers were Max Cohen and associates, owners of the adjoining property containing the New Amsterdam Theatre and offices.
Despite credit restraint, small and medium-size banks still have funds to lend, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.
The Cubs and the Dodgers played until almost 9 o'clock last night at Ebbets Field and wound up with no profit, game-wise. The Bruins won the opener, 5--4, in 3 hours 34 minutes.
MOST townsfolk hurry by 110-112 East Fifty-ninth Street, east of Park Avenue, with no thought to its quaintness in the modern scheme of things.

RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 21 (UP)--Althea Gibson today became the first Negro to win a major tennis title in the United States. The New York girl repeated her Wimbledon conquest over Darlene Hard to capture the national clay courts women's singles crown. The scores were 6--2, 6--3.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 21 --Walter S. Gubelmann's seventy-one-foot yawl Windigo, A.E. (Bill) Luders Jr's thirty-ninefoot sloop Storm and Richard C. Vallentine's thirty-foot sloop Rinavall won the major trophies as the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual three-day cruise ended today. Storm was the only successful trophy defender.
The city roasted yesterday on the hottest day in nearly two years. The temperature hit 97.3 degrees at 3:25 P.M.
Individuals and businesses slowed down slightly in their use of checkbook money in June, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Republican leaders here scented political capital yesterday in the naming of a Tammany Hall publicity man to run interference for the goodwill endeavors of the Dominican Republic.
CARLISLE, Pa., July 21-- Robert Paul Masland, first vice president of C.H. Masland Sons, a carpet-manufacturing concern, died today at Carlisle Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 21-- Tim Holland of Rockville turned in a consistent brand of golf today as he retained the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship by defeating Mike Mattwell of St. George's.

CLEVELAND, July 21 (AP)-- The judge who presided at the trial of Dr. Samuel Sheppard issued a statement tonight saying he believed Ohio's Attorney General should deny any individual or group the privilege of acting as "a court of last resort" in Ohio.

KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., July 21--Kenneth Roberts, whose accuracy and colorful style gave the historical novel increased stature, died today at his home, Rocky Pastures. He was 71 year old. Death followed a coronary thrombosis that had confined him to his bed for several weeks.
LONDON, July 21--Armar E. Archbold, American yachtsman, died in West Highland Hospital, Oban, Scotland, today. He was 48 years old.

The two-story garage at 2080 Jerome Avenue at Burnside Avenue, the Bronx, was leased by Goldstein Brothers to Louis and Arthur Tamerlis. The lease is for fifteen years at an aggregate rental of $315,000. Samuel Bardfeld and Morris A. Kapplow were the brokers. The property is 150 by 100 feet.
ROME, July 21--Pope Pius XII granted a special audience today to the American comedian Red Skelton and his family.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 21--Lionel Hebert, the new Professional Golfers Association champion, is a kid brother who grew up. "He certainly is the big brother in the family now," proudly admitted his brother Jay, a former Long Island open champion, as crowds swarmed to congratulate the 29-year-old Lionel.

The freight rate index of the steamship charter market last week reached its lowest point since 1954 as coal, usually the market's bulwark, was smashed down to the lowest point in more than three and a half years.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 21--The younger of two golfing brothers became the National Professional Golfers Association champion today. Lionel Hebert, 29, who until this week had been generally overshadowed in the pro ranks by his 34-year-old brother, Jay, defeated 27-year-old Dow Finsterwald, a native of Athens Ohio by 2 and 1 in a scheduled thirty-six-hole final.
The Liberal party is battling to maintain its balance-of-power role in New York politics.
CHICAGO, July 21--Grains and soybeans generally moved upward last week. Oats were the only exception.

LONDON, July 21--The search by investors for protection against the effects of inflation reversed the pattern of business in the stock markets here last week. Government stocks, which a week ago had dropped to a record low, revived.
The American Civil Liberties Union called yesterday for a Congressional investigation of charges of brutality at the Marine Corps Recruit Training Depot at Parris Island, S.C.

In the case of the average Congressional investigation, it involves no great problem in self-restraint to refrain from comments that might be construed as casting doubts on its usefulness or prejudging its results.
BRIGHAM CITY, Utah, July 21 (AP) car hurtled off a canyon road, across a creek and smashed into a concrete abutment today, killing two New Yorkers.
WASHINGTON, July 21--One of the Government's few "builtin" anti-inflation devices--a cash surplus outside the budget--is rapidly being eroded.
SOMERSET, Ky., July 21 (AP) --Eight boys and girls, crowded into a 1941 model car, were killed today when a freight train smashed into their automobile on the outskirts of town.
WALTHAM, Mass., July 21-- Prof. Simon Rawidowicz, a writer on Jewish philosophy, died yesterday of a heart attack in Waltham Hospital. His age was 60.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP)--Jim Wilson blanked the Red Sox on three hits today as the White Sox made it two out of three in the series with a 3-to-0 victory. It was the second straight shutout for a Chicago pitcher, Dick Donovan tossing a one-hitter yesterday.
AT 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning the program entitled "Look Up and Live" presented a magnificent halfhour television drama over Channel 2.
The Giants were still playing baseball at the Polo Grounds yesterday and Mayor George Christopher of San Francisco did nothing over the week-end that seemed likely to get them to the Pacific Coast.
The rate of increase in youth crimes in the city has slowed. This was reported yesterday by Capt. Frederick J. Ludwig, commander of the police Juvenile Aid Bureau.
Free performances of "The Two Gentlemen of Verona" will be given in Central Park (Belvedere Tower area, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street), starting at 8:15 tonight.
BONN, Germany, July 21-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer may carry all but one of the ten West German states in the election Sept. 15, experts believe.
Arthur Levitt, State Controller, announced yesterday that he would make a new effort this week to persuade the Federal Census Bureau to raise its population figures for New York City.

WASHINGTON, July 21--Tie votes in the 435-member House of Representatives are rare. And it has to be a major issue, with a close vote in prospect, when Speaker Sam Rayburn gets in line for a teller vote.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) --Cincinnati closed in on the front-runners in the National League race today as Gus Bell paced a double-header sweep by the Redlegs over the Philadelphia Phillies with two home runs. The scores were 4--2 and 6--4.

PITTSBURGH, July 21--Even with seasonal shutdowns, extended vacations and heavy repair and maintenance programs, steel demand is deemed good. Activity is at a low for the year, but production is expected to turn sharply upward in another sixty days.
The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights was ordered closed yesterday after nearly a decade of controversy over the Rev. William Howard Melish.
Rolland W. Taylor has been elected president of Foote, Cone Belding. Trade sources termed it a surprise development.
"Do You Trust Your Wife?," the television quiz show that formerly starred Edgar Bergen as master of ceremonies, is expected to resume Sept. 30, but without the services of the ventriloquist.
Adlai E. Stevenson, twice the Democratic party's candidate for President, is the subject of a biography to be published Aug. 5 by Doubleday, entitled "A Prophet in His Own Country."
After a general decline in prices that lasted two weeks, cotton futures turned firmer on the New York Cotton Exchange last week. Gains of $1.45 to $2.90 a bale were recorded.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20-- It is persistently rumored here that President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt plans to announce the union of Egypt and Syria in an address next Friday.
Governor Harriman will choose an interim appointee this week to fill a vacancy on the Queens County Court bench.
Production growth in some branches of Soviet heavy industry greatly slowed or even halted during the first half of 1957, the Soviet mid-year report disclosed.

DURHAM, England, July 21 --For the first time in the history of the Labor party, its leaders are preaching pro-Americanism. Unless there is a drastic change in party thinking, British socialism will support much closer ties with American capitalism at the next general election than will the Conservative party.

The American-flag shipping industry, long a vigorous opponent of the St. Lawrence Seaway project, has started a campaign to get the waterway transferred from its current administrators to other Federal agencies.
MOSCOW, July 21--Izvestia, the Government newspaper, called today for more and better styling to relieve the drabness of life in the Soviet Union.
John Wolcott, a young engineer from Middlebury, Conn., outdrifted an engineer from Washington to gain the United States District I Snipe championship in Eastchester Bay yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 22--The Kuznetsk Basin, Siberia's leading coal region, was said today to be twice as rich as had been thought.

Supporters of the Rev. William Howard Melish charged yesterday that Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal ,Church in Brooklyn Heights had been closed without proper authority and on the "flimsiest pretext."

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) --The Department of Justice announced today it had field a complaint contending that the recent acquisition of the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation by the El Paso Natural Gas Company might tend to create a monopoly, in violation of the Clayton Act.

Quiz show winners aren't the only ones who have to learn how to live with sudden bonanzas. Others in the same category are bonus ball-players, one of whom is Robert Dale Taylor, who last month was signed by the Milwaukee Braves for a record sum. Taylor differs from the quiz show contestant in that he is being asked the questions after receiving the money.
WASHINGTON, July 22--The Administration is afraid that its disarmament negotiations with the Soviet Union are running ahead of Congressional and public understanding and support.

Li'l Fella was the big boy in the $33,775 Great American Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. With Bob Ussery giving him a splendid ride, the Jaclyn Stable's color-bearer registered a neck triumph over the odds-on Jester.

THE Underwriters Laboratories, the organization that certifies the safety features of electrical appliances, reported yesterday that it had tested a number of General Electric portable television receivers and found them free of defects.
WASHINGTON, July 22-- Secretary of State Dulles urged the Soviet Union tonight to give "convincing proof" of its "seriousness" about a disarmament agreement.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22 --There were dismastings, capsizals and assorted kinds of rigging damage today when the first real wind of Larchmont Race Week slapped 295 sailing craft.

HAVANA, July 22--Indications here today are that Fidel Castro, rebel leader, has been able to obtain the support of hitherto badly divided factions and that he speaks for a majority of the opposition to President Fulgencio Batista.
LONDON, July 22--The British Government moved today to protect its oil interests in the Persian Gulf area by announcing full military support for the embattled Sultan of Muscat and Oman.
NEW YORK'S Biggest theatre bargain--the free Summer Shakespeare Festival-returned to Central Park last night with a broad and raucous rendition of "The Two Gentlemen of Verona." And. if

An internal struggle for control of Loew's, Inc., giant motion picture company, became public yesterday. Charges of "intrigue, conspiracy and political manipulation" were aired in the battle over the company and its production arm, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 22 (AP)--Joe McCarthy and Sam (Wahoo Sam) Crawford today were formally inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame by Commissioner Ford Frick at brief, colorful ceremonies.
WASHINGTON, July 22-- The United States Information Agency is sharply reducing its operations in Western Europe. The biggest cut there will be in the program for Germany.
WHITE PLAINS, July 22-- The recommendation for a county-wide sales tax in Westchester to help the public schools has met strong opposition here.
LONDON, July 22 (UP)--The Soviet Premier was reported to have blamed Britain for delays in reaching a disarmament agreement.
A Dominican revolutionary leader denounced yesterday a proposed private investigation of the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez as a "cheap publicity stunt."

WASHINGTON, July 22--The biographers of the brilliant lawyer and patient diplomat who has been Secretary of State throughout the Eisenhower Administration cannot fail to note that this is one of the periods in the official tenure of John Foster Dulles when things are going more his way than usual.
Bernard Spooner, head of the Spooner Armor Company, manufacturer of a bulletproof vest he developed, died on Sunday at his home, 817 West End Avenue. His age was 67.
WASHINGTON, July 22-- President Eisenhower nominated Fred C. Scribner Jr. today as Under Secretary of the Treasury.
BONE, Algeria, July 21-- French hostility toward Tunisia is particularly manifest in the region of Bone, where the nearby frontier is regarded as the main point of departure for rebel incursions.

MONTREAL, July 22--The Montreal Festival opened this evening with a performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" at the Saint-Denis Theatre. This festival has come a long way since 1932, the year of its inception.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation attained the highest sales, earnings and production in its eighty-five years history, in the fiscal year ended April 30. John R. Kimberly, president of the pulp and paper producer, said current operations continue to be highly satisfactory.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 22--Sixty-two Hungarians who found refuge on Yugoslav soil are leaving for the United States tomorrow by way of Vienna.
HONG KONG, July 22-- Accounts of flood damage in north and central China have been received here in radio broadcasts from Peiping.
How many hundredths of a second does it take you to get your foot from the accelerator to the brake? Fifty hundredths --half a second--is good. Sixty hundreths is "very slow."
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP)--A group of Senators from the mining states warned today that competition threatened to wipe United States lead and zinc producers unless tariffs were raised on these metals.

As President Nasser starts on a week of militaristic festivities in Cairo to celebrate the fifth anniversary of his revolution against King Farouk, the first anniversary of his seizure of the Suez Canal and the opening of his new puppet parliament, he is likewise organizing new ...
WASHINGTON, July 22-- President Eisenhower told Congress today that the disposal of farm surpluses abroad would cost the Government about $1,600,000,000 by next July.
Bobby Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, stopped Bobby Courchesne of Holyoke, Mass., at the end of the eighth round of the main event listed for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, July 22-- Marion B. Folsom said today that he hoped President Eisenhower would "get on the phone" in an effort to win House Republican votes for the bill for Federal aid to school construction.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 22 (AP)--Sol-Hi, unharried in the early portion of the race, gained a good lead and then held off a surge by Helfast to Win Monmouth Park's feature today.
THERE is a man in Manhattan who remembers the days when girls wore sweaters for warmth.

CAIRO, July 22--President Gamal Abdel Nasser opened Egypt's first post-revolution "People's Parliament" today with boasts of victory over imperialism and a promise to pull the Egyptians into the atomic age.
WASHINGTON, July 22--Conferees from the Senate and House agreed today to provide $33,759,850,000 to run the Department of Defense through the present fiscal year.
Prices of cotton futures dipped 8 to 18 points yesterday in a small volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.
DETROIT, July 22 (AP)--Automobile production this month has been tightened up somewhat with indications that the volume will not reach the earlier indicated 500,000 units.
Saul F. Dribben, retired chairman of the board of directors and former president of Cone Mills, Inc., 1440 Broadway, died yesterday while on a fishing trip near Smiths Falls, Ont.

When Mayor Wagner, as chairman of the Metropolitan Regional Conference, stepped forward to oppose the New York Central's request for a commuter fare increase he exposed himself to criticism from the railroad that was both plausible and deserved.

Dr. Alfred Einstein Cohn, an authority on the human heart and one of the first physicians to make electrocardiograms in this country, died Saturday at his home, Iron Hill Farm, New Milford, Conn. His death, at the age of 78, came after a long illness.

New York State's pending public borrowing for highway construction and grade crossing elimination will total $27,860,000, it was announced yesterday. The money is to be raised July 30 by the sale of bends dated Aug. 1, 1957 and due serially on Aug. 1 from 1958 to 1977. A preliminary report last week estimated the borrowing at $27,000,000.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 19 --A pill that may increase resistance to cold is being tested at the Arctic Aeromedical Laboratory near here.
SOMETHING of the sad and restless spirit of such mem orable French films as "Port of Shadows" and "Devil in the Flesh" may be found in the latest import of director Henri Verneuil.
LAKE WALES, Fla., July 22 (AP)--David Crawford, 77, retired president of Pullman, Inc., died today at a Lake Wales hospital.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today formally authorized Alleghany Corporation and the New York Central Railroad, which Alleghany controls, to share equally with ten railroad companies in ownership of the Illinois-Missouri Terminal Railway Company.
A 22-year-old messenger employed in the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has been sent to Bellevue Hospital after "going berserk" last Thursday, Mr. Hogan disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22--The General Motors Corporation was accused today of having "overstated" or "misstated" cost figures on a $375,000,000 Air Force contract and profited $17,459,200 more than the Government thought it would.

WASHINGTON, July 22-- The Export-Import Bank today announced it would join to the extent of $60,000,000 in a loan launched by ten United States commercial banks to permit liquidation of Colombia's commercial arrears to banks and exporters in the United States.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 22--Israel lodged a formal complaint today with the United Nations, charging that Syria had violated the armistice agreement between the two countries.

The nine-story apartment building at 125 East Sixty-third Street has been sold by 125 East 63rd Street, Inc., a subsidiary of the Fred F. French Investing Company, Inc. The purchaser is a client of McLaughlin Fougner, attorneys. Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers in the transaction, will become managing agent for the building.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) --The Government said today that $2,000,000 in "windfall" profits had been recovered from five Brooklyn builders and would be distributed to the Farragut Gardens Corporation of that borough.

As the Senate begins voting on substantive provisions of the civil rights bill a historic point in American history is being reached. This is the first time since Reconstruction days that such a measure is actually being debated, considered and voted on in the upper house ...
CHICAGO, July 22--A rough welcome was promised today for any New York waterfront organizers who came to Chicago in an effort to organize dock workers in this area.
WASHINGTON, July 22-- George Meany told a Senate committee today that he would charge officers of the United Textile Workers with having violated the ethical practices code.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 22-- Adath Israel Temple was the scene here this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Patricia Selig Trost, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. Trost of Glenview, to Frank Friedler Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Friedler of New Orleans.

"American Bandstand," a ninety-minute daytime program of recorded popular music, dance contests and interviews, will make its debut Aug. 5 over the American Broadcasting Company television network. It will be presented from 3 to 4:30 o'clock, Mondays through Fridays.
Jack Arthur Goodman, vice president and executive editor of Simon Schuster, publishers, died of a cerebral hemorrhage early yesterday at the age of 48.
The lands that border the Arabian coast on the Persian Gulf are rich in exotic names, exotic products and exotic political arrangements.
Oral arguments on proposed air fare increases have been scheduled by the Civil Aeronautics Board for 10 A.M. July 31 in the Commerce Building in Washington.
WASHINGTON, July 22--The nation's total output of goods and services rose to another high in the second quarter of this year, the Council of Economic Advisers estimated today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)-- The Administration bill would impose a sliding scale of taxes on lead metal imports when the price fell below 17 cents a pound, and on zinc when its price went below 14.5 cents a pound.
"CARMEN," with an allMetropolitan Opera cast, Max Rudolf conducting, was the attraction that drew a near-capacity crowd to Lewisohn Stadium last night.

As the temperature rose yesterday, the stock market wilted. It was pure coincidence. Actually, hot weather may well stimulate attendance in the financial canyons, as traders take refuge in their air-conditioned quarters.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP)-- A Federal Judge today dismissed a complaint of Schenley Industries, Inc., challenging the legality of a $10.50-a-gallon Federal tax on distilled whisky stored in bonded warehouses.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 22 --Fore some time college officials have been concerned that the years ahead would be marked by a battle between the quantity of students and the quality of education.
LONDON, July 22--A British sociologist charged today that the United States was permeated with Marxist habits of thought as a result of the Wide influence of Communists who have recanted.
WASHINGTON, July 22--A House committee accused the Eisenhower Administration of gross negligence today in failing to protect the public against the threat of a hydrogen bomb attack.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 --Warner Brothers has selected three more players for principal roles in its projected film of the Herman Wouk novel, "Marjorie Morningstar."
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) --The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption for the June period averaged 32,485 bales for each working day.

The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham reportedly may extend his Madison Square Garden evangelistic crusade through Labor Day. Plans to continue the campaign beyond its third scheduled closing Aug. 10 are known to be under serious consideration by Graham team members and the local sponsoring committee.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22-- Oscar D. Diegoli, president of Ansec and the American Foreign Power Company's Argentine subsidiary, said today that he had asked the Government to prevent a threatened mob seizure of one of the largest power plants in Argentina.

BUFFALO, July 22--The ninety-fourth, and probably the last, regular convention of the State Federation of Labor opened here today with something less than enthusiasm for merger with the State Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Now comes another "sweetened" issue to the bond market. The $25,000,000 market borrowing by Tennessee Gas Transmission Company is back on the track again after a brief derailment late last week.

An amphibious family showed yesterday that even toddlers can begin to learn how to be at home in the water. The family followed the method described in a booklet for parents. "Teaching Johnny How to Swim," just published by the American Red Cross.
The League of Advertising Agencies has formulated a plan to help train personnel for medium-size and small agencies.

The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that Frank Costello must again stand trial for denaturalization and possible deportation. Ten months ago Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri dismissed the Government's case against the 67-yearold gambler because it contained wiretap evidence.

MOSCOW, July 22--Exuberant tributes to Soviet-Polish friend ship dominated this capital today. At the same time, visiting Yugoslav Communists served notice that Moscow's warmth would not wilt their ideological independence.
MONTREAL, July 22--Officials of Trans-Canada Pipe Line, Ltd., have set a Nov. 1 target date for completing the 341-mile eastern hook-up of the transCanada natural gas pipeline.
THE Mountain has come to Manhattan. Since most New Yorkers can't get away to the Green Mountain State for its yearly festival of arts, a group of Vermont craftsmen has migrated here.
WASHINGTON, July 22--The Senate voted 90 to 0 today to repeal a Reconstruction era law empowering the President to use troops to enforce the civil rights decrees of the Federal courts.

Darryl F. Zanuck's "The Sun Also Rises" has been booked into the Roxy Theatre for an opening some time next month, according to Twentieth Century-Fox, which is presenting the film version of the Ernest Hemingway novel.
WASHINGTON, July 22--A State Department spokesman said today the United States would do what it could to "keep tempers quiet" in the flare-up in Oman in the Arabian Peninsula.

TODAY'S books are short novels that reflect the grimness and the gaiety of European attitudes on the eve of World War II. One is Marguerite Yourcenar's "Coup de Grace."* The other is Erich Kastner's "A Salzburg Comedy."
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 22 --Lawyers took eight hours in their summation at the trial of eleven white Southerners accused of crimnial contempt of a Federal court injunction.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 22--"Don't cook it yourself. Let us do it." That is the advice of Mrs. Audrey Hurdman of East Hampton. As manager of the Bazar Culinaire here, she prepares ready-to-serve-at-home delicacies like boeuf bourguignone, ratatouille nicoise, brioche mousseline and pirozihkis.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23--At the initiative of the United States the plight of 700,000 Chinese refugees from Communism will be laid before the United Nations General Assembly this fall.
LONDON, July 22--The victory now in sight against crippling poliomyelitis will be followed by the conquest of other disabling diseases caused by viruses.

Sales and earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation were lower in the second quarter this year than in the same months of 1956, the company reported yesterday. Despite this, the company achieved in the first six months of 1957 the highest sales and earnings for any similar period in its history. Expanded titanium production contributed to the result.
THE trend that leads people with similar problems to get together in groups has gone one step farther. The newest instance is an organization known as "Parents Without Partners."
Strike-induced cement shortages forced a halt yesterday in the construction of a $4,500,000 hotel project at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
Following is the text of a broadcast from Washinton last night by Secretary of State Dulles, as recorded by The New York Times:
The East German team took a 2-1 lead over the United States in the ninth round of the world student chess championship at Reykjavik, Iceland, yesterday, according to a report received here.

CHICAGO, July 22--Weakness in the expiring wheat futures was the feature of the Chicago Board of Trade today with the old style July delivery off the full permissible limit of 10 cents a bushel. The new style delivery in the same month broke 5 cents from its early session high. It showed relative firmness, however, compared with the old.
Two $40-a-week stock clerks found $62,379 yesterday in the S. Klein store at 6 Union Square. The money was part of $74,109 in receipts reported missing from the store June 29.

WASHINGTON, July 22--The House of Representatives approved tentatively today a bill that would give a 12 per cent rise in pay to more than 500,000 postal employes. At cash value the increase Would amount to an average of $546 a year.
WHITE PLAINS, July 22--A youth who shot and killed his mother and sister last May 23 at the family's home in Rye, was arraigned here today as a juvenile delinquent.

LONDON, July 22--Activity in Government funds continued to expand on the stock exchange today and the recovery in prices was extended. Leading industrials were quieter and prices moved irregularly. The demand for Government funds was again centered on medium-dated issues. With a few exceptions prices closed with gains ranging up to 10 shillings ($1.40) on the 100 ($280) unit.

A total of 12,442 ship arrivals and departures was recorded here in the first six months of 1957, the Maritime Association of the Port of New York reported yesterday. This represented a decline of 3.9 per cent as compared with the corresponding period of 1956.
The city remained in the grip of the year's worst heat wave yesterday.

Until "Boon Island" was published in 1956 Kenneth Roberts' name had not appeared on a historical novel for nine years. Knowing this "Downeaster's" devotion to detail and accuracy, one can well imagine what he had been doing in that nine-year interval.

PARIS, July 22--French scientists said today that some artificially induced characteristics in ducks had been transmitted to their ducklings. The work was reported in a paper read today to the Academy of Sciences by Prof. Robert Courrier.
The Army's efforts to increase its mobility in the atomic age focus on the sky as well as on the ground.

FUCHU, Japan, Tuesday, July 23--A young United States airman has been sentenced to four months at hard labor for refusing to get a "white sidewall" haircut. But his civilian lawyer said today an appeal would be carried to Washington if necessary.
CAIRO, July 22--Egyptian authorities granted permission tonight to a Danish vessel to carry a cargo of rice through the Suez Canal on its way to Israel.
BONN, Germany, July 22-- The case of the speed-happy waiter who plotted to blow up the Federal Parliament building has thrust West Germany's chronic espionage problem back into the headlines.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22-- The two Australians who are likely to fill in for Lewis Hoad and Kenneth Rosewall on the defending Davis Cup team in December and three members of the 1956 American team were included in the field that started play today in the Pennsylvania state tennis championships.
William Zeckendorf Jr., new president of Manhattantown, Inc., said yesterday that excavation work would begin next week for the long-stalled upper West Side redevelopment.

BABYLON, L.I., July 22-- Killies are bait-fish about the size of large fat minnows and they can live a long time in adverse circumstances. Adverse circumstances to baitfish mean being out of water or affixed to a hook in the water.
WASHINGTON, July 22--The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy headed today toward a peaceful compromise in the long partisan fight over the program for developing atomic power.
WHEN the Queen Mary came in last week there disembarked a towering figure of a man with graying, close cropped hair and a serenity that has been unfailing in both triumph and disaster.
Cocoa futures fell yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, reflecting weakness in London and reports that the minimum export price of the main Accra crop will be lower than anticipated.

Shelley Winters has been offered the sole woman's role in "The Saturday Night Kid." The star acknowledged yesterday that she might appear in Jack Dunphy's three-character play, described as a serious melodrama. Miss Winters' assignment would be the name role, which she observed was "poetic in an earthy way."
Dr. John J. Theobald has emerged as the leading candidate for the post of Superintendent of Schools.

The Cuban situation has moved into a new and important phase with new political pronouncements from the resistance leaders. The main statement came from the Sierra Maestra, where Fidel Castro and his young rebels continue their successful defiance of the Batista Government.
DR. JOHN JACOB THEOBALD, who is expected to be the next Superintendent of Schools, is one educator who does not live in an ivory tower.

PARIS, July 22 (Reuters)-- Shippers afraid of further trouble in the Suez area are ordering more super-tankers as a result of the crisis last fall, the Organigation for European Economic Cooperation reported today.
"Agenda for Action: Toward Peace Through Disengagement," a new book by James P. Warburg, will be issued in clothbound and paper-back editions on Aug. 22 by Academy Books.
ALDERSON, W.Va., July 22 (AP)--A British war bride who slew three of her four children at a lonely African military outpost left prison today to resume her married life.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. The world sugar positions, coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, tin and cooper declined; potatoes and zinc rose, and price movements for domestic sugar futures, wool, hides and rubber were mixed.

CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP)-- Pittsburgh's Pirates twice blew a one-run lead tonight before punching out three runs on four hits and an error in the fifteenth inning that trimmed Cincinnati's Redlegs, 6--3. Bob Skinner belted two home runs for Pittsburgh.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23--Algerian nationalist leaders denied today that they had held secret talks recently with a high French official on the possibility of halting the Algerian revolt.
NEW' DELHI, India, July 23i N Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru expressed .concern today! over the deterioration of relations between India and Pakistan.

BABYLON, L.I., July 23-- Victories in two of today's three events put the Point o' Woods Yacht Squadron crew ahead in the nine-race series for the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's junior championship.
The volume of commercial and sales finance paper outstanding in the United States decreased 12 per cent in June, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
LONDON, July 23--Britain is rapidly approaching self-sufficiency in nuclear weapons, Duncan Sandys told the House of Commons tonight.
PARIS, July 23--French legal experts suggested today a possible means of extraditing to the United States an American couple accused of spying.

First National City Bank of New York said yesterday that 98.7 per cent of its offering of $120,000,000 in new capital stock had been taken up by shareholders. Of the 2,000,000 additional shares offered on a one-for-five subscription basis at $60 a share, ...

YONKERS, July 23--Billy Bumpas stepped away from six rivals in the final half-mile to win the $3,500 Oakdale Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 7-year-old black horse, the second choice, won by five lengths and paid $6.20 for $2.

IN this day of Skiatron millions and inviting franchise shifts, one readily can understand the impression that sentiment is a commodity as dead in baseball as the nickel scorecard. Maybe so, but you're going to see an awful lot of it at the Yankee Stadium, come Saturday, when close to sixty former ...
A request for $350,000 to enable the Board of Education to keep open 100 school recreation centers on week-ends during the regular school year, was sent yesterday to Mayor Wagner.

Robert Moses said yesterday that the proposed cultural center at Lincoln Square might be "scuttled" by the Federal Government's insistence on a third set of appraisals for reselling land to Fordham University and the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.
Mickey Mantle, who had been in a bit of a batting slump, returned to life with a vengeance last night to pace the leagueleading Yankees to a 10-6 triumph over the White Sox.
WASHINGTON, July 23--The Defense Department reduced today its draft quota for September to 8,000 men for the Army.

Edmon Ryan, who made his debut on Broadway as the gullible State Trooper in "Post Road" and who has since appeared in "Command Decision," "Dream Girl" and "The Male Animal," will try his fortune at producing next fall.
A dividend action can move the price of a stock one of three ways--up, down or "sideways." The effect does not always seem logical.
COLUMBIA, N.J., July 23-- As Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, the heavyweight fist fighter, was seated at luncheon today his handlers were asked to explain his character and complexities.
CHICAGO, July 23--Wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade got away to an easy start today, continuing yesterday's downward trend. Prices fell generally about 2 cents a bushel.
LONDON, July 23 (AP)--The ratification of Derek Ibbotson's 3:57.2 time as a world mile record was a step closer today despite some complaints that the race Friday was not run properly.
The lower concourse of Rockefeller Plaza resounded yesterday to the precision marching of eight drill teams of the Civil Air Patrol cadets.
DENVER, July 23--In front of a red sandstone rock formation more than 60,000,000 years old, a Wagner opera was presented tonight in the Red Rocks Theatre.
WASHINGTON, July 23--The House voted, 140 to 55, today to debate a school construction bill more generally regarded as already dead.

WASHINGTON, July 23--The Senate overwhelmingly rejected today two efforts to preserve in the Administration's civil rights bill some Federal injunctive powers that would go beyond protecting the right to vote.
Secretary Dulles' broadcast to the nation and to the world on Monday evening made three essential points: first, that there could not be any acceptable measure of disarmament ...
MINEOLA, L.I., July 23-- The Nassau County Republican party will nominate candidates for town office this year both at the Sept. 10 primary and at town conventions.
LONDON, July 23--Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd told Parliament today that Royal Air Force jets had been authorized to go into action against tribal rebels in central Oman.
An Old familiar front-running number, "11", appeared on a new car during the national point races at Upper Marlboro, Md., on July 13 and 14. No. 11 belongs to Dr. Richard Thompson ...
The Transit Authority's experiment in gracious living-- an air-conditioned test train on the Lexington Avenue subway line-is getting rave notices from the riders. One hundred and
Governor Harriman was quoted last night as saying that Sydney S. Baron could not handle publicity for both Tammany Hall and the Dominican Republic.

HONG KONG, July 23-- Planes have dropped 62,000 pounds of freshly cooked foods to the starving flood victims of Shantung province in the last three days, it was announced tonight by the Pieping radio.
WASHINGTON, July 23--The House of Representatives approved today its tentative decision of yesterday to recommend a 12 per cent pay increase to more than 500,000 postal workers.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) --A former union organizer told Senate investigators today that the Communist party incited and led the $54,000,000 Singer Manufacturing Company strike in 1949.

BONN, Germany, July 23-- An East German espionage ring operating in a small hotel near Bonn was recently broken up by the West German security police. The leaseholder of the hotel was arrested and is facing trial by the Supreme Court on charges of suspicion of treason.
James Reynolds, author and artist, died on Sunday at Bellagio, Italy, according to word received here yesterday by his publishers, Farrar, Straus Cudahy, Inc. His age was 65.
ALGIERS, Algeria, July 23-- The continuation of normal economic activities in Algeria despite the rebellion apparently has arrested an exodus of French landowners and a flight of capital to France.

BONN, Germany, July 23-- Informed quarters believe the forthcoming visit of Nikita S. Khrushchev and Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin to East Berlin may be connected with a plan to influence the election in West Germany.
LONDON, July 23--Two British oil companies have decided to dispose of their marketing interests in Israel because they say they are unprofitable.

The Hamilton Watch Company is continuing to diversify its operations in an effort to reduce its dependence on watches, but development costs are effecting earnings, Arthur B. Sinkler, president told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

A nation-wide survey of consumers last month reveals a weakening in their confidence about business conditions and a more cautious attitude on buying. These results were reported yesterday by the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan.
Maurice Sterne, painter and sculptor, died yesterday at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
The Georgia Rural Roads Authority raised i17,500,000 in the public market yesterday by selling serial bonds secured by revenues pledged from motor vehicle tax collections.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)-- The House Ways and Means Committee acted on a bill today to strengthen the Government's hand in forcing unscrupulous or careless business concerns to pay Federal taxes withheld from employes' paychecks and other sources.

NEVIL SHUTE, one of the most consistently popular novelists in the Englishspeaking world, has an old habit of writing with immense good cheer about the most dreadful disasters and the most horrible possibilities.
Most charges for truck loading and unloading at the port's piers will be increased on Aug. 19.
American bobbysox slang mingled gracefully yesterday with foreign accents as students from twenty-nine countries talked of their impressions of America.

JAZZ took its turn on the stage of the Wollman Memorial Theatre in Central Park last night. It followed a misfired effort at musical comedy--"Rosalie"--and Cab Calloway's better planned night club show.
The president of Capital Airlines, James H. Carmichael, has been elevated to chairman of the board and an Air Force general has been named to succeed him.
Anthony F. Saidy of Fordham University, the highest scorer for the United States in the annual students international chess tournament at Reykjavik, gained ...
The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham affirmed last night a decision not to extend his Madison Square Garden evangelistic crusade beyond Aug. 10.
Has the Board of Education already tacitly chosen a new Superintendent of Schools to succeed Dr. William Jansen when he retires for statutory reasons of age at the end of the next school year?

BUFFALO, July 23--The State Federation of Labor sought today to avert a floor fight over merger with the State Congress of Industria] Organizations at the federation's ninety-fourth annual convention here.
SOUTH HACKENSACK, N. J., July 23--The Bergen County Medical Society today began an investigation of two complaints of inability to obtain physicians to provide emergency medical aid.

Evidence is still lacking of the big mobilization of governmental machinery, political party doorbellpushing, and the persuasion of the public necessary to sign up the voters under permanent personal registration.
A once-powerful voice in education was silenced yesterday with the official closing of the Progressive Education magazine after an uphill fight to keep alive.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP)The House Armed Services Committee approved today a bill to permit the Navy to scrap the battleship Kentucky and six other unfinished World War II warships.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the six and twelve months ended June 30. Sales of gas and electricity were higher, but steam sales declined.

"The stock market is adrift in its own kind of horse latitudes,'" according to one observer yesterday. The comment was apt. Horse latitudes is the designation given by seamen to areas of calm, particularly in the Western Ocean.
Mrs. Laura Guyol Wolfe, who as Helen Worth had conducted a counseling column in The Brooklyn Eagle for twenty-five years, deed yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 73 years old.
Families should keep medical records as they used to record births and deaths in the family Bible, Dr. Paul Dudley White said here yesterday.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 23 --Seven racial segregationists were convicted of criminal contempt today by a jury of white Southerners in a Federal District Court.

PARIS, Wednesday, July 24 (Reuters). -- Sacha Guitry, French playwright-actor, died here today. He was 72 years old. He had been ailing for several months, but his condition became worse in the last few days.

For the first time since the Government's vast social welfare program was set up, back in 1935, those charged with the administration of the Social Security fund are expected to pay out more in benefits this year than they receive in tax payments from the 73,000,000 persons now covered.
The saga of Sid Caesar added another chapter yesterday when the comedian announced he had renewed acquaintances with two old friends--Imogene Coca and the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)-- Public health officials said today that tiny amounts of tars in cigarette smoke might offer a clue to the possible relationship between smoking and lung cancer.

DUBLIN, July 23--More than 800 guests, including members of leading Irish and English families, crowded and overflowed the little parish Church of Adare in County Limerick today for the marriage of the Marquess of ...

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., July 23--School tuna, after resting up for a couple of days on the week-end, resumed operations so viciously yesterday that almost anybody could take them--if he was in the right place.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., July 23 --School boards in Charlotte, Winston-Salem and Greensboro voted tonight to admit twelve Negro pupils to all-white public schools.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 --Robert Ryan and Aldo Ray will co-star with Tina Louise in "God's Little Acre."

An age-old lesson in viewpoints is on display in Grand Central Terminal along with the Army's Redstone ballistic missile. The Army reported yesterday that the missile display drew more scientific and technical questions from youngsters than from their fathers.
PYLOS, Greece, July 16--Excavations this summer on the site of the palace of King Nestor have cast further light on the way of life of royalty here twelve centuries before the time of Chrigt.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) --Southern Senators said today that the conviction of Frederick John Kasper and six Clinton (Tenn.) residents had destroyed a major argument against trial by jury in civil rights cases.
The Manufacturers Trust Company has leased about 15,000 square feet for a new branch office in the Time Life Building that will rise on the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) ...

LONDON, July 23 (AP)--The Moscow radio asserted today that the United States had greatly increased its "espionage sabotage and subversive activities" against the Soviet Union.

LONDON, July 23--Investors were hesitant today and, with demand selective, prices moved narrowly. Losses in pennies predominated. Caution was engendered by a serious provincial bus strike that is having effect on industrial production and by the tribal unrest in Oman.
WASHINGTON, July 23--The State Department took steps today to prevent the revolt against the Sultan of Muscat and Oman from blowing up into a political clash between the United States and Britain.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23-- At the age of 37 Henry Van Rensselaer of Greenwich, Conn., is having the tennis season of his life.
WASHINGTON, July 23--A Federal Power Commission examiner tossed another Hells Canyon issue at the Administration today.

The Rev. G. Clare Backhurst, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church in Gramercy Park, has written his church's thanks to a donor of the Jewish faith for a $100 contribution toward the refurbishing of Calvary House, a church adjunct.
The longest criminal trial in the history of the English law courts took place in the nineteenth century and culminated in "an incredibly preposterous play on human gullibility by a crude impostor."

FLORENCE, July 22--That genius for enjoyment that makes Italians the world's best creators of amusing sportswear and boutique fashions was evident today as the Florentine Italian fashion show opened in a spirit of high humor.
The Maritime Administration hopes to earmark more than $120,000,000 in construction subsidy funds for new freighters before the end of this year.

Deposit in school savings accounts across the country increased 12.5 per cent during the last year and l4 per cent more school children took part in savings programs, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.

PARIS, July 23--In any democratic system there is continual struggle between the individual and the government he has devised to protect and administer him.

PARIS, July 23--A federal system for North Africa, in which the Algerian conflict would be solved within a larger framework, was proposed today by Pierre Mendes-France, former Premier.

CAIRO, July 23--Egyptian authorities said today that investigation had proved that the Israeli citizen seized yesterday from a Danish vessel before she passed through the Suez Canal was an active member of the Israeli armed forces.
THERE'S a lot more for chil dren to see in New York than the Statue of Liberty and the Empire State Building, Summet is a good time for stay-athomes as well as visitors to hunt out the best sights.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 23-- Mrs. Norman Woolworth of Wee Burn and Mrs. Charles Spalding of Round Hill won the qualifying medal of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's eleventh annual four-ball best-ball tournament today.

The properties at 561-63 Third Avenue and 203 East Thirtyseventh Street in the Murray Hill district have been sold by B. J. Daniels and Gregory Spurdis. The buyer was Harry Horwitz, realty operator.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)-- Paul Kayser, president of El Paso Natural Gas Company, said today that if the Government wins an antitrust suit against his company, "millions of gas customers would Inevitably pay higher costs for their service."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 --The American Broadcasting Company will break ground tomorrow for its Hollywood plant expansion program. The anticipated ultimate cost will be $30,000,000, according to Earl J. Hudson, vice president in charge of the western division,

WASHINGTON, July 23--A joint Congressional Atomic Energy subcommittee approved today a modified $58,000,000 program for Government development of atomic power plants.
Wallace Reid of 955 Lexington Avenue, who retired recently as head of his own insurance business at 55 John Street, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 87.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 10 to 8 points yesterday.

The general reaction to the Dominican Government's latest move in the Galindez case seems to be: how strange! It is indeed strange for a foreign government to hire an American public relations firm to investigate a sensational criminal case in which it is accused.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Senate investigators implied today that an officer of the United Textile Workers had spent union funds for personal shopping for himself and his wife.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20-- President Juscelino Kubitschek of Brazil is working hard to mend his ill-tended Congressional fences.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23--Outflow of global private capital for investment abroad in 1956 set a record for the postwar period, Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold declared today.

CHICAGO, July 23--Overpowering speed and a curve that baffled the opposition enabled Dick Drott, the rookie righthander of the Cubs, to add fourteen strike-out victims to his list as the Chicagoans blanked the Giants, 4-0 at Wrigley Field today.

The first American supermarket in a Communist country will be opened at the Zagreb, Yugoslavia, Grand Fair on Sept. 7. This was disclosed yesterday by John A. Logan, president of the National Association of Food Chains.

Davega Stores Corporation expects to operate at a profit for its fiscal year ending next Feb. 28, although "most of our profits are still in the customers' pockets," H. M. Stein, president and treasurer, said at the annual meeting yesterday.

Events today: Fine Art Wind Quintet, Morningside Park at 121st Street, 10:30 A. M.; Allen J. Sever, organist, St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, 12:10 P. M.
MILWAUKEE, July 23 (UP)-- Johnny Logan kept his hitting streak alive tonight and as a result the Milwaukee Braves beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 1-0.

SOME of the lucky New Yorkers who vacation in Europe are starting to return; to a wellfed man, they report: Eating in Paris is expensive. But, as was emphasized recently by Helmut Ripperger, cookbook writer, good ...

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 23--Israel moved quickly today to protest both the arrest of an Israeli sailor by the Egyptians and the delaying of a chartered ship seeking to pass through the Suez Canal with a cargo for Israel.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23 --The night-and-day travail of Henry Duys to sail a yacht made the best story of this almost windless afternoon at Larchmont Race Week.
One good way to win a horse race is to own a racetrack and run your horses on some other course. Chevation of the Foxcatcher Farm won the feature event at Belmont Park yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 23--Vice Admiral John Wilkes, U.S. N., retired, training commander for the 4,000-unit landing craft fleet in the Normandy invasion during World War II, died in the Naval Hospital at Bethesda, Md., Saturday.
TUNIS, Tunisia, July 23--A special session of the National Constituent Assembly is expected to proclaim Tunis a republic Thursday.

Corporate securities totaling $162,875,000 will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates. The offerings include debt securities of public utility and gas transmission companies and convertible prefered and common shares of industrial enterprises.

Samuel Reshevsky, international grandmaster, last night drew the seventh game of his ten-game chess match with Arthur B. Bisguier, United States champion, in thirty-seven moves to maintain his lead with a score of 4--3. The series is being played at the Manhattan Chess Club.

MOSCOW, July 23--The Communist party confirmed today that the recent struggle for Soviet leadership had been launched at a gathering of the Presidium of the Central Committee. The meeting had not been previously disclosed in the Soviet Union.

CONCORD, N.H., July 23-- Dr. Robert Chambers, biologist who was a pioneer in the comparatively new branch of science called micromanipulation or micrurgy, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 75 years old and resided here.

MONTREAL, July 23--Dr. Waclaw Babinski, who as a representative of the Polish Government in Exile was largely responsible for having brought to Canada some of Poland's art treasures during World War II, died here yesterday. He was 70 years old.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 23 (UP)--Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Find, a 7-year-old gelding, today scored one of his greatest victories.

LONDON, July 23--Two brand new delicious fabrics dominated the opening day of the London winter collections. One, a silky Mohair and nylon mixture by Ascher was used by both Michael and Sherard and has been chosen in Paris by Dior, Balenciaga and Givenchy among others.
Robert A. Futterman of New York, an investor in real estate in leading cities throughout the country, has taken title to the Chamber of Commerce Building in Miami, Fla.
The mercury dropped comfortably below its usual midJuly level yesterday, ending a record-breaking three-day heat wave.
A plea for Federal aid to abolish the nation's "educational slums" was made yesterday by Dr. John K. Norton of Columbia University's Teachers College.
WASHINGTON, July 23-- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York, introduced a bill today to eliminate what he termed a "roadblock" in the Government's fight on subversives.

Reflecting higher volume of sales, consolidated net income of the Corn Products Refining Company and its domestic and Canadian subsidiaries increased to $9,315,320 in the first half of this year from $7,272,927 a year ago.

CAIRO, July 23--President Gamal Abdel Nasser paraded an impressive array of Soviet-built military equipment today in celebration of the fifth anniversary of his revolution. Scores of twin-jet Ilyushin bombers and MIG jet fighters screamed low above the reviewing stand.
The State of California borrowed $50,000,000 in the public market yesterday in furtherance of a thirty-six-year program for helping war veterans buy homes and farms.
WASHINGTON, July 24--The Departments of Defense and State fought today against a new move in Congress to prevent trials of United States servicemen in foreign courts.

MONTAINVILLE, N.Y., July 24--L. Valentine Pulsifer, a director and former president of the Valspar Corporation, maker of varnishes, and inventor of several improvements in the commercial paint field, died here today in his home. His age was 75.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24--The Hecht-Hill-Lancaster Company and United Artists have entered into a new multiplepicture contract involving a projected production expenditure of $26,000,000.

In his collection of probing essays and sketches, "Commentary," John Galsworthy relates how a poor couple living in a slam section of London started out with their only child for a Sunday morning stroll in a park.

Ten minutes after the running of the $27,800 Stymie Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, Benjamin R. Steen phoned his wife at their home in Toronto. Said Steen, "We won. You stayed home on the wrong day."
It's becoming a familiar story now: the stock market yesterday continued to drift in the doldrums. Prices ended irregularly higher in the lightest trading since April 1.
PARIS, July 24--An investigation indicated today that a French Government representative met Algerian rebel leader Mohammed Yazid in Tunis despite the latter's denials.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 23-- The declaration of a truce by Cypriote terrorists four months ago brought a suspension of violence but not of intimidation, acting Governor George Sinclair said today in an interview.
LONDON, July 24--Prof. J.B. S. Haldane, one of Britain's leading geneticists, left England today to settle in India.
A three-year program to stimulate, better teaching in science and engineering has been set up by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

LONDON, July 24--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin maintains that the Western position on a suspension of nuclear arms tests precludes agreement on the subject at the five-power disarmament talks. The Soviet leader made that statement in a letter to Harold Macmillan, British Prime Minister, that was published here today.

CHICAGO, July 24--Wheat futures on the Board of Trade today held inside a moderate range. There was some talk of an increase in the demand for flour, but buying was not sufficiently aggressive to bring any significant changes in prices.
EAST ISLIP, L.I., July 24-- Miss Emilia Hope Howell and William Ancrum Boykin Jr. will be married Oct. 12.

ST. LOUIS, July 24--Last night the Dodgers made three hits and won a ball game, 1--0. Tonight at Busch Stadium their hit total was the same but the result was different. They didn't get any runs and the Cardinals took the contest, 3--0.

The C.I.T. Financial Corporation opened for subscription yesterday four new series of 4 per cent debentures bearing maturities longer than the series placed on the market by the financing company on July 14.
LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP)-- A Federal judge today set Sept. 16 for retrial of nine of the fourteen California Communist leaders affected by last month's Supreme Court decision.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 24-- Long Island's flat landscape will gain a brilliant $20,000,000 splotch of color next Thursday night when the new Roosevelt Raceway opens for harness racing.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 23--The thrifty Dutch are living beyond their means and their economic future is far from bright.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 24--A young party pledged to white supremacy is preparing to bid for power in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.

A decline of 3,706 000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 178,267,000 barrels, compared with 181,973,000 a week earlier and 178,352,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- The House of Representatives adopted an amendment to the school construction bill today. The amendment said that it was the intent of Congress that there should not be Federal control of schools.
ALBANY, July 24--The Appellate Division today struck down a ban imposed by the Board of Regents on the motion picture "Lady Chatterley's Lover."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24-- A strike threat hung over West Coast shipyards from Puget Sound to San Diego today as 12,000 craftsmen in ten unions prepared to vote on a "final" contract offer by emnloyers.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, July 24 (Reuters)--The Federal high court ruled here today that the East German nationalized Carl Zeiss optical works must not use the name "Veb Carl Zeiss Jena" and the internationally known Zeiss trademarks in West Germany and West Berlin.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- The commissioner of the National Football League testified today that professional football would be "doomed" unless Congress exempted some of its practices from the antitrust laws.

LONDON, July 24--The decision of the British oil companies to sell their marketing interests in Israel was interpreted today as part of a trend in British diplomacy toward support of the Arab states at Israel's expense.

The drabness of life in the Soviet Union is one of the things which depresses a Western visitor there most strongly. The somber dress of the people, the crumbling disrepair of many structures, the lack of grace in such objects as automobiles, these strike many Western visitors immediately.

The Air Reduction Company, Inc., achieved the highest earnings for any half-year period in the first six months this year, with sales at a new record for the quarter and six month periods, John A. Hill, president, reported.
TOKYO, July 25 (AP)--Japan, a major buyer in the world cotton markets, has disclosed plans to cut its purchases of cotton by 25 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)-- A bill broadening coverage and extending Social Security benefits was introduced today by Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican of New Jersey.

LARCHM0NT, N.Y., July 24--The tremendous growth of sailing interest on Long Island Sound as elsewhere, particularly among teen-agers and younger salts, was reflected today when a mammoth flotilla of 275 sloops turned out for Larchmont Race Week Junior Day.

CHICAGO, July 24--Johnny Antonelli, the Giants' winningest pitcher last year but their losingest this season, dropped a 2 1 decision to the eighth-place Chicago Cubs today at Wrigley Field. It was the tenth setback for the stylish southpaw, who won twenty games in 1956.
Sixty-one grants and appropriations totaling $4,527,064 were announced yesterday by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.
Dr. Jacques R. Fischl, chief physician of the New York Yankees baseball team, died of a heart atack yesterday morning at the Westminster Hotel in Le Touquet, France. His age was 43.
The machinery to make James R. Hoffa president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters will be set in motion tomorrow.

LONDON, July 24--Ronald Paterson proved today that although fashion may have a short life it has a surprisingly long mem ory. Reaching clear back to China's Shang-yin dynasty of 1500 B.C. he based his "Chia" line on a bronze vase of that period.

Nugent Fallon of 74 Greenway Terrace, Forest Hills, Queens, chairman of the board of the Suffolk County Federal Savings and Loan Association, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 73.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 24---- Judge Homer L. Kreider of the Dauphin County Criminal Court completed his general charge to the jury in the Pennsylvania Turnpike conspiracy case late today.

The nations of this hemisphere must cooperate in economic affairs if Pan Americanism is to become a modern reality, Dr. Josh R. Chiriboga V., Ambassador from Ecuador, said yesterday. Economic inequalities, he said, threaten the political achievements of Pan Americanism.

ALBANY, July 24--Six appointments today filled out the membership of the new Higher Education Assistance Corporation. Three were made by Governor Harriman and three by Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly.
A group of one-story industrial buildings in the Heights area of Brooklyn has been purchased by Isaac Alper, a realty investor.

A deficiency of 31 per cent in watershed rainfall has combined with high, hot-weather water consumption to reduce the city's water storage to 70.3 per cent of capacity. A year ago at this time the reservoirs were nearly 90 per cent full.

There was no obvious connection of cause and effect between the verdict of guilty rendered in the criminal contempt case in Knoxville, Tenn., on Tuesday against Frederick John Kasper and six of his associates and the continuing debate on the civil rights bill in the Senate.
"Zuleika," the current London musical that stems from Sir Max Beerbohm's novel "Zuleika Dobson," will be the first stage presentation at the reconverted Globe Theatre.

An influential segment of the American merchant marine that hailed Congress last spring for drastically, reducing shipbuilding subsidy funds appealed yesterday for restoration of the funds next year.

A bundle containing $11,200 in worn, brittle currency was found in a taxicab yesterday morning. The driver had just taken a well-dressed man from Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street to the Biltmore Hotel at Fortythird Street.

Sydney S. Baron was dropped as publicity man for Tammany Hall yesterday.

Heavy commission house selling, light hedging and stop-loss selling dropped cocoa prices sharply in active trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market opened higher on trade and commission house buying and short covering.

The Northern States Power Company (Minnesota) and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues for three and twelve months ended June 30. Net income for the June quarter, however, fell slightly behind the 1956 level.

SYDNEY STUART BARON, who was dropped yes terday as publicity director of Tammany Hall, is a smooth young man from Brooklyn who went places in a hurry.

MOSCOW, July 24--Mikhail G. Pervukhin, recently demoted to alternate member of the Communist party's ruling Presidium, has been appointed chairman of a new State Committee for Foreign Economic Relations.
LONDON, July 24--Violence in strikes at Covent Garden market and among 100,000 employes of provincial bus lines caused concern today in Britain.

Morningside Park, near Columbia University, resounded to the tramp of marching feet yesterday morning. They were little feet and they were not marching in close formation.
LONDON, July 24--Interest in industrial stocks again was selective on the stock market today. The tone of the market was firm despite the contraction in business volume.
The port's truckmen yesterday sought Federal, state and municipal aid in an attempt to stave off another increase in truck loading or unloading rates at the piers.

A six-story apartment house for twenty-four families at 226 Second Avenue, near Thirteenth Street, has been sold by the 226 Second Avenue Corporation. It was bought by the 226 East Avenue Corporation through William M. Schwartz, broker.
HONG KONG, Thursday, July 25--An attempt "to overthrow the Chinese Communist Government" was reported last night in a cryptic news item broadcast by the Peiping radio.
WASHINGTON, July 24-- With firm support from President Eisenhower, the House Interior Committee killed a bill today for a Federal Hells Canyon dam.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 24 (AP)-- Toe Gagliardi opened the defense of his amateur golf title successfully today. Ray Billows and Johnny Konsek also turned in first-round victories, but Tommy Goodwin was upset.

Honors usually reserved for debutante ocean queens were accorded here yesterday to one of the port's unsung workhorses. The harbor welcomed a new tanker, the 630-foot Sinclair Refining Company's J.E. Dver.
The television industry, which for ten years has thought in terms of continuing boom, is experiencing the "softest" demand for air time that it has ever known.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 12 points yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24--Mohammed Yazid, Algerian nationalist spokesman here, declared today that he stood firmly by his denial that neither he nor other Algerian leaders had talks recently with a French Government representative.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)-- New import taxes on lead and zinc could bring retaliation from foreign producing countries, the Senate Finance Committee was told today.
MILWAUKEE, July 24 (AP)-- Jack Sanford held Milwaukee to five hits for his thirteenth victory of the season as the Phillies beat the Braves, 3--1, tonight.

A sixteen-nation meeting of the Indo-Pacific Fisheries Council, recently concluded in Bandung, has been able to make through the Food and Agriculture Organization an encouraging report to the United Nations.

The Treasury's largest refunding operation in history ended yesterday as subscription books closed on three new issues of 3 5/8 and 4 per cent securities offered in exchange for $23,943,000,000 debt maturing next month and in October.
A WONDERFULLY absorbing study of Puerto Rican life in New York was televised in drama form last night on Channel 4's "Kraft Television Theatre."
LONDON, July 24--The Army will lose fifty-one major units in a reorganization of Britain's defense forces, it was announced today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 24 (AP)--The ninth shot of the current Nevada test series flashed over the desert today. It sent a rumbling shock wave rolling across trenches, an underground dugout and the hillside perch of thirty-one civilian defense observers.

Acquisition of assets of the L.J. Wing Manufacturing Company, Linden, N.J., by the Aero Supply Manufacturing Company, Inc., Corry, Pa., has been announced. Wing, a manufacturer of industrial, ventilating and heating equipment, will operate as an independent division of Aero Supply.
AL LOPEZ is so self-effacing that the aver age baseball fan probably is not fully aware of his outstanding managerial attributes.
BUFFALO, July 24--A threatened revolt against a merger of the State Federation of Labor and the State Congress of Industrial Organizations was resolved here today by compromise.

CHICAGO, July 24 (UP)--Eddie Machen of San Francisco pounded out his twenty-second straight victory tonight, scoring an unimpressive ten-round decision over Bob Baker of Pittsburgh in a televised fight at Chicago Stadium.
TODAY, 11 A.M.: A story hour for children between 4 and 8 years of age will be conducted by Miss Janet Pinney at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. The program is free.
The mysterious disappearance of five pieces of jewelry from a woman passenger's baggage after the sinking of the Italian liner Andrea Doria was reported here yesterday.
