HARTFORD, July 24--The right of Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff to replace his own interim appointees to the minor courts was argued today before a special session of the State Supreme Court of Errors.
WASHINGTON, July 24-- The Senate struck from the Administration's civil rights bill today all Federal enforcement powers except those to protect the right to vote.
In 1950, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States offered the railroads a somewhat similar financing plan.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 24 --Sydney A. Syme, a retired Westchester County and New York attorney and a former Supreme Court Justice of the Ninth Judicial District, died today in his home at 1225 Midland Avenue after a long illness. He was 8l years old.

Travel agents won one round from the city yesterday but lost another. The city is attempting to license them to resell tickets to theatres and other amusement places as part of package tours. These tours include hotel, transportation and sight-seeing.
Miss Celeste Reed Seymour was married yesterday afternoon to Norman Henry Grulich of New York and New Milford, Conn., in the Crystal Suite of the Ambassador by Municipal Court Justice George Starke.
The first five years of Puerto Rico's status as a commonwealth, or "free associated state," is being celebrated today with pride and satisfaction both in the island and in the United States.
Rosemary Clooney will be the star of a live musical program to be televised next season on Thursdays from 10 to 10:30 P.M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.
PARIS, July 24--Plans for profound reform of French education following modern and more democratic patterns were presented today to the National Assembly.
Prime Minister Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy of Pakistan last night listed advantages his country would proffer to attract foreign investments.
ALBANY, July 24--State revenue for the first quarter of the current fiscal year is running $22,413,340 ahead of the year before.

Earnings of the General Motors Corporation declined 4.4 per cent in the first six months this year from the 1956 level. Sales, however, were slightly higher than last year and second only to the record set in the first half of 1955.
The Columbia Alumni News, a monthly magazine published since 1909 by the Alumni Federation of Columbia University, is ceasing publication with the July issue.
WASHINGTON, July 24--The House of Representatives approved today a compromise $33,789,000,000 appropriation bill to run the Defense Department in the current fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 24--The Army and Air Force announced details today of their plans to reduce the size of their forces. The reduction will be part of the 100,000-man cut in the uniformed military establishment ordered by the Defense Department.
The Food and Drug Administration has begun an educational campaign against door-to-door selling of various food additives and vitamin preparations.

LONDON, July 24--Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General of the United States, proposed today that all international disputes be settled under a judicial tribunal or system of tribunals that would command the confidence and respect of the world.
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday declines in net income for the three, six and twelve months ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Thirty-four major Eastern railroads turned to Congress today for an escape from the squeeze of tight money.
After deliberating all night, the blue-ribbon jury weighing the conspiracy, and bribery case against Johnny Dio reported yesterday morning that it could not reach a verdict.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24-- By a fraction of an inch, Mike Green fell short of the most important victory of his tennis career today.

MENLO PARK, Calif., July 24 --Rear Admiral Charles Julian Wheeler, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Wheeler have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doanda Risley Wheeler, to Philip Ridgeway Randall. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Ridgeway Randall of Stoughton, Mass.

Bulgaria the eleventh-round opponent of the United States, leaped into second place yesterday in the international students chess tournament at Reykjavik, according to a report received through Icelandic news channels.

The tenth summer season of experimental offerings at Lucille Lortel's White Barn Theatre, Westport, Conn., will begin Aug. 4. The initial attraction will be Tennessee Williams' dancedrama, "The Purification," to be ...
MOSCOW, July 24--The Soviet Union said today it expected at least 500,000 foreign visitors this year. More than 300,000 of these will be coming on business trips.
WASHINGTON, July 24--A scientist specializing in laboratory tests of cigarettes urged Congress today to "apply legislative remedies" to strengthen the Federal Trade Commission.
A new art gallery with an accent on youth opens today at 132 Lexington Avenue. Some of the artists could not attend the preview yesterday because they were temporarily detained at Youth House.
An investigation has been started to ascertain whether some members of the Police Department are receiving graft from the construction industry.

FLORENCE, July 23-Italian designers of haute couture opened their combined collections in Florence's Pitti Palace today with American Ambassador James W. and Mrs. Zellerbach up from Rome to applaud the proceedings.
An extensive campaign aimed at making a track an attraction will begin next week.
BUENOS AIRES, July 24-- The Provisional Government of President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu has taken control of the operations of Argentina's largest private electric power company.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) --Three United States Representatives today demanded, that Congress investigate radio and television "censorship" of songs to delete terms objectionable to Negroes and other minority groups.
WESTHAMPTON, L.I., July 24--Francois has a new surf rod and a Mitchell surf reel, and the monsters of Long Island waters may well quail.

CLINTON, Tenn., July 24-- The general mood in this mill town today, following the conviction yesterday of Frederick John Kasper and six others for interfering with integration at the local high school, was part surprise, part shock.
MANAMA, Bahrein, July 24-British jet fighters pounded a mud fort with rocket fire today in the first air offensive against a rebellion in the Arab sultanate of Muscat and Oman.

LONDON, July 25--A "major piece of apparatus" for detecting fusion reactions has been designed and built in collaboration with industrial concerns, it was disclosed today in the third annual report of this British Atomic Energy Authority.
Control of the Chrysler Building, along with its annex and the Graybar Building, is being sold by Webb Knapp, Inc., to a group of realty investors.
ALBANY, July 25--The State Board of Parole has ruled that Joseph (Socks) Lanza must remain in prison for nearly two and a half years after the expiration of his original sentence.
The Union Pacific Railroad Company reported yesterday for the six months ended June 30, a net income of $33,819,986, or $1.43 a share on the common stock.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 25--Donald L. Reynolds, editor in chief of The Industrial Bulletin, monthly news magazine of the New York State Department of Labor, died of cancer today in his home at 8 Van Wyck Street after an illness of two months. He was 47 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (U.P.) --Senate rackets investigators said today that two top officials of the Textile Workers Union had hurriedly raised $111,150 in three weeks after ...
Ricci Tavi of the Christiana Stables, a 4-to-1 shot, took the Hempstead Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday in record time.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 25-- Puerto Rico celebrated the fifth anniversary of the creation of the Commonwealth today.

MILWAUKEE, July 25 (AP)-- Robin Roberts broke a string of seven straight losses and hurled his first victory since June 6 today as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the league-leading Milwaukee Braves, 5--3.

The nation's second largest steel company had a record first half year in virtually all of its operations. Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday new first-half highs in net billings, net income and production of ingots and castings. The records were based on a combination of first quarter highs buoyed up by near-record second quarter levels.
ITHACA, N.Y., July 25 (AP)-- James G. Needham, Professor emeritus of Entomology and Limnology at Cornell University, died last night after a long illness. He was 91 years old.

Prof. J.B.S. Haldane, one of Britain's leading geneticists, has left his native land to settle in India, which he describes as "a free country where there are no foreign troops based all over the place."

The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham went to the Bronx yesterday to offer forgiveness and a better way of life to a man accused of taking $500.19 in offerings at the Graham rally in Yankee Stadium last Saturday.
Lively is the word for the three months ended June 30, according to the quarterly report of the New York Stock ExChange published yesterday.

The spectacular comeback of the Chrysler Corporation has gained momentum, with halfyear earnings up 380.6 per cent from the same six months last year. Second-quarter earnings were also at a new peak and 456 per cent ahead of a year ago.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)-- An informer of the Federal Bureau of Investigation within the Communist party testified today the Reds concentrated in the steel industry in eastern ...
LONDON, July 25--The American Bar Association was told today that national security might be endangered if the courts "lean too far backward in the maintenance of theoretical individual rights."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 --With the new television season only five weeks off, production of filmed shows is beginning to pick up in Hollywood.

A calf that escaped from a Greenpoint slaughterhouse and sought to compound its advantage by getting out of Brooklyn as well was rescued last night from Newtown Creek by a patrolman with a life preserver.

A four-story apartment building at 1544 Gillespie Avenue, cornet of Middletown Road in the Bronx, has been sold by 1544 Gillespie Avenue Realty, Inc. It was bought by an investing client of Morris Golub, attorney.

The nation's total output of goods and services, or gross national product, rose to a new high annual rate of $433.5 billion during the second quarter of 1957, according to the Council of Economic Advisers. This was an increase of $4.4 billion over the figure for the first quarter.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25--Agricultural production throughout the world is mounting steadily, although the total number of far workers is dwindling, according to the 1956 yearbook of the Food and Agriculture Organization, made public today.
The Bankers Trust Company has turned the sidewalk superintendent operation inside out.
LONDON, July 25--Three prominent elder statesmen have urged the British Government to review the decision by two British oil companies to dispose of their marketing interests in Israel.

The city's agreement with Webb Knapp, Inc., for the real estate company to take over the Manhattantown redevelopment was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board's vote was 15 to 1. Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens cast his ballot against the agreement.

SHARJA, Trucial Oman, July 25--The great fort at Nizwa, in the heart of the Oman mountains, was the target today for rockets and cannon fire of Royal Air Force Venom jet planes. They flew twelve sorties from a sandy runway here.
Following are excerpts from Milovan Djilas' book "The New Class," which is to be published here Any. 12 by Frederick A. Praeger:
The Russian team clinched first place last night in the world student chess championship at Reykjavik, Iceland, according to a report received here.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 25 --Alfie Keeshan and Pete Beamish were able to look back at their opponents from lofty point perches at the end of today's light-air Larchmont Race Week sailing.
Following is a list of the city's Boards of Elections, and their branch offices, at which voters may register and enroll under the new system of Permanent Personal Registration.
The National Cash Register Company rang up new records in sales and earnings for the first half year, according to the mid-year report yesterday of Stanley C. Allyn, chairman.

The Standard Oil Company of California in the first half had a net income of $136,328,987, or $2.16 a share, R.G. Follis, chairman, reported yesterday. This compared with $122,050,274, or $l.93 a share, in the first half of 1956.
The question of what constitutes a "soft" television market came up for more hard discussion yesterday.
Cocoa futures rose the 1-cent a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. There were eighty-four unsatisfied bids at the close. Volume was 306 lots.
A devastating criticism of Communist rule has been written by Milovan Djilas, former Yugoslav Vice President, who is now a prisoner in his native land.
CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 25 --Virgil (Buck) Worsham, Pelham Country Club professional, gained the first-round lead in the Westchester open championship with a 67 today.
The Police Department indicated yesterday that it would refuse to cooperate with Morris L. Ernst in his investigation of the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez for the Dominican Republic.

The extensive support of social legislation and charitable and humanitarian causes by the Fraternal Order of Eagles was hailed here yesterday at the opening or the order's fiftyninth international convention.
LONDON, July 25--Prices of industrial equities were irregular on the stock exchange today.
The $11,200 in worn bills that was found in a taxicab on Wednesday morning was still unclaimed last night.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (U.P.) --Ed FitzGerald's one-out single in the tenth inning scored Roy Sievers from second base to give the Washington Senators a 3-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.

Dr. Bernard Rosenberg, a dentist here for more than fifty years, died Wednesday while visiting a cemetery in Brooklyn. His age was 76. He lived at 245 West 104th Street and had offices at 33 West Forty-second Street.

TUNIS, Tunisia, July 25--Beneath the eyes of nine dead Beys, whose portraits hang in the legislative chamber in Bardo Palace, the Tunisian National Constituent Assembly deprived the reigning Bey of throne and authority today and declared a Tunisian republic.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The Federal Government's housing chief threatened today to cut off New York City from future slum clearance aid unless Robert Moses chaneed his methods.

The shadow of a giant crane fell over the Italian arch at the head of Vanderbilt Avenue yesterday, and then to the thuds of a swinging iron ball the last architectural trace of the Marguery Hotel began to crumble.
The news that the Aramburu Government in Argentina has seized CADE, the European-owned electric power company, is a shock. It will alarm and disappoint all friends of Argentina.

WASHINGTON, July 25--Harold (Red) Grange and four other gridiron figures defended the Notional Football League's player-draft system today. They urged that Congress exempt the professional organization from antitrust regulations.

JUST before the sun drops behind the Palisades to morrow night close to 200 men, women and children in Japanese costume will file out of the old Marion Davies mansion at 331 Riverside Drive, which is now the American Buddhist Academy.

Member banks were able to cut back their borrowings from the Federal Reserve and improve their average excess reserve position in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. On average, net borrowed ...
WASHINGTON, July 25--A Senate decision on the jurytrial issue, the last major controversy in the Administration's civil rights bill, is now possible by the middle of next week.
The New York Yankees yesterday staked out territorial rights to all major league baseball in this city.

Pleasure boat owners are extroverts. They like to do things in the grand manner. Some of them may even be show-offs. They wear white yachting caps, uniforms, dark blue jackets, white slacks and adorn themselves ...
BERLIN, July 25--Walter Ulbricht, East German Communist leader, is mobilizing the party behind decentralization of industry and state administration patterned after the Soviet Union.
MORRISVILLE, Pa., July 25 --Twenty-five school and college, science teachers met "Hazel" and "Nancy" today. The teachers were impressed.
Crop losses were placed at more than $38,000,000 yesterday as the drought seered deeper into the Northeast's farmlands. The Weather Bureau saw no sign of rain for the next several days.
LONDON, July 25--John Cavanagh, pace setter of English couture, was, according to rumor, drastically shortening his skirts.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The House of Representatives killed the $1,500,000,000 school construction bill today, 208 to 203.

WHETHER James VI of Scotland, who was James I of, England, was "the wisest fool in Christendom" is still a matter of conjecture. But that he was one of the least attractive kings in English history is reasonably certain.

The great military strategies of World War II have been the subjects of many books published within recent years. Another phase of the war, the overcoming of the Monte Cassino road block to the Allied advance up the Italian peninsula, will be presented by Fred Majdalany in "The Battle of Cassino."
Johnny Dio was found guilty last night of selling labor peace. He and two confederates were convicted on charges of bribery and conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee approved today they nomination of Jerome K. Kuykendall for a full fiveyear term on the Federal Power Commission. Democrats, however, promised a fight against him on the Senate floor.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25-- Ashley Cooper and Neale Fraser found themselves in serious straits today before Australia's prospective Davis Cup defenders joined Victor Seixas and Sam Giammalva of the American, team in the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania grass court tennis championships.

LONDON, July 25 (U.P.)--Jack McCord, 74-year-old Alaskan pioneer, married Grace Doering, 66, American woman lawyer, here today after a forty-twoyear courtship that started at the San Francisco World Fair in 1915.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Two scientists from the Rand Development Company, Cleveland, testified today to extracting what they said was a cancer-causing tar from cigarettes.
Samuel Reshevsky and Arthur B. Bisguier played to a draw in thirty-five moves at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.
CUSTER, S.D. July 25-- Drought-breaking moisture has brought a vital opportunity for soil conservation to the nation's Great Plains, Under Secretary of Agriculture True D. Morse declared today.

NAGASAKI, Japan, Friday, July 26 (AP)--At least sixtyeight persons were reported dead and 665 missing or unaccounted for today after torrential rains spawned flash floods and, landslides across northern Kyushu, Japan's southern main island.
GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 25 (U.P.)--Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris and Hugh Stewart of San Marino, Calif., gained the men's singles quarter-finals at the Swiss tennis championships today.

YONKERS, July 25--Meadow Mim, a 7-year-old chestnut mare, upset the chalk players by winning the $25,000 invitation Lakeville Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Driven by Wayd Cotter for the K and K Dress Stable of New York, Meadow Mim was a 44-1 shot.
The head of the second largest banking chain in Westchester County gave his approval yesterday to acquisition of the larger County Trust Company of White Plains by a bank holding company.
LONDON, July 25--The United States proposed today that an international committee be established to fix the terms of a ban on the military use of inter-continental missiles.
PITTSBURGH, July 25 (AP)-- A 29-year-old dynamite blaster touched off a powerful bomb tonight as he sat with his estranged wife, in a car parked on a busy street. Both were killed by the blast.

DORSET, Vt., July 25--Miss Anita Louise Humphreys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Humphreys of 450 East Sixty-third Street, New York, and Sledmere, Dorset, became the bride this afternoon of Arthur Woodruff Jones Jr., son of Mrs. Jones of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Jones.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., July 25 (AP)--Joseph W. Henderson of Philadelphia, president of the American Bar Association in 1943-44, died today at Divine Providence Hospital.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25--Erika Farkas, a Hungarian teen-ager, once trained to become a ballet dancer. Today, at 17, she is learning to become a waitress in the hope that this will help her to find a new home and a new job outside Europe.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange eased 11 to 16 points yesterday (l point equals 5 cents a bale).

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 25-- Three former officers of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission were among five defendants found guilty tonight of conspiracy to defraud the commission of $19,500,000 in a turnpike contract.
PORT SAID, Egypt, July 25-- President Gamal Abdel Nasser will celebrate tomorrow the first anniversary of the nationalization of the old Suez Canal Company.
BUFFALO, July 25--The State Federation of Labor prepared today to speed final mer ger negotiations with the State congress of Industrial Organizations.
ROSCOE, N.Y., July 25-- Two months of drought have done their sorry work on trout streams in this part of the Catskills, and these are the times that try men's souls.
The state of Connecticut plans to sell $35,000,000 of bonds in furtherance of the financing of the state turnpike with the full faith and credit of the state pledged as security.

ST. LOUIS, July 25--Milwaukee's defeat today left the National League first-place door wide open for the Dodgers, but the Cards slammed it in the Brooks' faces tonight. The Redbirds best Don Newcombe for the second straight time, outscoring the Dodgers, 3--2, before 27,892 fans at Busch Stadium.
The State Commision Against Discrimination reported yesterday that it had received 50 per cent more complaints of bias in the first six months of this year than in the same period of 1956.

TOKYO, July 25--Donald Wheeler, the United States airman who rebelled against a "white sidewall" haircut, walked out of the stockade today with his rank and pay restored and his court-martial sentence to four months at hard labor wiped out.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that the city could not accept the Federal Census Bureaus estimate of a population loss of 120,448 persons since 1950.
The White Sox served fresh notice to the Yankees yesterday that the world champions still had a battle on their hands for another American League pennant.

CHICAGO, July 25--This was a special day in the life of Michael Francis McCormick of the San Gabriel (Calif.) McCormicks. The 18-year-old southpaw, to whom the Giants reportedly paid a $65,000 bonus last season, today achieved his first major league victory, a 5-2 verdict over the Cubs at Wrigley' Field.

THE steady seasonal rise in the price of food was held responsible for June's record cost of living. And, when the records for July are totted up, bacon and eggs, the classic American breakfast, will have to number among the guilty foods.
The demolition of a once prominent national and local landmark, the eighty-year-old Christopher Street Ferry Terminal, began yesterday, to make way for a new railroad freight terminal.
TRENTON, July 25--Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today that he had saved New Jersey taxpayers $57,000,000 by his veto of measures passed by the Republican-controlled Legislature.

Supreme Court Justice Francis X, Conlon appointed a special examiner yesterday to preside over a hearing in the competency of Eugene F. Suter Jr., who renounced his interest in a $350,000 legacy left by his father.
For a number of years, Roger L. Stevens has been thinking of bringing over the Stratford-onAvon Shakespeare Memorial Theatre, with Sir John Gielgud in the company.

LOUIS XVI of France liked to tinker with locks. Mohammed el-Amin deposed as Bey of Tunis yesterday, loves to tinker with clocks and watches. Like the last of the eighteenth-century Bourbon monarchs, the Bey was dethroned by a revolutionary government.
ANGELS' PEAK, Nev., July 25 (UP)--The tenth nuclear shot of the summer series exploded at 9:30 A.M. today from a balloon anchored 500 feet above the Atomic Energy Commission's proving grounds.

Two brothers were indicted yesterday in a $436,500 swindle based on fictitious orders for paper novelties. They are Abe and Aaron Linzer, doing business as the Linbro Manufacturing Corporation, 432 Twelfth Street, Brooklyn.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 25-- Mrs. Norman Woolworth of Wee Burn and Mrs. Charles Spalding of Round Hill will meet Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and LaJunta White of Englewood in the final round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association four-ball, best-ball tournament tomorrow.

BOSTON, July 25 (U.P.)--Bob Porterfield left the Red Sox bullpen for a starting role today and stopped the Athletics, 5-3. He gave six hits for Boston's fourteenth victory this season over Kansas City in eighteen games.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 25-- A poll of the jurors in the Clinton integration contempt trial showed today that all regard themselves as "only true Southerners."
The owner of an income tax service known as "Our Family Counselor" has been indicted on charges of having swindled the Government out of more than $800,000 in 1951-53.
PARAMUS, N.J., July 25-- Miss Julia F. Sampson, a teacher of the Gregorian chant and onetime conductor of the St. Pius X Choir of the St. Pius X School of Liturgical Music, died Tuesday ...
Rail stocks came into their own yesterday in an otherwise lackluster market. Prices in general were ragged in light trading. Strength in the last two hours pushed averages up slightly.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The conviction by a Federal court jury at Knoxville, Tenn., of seven of eleven citizens cited by the judge for criminal contempt is reported by some observers as having had the following effect on Senators who will vote next week on the jury trial issue in the Administration's pending equal rights bill:
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)-- The 114-mile United States portion of the St. Lawrence Seaway is more than half completed. It is thirty-nine months since construction began.
A civic task of major proportions has been undertaken by the group of community leaders who have accepted membership on the Citizens Committee on Permanent Registration.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The long-delayed Niagara power project moved ahead in Congress today. This step may lead to approval of the $600,000,000 development at this session.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 --It was not so long ago that the Hollywood experts were convinced that "big pictures" would be the salvation of the movie business. Make'em big, the feeling was, and everything would come out all right at the box office.

Business loans outstanding on the books of the larger New York City banks dropped another $181,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday. borrowings $530,000,000 below that of June 26, the high point of the June tax borrowing period, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad yesterday announced plans to appeal a Public Utility Commission ruling against the reduction of passenger service on the Boon-, ton-Hoboken branch. The line accused New Jersey of paving the way toward state socialism in transportation.

BONN, Germany, July 25-- The Federal Law Bulletin has published the text of a new law governing the repayment of movable assets taken from victims of nazism, by the Third Reich, the former state of Prussia and by Nazi organizations.
The Ludwig Baumann-Spears furniture store chain is negotiating for the sale of its Pittsburgh stores and warehouse facilities, it was learned yesterday.
The city's Board of Education yesterday set itself up as a "screening" committee to select a Superintendent of Schools.
The Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries increased sales in the first six months this year to $216,921,613 from $212,561,482 in the period a year ago.

William A. Davidson, former vice president and director of the Singer Manufacturing Company and former president of the Diehl Manufacturing Company, its electrical subsidiary, died yesterday in the Institute of Living, Hartford.

PRINCETON, July 25--Dr. Oswald Veblen, an internationally known mathematician, and his wife donated eighty-one acres of their property to Mercer County this week for the development of a public arboretum.
Three links in the $750,000,000 rterial road program for the metropolitan area were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
MARAIS and Miranda, balladeers who have given many New York recitals, made their Lewisohn Stadium debut last night in a program entitled "Folk Music Festival."
Investment builders have purchased a blockfront on East Fifty-ninth Street in the Sutton Place district for improvement with a nineteen-story apartment house to be operated on a cooperative basis.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP)--The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen took steps today to strengthen its position as an affiliate of the merged labor organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25--Establishment of a permanent United Nations force for "preventive policing" would help expedite disarmament, Prime Minister Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy of Pakistan asserted today. He declared that the best guarantee of international peace lay in enhancing the prestige of the world organization.

PARIS, July 25--The Government will have a hard fight to check inflation in time to postpone the devaluation of the currency, in the opinion of experts here. The Government's plan of action, will be discussed by the Cabinet tomorrow.

LONDON, July 25--The Conservative Government's policies for defeating Britain's breakneck inflation, which, it asserted, was caused primarily by wage increases, were endorsed tonight in the House of Commons.

LOS ANGELES, July 25-- A passenger who had insured his life for $125,000 was blown out of an airliner today 10,000 feet above the Southern California desert. The twin-engine Western Airlines' Convair made...

CHICAGO, July 25--Federal Judge William J. Campbell today dismissed a $3,000,000 antitrust suit against the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, its magazine, Woman's Day, Inc., Hunt Foods, Inc., the Morton Salt Company and the General Foods Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The gap between the International rotherhood of Teamsters and the mainstream of organized labor widened today as these developments become known:
WASHINGTON, July 25--The United States will officially join the International Atomic Energy Agency in the next few days. thus bringing the atoms-forpeace group into existence.
Herbert R. O'Brien, New York City director of Civil Defense from October, 1952, to November, 1954, died yesterday in the Abraham Jacobi Hospital of the new Bronx Municipal Hospital Center.
The opening of nineteen more branches for permanent personal registration was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- President Eisenhower is designating every American traveling abroad as a goodwill ambassador.

CINCINNATI, July 25 (U.P.)-- Art Fowler, suddenly starting to click after failing to win a game during the first three months of the season, pitched the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 9-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.
A device smaller than a cigarette was pictured yesterday as holding the answer to engine flameout, one of the few remaining hazards peculiar to jet flight.
Obscured by the more spectacular similar events occurring in the Soviet Union, a major purge has been going on in Rumania.
The budding hopes that the London disarmament talks may at last lead to some positive results have wilted under the latest Soviet pronouncement.
BLAME it on the heat, or maybe it was the wrong time of the year, but the professional round-robin tennis tournament at Forest Hills wasn't nearly the financial success that was anticipated.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 25 (AP)-- Joe Gagliardi of Larchmont, the defender, moved through the second round of the thirty-fifth annual New York State amateur golf championship today. He beat Bob Haynes of Geneseo, 3 and 2, over the Elmira Country Club's 6,240-yard, par 70 course.

HARTFORD, July 26--The State Supreme Court of Errors asked today for another hearing in October on a controversy involving minor judgeships in Hartford, Manchester and Meriden.

Harclay House, an eight-story apartment building at 299 South Harrison Street, East Orange, N.J., has been purchased by a syndicate of investors headed by Morris Karp and Bernard I. Sandford, Bronx realty operators.
The ways of men and the stock market are often strange, and yesterday there was a good example.
BALTIMORE--One of a multitude of gag-signs enlivening the clothing factory of the three brothers Swartz reads: "Blessed Are They Who Go Around in Circles For They Shall Become Big Wheels."
LONDON, July 26--Britain gave strong support today to the United States proposal for steps toward a ban on the military use of intercontinental missiles.
WHITE PLAINS, July 26-- Westchester County has some of the worst slums in the New York metropolitan area, a survey committee reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 26--The Senate's all-out civil rights forces stiffened their resistance today to any jury-trial provision in the Administration's bill.
Robert Moses said yesterday that New York would continue to insist on "unique treatment" in its resale of land under the Federal-city slum clearance program.

Mrs. Evelyn Foster Olds, wife of Irving S. Olds, retired chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, died yesterday in her home at 141 East Seventysecond Street, after a long illness. Her age was 68.
A new, virtually maintenancefree bulkheading has been introduced to the shipping industry. It will soon get its first service trial aboard three vessels of the Isbrandtsen Company.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 25-- Faced, with an operational water shortage as a result of an abnormally extended dry season coupled with heavy loss from Gatun Lake because of high ship traffic, Panama Canal officials are thankful for one lucky estimate."
Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy, the genial visiting Prime Minister of Pakistan, saw some of the good and bad of New York yesterday.
Expansion of the Social Security program to include medical benefits for persons reaching retiement age was advocated yesterday by Senator Richard L. Neuberger.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission today dismissed charges against a major camera manufacturer which it had accused of illegally disciplining dealers who sold at less than "fair trade" prices.
HONOLULU, July 26--William F. Quinn, 38-year-old native of Rochester, N.Y., today was named Governor of Hawaii by President Eisenhower. He will succeed Samuel Wilder King, 71.

IS it possible to duplicate at home the corned beef brisket that delicatessens serve in sandwiches, asks Mrs. Rhea Lattman of New York. She has tried preparing the meat several times but the results have not satisfied her.
The Bishop of Berlin last night said unity in Christian faith was "the broad highway leading to reunification of Germany and a united Europe."

The Federal school aid plan originally proposed by President Eisenhower has again been sunk. It went down in the House of Representatives with an anti-segregation clause tied to it, but it might have been defeated, anyhow.
A second-quarter increase in net income of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. lifted the halfyear total 7.6 per cent over the first six months a year ago.

LONDON, July 26--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told the American Bar Association today that collective strength and a sufficiency of nuclear power to deter aggression were essential to the security of the free world.
WASHINGTON, July 26--The White House said today that President Eisenhower was greatly disappointed over the failure of the House of Representatives to pass a school aid bill.
The Meadow Club of Southampton has been staging tennis of the top flight continuously for more years than almost any other club of the country with the exception of the Newport Casino.

TUNIS, Tunisia, July 26--The Tunisian Cabinet resigned today following yesterday's proclamation of a Republic here. Habib Bourguiba, newly elected President as well as Premier of the Republic, accepted the resignation of his colleagues.

MONTREAL, July 26 (UP)-- Frank Shaughnessy set his sights today on the Brooklyn baseball territory--if and when it becomes available. His eventual goal is to make the International League, of which he is president, a third major league.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, July 26 --Prime Minister Bakshi Ghulam Mohammed reorganized his divided Kashmir Cabinet today, He dropped three alleged Leftists and re-established control over his own Government with a new team.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (UP)--Qantas Empire Airways, Australia's overseas airline, re-, ceived its right to operate between Sydney and London by way of New York at the expense ...
ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 26 --The enterprising Empire State Music Festival presented two American debuts here tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 26--Col. John C. Nickerson Jr., the Army ballistic missiles expert who was convicted last month of divulging secrets, was assigned today to an obscure job in the Panama Canal Zone.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)-- Mark Foote, Washington correspondent for the Booth Newspaper Syndicate of Michigan for forty-four years died tonight of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.
ROSCOE, N.Y., July 26-- The strong, hardy out doorsmen who infect the Catskills, discouraged by the worst fishing in memory, were just settling down to comforting themselves with the prospects ...
GAEVLE, Sweden, July 26 (U.P.) --Tom Courtney produced the season's fastest 800-meter run tonight when he was clocked in 1:46.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 27-- A torrential downpour, bringing floods and landslides beginning Thursday night, has caused more than 600 casualties and millions of dollars damage in Northwest Kyushu.

RYE, N.Y., July 28--A fleet of thirty cruising yachts sailed from Scotch Caps shortly after noon today on a distance race to Fishers Island. This opened the American Yacht Club's twentysixth annual cruise.

Sales and earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation fell sharply in the quarter and six months ended June 30 from those of a year earlier. Results were affected by the drop in the price of copper, the report says.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)-- A Presbyterian minister told President Eisenhower today "something has broken down" in the traditional system of separating church and state in this country.

ALBANY, July 28--A legislative committee is touring the state this summer in an effort to prove that the hunter and the farmer can be friends.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- Starting Tuesday, thousands of wrong numbers will be dialed in Washington. This confusion will go on until United States Capitol callers get the habit of a new number. Eventually there should be fewer wrong numbers than ever before and dialing will be faster.
MANILA, July 28--The Nationalist party convention was deadlocked today on the nomination of a candidate for Vice President.

CHICAGO, July 28 (UP)--The Philadelphia Phillies swept a double-header from the Chicago Cubs today. They took the opener, 3--2, rallying in the final two innings, and staged a fiverun seventh inning surge to help Jack Sanford score a 7-1 victory in the second game.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 28 --Venezuela's dictatorial President has refused to say for the time being whether he will seek re-election Dec. 15 for another five-year term.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) --J. Edgar Hoover, defending the role of confidential informants, said today that they had enabled the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other law-enforcement agencies to arrest more than 2,700 persons last year.

A scientist, uring an ordinary hypodermic syringe, injected a dose of radioactive carbon 14 into the trunk of a small pine tree a few days ago.
CHICAGO, July, 28--The general trend of grain futures during the week was lower, and while declines were not substantial, the market did not show much of an inclination toward recuperative action.

OTTAWA, July 28--Secretary of State Dulles flew from here late tonight for the London disarmament talks assured of the Canadian Government's continued support of the United States plan for aerial inspection.
CHICAGO, July 28--White and Negro picnickers clashed this afternoon in a South Side public park. About 100 policemen were needed to quell the disturbance.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 28-- Edgar Craig's Polaris scored a thrilling triumph in the S Class race of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta today. One second separated the first three boats.
After an ownership of thirty years, the five-story apartment house at 363 East 150th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Augusta W. Hohle.
LIBERTY, N.Y., July 28-- Roger W. Straus, chancellor of the State Board of Regents, died this afternoon in Liberty Loomis Hospital. His age was 65.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has obtained control of a large parcel of real estate in the Grand Central area. He has purchased the southeast corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

PITTSBURGH, July 28--Optimism in the steel industry is being supported with a better flow of orders.

SOME suggestions have just come to hand for the pres ervation and improvement of trout fishing in the reservoirs, inlets and outlets of Westchester County. Some of them sound sober and sensible, though there is sound reason to suspect that they are not either.
Two new British imports open on the same bill at various neighborhood theatres today.

LONDON, July 30--Reports of a split in the Cabinet over the future allocation of forces and funds for British defense were authoritatively denied today. The impression persists, however, that wide differences; if not a split, do exist.
MILWAUKEE, July 30 (UP)-- The first-place Milwaukee Braves, aided by Lou Burdette's five-hit pitching and Pittsburgh's loose fielding, scored a 5-2 victory tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 --Two scholarship awards for film students, one each at the University of California at Los Angeles and at the University of Southern California, were announced today by the Screen Directors Guild of America.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 30 (Reuters)--The Soviet Union promised to attack Iraq if Iraq intervened against a Jordanian palace revolution, a prosecution witness told a military court today.

LONDON, July 30--The United States, speaking on behalf of the Western powers, is prepared to offer to the Soviet Union two proposals for zones of aerial inspection that would guard against surprise attack.

GUATEMALA, July 30--President Luis Arturo Gonzales Lopez, speaking today after the funeral of Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, said the nation's first responsibility was to carry on the assassinated President's ideals and program.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1--Malcolm Anderson of Australia was beaten on his first day of play in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today.

AT Seabrook Farms in southern New Jersey, the person nel is of international background. Assistant purchasing agent at this large establishment, where fruits and vegetables are grown expressly for freezing, is Endel Mido, who was born and raised in Estonia.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 31--Walter B.M. Brownlie of 8 Webb Road, Sleepy Hollow Manor, manager of the local Chevrolet factory of the General Motors Corporation, died of a heart attack last night in Paul Kimball Hospital, Lakewood.

Scarcity amid more than plenty is the prospect for a major crop. In a report on the feed situation yesterday, the Department of Agriculture said there might be a scarcity of corn for feed despite a record surplus of the grain.

MILWAUKEE, July 31--Walter J. Kohler Jr., three times a Republican Governor of Wisconsin, and William Proxmire, three times defeated as a Democratic candidate for Governor, will vie Aug. 27 for the Senate seat left vacant by the death of Joseph R. McCarthy.
NEW HAVEN, July 31--The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches faced up today to a dilemma of religion in a period of crisis:

WASHINGTON, July 31-- Suggestions that Maxwell H. Gluck, owner of fine racing horses and a dress shop chain, might have won a diplomatic post by contributing to Republican campaign funds drew an angry retort from President Eisenhower today.
GUATEMALA, July 31--The new President of Guatemala indicated today that his Government would work to continue the close ties with the United States maintained by his assassinated predecessor.
HONG KONG, July 31--More Chinese are leaving Communist China than are entering it. This reverses a trend evident in the earlier years of the Communist regime.

W. Randolph Burgess, Under Secretary of the Treasury, has been testifying this week before the Senate Finance Committee on the management of the Federal debt. This area of Treasury activities is his particular responsibility.

The Columbia Broadcasting System will-go under water Sunday afternoon to cover a swimming and diving championship meet in Philadelphia. The contests are under the auspices of the Amateur Athletic Union.
The Republican State chairman pictured this city yesterday as a scandal-ridden community badly in need of a change of administration.
MUNICH, Germany, July 31-- Radio Free Europe has begun daily broadcasts to Eastern Europe of excerpts from a book by Milovan Djilas, in which the former Yugoslav Vice President denounces communism.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- There is a point in Marc Connelly's "Green Pastures" where "De Lawd" looks down from Heaven and remarks, during a particularly trying day: "Even bein' God ain't no bed of roses."
Committees have been chosen and initial plans have been formulated for the eighth annual Gotham Ball. The traditional Thanksgiving Night debutante fete will be held at the Plaza on Nov. 28.
OSLO, July 31 (UP)--The world record holder, Roger Moens of Belgium, today beat America's Olympic champion, Tom Courtney, and England's Derek Johnson in an 800-meter run.
THE rail and gallinule hunting season in New York will open Sept. 1 and run through Nov. 9, the State Conservation Department decided yesterday.

HAVANA, July 31--About 200 women demonstrated against the Government at the City Hall of Santiago de Cuba this morning. The demonstration occurred while United States Ambassador Earl E. T. Smith received the keys of the city.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- President Eisenhower warned today that newly free nations could not long remain free unless they received help in their economic development.
Stocks were on somewhat of a treadmill last month.
PITTSBURGH, July 31--The relatively unknown pair of H. Sanborn Brown of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Martin J. Cohn of Oak Park, Mich., this afternoon captured the Life Masters Pairs championship.

MILWAUKEE, July 31-- William Proxmire was voted the "biggest grind" in his class at Hill Preparatory School, Pottstown, Pa., in the mid-Nineteen Thirties. Many in Wisconsin regard him as the "biggest grind" in contemporary politics.
The city moved yesterday toward a decision on the offer of the Consolidated Edison Company to buy the rapid transit power plants.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 --The Mirisch brothers--Harold, Walter and Marvin--have resigned their executive positions at Allied Artists And will leave the company on Aug. 31.
ST. LOUIS, July 31--The tongue-lashing Manager Bill Rigney gave his Giants following last night's setback by the Cardinals brought no immediate change for the better.
SHARJA, Trucial Oman, July 31--The British have switched from simple warnings to "offensive action" in their drive to support the Sultan of Oman and Muscat against rebels in Oman.
Two boys who rescued three youngsters from drowning were sworn in yesterday by the Park Department as honorary lifeguards.

IT being comparatively quiet in the on-toCalifornia movement, with no visiting Mayors in town and even Walter F. O'Mal ley keeping strangely silent, this could be as good a time as any to look around and see what's happening on the ball fields.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31--A fashion show will be staged in the garden of the Highway-Behind-the-Pond home of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Hinton for the benefit of East Hampton's Guild Hall.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- President Eisenhower, still seeking men willing to take several major Government jobs, suggested today that Congress take a look at the conflict-ofinterest laws.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- President Eisenhower reiterated today his opposition to the inclusion of any jury-trial provision in the Administration's civil rights bill.

United Engineering Trustees, Inc., which represents five national engineering societies, took title yesterday to the major part of the blockfront on the west side of First Avenue from Fortyseventh to Forty-eighth Street.
BUENOS AIRES, July 31-- The People's Radical party began today an effort to reunify the nation's Radicals into one force capable of sweeping the Presidential and legislative elections next February.
Mayor Wagner denied yesterday that he and his seven colleagues on the Board of Estimate were planning to vote themselves salary rises effective next Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- President Eisenhower said today that he did not like, but would have signed, the compromise emergency school construction bill that lost by five votes. He told his news conference he would have another bill ready at the next session.
The Yankees, who have lost only once to the Athletics all season, ran up the count to sixteen out of seventeen by polishing off their "cousins" from Kansas City twice yesterday.
Resident golfers regard their own Staten Island as a "tight little, homey community." Frank L. Markey and Charles Barnett cite facts to support such a description.
BAY SHORE, L.I. July 31-- Charley Dominy's Independence V made it two in a row in the Star Class competition for the Corry Trophy today.
Offices in Norway House at 290 Madison Avenue, at Fortyfirst Street, have been leased by the Tobacco Merchants Association of the United States. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., was the broker.
Volunteers have bean asked from among convicts at Ohio State Penitentiary for the third in a series of experiments to explore the possibilities of vaccination against cancer.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 31--Joe Marra, the defending champion, fired a two-under-par 68 to pace the qualifiers in the thirty-eighth annual Westchester County Golf Association amateur championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 31-- A college economics" professor who took a long look at teen-age financial habits reported today that they were much more stable than many adults realized.
A decline of 2,569,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
CHICAGO, July 31--Wheat futures today generally reversed their recent trend, with the deferred doing better relatively than the near-by September.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 31 --A twenty-three-inch alligator slithered out of a dried-up swamp off George Street last night, presumably looking for water.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)--The Inland Steel Company reported today record earnings for the first half of 1957.

WASHINGTON July 31 (UP) --George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, ousted an official of a small Chicago local today on the ground that he derived "personal advantage" from an insurance agency doing business with the Teamsters union.
A funeral service for Roger W. Straus Chancellor of the State Board of Regents, was held yesterday at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.
LONDON, July 31--The stock market was fairly buoyant today. British Government securities extended their gains with rises of up to 12s 6d ($1.75) on the 100 ($280) unit.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Available records do not disclose who was the first member of Congress to add a form of journalism to reprints of his oratory in an effort to keep constituents posted on the events and issues of government.
A $250,000 negligence suit brought against the Government by the parents of an 18-year-old secretary who was slain by a deranged veteran was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Richard H. Levet.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday all the money and manpower needed to make a success of permanent personal registration here.
LONDON, July 31--Sir Winston Churchill said here tonight that justice was not being achieved in the United Nations and that changes must be made or the "whole structure" might fall.

MILWAUKEE, July 31-- Walter Jodock Kohler Jr., three times the Governor of a state where dairy farming is regarded as one of man's most honorable vocations, once shocked the politicians by refusing to pose for a campaign picture showing him milking a cow.
GENEVA, July 30--The United Nations Economic and Social Council approved today a resolution urging the General Assembly to establish a special fund to aid under-developed countries.
BONN, Germany, July 31-- The chief of the West German delegation to the trade and political negotiations in Moscow has been recalled, the Bonn Government announced today.
State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray reported yesterday that in June private home construction in New York slumped for the twentieth consecutive month.

Nassau County, L.I., announced yesterday plans for the sale of new bond issues totaling $21,002,000 to finance various public improvements. The securities will be offered at public bidding on Aug. 19.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Investigators for the House of Representatives reported today that the Army's heavy tank program had produced a record of costly failures.
WASHINGTON, July 31--The United States Court of Claims today held invalid a 1950 Post Office Department contract for pneumatic tube mail service in New York.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) --Larry Doby slammed four singles and drove in what proved to be the winning run in the ninth inning tonight to lead the Chicago White Sox to their fourth straight victory, 6--5, over the Washington Senators.
WASHINGTON, July 31--Nazi Germany's efforts to bring the Duke of Windsor under German influence in the turbulent summer of 1940 were revealed in captured German war documents made public today.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points up to 6 points off yesterday.
VINELAND, N.J., July 31-- Six members of an old Vineland family were killed today in this city's worst automobile accident.
Four youths were arrested last night in the aftermath of a teenage gang fight in Washington Heights in which one youngster was fatally stabbed and another wounded seriously.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 31-- John J. Relihan of 72 Oldfield Road, project engineer for Gibbs Hill, Inc., New York and Los Angeles consulting engineers, died today in St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport. His age was 60.
The election of Dr. Alex Stewart as president and general manager of the R-N Corparation, owned equally by the National Lead Company and Republic Steel Corporation, was announced yesterday.
Those big racks of preprinted tickets behind the New York Central Railroad ticket counters at Grand Central Terminal are being banished.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation continued its sharp recovery from the effects of a long strike, with record sales for the quarter and six months ended June 30. Earnings also climbed substantially.
PARIS, July 31--The Cabinet was deadlocked tonight over the means of meeting the financial crisis that threatens France's currency and solvency.

There was a touch of humor behind the vote of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday to hold public hearings on all nominations for Ambassador. President Eisenhower, however, did not think...
In an unusual ceremony and an unusual gesture the American Bar Association has donated and dedicated a memorial to Britain's Magna Charta. The act and the memorial...
HOLYOKE, Mass., July 31-- Mrs. Minnie Ryan Dwight, editor and publisher of The Holyoke Transcript-Telegram, died today in Holyoke Hospital of a coronary thrombosis. She was 84 years old.
THE audience last night at Lewisohn Stadium was not large. Yet the weather was fine, the program interesting, and the soloist superb. Jorge Bolet, ahe Cuban-born pianist, was the evening's soloist.
HONG KONG, Thursday, Aug. 1 --Communist China has reduced its military forces and is prepared to cut them still further if the big powers reach an agreement on disarmament.

READING "The Louisville Story,"* an important book for Americans interested in civil rights, the thought occurred that there is more history worth studying here than in many of the biographies of Civil War platoon leaders accidentally placed for a few days not far from what today is General Eisenhower's Gettysburg farm.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- Twenty-seven corporations won Federal tax rebates in excess of a million dollars each during l956, the Congressional Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation reported today.

"It's just a tired market" was the description heard more than once yesterday in the financial district. It fit the trading picture. Prices edged up during the most of the session in desultory dealings and then turned easier in the final minutes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31-- The Philco Corporation filed a denial in the Federal District Court here today to charges it had infringed on Radio Corporation of America patents. The denial was filed in reply to R.C.A.'s countersuit against Philco.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Following is the text of the statement read by Senator John L. McClellan, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field, at the openings of today's hearings:
The first major new issue of non-callable corporate debt securities since the Great Depression is on the market today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 --Dr. Frank Baxter, Professor of English at the University of Southern California and wellknown television personality, is about to close a deal to replace John Nesbitt as host and master...
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices increased 1.23 per cent between mid-June and mid-July.
There's foam aplenty in the beer marketing situation:
Business and real estate interests opposed to the projected $77,000,000 mid-Manhattan Expressway along Thirtieth Street detailed their stand to Borough President Hulan E. Jack yesterday.
The new Roosevelt Raceway, a $20,000,000 harness racing plant, will open tonight when the Westbury (L.I.) track begins a 105-night meeting.
Pontoon-equipped helicopters with a capacity of twelve passengers will begin using the Manhattan heliport today.
MOSCOW, July 31--The ousted members of the Soviet hierarchy were accused today of having challenged the Communist party's basic right to take the leading role in Soviet affairs.
PRESIDENT EISENHOWER--Please sit down; please sit down.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP)-- A New York drug concern today denied Federal Trade Commission charges of misleading advertising. At the same time it criticized the commission.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- James R. Hoffa of the Teamsters Union was accused today of aiming for a position where he could throttle the Eastern seaboard and part of the Midwest.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 31 --Augustine J. Cunningham, Rochester industrialist and head of James Cunningham Son, died today at the age of 79.

PARIS, July 31--Guy Laroche is cut out for success. This, his second collection, established his particular position in couture. His clothes are the French equivalents of such American wholesale designers as Junior Sophisticates, Anne Fogarty and Luis Estevez of Paris and the young generation of Paris is certain to flock to his door.
CHICAGO, July 31--Ninthinning errors helped the Dodgers to a double victory over the Cubs, 3--2 and 2--1, at Wrigley Field today.
The growing shortage of Broadway playhouses, already manifest despite the earliness of the season, was clearly brought home yesterday with the news of an interim booking.

Scattered thunder showers dampened parts of the metropolitan area yesterday but were of little help to droughtstricken farmers. Last night, at Southampton, L.I., the Long Island Farmers Institute voted unanimously to have all of Long Island designated a dis aster area and made eligible for Federal and state aid.
EVIDENTLY, an astute woman can run a string of pearls, a plain black dress and a pair of sturdy arches into a modest fortune.

Food Fair Stores, Inc. which operates 273 stores, has moved into sixth place in sales among the nation's retail food companies. Records in volume and earnings were set in its fiscal year ended April 27.

LAFAYETTE, Calif., July 31 (AP)--Maj. Gen. James Lester Bradley, U.S.A., retired, who commanded the Ninety-sixth Infantry Division in the Pacific in World War II, died here yesterday. He was 65 years old.
The Health Department disclosed yesterday that it had traced at least fifty-five cases of "serious" food poisoning to chicken salad sold by the Horn Hardart Company in its automats and retail shops.
The possibility that New York Giant fans might continue to follow the fortunes of their favorite baseball team here as tenants of Yankee Stadium evaporated yesterday.
LONDON, July 31--Nazi Germany in its hour of almost decisive military triumph still saw the world through a hazy mixture of credulity and romanticism.

LONDON, July 31--Progress toward completion of the Western plan for zones of aerial inspection of disarmament was made at a series of talks between Secretary of State Dulles and British, French and Canadian officials today.
As James Reston reports in this newspaper this morning, President Eisenhower had a rough time of it at his news conference yesterday.
A contract between a union of milk tank drivers and employers expired last midnight, but an immediate strike was not expected.
WASHINGTON, July 31--The House of Representatives approved today a compromise bill for development of Niagara power by New York State, 83 to 16.
Robert K. Christenberry and his associates on the Republican city-wide ticket charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner's Democratic Administration was failing to provide adequate police protection.
EDGEWATER PARK, N. J., July 31--The saying of grace before lunch by school children in this central New Jersey township has been declared illegal by Attorney... General Grover C. Richman Jr.
YONKERS, July 31--Wilmington's Star won the $25,000 Au Revoir invitation mile pace by a length as Yonkers Raceway's spring and summer meeting ended tonight.
New securities publicly offered here in July touched a new low for the year. Bond flotations were the smallest since December. Stock offerings were the smallest since last August.

WASHINGTON, July 31--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended July 24:
Under a cool, top-quality ride by little Pete Anderson, Harry La Montagne's 12-to-1 Plotter won the $29,000 Top Flight Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 31--The White House announced today a "supplementary" plan for "equitable" return to German owners of assets seized during World War II.
The Parker Pen Company will spend $750,000 in the next few months promoting a new "nonskid" ballpoint pen called the TBall Jotter.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has ordered a cut in expenditures for the military's maintenance and operations activities.
When New York City's expense budget is nearly $2,000,000,000 a year a prospective revenue loss of $4,000,000 may not seem very significant.
Trading in futures was nervous yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices fluctuated as much as cent a pound during the session.

The United States Rubber Company had a net profit in the second quarter this year of $9,960,473. This compared with the $9,555,758 in the similar three months cleared last year. Sales, however, dropped to $219,073,735 from the $234,445,800 volume a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Captured German war documents made public today supply fresh evidence of a Nazi undercover campaign to harass President Franklin D. Roosevelt and promote isolationism in the United States in the 1940 Presidential campaign.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 31-- The keel was laid today for the frigate Mahan, one of ten being built by the Navy to launch surface-to-air guided missiles of the Terrier type.
WASHINGTON, July 31--The Atomic Energy Commission said today it was developing nuclear power plants that could propel long-range rockets and possibly space ships.
COLONIA, N.J., July 31-- Louis Neuberg, vice president in charge of sales of the chemical divisions of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation, died last night of a heart attack at his home here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Senate removed the prospect of payless paydays for the armed services and Agriculture a Department today by completing Congressional action on two big appropriations bills.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP)--The continued advance of British Government securities was a conspicuous feature of trading on the London stock exchange today.
A prayer for higher pay for postmen was offered yesterday at Third Avenue and Eightyfourth Street as a bill to grant it approached a vote in Congress.
Five hundred persons, including 100 representatives of foreign countries, attended a solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for President Carlos Castillo Armas of Guatemala.

The suspension of constitutional guarantees for forty-five days in Cuba is a move of grave import. It could mean the beginning of the end of the Batista regime. In any circumstances it forebodes a period of tension; unrest and repression.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, described the reduced Congressional defense appropriations today as "a reasonable" minimum for the security of the nation.
Purchases of crude oil were cut yesterday by two major companies in five important producing states of the nation.

CHICAGO, Aug.1--Gil Hodges belted the thirteenth grand-slam homer of his career at Wrigley Field today as the Dodgers buried the Cubs beneath a 12--3 score. The Brooks lost only once in the five-game series with the cellar occupants.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Christian A. Herter, Under Secretary of State, today defended the appointment of Maxwell H. Gluck as Ambassador to Ceylon.
A group of youthful Swedish scholars who changed their minds have arrived in the United States for a visit.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 1-- The nomination of Mr. Gluck as Ambassador has created the liveliest interest here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--An amended bill to give United States defense officials stronger authority to prevent trials of American servicemen by foreign nations was approved by the House of Representatives Armed Services Committee today. The vote was 31 to 4.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 1 --William R. Rose, former president of the defunct Home National Bank, who now drives a truck, has been offered a free half interest in the paper mill that benefited from Mr. Rose's alleged manipulation of the bank's funds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Census-Bureau agreed today to make an adjustment for military personnel in its special censuses of New York State communities.
ROME, Aug. 1--Pavel Tchelitchew, American painter, died here yesterday in Salvador Mundi International Hospital. He was 58 years old.
LONDON, Aug. 1--Recommendations were made today for a 17,000,000 ($47,600,000) improvement program to prepare London Airport, the busiest in Europe, for the jet age.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)-- A State Department official said today that new trade agreements might have to be negotiated with some countries if the United States imposed import taxes on lead and zinc.

CAIRO, Aug. 1--The Imam of Oman, Ghalib bin Ali, has appealed for "intervention by the African and Asian states to stop aggression against the Omanians," his Cairo representative, Mohammed el-Hari- ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The civil rights debate turned tonight on a fine legal distinction that Administration lawyers believe may mean the difference between a workable statute to protect voting rights and an unenforceable promise to the disenfranchised.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 1--The new Tunisian republic will be as Western in sympathy and policy as the Tunisian monarchy that was abolished last week. Habib Bourguiba emphasized this point in his first interview as President of the republic.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 1 --A group of Roman Catholic priests was accused by the Government today of having aided the rebels in last fall's revolt. The Government said the priests were under arrest and would be brought to trial soon.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 1--The United Nations Truce Supervision Organization has informed Israel that it will not investigate her charges that Syria has violated their armistice agreement by making "aggressive threats."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)-- Stockholders were advised yesterday not to get too excited about tax refunds.
Sales of major department stores in the metropolitan area last month were 11 per cent higher on the average than in July, 1956, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.
PARIS, Aug. 1--The dispute in the French Cabinet on budget cuts to meet the financial crisis appeared to have sharpened tonight after a long session of the ministers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--A former labor leader told Senators today that the International Ladies' Garment Workers once had hired John Dioguardi (Johnny Dio) for a specially tough organizing assignment. He estimated it was about 1950.

A surplus Army searchlight as big as a cement mixer is being used by the B.F. Goodrich Company to concentrate the sun's rays on a spot a tenth the size of a dime in a research program on high-temperature materials.

THE harness racing frenzy that started in New York City a little more than 150 years ago touched a peak last night when the new Roosevelt Raceway, which cost $20,000,000 to build, opened in blinding splendor at Westbury on Long Island.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 --John Huston, director-producer, who long has been interested in the John Dos Passos novel, "U.S.A.," as a potential motion picture drama, is expected to make a final decision on the matter within a few days.

Joseph R. Vogel, president of Loew's, Inc., declared yesterday that Louis B. Mayer, Joseph Tomlinson and seven other persons who attended the rump meeting of Loew's board of directors on Tuesday had been placed on notice.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1.-- Brig. Gen. Leon Cantave, powerful figure behind the scenes of recent political turmoil in Haiti, has set himself the task of rescuing his country from economic chaos.
TRENTON, Aug. 1--Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. said today that he would seek an amendment to New Jersey's school law that would permit the saying of grace in public schools.
MONTREAL, Aug. 1--The Montreal area will have a "suburban" harbor with the building of a 4,000-foot wharf just above the Cote Ste. Catherine lock of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

Yugoslavia has received an object lesson on the subject of the political strings which are attached to Soviet economic aid, aid which Moscow never tires of asserting is completely devoid of any such strings.

The Commercial Transport Corporation and the American Barge Line Company merged yesterday to form one of the largest inland barge enterprises in the world. The consolidation had been negotiated for more than a year.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 1--The role that religion can play in a nuclear age was debated here today by 150 of the world's leading Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churchmen.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP)--Improved flour business moved wheat futures higher on the Board of Trade here today, but later profit-taking reduced gains of up to a cent a bushel to fractions. All other grains closed steady to strong.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 1-- The Argentine Government has authorized its state oil agency (Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales) to sign a contract with a United States-Argentine syndicate for construction of two oil pipelines and topping plants.

A three-man, independent stockholder committee of Superior Tool and Die Company is soliciting proxies against management proposals to increase the authorized common stock and to issue new cumulative preferred shares.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 --Twentieth Century-Fox TV Productions has completed a deal with the National Telefilm Associates film network for two new half-hour series.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1--Foreign correspondents are the exclusive target of a new Yugoslav decree that lays down penalties for "false and malicious reports."
WASHINGTON, Friday, Aug. 2--The Senate wrote the right to jury trial into the Administration's civil rights bill early today.

Second-quarter sales and earnings of the National Dairy Products Corporation were the highest for any three months in its history. Results for the halfyear were also at a record for an initial six months, according to a semi-annual report yesterday by E.E. Stewart, president and chairman.

Because he stayed close to the rail while another horse made a drift-out swing into the stretch, the 6-year-old Writer, owned and trained by Fred J. Thompson, won the $12,000 handicap that headed Belmont Park's program yesterday. He was the $15.70for-$2 fifth choice in a field of six.

YONKERS, Aug. 1--Westchester's first new county park since 1932 was opened today. It is the $1,100,000 Dunwoodie golf course here, which has fringe acreage that will be developed for other sports and recreations.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 1-- Horse exhorters from all over-- 42,693 of them--crowded the unstained facilities of the new Roosevelt Raceway tonight for a taste of the bettor's future. There weren't enough entrance gates to accommodate all those who wanted to get in quickly and there weren't enough betting windows to meet the demand.
