One of the chemical industry's best-known trademarks, the Monsanto Chemical Company's block "M", has been modernized.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 1 --A new political crisis was building up in Pakistan today. Principal causes were an announcement by the Election Commission discrediting Prime Minister Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy's March, 1958, deadline for the country's first general elections and some ominous rumblings in the eleven-monthold coalition Government.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1--Five Spanish sailors who deserted from two Spanish destroyers in San Diego last month will be returned to their ships.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) --Eighteen-year-old George Onekea churned through John B. Kelly Pool in 18 minutes 58.2 seconds to lead eight qualifiers, including the defending champion, George Breen, of the Buffalo Athletic Club, in the 1,500meter event of the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 1--The Colonial Office is planning a new attempt to bring political stability to Kenya.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1-- Yadavindra Singh, former Maharaja of Patiala, has fallen in line with Indian Government's national economy drive. In a letter to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru last week he asked government to cut his $357,000 a year privy purse by 10 per cent.
TOKYO, Aug. 1--Some statistics were made public today by the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan that were found pleasing to worried Japanese foreign trade officials.

As soon as Alfred Drake is finished with his portrayals of Iago ("Othello") and Benedick ("Much Ado About Nothing") at Stratford, Conn. in September, he will get to work on the direction of "Love Me Little."

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UP)--Ed (Porky) Oliver, who hasn't won a tournament in more than a year, took a one-stroke lead in the men's professional division of Tam o' Shanter's "All-American" golf tournament with a sixunder-par 66 today.
New York City will sell on Aug. 15 $40,000,000 of serial bonds maturing over fifteen years, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Atomic Energy Commission reduced prices today on cobalt 60 to encourage more widespread production and use of the radioactive material.
Following is a list of the city's Boards of Elections, and their branch offices, at which voters may register and enroll under the new system of permanent personal registration.

The residents of Forest Hills Gardens in Queens may have seen the last of the all-day subway parker. The narrow streets of the 175-acre community have long been clogged by commuters who drive to within walking distance of three stations of the IND subway and the Forest Hills stop of the Long Island Rail Road.

THERE ought to be some mild comments now on the Long Island bluefish situation, but first it is essential to say something about Danny Takumitsu and his relation to the outlandish world of surffishing.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur O. Choate Jr. of 154 East End Avenue have made known the engagement of Mrs. Choate's daughter, Miss Carol Elkins, to Andrew Varick Stout Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. He is the son of A. Varick Stout of Greenwich and Mrs. Herman Boker of New York.

BLOOMFIELD TOWNSHIP, Mich., Aug. 1--Benjamin E. Young, chairman of Industrial Enterprises, Inc., and a director of the National Bank of Detroit and other companies, died here yesterday in his home. His age was 59.

With the taking of title to a $2,700,000 site adjacent to the United Nations the major engineering societies of the nation have made known their firm commitment to keep New York City as their headquarters.

GEORGE MORTON LEVY is a solid, bouncy little man, about 5 feet 5 inches in height. He dresses neatly, conservatively. His gray hair is parted just off the middle. His eyes sparkle behind rimless spectacles.
POINT O' WOODS, Fire Island, Aug. 1--Two former winners are in a battle now for the Corry trophy, emblematic of star class supremacy on Great South Bay.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1--The twenty-ninth annual Summer National Contract Bridge Championship continued this afternoon with 480 men and 400 women playing the first qualifying sessions of the Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs Championships.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 1 --A rusty tin box containing $12,350 in cash has been found in a wall of a burned farmhouse that was the home of the late author Louis Adamic.

Excess reserves of Federal Reserve member banks declined in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. At $69,000,000, they were down $101,000,000 from the week before.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Government of the Philippines honored Arthur Hays Sulzberger tonight for contributions toward fostering a "closer PhilippineAmerican relationship."
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1--Ramanathan Krishnan of India and Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., reached the semifinals of the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 1 --Those concerned with the New York Yacht Club cruise, which will begin tomorrow, learned tonight that Briggs S. Cunningham of Southport, Conn., had become part of the America's Cup defence picture.

Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company notified its stockholders in a quarterly report yesterday that it had limited its 1957 drilling program to "those gas wells required by lease expirations and to the development of oil discoveries."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Army announced today that the withdrawal of ground combat troops from Japan had begun.

SHOPPERS can expect very little relief in the upward swing of beef prices now prevailing at the meat counters. According to our market scout's information, the current price trend is expected to last for many weeks.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 --Another American crusader named Graham has created quite a stir in India. This one is campaigning for free enterprise.
A strike of drivers that had halted bus service to New York's major airports since July 8 was settled last night.

PARIS, Aug. 1--Dior left the hemline alone. This time all the furor centered on the hips and the bosom. The waist slipped to hip-level on coats; suits and day dresses. Necklines on cocktail dresses dipped daringly to reveal most of the bosom, and skirts belled out widely around the hips.
A senior engineer at an electronic plant in Nutley, N.J., had always wanted his father to see where he worked, what he did and what the enterprise produced.
DUBLIN, Aug. 1--A party of 125 American lawyers led by Chief Justice Earl Warren came to Ireland today to relax after the American Bar Association's conference ended in London.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1-- The blueprint for an all-embracing council of American transport unions--air, land and sea-- was sketched today by the man who expects to succeed Dave Beck as president of the Teamsters Union.

BY the time American troops were reconquering the Philippines the Japanese were no longer dying to the last man rather than suffer the humiliation of surrender. One of the Japanese soldiers captured was a scholarly professor of French named Shohei Ooka.
JUST under 34 years of age, Dr. Bernard Schwartz has achieved recognition as one of the nation's leading legal scholars and teachers.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 1--Clem Miner Jr., 17-year-old Stamford, Conn., golfer, eliminated Joe Marra, the defender, in the second round of the Westchester amateur championship today by 1 up.
The twentieth anniversary of Boys Harbor, a camp for needy boys in East Hampton, L.I., will be celebrated with a carnival and fashion show on Aug. 17 on the camp grounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--Bert Bell, commissioner of the National Football League, recognized today the National Football League Players' Association. He said he was ready to start negotiating "immediately" with its officials on contracts.
Prices of cotton futures eased 3 to 10, points, 15 to 50 cents a bale, yesterday in moderate business.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 736,407 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

A 16-year-old boy was seriously wounded last night in a free-for-all fight between two teen-age gangs in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. The battle was the third serious outbreak of youthful violence in the city in less than a week.
A three-story building at 179 William Street, north of Beekman Street, in the insurance district, has been sold by Henry T. Stender.
SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 1-- This country is full of delightful surprises. In a setting that belongs traditionally to horse opera, a company of young Americans presented Italian opera last night.

All world sugar positions dropped to new lows for the move yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was active. Final quotations fell 11 to 22 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 68,250 tons.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1--If, as all hands here agree, Stan Musial is tired, the Giants' pitchers must shudder at the thought of having to face a well-rested Musial.
Outstanding loans to business by the larger New York City banks rose $36,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Rank of New York reported yesterday.
De Witte Wyckoff of 21 Stuyvesant Oval, who retired last December as a member of the legal staff of they American Bankers Association, died on Wednesday at University Hospital. His age was 70.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1--A complete schedule of events for the World Festival of Youth and Students here would rival a good-sized telephone book for length. But not everything is happening according to schedule.

The president of the National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that there was "no cause for hysteria" in the television industry because "a few facts about unsponsored time and late selling find their way into print."

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (AP)-- The Cincinnati Redlegs, stopped with only four hits through the first seven innings, rallied for three runs in the eighth tonight for a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phils.
HONG KONG, Aug. 1--A Communist spokesman in Peiping took a new jab at the Japanese Government today.

An inside report on Germany is given in a new book by Charles W. Thayer. The author has spent more than ten years in Germany as vice consul in Berlin, head of the Voice of America, political liaison officer to the Bonn Government and Consul General and Land Commissioner in Bavaria.

Six of seven young Hungarians who hijacked a commercial airliner a year ago to escape to freedom completed their trip yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The seventh, ill with tuberculosis, remained in West Germany.
IF you're in need of mahogany paneling, marble flooring or Church Gothic furniture hie yourself down to the First Presbyterian church house, Twelfth Street at Fifth Avenue.

Who are the friends of organized labor and who are its enemies? Chairman John L. McClellan of the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field made a clear statement on this subject on Wednesday at the opening of a new series of hearings.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug.1--Dr. Cornelius Weygandt, an authority on contemporary Irish literature and Professor Emeritus of English Literature at the University of Pennsylvania, died yesterday in the Huggins Hospital, Wolfeboro, N.H. His age was 85.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 1--The chief of the West German delegation will be sent back to Moscow next week to resume negotiations on trade and political questions with the Soviet Government.
Wall Street was still waiting yesterday--waiting for some major development on the political or economic news front to warrant a decisive movement in stock prices.

The House roll-call vote yesterday of 313 to 75 to permit New York State to develop electric power from the United States share of Niagara River waters was decisively overwhelming. It seems to foreshadow
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 1 (AP)-- Sweden's Dan Waern, a 3:59.3miler, today stepped the distance in 4:01 for first place in an international track and field meet in which Americans won five events.
PARIS, Aug. 1--Stephen P. Kennedy, New York's Police Commissioner, spent most of two hours today studying how Paris coped with automobile traffic.

A young man dived into the Hudson River late Wednesday night to retrieve a woman's handbag. It was found to contain savings bonds, postal certificates and bankbooks representing nearly $10,000. The valuables were returned to the owner, who offered neither reward nor thanks.

Glum is the word for quite a few railroads, especially in the Northeast, now that July is over. Passenger losses are not the only gripe this time. The carriers are discouraged about freight traffic in July and continued silence from the Interstate Commerce Commission on their latest raterise plea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)-- Immigration Commissioner Joseph M. Swing today announced the appointment of John L. Murff as director of the New York Immigration and Naturalization District, with headquarters in New York City.
LONDON, Aug. 1--The Western powers are ready to present their proposals for aerial and ground inspection to safeguard the world against surprise attacks.

Most ocean-crossing yachts had their moments in the sun and then passed on. J.P. Morgan's black Corsair, Cornelius Vanderbilt's Winchester, Vincent Astor's Nourmahal and others succeeded, without knowing it, in leaving a heritage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Teamsters Union picked up the hotel bill of Joe Louis, former heavyweight champion, on his recent visit here to attend the bribery trial of James R. Hoffa.
From 30,000 to 50,000 Negro infants were reported yesterday to be living in institutions or inadequate foster homes because their opportunities for adoption are not equal to those of white children.
HAVANA, Aug. 1--Constitutional guarantees were suspended throughout Cuba today for forty-five days as violence flared against the Government.
Reversing a previous stand, the American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday its opposition to the inclusion of questions about religion or religious affiliation in the 1960 Federal census.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)-- President Eisenhower, air leaders and the nation saluted the Air Force on its fiftieth birthday today.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Aug. 1-- Former State Senator Arthur H. Wicks resigned today as Ulster County Republican chairman. His retiremerit will remove a strong voice from Republican party councils in the State.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The United States and Canada announced plans today to integrate their air defense operations and planning for the North American continent.
The Public Service Commission was astonished to receive yesterday a petition from Westchester residents insisting that a bus line "be required to apply for an increase in its tariffs."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The House of Representatives passed the Niagara power bill today by a roll-call ballot of 313 to '75.

Resolving the conflict within the Administration over final disposition of enemy property seized during the war, President Eisenhower has now issued a White House statement promising a fair and final solution of a problem of vital importance to the comity of nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The Public Health Service warned today of "the very definite probability"--not just a possibility-- of a very large outbreak of Asiatic influenza in the United States this fall or winter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--Dr. Bernard Schwartz of New York University, a leading authority on constitutional and administrative law, has been selected as chief counsel of the Congressional inquiry into the vast operations of the Government's regulatory agencies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1-- Recurrent rumors of the resignation of Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, reached their height today with a report that it would be announced at the White House at 3 P.M.--the time of the Secretary's scheduled news conference.

TORONTO, Aug. 1 (Canadian Press)--Loblaw Groceterias Company, Ltd., had net income in the year ended June 1 of $8,015,740, equal to $7.36 a combined second preferred and common share, after first preferred dividends of $997,500. This compared with $5,668,088, or $5.86 a share, in the preceding year.
BOSTON, Aug. 1--Dr. Edward E. Hitschmann of Cambridge, psycholanalyst and author, died yesterday in Gloucester, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 86.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 1-- Favored by 'some "made-toorder" weather, the $20,000,000 new Roosevelt Raceway played host to a night world record harness racing crowd of 42,693 tonight.
Richard L. Stokes, author, critic, lecturer, reporter and opera librettist, died yesterday at his home, 1331 Madison Avenue. He was 74 years old.
An offer by Westcoast Transmission Company, Ltd., to acquire assets of Peace River Natural Gas Company, Ltd., has been approved by the latter's directors, it was learned here yesterday.
A GRAND master of the violin played to 14,000 persons last night at Lewisohan Stadium.
MANAMA, Bahrein, Aug. 2-- The British stepped up today the tempo of their drive against the rebellious Imam of Oman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The American Telephone and Telegraph Company finally obtained registration of its familiar blue bell as a service mark this week.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2--The Communist party and Soviet Government appealed today for a vast increase in private building, particularly of cooperative houses whose apartments would be owned by the tenant-builders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The Federal Housing Administration has about decided to raise from 5 per cent to 5 per cent the interest rate on the mortgages it insures. An announcement is probable next week.
Neighbors who are resisting the Gramercy Park slum clearance project sought help from the City Council yesterday to change the Federal-city program for redeveloping blighted areas.
Justice Arthur Klein of the State Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday on petition to compel the Board of Elections to use voting machines in this year's Democratic primary election in Brooklyn.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points off to 11 points up yesterday. There was a moderate volume of business.
Loew's, Inc. experienced a sharp set-back in its operations for the quarter ended June 6. Earnings for the forty weeks to the same date, however, were better than a year earlier.
The city's Health Commissioner assured New Yorkers yesterday that medical authorities were making preparations to cope with any possible invasion of Asiatic influenza this fall or winter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Robert W. Burgess, Director of the Census, stressed today that the Census Bureau would consider as "standard and official" population figures for New York State municipalities only those based on actual head count.
Encouraged by a spurt in this week's central registration, James M. Power, president of the Board of Elections, predicted yesterday that 500,000 voters would be registered centrally this year.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP)-- A public relations man has complained to the United States State Department that Venezuelan security police jailed him for one week as a "political prisoner" last month.
CHICAGO, Aug, 2 (U.P.)--Cal Neeman connected for a threerun homer in the eighth inning today to lead the last place Cubs to a 6-4 decision over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)-- William P. Rogers, Acting Attorney General, today announced a civil antitrust action against Hughes Tool Company of Houston, Tex., and New York City.
EARL EDWARD TAILER SMITH, the new United States Ambassador to Cuba, who has found himself plunged into a controversy over diplomatic procedure, is a newcomer to diplomacy.
As many as five consecutive words missing from the text of the Dead Sea Scrolls have been "rewritten"' by an electronic data-processing machine in the style of the author.
AMONG those who make jellies and jams at home--and the season for that activity is now at its height--one faction frowns on the use of commercial fruit pectins.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 2-- There is grave danger that if the Algerian guerrilla war continues for another year the nationalist rebels will seek Communist support, according to President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia.
LONDON, Aug. 2--The bus terminal at Victoria Station has been the scene of many human dramas, but none quite like the arrival today of the bus from Calcutta.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Administration officials said today that the jury trial provision added by the Senate to the civil rights bill could cripple enforcement of the antitrust laws and of statutes enforced by more than thirty Federal administrative agencies.

LUXEMBOURG, Aug. 2--Certainly a major reason for this week's Berlin Declaration by the big three Western, powers was to help Adenauer in next month's general elections. It is patently evident why we are so anxious to do so.
Reconstruction of the pier at Thirty-fifth Street in Brooklyn that was shattered by fire and explosion last December will begin at the end of this year.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (Reuters)-- The sterling area's gold and dollar reserves, after a slow climb for five months, fell by $14,000,000 in July, the Treasury announced today.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., Aug. 2--Secretary of the Interior Fred A. Seaton urged support today for the Administration's long range minerals program, saying "it is time to abandon makeshift minerals legislation."
Two stockholders of Loew's, Inc., instituted legal action yesterday against Louis B. Mayer, former production head of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, for repayment to the company of $2,750,000.

The stockholders of Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., will be asked at a special meeting here Sept. 10 to approve an amended plan of debt arrangement under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act, an agreement with A.M. Sonnabend and a reclassification of its outstanding stock.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the first half of this year net income of $44,848,197, or $2.93 each on the 15,290,646 average capital shares outstanding in the period. Sales and other operating income totaled $645,945,743.

In the welter of statistics that currently come from the Transit Authority about the numbers of passengers carried by our rapid transit system and the amount of fares paid, we frequently fail to note the figures on a prosperous and growing facet of subway activity--the concessions.

IN the Print Room at the New York Public Library the learned librarians have devised an interesting division of folders on Abra ham Lincoln. They have separated the thousands of prints into two convenient categories: Lincoln, bearded; Lincoln, beardless.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--There is a legend at the Government Printing Office that a number of United States Senators rise at 5 each morning, go out on their porch and wait for The Congressional Record to arrive.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most of the markets was dull and featureless. Most of the volume involved balancing of holdings for the week-end.

The visit of Ambassador Earl E.T. Smith to Santiago' de Cuba has stirred up a great controversy in Cuba. The State Department has ordered "a full report" which, of course, is not an implied rebuke, since the department has no basis for judgment until the report comes.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 2 (AP)--Frank Lloyd Wright, the architect, marched out of a meeting of the Marin County Board of Supervisors here today when his loyalty was challenged in a letter.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP)--Jackie Jensen smashed a bases-loaded single in the tenth inning tonight to provide Boston with a 5-4 victory over Chicago. A previous Red Sox lead, furnished by Ted Williams' thirtieth homer, was erased by a ninthinning White Sox rally.
An L-shaped property surrounding the southwest corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and West Fortythird Street has been sold by Henry Payson, realty operator.
The Esso Standard Oil Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), reduced prices yesterday of light heating oil, kerosene and diesel
Metal-awning manufacturers were aroused yesterday by a clampdown that the City Department of Buildings has put on larger aluminum awnings.

LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 2 (AP) Dr. Ward V. Evans, an educator and chemist, died today at Lancaster General Hospital. He had suffered a stroke yesterday at his summer home in Fishing Creek. His age was 74.

TOKYO, Aug. 2--The announced disbandment of the last United States combat division in Japan--the First Cavalry--and transfer of its flags and name to Korea was spread all over the main pages of Japan's newspapers today.

Maxwell H. Gluck, newly appointed Ambassador to Ceylon, said yesterday that he was backing an effort to obtain Federal support for a private corporation to invest $25,000,000,000 in underdeveloped nations.
In a contest fought almost exclusively along the ropes, Bobby Boyd of Chicago, earned a tenround split decision over Los Angeles Willie Vaughn at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

BOMBAY, India, Saturday, Aug. 3 (Reuters)--Devadas Gandhi, youngest son of Mohandas Gandhi and managing editor of The Hindustan Times of New Delhi, died in Bombay early today of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2-- Charles J. Solomon and David Warner of Philadelphia led a field of 240 contract bridge pairs this afternoon after the second qualifying session in the 1957 Men's Pairs Championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)-- The nation's' vast road-building program gets three billion dollars in aid next year, with most of the money earmarked for the projected 41,000-mile network of superhighways.

Five men were arraigned in Kings County Court yesterday on two separate indictments charging labor racketeering. They pleaded not guilty before County Judge Hyman Barshay and were held in bail ranging from $1,000 to $3,000. No date was set for trial.
LOS ANGELES Aug. 2-- Selection of a jury in the case involving the magazine Confidential was started in Superior Court today.
JAMESTOWN, R.I., Aug. 2-- Henry C. Boschen's New York-32 sloop Sirius out of Larchmont, N.Y., won the final leg of the American Yacht Club's cruise in the big cruising club division today.
Thousands of Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York will honor Cardinal Spellman on Sept. 7, the twenty-fifth anniversary of his consecration as a bishop.
Helen Schiffenhaus, a lively brunette in her thirties, is proving that New York's Summer Festival can be enjoyed even from a wheel chair.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--A Senate committee was told today how racket-run unions and certain employers together preyed on thousands of low-paid workers in New York.

DUCK ISLAND, Conn., Aug. 2 --The longest run of the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise gave Walter S. Gubelmann's seventy-one-and-one-half-foot yawl Windigo the Edward Welch Clucas Memorial Torphy today.
A fascination for foreign cars brought about the arrest of nine youths in Queens early yesterday.
GUATEMALA, Aug 2--It was by a narrow margin that Guatemalan authorities decided on a constitutional succession to the Presidency after the assassination of President Carlos Castillo Armas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- One of the oddest coalitions of strange political bedfellowsever gathered together in Washington defeated the Administration's right-to-vote plan.

The Tidewater Oil Company protested yesterday against the oil import formula recently devised by the Government and has asked Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks for a hearing provided for in hardship cases.
SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 2--Paul Kelly, the 1953 champion, and Pete Nisselson, the No. 1 man on the Yale team las spring, gained the final of the Westchester amateur golf championship today.
Following is a list of the city's Boards of Elections, and their branch offices, at, which voters may register and enroll under the new system of permanent personal registration.
A Bronx youth was stabbed to death early today after acting Police Commissioner James R. Kennedy had alerted the entire Police Department to end the current flare-up in ...
MOSCOW, Aug. 2--The Soviet Union accused the Western powers again today of trying to "frustrate" the London disarmament negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)-- Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, told the Senate today that President Eisenhower was "politically immoral" and had violated the spirit of the conflictof-interest law by accepting gifts worth "thousands and thousands of dollars."
The American Tobacco Company reported lower sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30 from the corresponding periods a year ago.
PARIS, Aug. 2--With the Cabinet battle over budget cuts in suspense, signs of the forthcoming battle over wages and prices took sharper form today.
TEI, AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2-- British oil interests were warned today that they might forfeit ownership of their refinery plants in Haifa if they suspended operations in Israel.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 2 (AP)--The New York Department of the American Legion adopted by a loud and unanimous voice vote today a resolution urging legalized bingo on a local-option basis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (U.P.)-- Members of a House subcommittee munched on reducing pills today while being told that that was not the way to lose weight.
Four small buildings at 13 to 21 Harmon Street in Brooklyn have been bought by the Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm.
BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 2-- The Star Class competition for the Corry Trophy came to a close today by agreement, with Charley Dominy's Independence V the winner.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2-- Eighty-one passengers on a crowded Broad Street subway train were injured today in a panic that occurred after an electrical explosion under the first car.

It seems today that the Senate has said no to any real extension of civil rights at this session. It did this after four weeks of maneuvering in which a nucleus of eighteen Southern Senators distinguished themselves for their parliamentary genius, if not for their sense of democracy.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP)--Stan Musial's third extra-base hit, a two-out double, drove in the winning run tonight in the tenth inning as the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Phillies, 5 to 4. Willard Schmidt, pitching in relief, scored his tenth consecutive victory.

Homeowners and building superintendents have been appropriately reminded by the Department of Air Pollution Control that now is the time to have their oil burners, breeching, chimneys and boilers cleaned and adjusted.
Ted Husing, who gained fame as a sports announcer during the Nineteen Thirties, will resume his chores on Columbia Broadcasting System radio after an eleven-year absence.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2 (AP)--James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said here today he would fly to San Francisco on Aug. 15 to outline to the West Coast's shipping industry a plan he hoped would bring peace to the American waterfront.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- James R. Hoffa showed his hand today in a power play to counter the threat of the Teamsters Union's expulsion from the united labor movement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--President Eisenhower left no doubt today that he would rather have no civil rights bill at all than accept weakening Senate amendments.
A campaign was announced yesterday to save the program that has been flourishing since 1910 at the Presbyterian Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 1 (U.P.)--United States track and field athletes won four events today in the Olympic Stadium giving them a total of nine triumphs during the two-day international meet. They won five events yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 2--A racegoer inspecting a new track concentrates on such conveniences as escalators, elevators and accessibility of pari-mutuel windows. Chances are he'll also let his eyes run over the decor under the grandstand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The index of wholesale prices in the primary markets declined 0.1 per cent to 117.9 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 2 (AP)-- The Baltimore Orioles swept a double-header from the Kansas City Athletics tonight. They won the twilight opener, 5--4, on Bob Boyd's home run in the thirteenth inning and the second game, 10--2, on the seven-hit pitching of Connie Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Admiral Arthur W. Radford, outgoing chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was hailed today, at a retreat review in his honor, as one of history's "champions for peace and freedom."
No material change in the market for new capital is visible. For the moment, the pace of new issues of corporate debt has slowed and bond prices are stable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (U.P.)-- Two employes of the Radio Corporation of America today re fused to answer questions about communism before a House subcommittee. R.C.A. immediately suspended the two workers.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2--Roy Emerson of Australia, the defending cup holder, and Kosei Kamo, the champion of Japan, won the two remaining quarter-final matches in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today.
WARREN, Mich., Aug. 2-- With the era of radioisotopes firmly established, General Motors has started the first company school to train key workers in handling radioactive material.
Enrico Caruso's voice drew hundreds of persons to the sylvan retreat of Bryant Park yesterday as the New York Public Library held its annual recorded Caruso concert.
An outbreak of payroll holdups here yesterday netted the robbers more than $20,000.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2--Grain futures improved today on the Board of Trade. The market was fairly active in spots and quiet in others. Closes were at the top prices. Setbacks were small.

Johnny Dio and three other convicted labor racketeers said in General Sessions Court yesterday that they wanted to comply with subpoenas to testify before the Senate committee now investigating labor and management.
For more than a year the city has been looking into reports of abuses in the treatment of workers by unscrupulous labor leaders and employers, Mayor Wagner disclosed last night.
Eleven Navy ships came into port yesterday to take part in New York's Summer Festival, and one was treated to a bomb scare.
LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 3-- Queen Elizabeth and the royal family were criticized today by a Conservative peer.

Lynn Loesser and Shamus Locke, producers, have engaged Billie Worth for the featured role of Martina in "Speak, Lucinda!" This is the Robert Wright-George Forrest musical based mainly on Moliere's "The Doctor In Spite of Himself."

LONDON, Aug. 2--Secretary of State Dulles, on behalf of the Western powers, offered today to open all the United States and part of West Europe to air and ground inspection in exchange for similar rights in the entire Soviet Union.
Federal Judge John M. Cashir issued an order yesterday temporarily restraining the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots from striking the Hudson River ferrie next Wednesday.
An order was issued yesterday in Federal Court temporarily restraining Tannem Co., Inc., a broker-dealer, Philip Tannen, its president and sole stockholder ...
Cleveland's Don Mossi held the Yankees hitless for six and one-third innings at the Stadium last night. It didn't do him a bit of good.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)-- President Eisenhower approve today a decision of the Civil Aeronautics Board to permit Pan American World Airways to operate permanently between San Francisco and Los Angeles and Tokyo over the Great Circle route.

New York State's--and especially New York City's--importance as the nation's corporate management center is emphasized in an analysis of Federal census studies just published by the State's Commerce Department.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 --Universal-International will put seven pictures before the cameras this month, making this the busiest August at the studio in more than five years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP)--Roberto de Vicenzo, 34, of Argentina, missed the Tam o' Shanter course record by a stroke today with an eight-under-par 64 and took the halfway lead in the men's professional division of the All-American golf tournament.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 29 --The Venezuelan dictatorship intends to write its own rules for the Dec. 15 Presidential election.

HONG KONG, Aug. 2--A new Communist-sponsored Patriotic Association of Chinese Catholics was established in Peiping today. A radio report from the Chinese Communist capital said the new national organization had ...

Cole Porter, who has written about 500 songs for Broadway and Hollywood, will compose a few more for television.
CARACAS, Venezuela; Aug. 4 --Political opposition in Venezuela is beginning to stir cautiously and still uncertainly in the wake of the Government's decision to hold general elections Dec. 15.

BETHPAGE, L.I, Aug. 4-- A bandit perched on the roof of a one-story bank building here, held up a store manager last night. He escaped with $7,000 after a ninty-mile-an-hour auto chase with a Nassau County policeman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 --A union of interest between Columbia Pictures and Universal-International has been brought into existence by television. Screen Gems, Inc., wholly owned Columbia subsidiary, will take over TV distribution of U.-I's backlog of pre-1948 feature movies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP)--Roberto de Vicenzo, 34, of Mexico City, refused to wilt under the pressure of a 66 tossed at him by Sam Snead and fired a 70 to hold the fifty-four hole lead by four strokes in the $25,000 allAmerican pro golf tournament today.
Pan American World Airways announced plans yesterday to begin service Sept. 10 on the polar route between the West Coast of the United States and Europe.
Time, Inc., revenues for the first six months of 1957 were the largest in the publishing company's thirty-five-year history.
WASHINGTON Aug. 4 (AP)-- The Air Force Association ended its annual convention today with the presentation of awards.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)-- Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, said today that he had decided against turning over to an American investigator evidence of a Dominican "network of terror" in the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP)--The Chicago Cubs climbed out of the National League cellar and spoiled Danny Murtaugh's managerial debut today by whipping the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6--0 and 3--2. The second game went eleven innings.
As a means of checking the . current flare-up in juvenile crime, Magistrate Hyman Korn yesterday proposed an 11 P.M. or midnight curfew for everyone under the age of 18.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)-- The State Department has begun a review of Secretary Dulles' passport powers to prepare for court fights with citizens challenging his right to restrict their travels.

Benjamin B. Hinerfeld, hosiery and lingerie manufacturer and a former special state deputy superintendent of banks, died yesterday at his home, 66 Park Avenue, He was 60 years old.

The 200th anniversary of the birth of Alexander Hamilton and the 167th anniversary of the Coast Guard he founded were observed here yesterday at Hamilton's grave in Trinity. churchyard and at the Coast Guard monument at the Battery.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4--The steel industry has turned the corner on the summer slump in orders and output. From now on out it is expected that volume of new business and the production of steel ingots will slowly rise. There is the possibility of a sharper advance by mid-September.
A Coast Guard ice patrol vessel is standing by a large iceberg in the vicinity of the steamer lane to Europe, according to the weekly ice chart of the United States Hydrographic Office.

ALBANY, Aug. 4 (AP)--Governor Harriman's consumer counsel said today that it would be an "outrage" if upstate milk dealers raised retail prices more than the increase paid to dairymen under a new Federal-state marketing order.
The Institute of Applied Biology, Inc., and the Cancer Research and Hospital Foundation, have ended their close association of the last ten years, it was reported yesterday.
Brig. Gen. Gilbert H. Stewart, U.S.A., retired, of 142 Randolph Place, West Orange, N.J., died yesterday in St. Albans (Queens) Naval Hospital after a long illness. His age was 78.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa sided with Federat housing authorities yesterday in their battle with Robert Moses, chairman of the city's Committee on Slum Clearance.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 4 (UP)-- The Mexico City Seismological Station recorded a series of earth tremors today in the Pacific Ocean area off Mexico's West coast.
HAVANA, Aug. 4--The Cuban Government has taken necessary measures to suppress the activities of terrorist Communists and saboteurs, President Fulgencio Batista said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--Hot weather stories are hard to come by, and the Washington press corps was mighty grateful last week to Maxwell H. Gluck, the new ambassador to Ceylon, a man who could ante up $40,000 to Republican campaign funds quicker than he could say Bandaranaike.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 4--The promotion of religious differences by passion, oppression and the "lying methods of the devil" was castigated here today by the Archbishop of Canterbury as a "sin against the family of God."

LAKE CHARLES, La., Aug. 4--A volunteer army of union craftsmen worked in marathon shifts this week-end and put up five homes, from foundations to rooftops, in hurricane-battered Cameron Parish.

DANVILLE, Va., Aug. 4-- Carroll Shelby of Dallas took top honors in the national championship point races on the new Virginia International Raceway today before a crowd of 10,000. It was the Sports Car Club of America's first meet on the course.

An Anglican bishop from West Africa declared in a sermon here yesterday that the peoples of the world "must learn to live together in the same house."
GENESEO, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP) --Four persons died and three others were injured in a car collision early today on Route 63, five miles west of here.

PARIS, Aug. 4--The Government published today a report on France's efforts to strengthen the Algerian economy. These efforts are "too often misunderstood or underestimated," the report held.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 4-- American and Israeli private promoters announced today a plan to build a $500,000,000 seaport city to accommodate a population of 150,000.

We publish with great pleasure on this page today a letter from Thomas J. Curran, Republican chairman for New York County, in which he commits his party to a most important principle leading to improvement of the judiciary in this city, We heartily congratulate Mr. Curran for taking a position of constructive leadership.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 4--An international organization of secondary school teachers has recommended steps to standardize high school diplomas so students may attend schools abroad without penalty.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 4--The continuation of inflationary financing has caused concern here.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 4 (UP)--Rain forced the Davis Cup American Zone tennis finals indoors for the first time in history today.

VIENNA, Ga., Aug, 4--Former Senator Walter F. George died at his home here early today after a six-week struggle against a heart ailment, He was 79 years old.

LONDON, Aug. 4--Fears of inflation here temporarily sub-- . sided last week. As a result, investors, who a few weeks ago were abandoning Government securities and rushing to the shelter of industrial company shares, returned in greater force to giltedge securities.

Short-term financing totaling $209,312,300 in behalf of 100 local housing agencies subsidized by the Public Housing Administration and seven land clearance and urban redevelopment agencies subsidized by the Federal, Housing and Home Finance Agency was announced yesterday.

VIEWERS who are beyond voting age are not likely to derive much pleasure from "American Bandstand," the disk jockey show that began yesterday on Channel 7.
The Dodgers harvested a little pennant hay while the moon shone last night. They beat the Giants, 5--2, at Ebbets Field and moved within two and a half games of the leagu-leading Cardinals.

About 400 members of the International Piano Teachers Association opened their convention yesterday at the Statler Hotel. They are "progressive" teacher's, pledged to the repudiation of the drill, drill, drill system.
Paul Winchell, ventriloquist, is expected to star in a Sunday afternoon (4:30 to 5) variety show beginning next month over the American Broadcasting Company television network.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 5-- The fans at Roosevelt Raceway finally took the rubber bands off their bankrolls tonight. A crowd of 24,806 harness racegoers wagered $1,455,035 for a per capita average of $58.
MANAMA, Bahrein, Aug. 5 --No more shadowy fig ure ever laid claim to sovereignty than the Imam of Oman, Ghalib bin Ali.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 5--A tri-state attempt to curb the public intoxication of boys and girls under the age of 21 was begun today.
THE fact that Long Island charter boats are loading up pretty regularly with school tuna right now gives added point to a plea from an old tuna hand for people to stop wasting this fine sports fish.

The Duquesne Light Company and subsidiaries expects its second half earnings to run "higher than a year ago," Philip A. Fleger, chairman, advised stockholders in the quarterly report mailed yesterday.

An Okinawan woman and a New England woman, two of the three wives of a United States overseas employe who died last year, embraced silently last night at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, planning to join in mothering the Okinawan woman's two daughters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)-- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to limit sharply the fast tax write-off program for the next two and one-half years and then kill it.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5--Wheat futures moved up in early trading today, with prices going to the best levels in almost a month. But the recovery on any of the active deliveries was not maintained.
Morris Ernst expressed confidence yesterday that he could obtain information from Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, on the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--A 50 per cent cut in night club and similar taxes was approved overwhelmingly today by the House of Representatives. The present 20 per cent rate applied to the combination of food, drinks and entertainment would be reduced to 10 per cent.
Danny Russo, a Brooklyn welterweight, gained a split decision over Eddie Lynch of the West Side in a bloody, wild-swinging eight-rounder at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
The interesting feature of Lord Altrincham's criticism of Queen Elizabeth and the royal family is the fuss that is being made about his article in Britain.

Pete Rademacher, a modest, soft-spoken, beefy product of a Northwestern farm, used to give some Eighth Avenue slickers the idea that he was a justplain-folks kind of guy with perhaps a fine mind for crops and seeds. But most people changed their impressions this week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5-- President Eisenhower reported today that his doctrine for the Middle East had helped to ameliorate conditions in that tense area, but he warned Congress there were "no grounds for complacency."

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 5 (UP)--Barbed wire was strung around gates at the atomic testing grounds today after a small group of "concerned Americans" had announced they would march into the prohibited area on the twelfth anniversary of the bombing of Hiroshima tomorrow.

The Maritime Administration announced over the week-end that pending applications for Government insurance on loans and mortgages for proposed new ships had reached a total of $691,400,000. This represents an increase of $191,400,000 since the first of the year.

ROME, Aug. 5--Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy of New York arrived here today determined to learn what made Rome's police so "effective." Many Romans would be inclined to tell him than plain toughness was the reason.
The need for more summer schools to take care of thousands of students who now are turned away was stressed yesterday, by Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UP) --The Senate raced today through approval of 446 nominations ranging from ambassadors to postmasters, but held back the controversial renomination of Jerome K. Kuykendall to the Federal Power Cominission.
Futures prices closed irregularty yesterday on the New York exchanges. A bank holiday in London reflected in part the lack of interest here. Trading in most markets was featureless.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5--The Federal Government has rejected applications for share insurance for three savings and loan associations operated by C. Oran Mensik.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 --Senator John F. Kennedy is scheduled to oversee some fierce fighting next week, but it will be strictly nonpolitical and a long way from Capitol Hill.

RYE N. Y., Aug. 5--The Wee Burn team of Bob Goalby and Douglas Moody posted a winning net best-ball score of 32, 30--62 at Apawamis today. They triumphed by two strokes in a Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur event that drew 113 pairs.
The Coca-Cola Company increased its earnings for the quarter and six months ended with June over the corresponding periods last year.
AT the moment, the tie that binds is the old school tie. College shops are opening their doors and their arms to all those who are campus-bound.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Aug. 5 --Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Whittlesey of Wellesley and South Yarmouth have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Whittlesey, to Frederick Gordon Potter Thorne.
The Boeing Airplane Company reported yesterday record sales of $651,890,419 for the first six months this year, compared with $407,344,045 for the same period last year.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 5--Dr. Israel Bettan, president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis and an authority on Jewish preaching, died last night at his home. His age was 68.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--The Navy announced today an economy cut of sixty ships from the active fleet. However, it said, some of the loss in fighting strength will be made up by new warships now nearing completion.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 5-- Israel charged today that Bulgaria had tried to renege on her responsibility for the downing of an Israeli plane near the Greek border two years ago. Fifty-eight persons were killed in the crash.

MANILA, Aug. 5 (AP)--Eugenio Perez, minority leader in the Philippines House of Representatives and former president of the Liberal party and Speaker of the House, died yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--The Government today raised the interest rate and lowered down payments on mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)-- Walter F. George was eulogized in Congress today as an outstanding Senator, statesman and citizen.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved yesterday 12-points up to 2 points off.

Red Skelton returned yesterday with his family from a three-week visit to Europe. His 9-year-old son Richard is suffering from leukemia, a cancerous condition of the blood, and may have only a short time to live.
BERLIN, Aug. 5--East Berlin decorated its streets with reds bunting today in preparation fort the arrival of Nikita S. Khrushchev.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5--Following are the texts of statement on atomic tests and disarmament approved today by the World Council of Churches and of a message to churches. The statement on tests was prepared by the Commission of the Churches on International Affairs.

The six-story apartment house containing thirty-three apartments and two stores at 3999 Third Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Burton A. Goldberg, real estate operator. The property is assessed for $68,000. It was sold for cash subject to a first mortgage of $26,000.

Bishop Lajos Ordass, primate of the Lutheran Church of Hungary who was reinstated last October, arrived here yesterday. He is on his way to attend the assembly of the Lutheran World Federation in Minneapolis.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 1-- Brazilian textile manufacturers are working to get rid of mounting stocks by exporting them.
SHELTER ISLAN, L. I., Aug. 5--C. Raymond Hunt's Class C sloop Harrier gained a second victory on this fine day during the New York Yacht Club cruise.

Robert Moses has decided to press for city approval of the controversial Thirtieth Street Expressway, Obviously annoyed by the endless informal discussion of the project, the City's Construction Coordinator has recommended that the issue be placed before the Board of Estimate "about the first of the year."

TORONTO, Aug. 5--William Lombardy of New York scored his second victory without a defeat in the third round of the world junior chess championship tonight. He defeated Mathias Gerusel of Bonn in only eighteen moves.

The Gulf States Utilities Company is planning to borrow $17,000,000 in the public market, Roy S. Nelson, president of the company, said yesterday. The company expects to call for bids on a bond offering on Sept. 30.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 5--A survey of the Communist educational system in Hungary concludes that it is impossible to educate the love of freedom out of the human spirit.

CAIRO, Aug. 5--The Cairo representative of the Omani insurgent chief delivered notes today to the United States and Soviet Embassies asking that the two cduntries try to halt the British assaults in the sultanate.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP)--Roberto de Vicenzo of Buenos Aires today played the last round in 70 for a 72-hole score of 273 to win the $25,000. All-American golf tournament by 4 strokes.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in a bulletin to its members, discusses the role of the City Council in New York's government and says: "Obviously, the high hopes set upon the Council as one of the fulcrums of municipal government have not been fulfilled."

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP)--Two 1958 model cars now are in production -- Ford's new Edsel and the Lincoln. Already more than 4,800 of the Edsel units have been built. They are expected to go on dealer display--and sale-- on Sept 6.

Following is a statement of Republican principles and platform issued yesterday in connection with the opening of Republican city campaign headquarters at the Sheraton-McAlpin Hotel. It was issued over the names of Robert K. Christenberry, the candidate for Mayor; State Senator Walter G. McGahan, candidate for Controller, and Mrs. Caroline K. Simon, candidate for President of the City Council.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 5-- Westchester County and the John A. Hartford Foundation reached a final agreement today on the use of a large tract of land on a high plateau at Valhalla as a campus for the Westchester Community College.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5-- The Rev. Charles J. McCarthy, a 45-year-old Jesuit priest, arrived home today after spending four years in Chinese Communist prisons. He was imprisoned as an "ideological saboteur" and was released in Shanghai June 14.

Steel production last month fell to 8,896,000 net tons. This was the lowest level since last August when operations were affected by the nation-wide steel strike.
A Federal-city agreement yesterday removed a serious barrier to the $200,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment project.

What may be the first cases of Asiatic influenza in the city were reported yesterday by the Department of Health.

ATHENS, Aug. 8--A staged Greek and English reading of Aeschylus' "Prometheus Bound," accompanied by orchestral and choral music and illustrated by tableaux, took place tonight in the open-air Theatre of Herod Atticus on the slopes of the Acropolis.
